fields.headline: Fretwork
fields.standfirst:
Fretwork
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London **
fields.trailText:
Fretwork
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London **
fields.body:
The music of Sir John Tavener tends to be something one either loves or loathes. For those in the former camp, Ikons of Light, the South Bank's three-week survey of Tavener's music and inspirations, is an exciting prospect, featuring performers of the calibre of the London Sinfonietta and the Chilingirian Quartet.

In recent years Tavener has experimented with writing for early instruments. This concert, given by the viol consort Fretwork, included three such works. Yet, in The Hidden Face, Fretwork seemed an underused resource. The distinc tive timbre of their instruments had little chance to make itself felt in writing so still and subdued that it allowed one of the players to drop out for a glass of water in the middle without causing any stir in the sound. The soloists, Michael Chance and Nicholas Daniel, communicated their lines beautifully, creating an atmosphere that lasted after the end of the piece until the applause began some 20 seconds later.

Apokatastasis, commissioned by Fretwork, was receiving its world premiere. This very brief work again involves viols and counter-tenor, with the distinctive contribution of two Tibetan temple bowls and a small gong. A celebratory incantation, it doesn't so much create a meditative atmosphere as rely on it being there already for the audience to have a chance of feeling the spiritual intensity - of which Tavener speaks in the programme note.

Tavener's music speaks to many people but does it ask any questions of them? His assumption of Eastern musical traditions can make for exciting and mesmeric sounds, but without a convincing structure underpinning them, it can also lead to triumphs of style over substance. Moreover, his self-conscious rejection of Western tradition perpetuates a rather patronising idea that spirituality is always to be found somewhere else: in new and unknown religions, in unheard sonorities in fact, in anywhere but within our own heads and on our own doorsteps.

It is telling that the most successful and substantial of his works in this concert was Nipson, the work with the most obvious structure and which made much use of Western musical language. Tavener shared the programme with viol works by his sixteenth-century namesake John Taverner, John Ward and Picforth. Next to the sober spirituality of the inexorable and inevitable logic of these, the modern works, for all their mesmeric qualities, seemed like fool's gold.

webTitle: Art review:  Paris goes to the seaside

fields.headline: Paris goes to the seaside
fields.standfirst:
Méditerranée
Grand Palais, Paris ****
fields.trailText:
Méditerranée
Grand Palais, Paris ****
fields.body:
If you are beginning to suffer from seasonal affective disorder, jump on the Eurostar and battle the crowds of Parisians at Méditerranée: from Courbet to Matisse, a sunny show of paintings from the likes of Monet, Bonnard, Dali, Cézanne and far too many pointillists. It will cheer you up no end.

The first thing you see is not a painting but a spotlit quotation from Gustave Courbet: "The sea gives me the same emotions as love." Swivel your eyes to the right and there is a canvas in which Monsieur Courbet is depicted dwarfed by the sea, black-suited against a sweep of beach. He has just raised his hat exultantly and his beard points out to the horizon. Everything else on the canvas is a vortex that draws your eye to the point where the darkening green of the sea touches fluffy white clouds.

In the next room is another quotation. "They all come here," wrote art critic Louis Vauxcelles in 1905 in the manner of a bored Midi hotelier, "like a band of migratory birds." And they did too. There's Braque's l'Estaque (1906) with a sizzling forest of red tree trunks bent down by the sun. Next to it is Derain's l'Estaque (1906) with burning yellows and reds - a heat map as much as a painting. That must have been some summer in the little fishing village. It was all Cézanne's fault: he visited l'Estaque from Aix in the 1870s and painted at least 60 views over the next 20 years, one of which is on show in the Grand Palais. Cubism was born in this village and in those canvases.

Part of the appeal of the exhibition lies in comparing the Riviera we know with the one the painters in this exhibition saw. In 1896 Théo van Rysselberghe painted La Pointe de Saint-Pierre à Saint Tropez, a pointillist evening of trees and calm sea. There's not a vulgar yacht in sight, not one bronzed, thong-sporting Riviera bum to spoil the view. How things have changed.

The problem is that the exhibition is too well-adjusted. Even Van Gogh painted some tranquil beached sailboats backlit by a sky that owed much to Monet. Thank heavens, then, for Edvard Munch. His 1891 Promenade des Anglais isn't quite as consummately disturbed as The Scream, which depicted events on a promenade a few hundred miles to the north. Nonetheless, this doesn't look like a nice Nice at all. Instead, it resembles Lyme Regis, with its cold light and its shy neurotics. Everyone in the picture is not only walking away from Munch, but holding umbrellas to shield themselves, not so much from the sun, but from the painter's gaze - a belt-and-braces rejection of the artist's project. Delightfully twisted stuff.

But this isn't the best picture in the exhibition. That title goes to Matisse's Porte Fen tre à Collioure (1914). It comes with the obligatory spotlit quote: "I began to use black, not as a colour of light and not as one of darkness." And there it is, a broad black band down the centre of the canvas, flanked by strips of blue-grey, dirty beige and hospital greens. Against all the odds, it shines. On the Riviera, even black is a sunny colour.

Until January 15. Details: 00 33 1 44 13 17 17.

fields.headline: The Woman Who ...
fields.standfirst:
The Woman Who ...
Southwark Playhouse, London ***
fields.trailText:
The Woman Who ...

Southwark Playhouse, London ***
fields.body:
Most of us don't think too much about the past and the generations that came before us until something happens. Perhaps an unexpected inability to conceive, a child born with a genetic defect, or an illness that makes us wonder about our grandparents and great-grandparents. But can we inherit more than Great Auntie Jeannie's red hair and her propensity for diabetes? Is our emotional makeup a case of nurture or nature, and can the emotional history of our ancestors impinge upon us more than half a century later?

The answer would seem to be yes in this fascinating promenade piece, which conjures ghosts from the shadows of the atmospheric Southwark Playhouse as past and present collide.

It is the year 2000. Luke and Beth have just moved into an old tea warehouse. Beth is pregnant, but can she hold on to the baby when her other pregnancies have ended in miscarriage? She begins to feel the answer lies somewhere in her grandmother's generation, when eight children were mislaid or lost. As the pregnancy and the conversion of the warehouse proceed, Beth starts scraping away at history to reveal the truth.

For all its sketchiness, there is something extraordinarily moving about this performance. Perhaps it is the very ordinariness of the story and the proximity of these solid ghosts, with their noses pressed against the window panes of the future like kids denied entrance to the sweet shop. You can almost reach out and touch them. It brings a lump to the throat because it makes you think about yourself and your own family and creates a sense of loss at what has been hidden by history.

This is so close to being the kind of theatre that you long to see that its almost-success rather than complete success is all the more upsetting. If it doesn't completely work, it is because an hour is too short a time to really get to know the characters, Clare Bayley's oth erwise admirable script is too emotionally reticent, and Deborah Bruce's beautifully acted production doesn't entirely solve the logistical difficulties of moving the audience around the building. But it is a brave and rewarding experiment.

Until October 21. Box office: 020-7620 3494.

webTitle: Theatre review:  The Secret Fall of Constance Wilde

fields.headline: Not wild about Wilde
fields.standfirst:
The Secret Fall of Constance Wilde
*
Barbican, London
fields.trailText:
The Secret Fall of Constance Wilde
*
Barbican, London
fields.body:
"No, no, no, no," cries Constance Wilde to her husband Oscar at the beginning of Thomas Kilroy's surprisingly lame play. Noh, noh, noh, noh would be rather more appropriate for Patrick Mason's Japanese-influenced production.

With its outsize puppets, shadowy masked puppet-masters, cages and staircases disappearing up into the unconscious, this overblown play is unintentionally comic. It is full of exchanges that go like this: Oscar (portentously): "When one sups with the gods one must pay the full price of admission." Constance (earnestly): "But what of the cost to others?" About £24 if you want a good stalls seat in the Barbican - and that's far too much for tosh like this.

This also masquerades as being Constance's story, when in reality it is just another contribution to the Wilde industry. Constance is defined only by the men in her life: she is the victim of her father's sexual deviancy, Oscar's betrayals and Lord Douglas's spitefulness. There is not a mention here of her as a woman of intelligence and energy who was a tireless campaigner for social injustice and women's rights.

What is being celebrated is not the woman, but the idea of constancy: the woman who stands by her man even when it turns out that he's sodomising little boys and spending all her money.

Making very much the best of a bad job, Jane Brennan emerges with some credit as Constance, which is more than can be said for Robert O'Mahoney, who plays Oscar with such tremulous-voiced affectation that you imagine he must be thinking that he is playing Jesus Christ himself. Unfortunately it is only the audience who get crucified.

Till Sunday. Box office: 020 7638 8891.
***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Covent Garden's deadly music
fields.standfirst:
Les Contes d'Hoffmann
Royal Opera House, London *****
fields.trailText:
Les Contes d'Hoffmann
Royal Opera House, London *****
fields.body:
Offenbach's Les Contes d'Hoffmann is one of opera's great conundrums. No other work has quite such an ambivalent attitude towards music. Its subject is the nature of aesthetic inspiration, but Hoffmann is a writer rather than a musician, and the work's denouement consists of the creation of verse, rather than harmony. Music throughout is an instrument of the demonic forces (real or imagined) that destroy Hoffmann as a man but make him as an artist.

It is Olympia's singing that fools Hoffmann into believing she is a human rather than an automaton. Giulietta's languid melodies seduce him into thinking her love for him is genuine, when in fact she's a high-class hooker. Finally, music possesses and ultimately kills poor Antonia, the only woman who genuinely loves him.

This ambivalence is reflected in the epic headiness of John Schlesinger's production, with its alternate images of seduction and revulsion, and its transformation of the three heroines into posing stars. It's now better than ever, largely thanks to a towering performance in the title role by Marcelo Alvarez - a tenor who can act as well as he sings.

In place of the usual sedate entrance, we first meet Hoffmann as he plummets wild-eyed and drunk down a colossal flight of stairs, a pathetic figure, already broken. Alcoholic mania is soon replaced by a visionary delight in creativity, but as he unravels the fantasies he imagines to be his past, we watch the slippage that leads to psychological ruin.

He's gauchely touching with Olympia, and flings himself among the guests at Giulietta's salon with the hesitant sexuality of a man attending his first orgy. His security with Antonia, however, is undercut by persistent, nervous swigs from a hip flask. The rot and disillusionment are already setting in. Vocally, Alvarez is superb, athletic, glorious, his only fault a tendency to stray off pitch when singing softly.

He's genuinely unmissable, though what surrounds him isn't always even. Interest has inevitably focused on Angela Gheorgiu as the tubercular would-be diva Antonia. She proves rather better at diva-dom than consumption, but she's tremendously committed, in contrast to her rather lacklustre performances of late. This may be because the competition from the other two women is stiff. Desirée Rancatore sails through Olympia's music with stratospheric ease and gleeful abandon. Best of the three, however, is Irini Tsirakidis's Giulietta, a feral, sexual animal with a voice that is depravity incarnate.

The real problem lies in the casting of Michele Pertusi as the various incarnations of Hoffmann's demonic nemesis. He's handsome, suggesting sexual rivalry as well as metaphysical destruction, but his voice is thick and solid, not always moving easily at speed, lacking the requisite flicker of Mephistophelian irony. He's at his best as sinuous, silk-clad Dapertutto; Coppélius's grotesque humour does not suit him at all.

The conductor is Emmanuel Villaume , who fills the score with a mixture of seditious eroticism, sparking wit and unnerving fury. The ROH Orchestra play it with exquisite finesse. The few moments of ropy coordination between stage and pit should sort themselves out during the run.

In rep until October 19. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

fields.headline: Hague offers pensions guarantee
fields.standfirst:
OAPs
Special report: Conservative party conference 2000
fields.trailText: William Hague unveiled plans yesterday to outflank Labour on pensions by offering a guarantee to every retired person that they would be better off under the Tories.
fields.body:
William Hague unveiled plans yesterday to outflank Labour on pensions by offering a guarantee to every retired person that they would be better off under the Tories.

On the eve of the Conservative conference in Bournemouth, Mr Hague pledged to roll government "gimmicks" into the basic state pension and to match any increases in the chancellor's last Budget before the general election.

"Everybody would be a little better off, and everybody would have dignity and choice," the Tory leader told BBC1's Breakfast with Frost. "There would be more money in total going to the pensioners of this country."

Under the Tory plans, the winter fuel payment, the Christmas bonus and free TV licences for the over-75s would be scrapped and rolled into the basic pension.

Single pensioners would receive an extra £5.50 a week, with an extra £7 for couples. Single pensioners over 75 would receive an extra £7.50, with couples over 75 getting an extra £10.

The Conservatives' plans would be funded by scrapping the New Deal for lone parents and by cutting the social fund, which lends money to poor families.

Mr Hague's announcement was designed to tap into pensioners' anger over the 75p a week rise in the basic pension in this year's Budget.

The government's poor handling of the issue led to an embarrassing defeat at the Labour conference in Brighton last week, when union leaders called on the leadership to restore the link between pensions and earnings.

The Tories' pensioners' guarantee follows an attempt to woo young voters by offering them a better pension if they opt out of the basic state pension.

People under 30 would be allowed to put their national insurance contributions into private investments. The Tories believe that this could double the money they would receive from the state pension.

Mr Hague said: "If we had done this 30 years ago then we would have far less pensioner poverty today. We are the only party planning for future generations."

Labour said it was ludicrous of Mr Hague to offer a guarantee to today's pensioners before the chancellor has even announced his plans. Alistair Darling, social security secretary, said: "William Hague is making policy up as he goes along. He has not seen our figures, and no one will believe he has costed these plans properly."

Mr Darling also warned that the plan for the under 30s - which he derided as a privatisation - would leave a £4bn black hole in the national insurance fund.

"How would the Tories fund this black hole in their pensions policy?" he asked. "The truth is that the Tories' pensions policy simply doesn't add up."

John Edmonds, leader of the GMB union, accused Mr Hague of cynical opportunism. Mr Edmonds, who led the union revolt against the government in Brighton last week, said: "Pensioners will remember it was Tories who broke the link between pensions and earnings, and it was the Tories who allowed pensions to wither on the vine for more than 20 years."

Mr Hague's announcement on the eve of the conference was carefully timed to deflect criticism that the party has lurched to the right.

Mr Ancram tried to show that the Conservatives have a caring image when he declared: "We are the party of the mainstream majority."

webTitle: Hero or villain? Brown faces a means testing time in dilemma over pensions

fields.headline: Hero or villain? Brown faces a means testing time in dilemma over pensions
fields.standfirst:
Grey power is proving a force to be reckoned with in and out of the workplace
Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown will win Labour the next election. Gordon Brown will lose Labour the next election. You pays your money and you takes your choice. Which of the roles is it to be for Mr Moneybags: stage villain or saturnine hero?
fields.body:
Gordon Brown will win Labour the next election. Gordon Brown will lose Labour the next election. You pays your money and you takes your choice. Which of the roles is it to be for Mr Moneybags: stage villain or saturnine hero?

Both sides of the chancellor were on show last week as he shuttled in and out of Prague. On Monday he was the darling of the conference as he tore away the New Labour veil to reveal an Old Labour face behind. But by Wednesday, he was on the losing side in an argument with Barbara Castle - Old Labour in its pure, undiluted form. Nobody likes losing, and Brown likes losing less than most. The chancellor's face was a picture of thunderous malcontent as he stalked off the podium.

The paradox lying behind all this is that Brown was trying to face down Mrs Castle and her union allies at a time when he has more money than he knows what to do with. Nine years of growth have had a dramatic effect on the public finances, and if Brown's plan for raising the economy's trend rate of growth to 2.75% succeeds, things can only get better.

In March, the chancellor said he was expecting to be in the black by £5bn this year; it now looks as if the surplus will turn out to be £15bn at least. Any previous Labour chancellor would have killed for that sort of projected surplus after he had already spent an extra £43bn over the next three years. There is money - lots of it - available for pensions, but just as with schools and hospitals, there is concern in the government's ranks that it will be too late for anybody to notice the difference before the election.

Indeed, the dreadful realisation has suddenly dawned on Labour that it could hand over a thriving economy to the enemy - just as John Major did. But whereas Brown had a £28bn deficit to mop up, Michael Portillo would have a £15bn surplus to blow on tax cuts.

That £28bn deficit helps explain how the government came to find itself in a fix over pensions. Reducing the deficit was a key element in Labour's attempt to show that it was competent to manage the economy, and this meant both surreptitious increases in taxes and sticking to Ken Clarke's spending plans.

But Clarke's plans were brutally tight and left no fat for the sort of blanket redistribution that those who had waited 18 years for a Labour government were expecting. It was not feasible for Brown to pursue a policy of fiscal conservatism without offering something to pensioners and those workers on the lowest incomes. So, the circle was squared by targeting resources on the most needy, rather than trying to spread around too thinly what little was available. This decision was a profound one, because it meant that the whole basis of Labour's approach to the welfare state would be means testing not universality. To make matters worse it was means testing by stealth, carried out under the guise of "targeting resources".

Once the principle of means testing was accepted, the whole of Labour's pensions policy could be justified as simply common sense. From a technocratic point of view, there is no justification in paying both a millionaire and someone living below the poverty line £5 a week when, by giving the millionaire nothing, you could give the poor person £10 a week. And, it has to be said, Labour has increased spending on pensioners.

Tackle the problem

But so carried away did Labour get by its own inexorable logic (and arrogance) that it failed to see some of the drawbacks of its approach. Means testing is bureaucratic, costly to administer, discourages thrift and encourages fraud. In the specific case of pensions, Mrs Castle has rightly pointed out that breaking the earnings link is tantamount to a fraud, since contributions into the national insurance fund are based on earnings, but the value of the pension is linked to prices. Finally, means testing involves all sorts of political baggage.

Even though vast chunks of state spending - from university grants to income support - are means tested, the term still carries a real stigma, especially for pensioners. The universal principle - embodied in the welfare state through the state pension, child benefit and NHS - has a binding effect. Poor people feel they are getting something as of right and rich people get something back for their taxes, discouraging them from opting out altogether.

It may be that times have changed so much that means testing is the only way to run a modern welfare system. Jeff Rooker, the social security minister, made a case for why times have changed in Brighton last week, saying that state earnings related pensions and the growing gulf between rich and poor made the old approach untenable. There is something in this. A universal system does work better when incomes are fairly equal, not so well when the disparities between rich and poor are wide. Labour could have chosen to tackle this problem by doing something about income inequality: instead it chose to tackle it by raising the state pension by 75p a week.

Another solution would have been to keep faith with the universal principle by restoring the link between pensions and earnings but using progressive taxation to ensure that the increase for the rich was taxed back. The government would pay out more gross, but the net payment would be the same and the benefit would still be felt by the poor. The objection to this, presumably, is that it would be complex, though it is hard to see how it could be more complex than the web of means testing Brown has constructed.

The chancellor assumes that everybody is as au fait with the intricacies of the minimum income guarantee or the pensioner tax credit as he is. If everybody knows what you are doing, understands what you are doing, and agrees with what you are doing, anything - even 75p a week - can be justified. But in the real world that is not the case, as Labour has only belatedly found out now that it has set off down a road from which it sees no turning back.

Except, of course, that next year there will be. In the government's own terms, 75p a week was logical because the pension was uprated in line with last year's September inflation figure, which was 1.1%. Raising the pension by 75p meant that, in theory, it maintained its purchasing power.

Looking at it this way shows the enormity of Labour's political error. According to the inflation rate, pensioners are on track to get between £2.00 and £2.50 a week on the state pension. But with billions sloshing around in the exchequer, what are the chances of a bigger increase of, say, £5 a week?

In the present climate, pretty good. The government will then be in the strange position of using the universal principle to get it out of the mess that its backdoor means testing has got it in to. From Labour's point of view, this may make little sense. They might believe that pensioners do not know what is in their own best interests. But perhaps pensioners would like to make that decision for themselves.

webTitle: Pop review: Morcheeba learn to smile

fields.headline: Morcheeba learn to smile
fields.standfirst:
Morcheeba
Manchester Academy *
fields.trailText:
Morcheeba
Manchester Academy *
fields.body:
If this gig is anything to go by, Morcheeba are fast becoming the dance-music equivalent of Travis. Thirtysomething couples smooch alongside inebriated students, while original acid-jazz fans shuffle their feet to the rhythm. Between songs, singer Skye encourages the audience to sing along, while the rest of the group look on with admiration.

After years of near hits and countless tours, Morcheeba finally seem to have developed a sound they're completely happy with. Better still, this new direction allows them to abandon the ghost of trip hop and embrace their teenage obsessions: old-skool funk, rap, disco and bubbling pop.

It's not just the music that's changed: all three songwriters have decided to adopt a healthier and happier approach to living. Hence positive titles like (You Can't Keep a) Good Girl Down, Rome Wasn't Built in a Day and Be Yourself. The first two songs have "anthemic crowd-pleaser" stamped across them, while the latter adds strong licks of guitar and cheesy scratching.

Unfortunately, world domination comes at a stiff price. Morcheeba Mark III are a very different band from the one that penned Trigger Hippie in 1995. For starters, a lot of the subtleties of their earlier songs have been replaced by self-indulgent guitar solos, smoother-than-silk backing singers and well-measured choruses. Paul Godfrey tries his hardest to retain some of the group's early trademarks (notably moody beats and emotive percussion), but his attempts are weighed down by the blandness of the material.

Part of the Process, Blindfold and Over & Over provide welcome relief from the nauseating niceness of Rome, Love Sweet Love, Girl Down and Love Is Rare, while a touching rendition of The Sea reminds you what a seductive band Morcheeba used to be.

Melancholy is the last thing on Skye's mind, however, and throughout Shallow End she jumps up and down, squealing like a 17-year-old clubber discovering the joys of ecstasy.

At Rock City, Nottingham (0115-958 8484) on Wednesday and Shepherd's Bush Empire, London W12 (020-7771 2000), from Thursday to Saturday.

fields.headline: Glasgow's tough questions
fields.standfirst:
Invisible Republic
Glasgow Print Studio Gallery ****
fields.trailText:
Invisible Republic
Glasgow Print Studio Gallery ****
fields.body:
Can white chocolate be political? Can clotted cream be a searing indictment? Kenny Hunter's latest sculptures raise questions that are even stranger than usual. In the elegant gentility of Duff House near Banff earlier this year Hunter placed a big black head complete with splendid Afro and dub sound system. It made you think, of course, about slavery and colonial power, as well as the unspoken racism that has shaped significant art collections. But it also made you stop and ponder the music puncturing the silence we tend to view art in. Why did that start, then?

Now, though, the colour and nearly every trace of life have been drained from Hunter's work, a series of large-scale sculptures fashioned from his trademark glass-reinforced plastic. Where once there were sweetie reds and yellows, now there is only white - a rich, creamy white - giving the work a monumental, classical look quite at odds with its subjects and mood.

Time and Space Died Yesterday is a Thunderbirds-style rocket out of a wall; Bonne Année Monsieur Baudrillard is a crazy skull on a clock; Tombstone is just that, but with fridge-magnet lettering arranged on it in neat rows. Quoting Gunter Grass's The Rat, the text is an elegy for all that will be left behind - the colour and sounds, the very life - in death.

The end, as a jokey or deeply philosophical concept, lurks throughout the show, with death, destruction and finality unmissable even in the lighter, more sarcastic work. This is fitting in two connected ways. Not only is Hunter marking the end of a phase in his work (the brightly coloured, jolly, jewel-like pieces) but for much of this year he has been working on a £10,000 commission for a public work in Glasgow to mark the life of Christ. No wonder death is in; irony seeps away.

This is what faces you in Bad Conscience and the Old Skool Plastik, a tower of first world war iconography: death in the trenches, rats crawling over skulls, unspent cartridges piled all around. It's a recognisable if still affecting soup of man-made misery, but recast in Hunter's creamy smoothness it somehow becomes a thing of beauty, a tribute of sorts.

Until November 11. Details: 0141-552 0704.

fields.headline: Topologies
fields.standfirst:
Topologies
****
The Warehouse, London
fields.trailText:
Topologies
****
The Warehouse, London
fields.body:
Rebecca Saunders is one of the most fascinating of the younger generation of British composers, and was a natural choice to open the British Music Information Centre's Cutting Edge series. The distinctiveness of her music - its emphasis on the qualities and colours of individual sounds and gestures - perhaps owes something to her training in Germany with composer Wolfgang Rihm. It was interpreted here by contemporary music ensemble Topologies.

The opening of Saunders's Mirror, Mirror on the Wall for solo piano illuminates many of her key concerns. Investigating musical representations of reflection, the piece begins with a series of quiescent chords. Ian Pace, whose whole performance was a model of controlled expressiveness, depressed other keys silently in the interstices between each chord. The tiny chiming of the sounded notes released the shadowy resonances of the silently played keys. The result was an overlapping ripple of sound, punctuated by crystalline fragments of rhythm and melody. This was a music made as much from the absence and decay of sounds as their actual articulation.

The next section of Mirror explores a more obvious kind of musical mirror-imaging. A flowing melody of tightly limited pitches in the piano's middle register acts as a pivot for fiercely declaimed chords at either end of the instrument's compass. As the work progresses, Saunders introduces a whole series of sounds and textures, from an insistent chiming to the dry thwack of the piano's pedals. Saunders's juxtaposition of these different ideas creates a musical world that suggests something outside its rich tapestry of sounds. Her score makes reference to the work's "waltz section", and by the end of Pace's performance it was as if one had experienced a warped, suggestive fairytale.

All of the other pieces on the programme - Duo for violin and piano, The Underside of Green (a trio for clarinet, violin and piano) and Quartet for accordion, clarinet, double-bass and piano - reveal the same basic technique of placing sounds and textures next to one another with fastidious precision. But in Underside and especially Quartet, the individual ideas are more extended and overtly dramatic than those of Mirror.

Quartet, the most recent piece played, is much more mysterious than an objective collection of pure sounds. This work has an expressive energy and dynamic trajectory, as well as the reflective focus of Saunders's earlier pieces. Topologies' vibrant performances were superbly authoritative throughout.

fields.headline: Ossified Germans
fields.standfirst: The fall of the Berlin Wall is still a factor in Rudi Voller's team
fields.trailText: The fall of the Berlin Wall is still a factor in Rudi Voller's team.
fields.body:
On the night of 3 October 1990, I walked along the Unter den Linden, the great boulevard of East Berlin, watching Germans celebrate their country's reunification. A few people drank champagne and shouted, but most just wandered in silence. No one knew what a united Germany would bring.

The strangest forecasts were going around: Margaret Thatcher thought Germany would invade Poland again, while Franz Beckenbauer, manager of the West German side that had just won the World Cup, said a united German football team would be invincible.

Many East Germans worried that their country would disappear. I asked an Ossi friend what in the GDR was worth keeping. He thought for a while. Well, he said finally, the abortion laws weren't bad. Another man praised the extra traffic lights in East Germany that automatically turned green if you wanted to turn left or right and the road was clear.

The Ossis have been proved right. Ten years on, the GDR has all but disappeared. The crumbling or bombed buildings are giving way to Western skyscrapers, few East German athletes are shining at the Olympics, and what was once a state is now a sort of minor protectorate run by politicians and capitalists from the West. The only arena in which the GDR still prospers is the national football team. This is stunning. The GDR was mediocre at football, yet more than a third of the German players who will visit England next week are Ossis.

Their childhoods were spent in a lost socialist era. Jens Jeremies, the moustachioed midfielder with a penchant for scoring own goals, began at six with Motor Görlitz and was trained as an industrial mechanic. Michael Ballack and 'Super-Ingo' Hertzsch, Germany's new hopes, grew up in what was then Karl-Marx-Stadt. Carsten Jancker, the huge striker, is from a small town in Mecklenburg. Jörg Heinrich, the blond full-back, played for the army club Vorwärts Frankfurt.

The list goes on, like a Communist fifth-column exposed by Senator McCarthy: Thomas Linke, Alexander Zickler, Marko Rehmer and Stefan Beinlich, all Ossis. The greatest German player of this generation is the Dresden boy Matthias Sammer, 33, but long since forced to retire by injuries.

Like Reds under the bed, these Ossis can be hard to spot. Most of them look like German football millionaires. All moved west early, as no big clubs survive in the East German economic desert. GDR icons such as Dynamo Dresden, Carl Zeiss Jena and FC Magdeburg now play regional football.

But a closer look often reveals the Ossi, just as in Cold War fantasies you could spot the Russian spy by the snow on his boots. The odd personal touch - Jancker's shaven head and Jeremies' little moustache - evoke a childhood in some grey high-rise reeking of brown coal on the Rosa-Luxemburgstrasse.

When the Ossis talk about their footballing education, they sound different indeed. Hand-picked as children, they spent their teens in boarding schools practising football for up to 25 hours a week. Once a month they were allowed to visit their parents. Zickler says: 'We had to do exercises like strapping medicine balls on our chests, or doing somersaults real specific football practice, as you see.'

It worked. These Ossis were taught how to kick with both feet. They were made to think about football. Jancker says: 'It was hard, but I wouldn't have missed that time.' Sammer told Der Spiegel : 'A seriousness was passed on. Now in training coaches try to make sure youngsters enjoy football. Nobody practises juggling a ball any more, because it's no fun.'

In Germany, sending children to boarding school is considered an inhumane practice. But so scarce are decent Western footballers that the German FA has kept the Eastern football academies going. The 14, schools with their total of 750 pupils, are a Communist version of the French and Australian academies so feted today. West Germany has nothing like it.

In the days of the GDR it used to be said that East German footballers lacked spontaneity - that they never hit a telling pass or dribbled past a couple of opponents. That remains true: the likes of Jancker and Jeremies hardly evoke Beckenbauer. But nor do their Western counterparts. The fact is that the 16 million Ossis produce almost as many mediocre international footballers as do the 60 million Wessis. Imagine how bad the German team would have been had the Wall not fallen. Yet if West German fans ever deign to note this, it is usually in the form of a jibe: when the former manager Berti Vogts called Jeremies his 'vacuum cleaner', it was joked that the Ossi would not know what that was.

I know a Berliner who was persecuted by the Stasi and expelled from East Germany because he used to support Western football teams. He has his own theory of the GDR's footballing afterlife. 'It's because,' he says, 'German football has sunk to the Eastern level.'

Michael Ballack and 'Super-Ingo' Hertzsch, Germany's new hopes, grew up in what was then Karl-Marx-Stadt. Carsten Jancker, the huge striker, is from a small town in Mecklenburg. Jörg Heinrich, the blond full-back, played for the army club Vorwärts Frankfurt. The list goes on, like a Communist fifth-column exposed by Senator McCarthy: Thomas Linke, Alexander Zickler, Marko Rehmer and Stefan Beinlich, all Ossis. The greatest German player of this generation is the Dresden boy Matthias Sammer, 33, but long since forced to retire by injuries. Like Reds under the bed, these Ossis can be hard to spot. Most of them look like German football millionaires. All moved west early, as no big clubs survive in the East German economic desert. GDR icons such as Dynamo Dresden, Carl Zeiss Jena and FC Magdeburg now play regional football. But a closer look often reveals the Ossi, just as in Cold War fantasies you could spot the Russian spy by the snow on his boots. The odd personal touch - Jancker's shaven head and Jeremies' little moustache - evoke a childhood in some grey high-rise reeking of brown coal on the Rosa-Luxemburgstrasse. When the Ossis talk about their footballing education, they sound different indeed. Hand-picked as children, they spent their teens in boarding schools practising football for up to 25 hours a week. Once a month they were allowed to visit their parents. Zickler says: 'We had to do exercises like strapping medicine balls on our chests, or doing somersaults real specific football practice, as you see.' It worked. These Ossis were taught how to kick with both feet. They were made to think about football. Jancker says: 'It was hard, but I wouldn't have missed that time.' Sammer told Der Spiegel : 'A seriousness was passed on. Now in training coaches try to make sure youngsters enjoy football. Nobody practises juggling a ball any more, because it's no fun.' In Germany, sending children to boarding school is considered an inhumane practice. But so scarce are decent Western footballers that the German FA has kept the Eastern football academies going. The 14, schools with their total of 750 pupils, are a Communist version of the French and Australian academies so feted today. West Germany has nothing like it. In the days of the GDR it used to be said that East German footballers lacked spontaneity - that they never hit a telling pass or dribbled past a couple of opponents. That remains true: the likes of Jancker and Jeremies hardly evoke Beckenbauer. But nor do their Western counterparts. The fact is that the 16 million Ossis produce almost as many mediocre international footballers as do the 60 million Wessis. Imagine how bad the German team would have been had the Wall not fallen. Yet if West German fans ever deign to note this, it is usually in the form of a jibe: when the former manager Berti Vogts called Jeremies his 'vacuum cleaner', it was joked that the Ossi would not know what that was. I know a Berliner who was persecuted by the Stasi and expelled from East Germany because he used to support Western football teams. He has his own theory of the GDR's footballing afterlife. 'It's because,' he says, 'German football has sunk to the Eastern level.'

fields.headline: The great leap forward
fields.standfirst: Billy Elliot, set against the 1984 miners' strike, triumphantly turns lads' culture on its head
fields.trailText: Philip French: It is a trifle sentimental. It will, I'm sure, prove a popular success
fields.body:
Writing briefly from Cannes, and comparing his film debut favourably with Lars von Trier's Dancer in the Dark, I called Stephen Daldry's Dancer (shown out of competition) 'Stepping Out meets Kes' and a 'sentimental crowd pleaser'. Daldry's film arrives in Britain under the new title of Billy Elliot (possibly he and screenwriter Lee Hall thought Dancer pretentious or fancy), and I wouldn't go back on what I wrote last May. It is a trifle sentimental. It will, I'm sure, prove a popular success.

As in Kes, the vulnerable hero is called Billy, comes from a northern industrial town and has a brutal elder brother who scorns his hobby. Like Stepping Out, there's a star role for Julie Walters and a dancing class with only one male. But the movie is subtler, more graceful than anything suggested above. And the acting, editing, production design and photography are first-rate.

From the opening credits, the film takes us into the mind and body of the 11-year-old Billy Elliot (Jamie Bell), as he bounces in slow motion to the strains of T. Rex's 'Cosmic Dancer', free as the air (or like electricity, as he later puts it). He maintains these rhythms as he makes breakfast in a clean but run-down terrace house.

The year is 1984, the place a small mining town in Durham crawling with cops. Billy's elder brother (Jamie Draven) and widowed father (Gary Lewis) are on the NUM picket line; his kindly, senile grandmother (Jean Heywood) is in need of the attention no one can give her; his mother died two years before, at the age of 38. The dancing is a form of expression and a way of escape.

Dad finds 50 pence a week for Billy to attend boxing classes at a local boys' club, which he does reluctantly, taking with him his grandfather's gloves, an obvious symbol of macho tradition. Due to the strike, the same premises are being used by a ballet class run by the blousy, good-natured, chain-smoking Mrs Wilkinson (Julie Walters). Billy stops to watch the dancing girls and is dared to join in by the teacher's precocious little daughter. He's hooked and secretly pays his 50p for ballet lessons.

In a witty and touching montage, Daldry cuts between Billy's progress in class, his faltering attempts to learn from a book on ballet using the bathroom mirror, and his father, brother and grandmother responding to the same half-heard music. Naturally, Dad explodes when he finds out about the dancing ('Lads do football, lads do boxing, they don't do frigging ballet') and a contest ensues with Mrs Wilkinson, who has hopes of Billy winning a scholarship to the Royal Ballet School.

The frustrated Mrs Wilkinson, the surrogate mother whose alcoholic husband has been made redundant, sees the promotion of Billy as the justification for her own life, and confronts the angry father, a similarly disillusioned person. But though the film takes her side, the movie doesn't turn Billy into a creature too good and sensitive for the dead-end, culturally impoverished world into which he's been born.

Indeed there's an important scene where he shows a considerate, middle-class boy the same brutality he has himself endured. Nor is this, like Brassed Off or The Full Monty, a picture about turning a brave face to hard times and demonstrating the resilience of the working class. In the thrust of its narrative, and in the cross-cutting between the violent clashes on the picket lines and the dancing classes, Billy Elliot suggests that economic circumstances produce cultural changes, and that we must adapt to and, in some cases, embrace, them. The film offers the 1984-85 miners' strike as a defining moment when the values and attitudes created by industrial society lost their validity. Received notions of what constitutes masculinity need modifying and an evening spent dancing on a stage can be as demanding as a night shift at the coal face, and more spiritually rewarding.

Billy Elliot is sympathetic to the striking miners and respectful of their solidarity, but its politics are of a transcendental kind. For Billy, dancing is a solitary rather than social activity and we're shown him rejecting the tentative, amorous advances of a girl and a young boy. The escape he seeks, first through fantasy, then through professional discipline, isn't to another place or a different class. It's into a different state of mind, into a new relationship with the living world. A marvellous early image, which is echoed near the end, sees Billy dance up a steep, ugly backstreet. Behind him, there's a cloudless sky over a blue sea on which sails a single, fairy-tale boat heading on some magical journey.

This captures the essence of the movie and takes the sarcasm out of the description of Billy by his teacher's embittered husband - 'Durham's own Gene Kelly'. Of course the film would not have worked had not Stephen Daldry discovered in Jamie Bell a dancer of easy dexterity, capable of expressing both Billy's inwardness and his boyish innocence.

webTitle: Wilkie off as Dundee see red again

fields.headline: Wilkie off as Dundee see red again
fields.trailText: Scottish round-up
fields.body:
Another week, another depleted schedule for the Scottish Premier League. With Rangers and Celtic both playing on Sunday - due to European commitments - there was a further chance to see just what Scottish football will be like should its big two get their wish and join the Atlantic League.

Alec McLeish's Hibernian continued their remarkable start to the season, beating St Johnstone 3-0 to cling on to second place. Elsewhere St Mirren narrowly held on for their second win of the sea son, scoring twice in the first half to move within two points of opponents Dunfermline.

St Mirren's new signing Graham Fenton turned in an outstanding performance - his pace and guile often confusing a subdued Dunfermline side. But although he went close several times, Fenton was unable to mark his debut with a goal and had to be content with applauding team-mates Jamie McGowan and Mark Yardley.

The new SPL system where the league will split into two later on in the season has at least ensured there's no such thing as midtable mediocrity anymore although that will be of little consolation to Dundee.

After a strong start to the season, Ivano Bonetti's side have begun to slide down the table and are now one place off the bottom six.

They have looked uninspired of late but are certainly not helped by a poor disciplinary record. Lee Wilkie became the latest player to be sent off for the Tayside side as they struggled to an uninspiring 0-0 draw. Both sides struggled to produce any real football of note and although there was plenty of effort, there were precious few clear-cut chances created.

The only real talking point was Wilkie's sending-off in the second half for a professional foul on Kilmarnock substitute Craig Dargo. Apart from that, there was little goalmouth action although veteran striker Ally McCoist came close.

In the First Division, leaders Livingston lost 3-2 to nearest rivals Falkirk, who fought back after conceding twice in the first 25 minutes. That battling performance put Falkirk in second place and level on points. Indeed the race for promotion is already hotting up with Ayr, who drew 3-3 with Inverness Caledonian Thistle, only one point behind the top two.

Struggling Airdrie produced their best result of the season when they stuck five past Morton. The West-coast side took the lead in the 23rd minute but one minute later Andrew Millen scored an own goal and Morton promptly collapsed. Airdrie were so rampant by the end the only surprise was they didn't add at least one more. That result means Alloa stay bottom. They have won only one game this season and never really looked likely to get another against a determined Ross County side, who finished 1-0 winners.

In the Second Division, Queens Park stay top after beating Stenhousemuir 2-0 while Queen of the South continue to prop up the table, going down 2-0 to Arbroath.

Third Division Cowdenbeath remain unbeaten after winning 2-0 against bottom placed Montrose, but they are being closely chased by Brechin City, who put four past East Stirlingshire to stay level on points.

fields.headline: Stewart finds his feet
fields.trailText: Two second-half goals from Marcus Stewart emphasised that Ipswich have successfully negotiated the step up that has proved a promotion too far for so many teams.
fields.body:
Two second-half goals from Marcus Stewart emphasised that Ipswich have successfully negotiated the step up that has proved a promotion too far for so many teams.

Stewart's double sealed a deserved victory and nobody should relish the prospect of facing George Burley's team at the moment.

For Everton manager Walter Smith this must be one of the worst days endured on either side of the Border. Apart from a spell shortly before half-time, Everton were a disjointed and dispirited side and thoroughly warranted the jeers that greeted them at the final whistle.

Injuries continue to frustrate Smith's attempt to field his first-choice team. Kevin Campbell's return this month has been cancelled out by the loss of Francis Jeffers for six weeks to an ankle injury.

With Duncan Ferguson in his customary place in the treatment room, Smith had to pair American Joe-Max Moore with Campbell yesterday and they needed a long time to strike up an understanding.

They weren't alone in looking like strangers in this Everton line-up. Smith's tendency to employ players in unaccustomed positions emerged again with midfielder Alex Nyarko handed a job in the middle of Everton's three-man defence. It was a gamble by Smith and Ipswich, manipulated skilfully by their midfield duo of Matt Holland and Jim Magilton, threatened to exploit Nyarko's settling-in period.

Holland and Jermaine Wright almost squeezed the ball beyond the Everton keeper Paul Gerrard as confusion reigned in front of him in the opening moments.

Richard Naylor, who had operations on both knees following last season's promotion play-off final, dived in ahead of Steve Watson to power a header into the ground and over the bar.

Such a start required drastic action from Smith. He ordered a switch to a four-man defence after only a quarter of a hour in a bid to introduce some stability yet, within four minutes, Ipswich were ahead.

It was a special goal for John McGreal, a Tranmere Rovers stalwart for a decade and yesterday fulfilling an ambition to play a league game at one of the city's Premiership grounds.

He rose well to accurately direct a header inside a post which Everton chose to leave unmanned as Titus Bramble floated in a free-kick. The mood of the crowd - already fractious - noticeably darkened, despite the fact that Smith's reshaped line-up looked like it would make inroads.

A header from Moore looped over the bar with keeper Richard Wright scrambling back and Moore was also involved in Everton's best attack of the half. Campbell, betrayed by his lack of match fitness, hesitated with his shot after being released by Nyarko in the 30th minute and eventually picked out Alexandersson. The Swede's shot was blocked by the chest of Wright and Moore was unable to force in the loose ball.

Wright also had to make a brave double save in first-half stoppage time from Campbell and the subdued Gascoigne. An encouraging climax to the half for Everton, but not enough to silence the boos.

Any chances of an Everton revival were removed when Stewart turned in Naylor's cross in the 49th minute after more slack marking.

Stewart added his second in the 60th minute, latching on to a poor back pass and, evading two challenges and scoring at the second attempt after Weir cleared his first one off the line.

fields.headline: Souness's dream slips away
fields.trailText: So far it's not been a good season for supposedly big former Premiership clubs. Sheffield Wednesday spent yesterday confirming that they are attempting to break the record for swiftest plunge into obscurity as they lost 2-0 to newly-promoted Gillingham, and there was no real joy for David Platt's Nottingham Forest - held to a dull 0-0 draw by visiting Wolves.
fields.body:
So far it's not been a good season for supposedly big former Premiership clubs. Sheffield Wednesday spent yesterday confirming that they are attempting to break the record for swiftest plunge into obscurity as they lost 2-0 to newly-promoted Gillingham, and there was no real joy for David Platt's Nottingham Forest - held to a dull 0-0 draw by visiting Wolves.

But the most surprising loss of form is Blackburn's. Ever since they went down, less than five years after winning the Premiership, people have been tipping the Lancashire club to go back up.

But increasingly that looks less and less likely. The arrival of Graeme Souness was intended to add some backbone to a team of highly-paid dilettantes but, after a good start, Blackburn have faltered and yesterday they looked wildly off the pace, losing 1-0 to West Bromwich Albion.

Of course it's still early in the season but, with the race to finish second in the division hotting up, Blackburn can hardly afford to continue throwing away points and the jury is still out on whether they have the strength to mount a serious challenge. Souness admitted as much afterwards, saying: 'It was disappointing. They deserved it because they showed a lot more aggression than we did. I have obviously got to be concerned about our away form. If you are going to do well, you have got to pick up a fair share of points away.'

Birmingham are another club of wealthy under-achievers. Every season they tend to finish there or thereabouts, but somehow they never quite make it past the final hurdle. Trevor Francis's side have once again started well but will have their mettle tested when they take on Watford at Vicarage Road today.

There's nothing like a change of manager to revitalise a club and since the surprise sackings of Keith Stevens and Alan McLeary, Millwall have been unable to stop scoring. Yesterday new boss Mark McGhee saw his side put four past Peterborough, although in a high-scoring day this was not the best - league leaders Walsall confirmed their class with a 5-1 victory over Notts County.

In the Third Division Brighton beat their bogey team, Leyton Orient, 2-0 at Withdene to move into fourth place. Meanwhile Halifax, yet to win at home, stay bottom after drawing 0-0 with Shrewsbury Town.

fields.headline: Shearer finally hits the target
fields.trailText: Alan Shearer knows how to time his goals. With England about to go into their first competitive match since his international retirement, and on the back of one of his worst ever goal droughts at club level, the Newcastle captain produced his first goal from open play this season to leave no one in any doubt as to his continued ability.
fields.byline: By Simon Burnton at Maine Road
fields.body:
Alan Shearer knows how to time his goals. With England about to go into their first competitive match since his international retirement, and on the back of one of his worst ever goal droughts at club level, the Newcastle captain produced his first goal from open play this season to leave no one in any doubt as to his continued ability.

But if Shearer's decisive strike was predictable, the man of the match was anything but. Tommy Wright, Manchester City's 37-year-old reserve keeper, shone in the absence of Nicky Weaver, ruled out with a groin injury. Now Joe Royle has two weeks to brood over this defeat and to decide who should start the next match in goal.

'It's typical of my luck that he gets injured when we've only got one game in three weeks,' said Wright. After the game, his manager was full of praise. 'He's been an unfortunate victim of the meteoric rise of Nicky Weaver,' said Royle, 'but if the goalkeeper's the man of the match in a home game I'm not really going to be a happy man.'

Twice in the first half Wright kept out goalbound efforts, leaping athletically to turn Shearer's header over the bar and then bettering even that effort when diving full-length to his left in the 25th minute to keep out a Gary Speed effort. In the second half he excelled again to tip over a curling shot from Lomana Lua-Lua. Wright's form served to inspire his opposite number, Shay Given, who blocked, stopped and scrambled at times to prevent City from scoring.

They had several opportunities, most of which fell to Paulo Wanchope and, tellingly, almost all of which came from set-pieces. City should have scored nevertheless, and when Mark Kennedy, their impressive half-time substitute, rounded Given in the 81st minute it seemed that they would, only for the Irish winger to slip and scuff the ball wide.

Newcastle, though, were the more inventive side and ultimately deserved the win, which halted a recent decline and left them in third place overnight. 'We had our chances, and on another day could have got a point,' said Royle. 'But that doesn't hide the fact that they were better than us on the day.'

fields.headline: Petrescu's rescue rattles Harry
fields.trailText: So far this season, Harry Redknapp has sworn his team have been in a ludicrously false position. Having witnessed a shambolic result from a game expected to yield maximum points, he was forced to review his opinion.
fields.body:
So far this season, Harry Redknapp has sworn his team have been in a ludicrously false position. Having witnessed a shambolic result from a game expected to yield maximum points, he was forced to review his opinion.

'At the end of the day, we are where we are,' he seethed. You could almost see the steam coming out of his ears. While he still believes West Ham will clamber into the top half of the table, any haughty conviction was wiped out with Bradford's late equaliser. His players, he confessed, were distraught.

Redknapp was scarlet with anger, and rightly so. His team had ample opportunities to haul themselves away from the foot of the table and wasted all but one. To add to the curses, their opponents could be admired for dogged work and stubborn character - inspired by the valiant, tigerish Stuart McCall at the heart of a three-man defence - but little else. Until their goal Shaka Hislop was a spectator, save for two dashes to claim from the feet of Ashley Ward and Dan Petrescu.

Resilience alone may not be enough for Bradford to preserve their Premiership status, but it sure is a powerful weapon. Having been on the back foot so long, they stole in at the death to claim their first goal, and first point, away from home. It carried them off the foot of the table. 'That's good news psychologically but we know we have a long way to go,' said manager Chris Hutchings, who acknowledged his team rode a lorryload of luck.

'At half-time we should have been 4-0 up,' gasped Redknapp. Instead it was just the one, fashioned by Frederic Kanoute and finished by Joe Cole. Bradford, struggling to keep tabs on the England wunderkind's movement, were punished with a cool header and the 18-year- old saluted his second goal of the season. The three lions will be expecting sooner rather than later, although Kevin Keegan will note his eager brilliance came in fits and spurts. Another plus point for England was the sight of Rio Ferdinand lasting 90 minutes in fine fettle.

Not so Bradford's defenders, two of whom were forced to withdraw after tangling with West Ham's tricky young attacker Kanoute. Gareth Whalley's afternoon ended before half-time, with his team-mates complaining he had been stamped on by the Frenchman. Then his replacement, Gunnar Halle, was forced off after hurting himself as he robbed Kanoute with a splendid saving tackle in the box.

City tightened up after the break and the longer West Ham struggled to increase their advantage, the greater the home anxiety spread. They sensed another goal was needed to finish off City, and when Stuart Pearce's thunderous header was cleared off the line by McCall and Michael Carrick struck a post, tension began to bite hard.

Bradford's recovery arrived just in time. In the 89th minute Igor Stimac gave away a careless free-kick. Benito Carbone chipped the ball in for Petrescu to glance home.

'We've battered them and given away a crappy goal,' Redknapp moaned. The brunt of the manager's frustrations was borne by Trevor Sinclair, whose tactical error proved so critical. He was detailed to track Petrescu but chose to stand on the goal-line. 'If you can curl a free- kick into the top corner from 35 yards you're some player but Trevor goes on a post,' remarked Redknapp sarcastically. 'There was no reason for him to be there. He took it on his own back and it cost us dearly. It cost us a game we dominated. It's a waste.' Peace of mind and the table's top half are some distance away.

fields.headline: Parrish wows celebrants
fields.trailText: The dark clouds of last season's relegation are rapidly lifting over Chesterfield. This was the fifth consecutive win for the Division Three pace-setters. So far, so good for an immediate return to Division Two.
fields.byline: Ed Jones at the Recreation Ground
fields.body:
The dark clouds of last season's relegation are rapidly lifting over Chesterfield. This was the fifth consecutive win for the Division Three pace-setters. So far, so good for an immediate return to Division Two.

Manager Nicky Law said afterwards: 'We started slowly but we got the break, and in the second half we were magnificent. That's the sign of a good team that we still scored four when we weren't at our best throughout. Of course, we aim to win every game. It's our goal to get promoted, but there's still a long way to go. Today the other results went for us, but we just have to think of ourselves and keep winning.'

Law was a rather surprising appointment as manager in the close season after the departure of John Duncan - there had even been rumours of a Nigel/Brian Clough double act - but he has been inspirational. He has brought in half a dozen new faces and the side have blended immediately.

Macclesfield may have hoped that Chesterfield's 4-0 midweek defeat at Craven Cottage would have knocked them off their stride, especially when striker David Reeves limped off after nine minutes, and Richard Barker scored following a Steve Payne error.

But a Ryan Williams-inspired comeback saw Chesterfield score twice in two minutes, with a third on the stroke of half-time.

Williams, who has already scored five times this season, was first to a Beckett cross from the left and his shot cannoned in off defender Darren Tinson. Williams then raced virtually the length of the field after a quickly taken free-kick. Roger Willis knocked Williams's right-wing cross back across goal and Sean Parrish smashed it in after Tony Bullock failed to hold the ball.

Parrish scored his second after Karl Monroe had failed to block Marcus Ebdon's cross, striking sweetly past Bullock from eight yards. The contest was over after an hour, Parrish completing his hat-trick following a twice-taken penalty after Macclesfield defenders were judged to have encroached the area.

webTitle: Four-star Villa fuelled by inspirational Merson

fields.headline: Four-star Villa fuelled by inspirational Merson
fields.trailText: In-form Villa scratch players' itchy feet.
fields.body:
Slow out of the blocks, suddenly Aston Villa are flying. A comfortable win over a limp Derby County, who never looked like ending their sorry record of being the only team in the English professional leagues without a win and slumped to bottom of the Premiership, made it 10 points from their last four games for Villa and could have a clutch of seemingly disaffected players thinking again about needing to move to more ambitious clubs.

Somehow John Gregory has kept Paul Merson, Gareth Southgate and Julian Joachim onside after all have talked of leaving in the past few months and all were outstanding yesterday. It may be the trio's pro fessionalism, or a desire to put themselves in the shop window, but while Gregory holds on to them, Villa's form could prove more than a false dawn.

None is flying more than Merson, who will be doing literally just that today, having been given his manager's thanks and blessing to jet off to Florida for a week's holiday.

The inventive Merson unlocked the game by setting up Joachim's first goal before scoring a fortuitous one himself, his 100th league goal. Then, after Alan Wright had drilled home a belter and Chris Riggott pulled one back for a belatedly stirred Derby, Joachim sealed a fair scoreline.

'One or two players have shot themselves in the foot but we are a pretty tight bunch of blokes,' said Gregory. Merson, still seeking an extension to his contract, impressed with his 'desire and hunger', added Gregory; Southgate was 'a diamond, which is why I don't want him to go', while Joachim 'fell out with me, I didn't fall out with him'. Loved by some, loathed by others, the outspoken Villa manager does have a knack of getting players to produce.

Joachim got his chance only because of a thigh injury to David Ginola, who was replaced in the 19th minute. Within another 10, he had tucked Merson's through-pass past Mart Poom and Villa were up and running. They soon turned midfield dominance into goals.

Before the break, Merson emphasised the disharmony in the Derby defence when his cross drifted to the far post, with the Estonian Poom and the German Stefan Schnoor the width of the Baltic apart when it came to communication.

Derby manager Jim Smith threw on three attacking substitutes for the second half but it backfired when Villa exploited gaps further back, Steve Stone supplying Joachim for a low cross from the right, which found Wright on the edge of the penalty area. His sweet shot saw the far corner of the net bulging.

Riggott provided a spark for disparate Derby by heading home Craig Burley's corner but there was no fire. 'It's worrying,' were Smith's reported words afterwards: the Derby manager chose not to come to the press room. The concern will have increased at the way his defence allowed Joachim to weave along the left byline before clipping the ball home. It will be interesting to see who Gregory selects for the next match - Joachim or Ginola.

Villa Park is currently a building site, with the old Trinity Road stand being rebuilt, though its beautiful red-brick facade is apparently being retained. It is like the team. If old heads remain and a couple of quality players are added, it could be good when it's finished.

webTitle: Classy Tigana is heading for the top

fields.headline: Classy Tigana is heading for the top
fields.trailText: Fulham underline their class - and their coach's credentials.
fields.byline: Ian Whittell at the Reebok Stadium
fields.body:
When Fulham owner Mohamed al-Fayed approached Eric Cantona last season to inquire whether the Frenchman would be interested in bringing his esoteric skills to the coaching ranks, he could have had little idea of where the conversation would lead.

Cantona, having declined the invitation, recommended Jean Tigana for the task. Nine games and nine victories into the new season, Cantona is looking as prescient in the art of managerial appointment as he ever was on a football field.

A contest that was billed as pitting Sam Allardyce's Lancashire hotpot against Tigana's haute cuisine did not disappoint, and while promotion contests are not traditionally settled in early autumn, the manner of the success against a previously unbeaten Bolton carried with it an ominous air.

It was, admitted Allardyce, all but over after Bolton gifted the visitors a bizarre lead after 10 seconds and would have been far more emphatic but for some mediocre finishing and a brilliant display by Bolton's Finnish keeper Jussi Jaaskelainen.

'It hasn't been a problem so far, keeping the players' feet on the ground,' said Fulham midfielder-coach John Collins. 'They're a good bunch of lads, level-headed, no big dreamers. The manager wouldn't let anybody get carried away. Everybody knows we have set high standards and we've got to maintain them or there will be changes.'

One change was forced upon Tigana, a start for Portuguese striker Luis Boa Morte for injured top scorer Louis Saha, a change that would prove, directly from kick-off, the strength in depth Tigana has at his disposal.

That the goal came from a Bolton kick-off merely added to the state of shock at the Reebok Stadium as Anthony Barness's attempted clearance was charged down by Barry Hayles and set in motion a disastrous chain of events for the home team.

The ball broke kindly for Lee Clark and his mistimed shot was half blocked by Mark Fish into the path of Boa Morte who reacted ahead of defender and goalkeeper to force the ball in.

'It's difficult to say how good they are because of what we gave them,' said Allardyce. 'We gave them something they didn't expect and they took full advantage of it.'

Perhaps. But the goal undoubtedly set the pattern for an excellent performance in which Bolton struggled to come to terms with Fulham's pace and movement on the counterattack, visiting forwards frequently finding themselves goal-side of the opposition back-line.

Thankfully for the game as a competition, if not for Kevin Keegan who leads England against him in a World Cup qualifier in 10 days, Jaaskelainen was inspired.

Clark helped Maik Taylor's long throw directly into the path of the unmarked Boa Morte who lost his one-on-one confrontation with the Finn. So, too, Clark with an unopposed 15-yard drive and, as the game progressed, Fabrice Ferandez, Clark and Boa Morte, again, would all find Jaaskelainen on top of his game.

Bolton's best first-half chance came from the veteran Dean Holdsworth, a clever lob well saved, one-handed, by Taylor but, that aside, Wanderers could not make superior possession tell.

Symbolically, as if to prove the gulf in class, after almost conceding an equaliser off a scrambled long throw-in in the 84th minute, Fulham finally decided to convert one of their plethora of chances.

Yet another long throw forward by Taylor was collected by Boa Morte, who sped half the length of the field, drew a fine save from Jaaskelainen and then calmly converted the rebound.

fields.headline: Boksic is the ace
fields.trailText: Croatian's skill ends Saints' winning run.
fields.body:
On the day Glenn Hoddle hoped to celebrate signing a new contract, he found himself ruefully singing the praises of the player who ruined Southampton's bid for a fifth successive league and Worthington Cup victory.

It is no secret that Alen Boksic has been frustrated by some of the quality around him at the Riverside. But it hasn't stopped him producing gems like the opening goal which turned this match in Middlesbrough's favour. The Croation then scored a second to kill off Southampton's comeback and his touch, movement and vision was on a different level to anyone else.

'He was a class apart,' said Hoddle, whose new agreement stretches to July 2002. 'Every time he had the ball in the final third he looked dangerous. It was so disappointing for us - they had three, maybe four chances and scored from three of them. We deserved more.' Hoddle had a point. Tahar El Khalej and substitute Trond Soltvedt both hit a post. Gary Walsh, on loan from Bradford City, made spectacular saves from El Khalej and Dean Richards.

Yet Saints can only blame themselves for failing to capitalise on a stream of inviting crosses, most of them delivered by Matt Le Tissier - making his first Premiership start of the campaign.

They could have been two up before Boksic collected a 50-yard pass from Christian Karembeu, turned inside and shot inside the far upright.

Gianluca Festa made it 2-0 after Hamilton Ricard headed back a centre from Keith O'Neill, and although Marian Pahars pulled one back from a chance set up by substitute James Beattie, Middlesbrough responded immediately. O'Neill supplied again and when Paul Jones palmed out his cross, Boksic returned his header with interest.

'He is always capable of creating situations for us,' said the Middlesbrough manager, Bryan Robson. 'If we continue to be resilient at the back, we always have a chance. Maybe we had a bit of luck, but we also had chances to score more ourselves.'

Hoddle's new contract means there will be no return to the club for former manager Dave Jones, who is facing a court appearance on child abuse allegations. 'I lost the England job because of non-football related matters,' added Hoddle, 'If it wasn't me coming in, it would have been someone else. We all hope Dave gets a just deal.'

Gianluca Festa made it 2-0 after Hamilton Ricard headed back a centre from Keith O'Neill, and although Marian Pahars pulled one back from a chance set up by substitute James Beattie, Middlesbrough responded immediately. O'Neill supplied again and when Paul Jones palmed out his cross, Boksic returned his header with interest. 'He is always capable of creating situations for us,' said the Middlesbrough manager, Bryan Robson. 'If we continue to be resilient at the back, we always have a chance. Maybe we had a bit of luck, but we also had chances to score more ourselves.' Hoddle's new contract means there will be no return to the club for former manager Dave Jones, who is facing a court appearance on child abuse allegations. 'I lost the England job because of non-football related matters,' added Hoddle, 'If it wasn't me coming in, it would have been someone else. We all hope Dave gets a just deal.'

fields.headline: Addicks rescued
fields.trailText: Impressive Johansson fires warning to Keegan.
fields.body:
Jonatan Johansson warmed up for Finland's World Cup qualifier against England with another impressive performance, including his seventh goal in eight games to keep Charlton high in the table - yet his manager claims he is still not fully fit.

The Finnish striker has been a revelation since joining Charlton from Rangers for £3.75m at the start of the season, showing the goalscoring power that may well prevent them from going straight back to the First Division like they did two years ago.

His strike here, a spectacular bicycle kick three minutes from time, rescued a point for Charlton, who are flying high after successive victories over Tottenham and Newcastle. Johansson also set up Charlton's opening goal and could have had a hat-trick. He looks certain to lead the Finnish attack against England in Helsinki on Wednesday week.

Yet Alan Curbishley claimed he is still working his way back from an early season ankle injury and said: 'He's not 100 per cent fit so there is more to come from him.

'He might cause problems for England's defence if he plays up front for Finland, but he was used as a substitute on the right wing in their last game.'

That seems inconceivable with the striker in such good form. He was a threat from the fifth minute, when he forced Magnus Hedman to save at his feet, to the 87th, when he scored.

He also had a long-range shot saved by the legs of Hedman and a header cleared off the line as well as hitting the bar before Andy Hunt headed the rebound home for Charlton's first goal.

That equalised John Aloisi's opening goal for Coventry, who could have been 3-0 up by half-time. Craig Bellamy was denied twice on the break and Youssef Chippo had a blistering long-range drive tipped away by Dean Kiely before Aloisi scored in the 41st minute with a scuffed shot that slipped through the goalkeeper's fingers and trickled over the line.

Hunt equalised on the hour but Coventry regained the lead 10 minutes later when Richard Rufus handled a corner kick and Bellamy scored from the resulting penalty.

But Johansson had the last word with the goal that keeps Charlton seventh and will send a warning to Kevin Keegan and his defence for their World Cup encounter next week.
