fields.headline: A stroll for stylish Hibs
fields.trailText: Saints buried as Alex McLeish's self-confident side consolidate second place.
fields.body:
Hibs' class distinguished them from a pedestrian St Johnstone in a match that ensured that the Easter Road side will remain second top of the Premier League for at least another fortnight. They may have been assisted by the early ordering-off of home defender Jim Weir, but the goals which Franck Sauzee, David Zitelli and Russell Latapy provided were all the result of impressive play.

Even before the masterly move that brought Hibs the first of their goals and St Johnstone the alarming sight of Weir's ordering-off, the Edinburgh team had begun to appear significantly the more inventive and threatening.

The composure and intelligent distribution of Sauzee, Paul Fenwick, Gary Smith and Ulrik Laursen in defence provided a solid platform on which the Hibs midfield and attack could quickly express the belief that they were tellingly superior to the home team, an impression they confirmed on most of the occasions they pushed forward.

The passing which dealt St Johnstone the first blow in the 16th minute began, appropriately, with Sauzee and Fenwick progressing from defence with a couple of expertly executed one-twos, ending with the ball being played forward to John O'Neil.

As the midfielder touched the sideways pass to Latapy, Mixu Paatelainen began his run through the heart of the home defence. Latapy's through-pass, played first time, was impeccable, allowing the Finnish striker to clear Weir and leave him with only Alan Main to beat.

In his desperation, Weir took Paatelainen from behind, an offence that seemed certain to be rewarded with a penalty. Referee Hugh Dallas, after a look at his lineman, ordered a free-kick just outside the area, a decision which was confirmed as correct by television pictures. Weir was shown the red card as he was carried off the field, having injured himself in his lunge.

It was the second time in three weeks the defender had committed the same crime, the first against Robbie Winters of Aberdeen on 9 September. He was punished twice on this occasion when Sauzee's low, powerful free-kick with his right foot was deflected by the defensive wall to the left of Main.

Zitelli's terrific finish just seven minutes later brought Hibs the two-goal lead which was the least they deserved and gave the Frenchman his first goal for the club since signing from Strasbourg six weeks ago. Nick Colgan's long punt was headed down by John O'Neil to Latapy, who adeptly played the ball into the path of Zitelli.

The striker waited until the advancing, flapping Main was well out of his goal before flicking the ball, left-footed, over him from the edge of the box.

With the game effectively over as a contest, Hibs spent much of the second half evincing a nonchalance which not only took the combative edge off their own play, but encouraged St Johnstone to believe they could yet produce an unlikely comeback.

During this period, Nick Colgan had to be alert to complete an excellent save from a ferocious low volley from Nick Dasovic and was then relieved to watch another low drive, this time from Craig Russell, slide marginally wide of his left-hand post.

But Latapy had yet to produce the moment of virtuosity which would bring the match another exceptional goal. The midfielder took possession from his fellow Trinidadian, substitute Lyndon Andrews, and began weaving his way through defenders until he was was just inside the area.

From there he hit the ball with the outside of his left foot low to the left of Main, the kind of execution which would tempt even the home supporters to put their hands together. With that, another satisfying shift for Hibs was brought to a close.

fields.headline: Wenger ready for shaken Reds
fields.standfirst: Gunners' coach says the time is right
fields.trailText: Gunners' coach says the time is right, writes Ian Ridley
fields.body:
It is one of the fiercest rivalries in the English game and the pair have given us some memorable spats and exchanges in the past few years. Today in the lovely old-fashioned parlance of preview, they renew acquaintance at Highbury. Yes, Arsène Wenger v Sir Alex Ferguson promises to be quite a contest again.

Actually, both managers are astute at the verbal jousting they have indulged in since Wenger arrived with intent four years ago, showing that he was not overawed by reputations nor about to be bullied. His strong words, softly spoken, left Ferguson questioning who this man breezing in from abroad was to talk about the ills of our game.

'He wants to protect his team and I want to protect my team,' says Wenger. It is one of the arts of management; those truly secure in their personality and abilities take the heat themselves and divert the attention from their players to leave them free to concern themselves only with such a significant game.

As Wenger adds: 'He is not stupid and I am not. We know it is much more important what Bergkamp and Giggs and Beckham will do.' If selected, of course. Who knows these days? Not even Wenger, it seems. 'The managers will not be playing at 4pm today - although I'd like it if he [Ferguson] played. Maybe we could play one against one after the game.'

A match that sees the endearing, reliable runabout that is the Premiership back at the front of the showroom after three weeks behind the sports cars of the Champions League, with Chelsea also playing Liverpool at Stamford Bridge, has poke beyond anything the managers need to fuel.

Midweek events have seen to that, with Wenger pulling a masterstroke against Lazio by deputing Dennis Bergkamp to create from a less cluttered right flank and Ferguson losing his gamble on fielding a weakened team in Eindhoven to keep powder dry for today. And what a turnaround that is, the Premiership taking precedence for United.

That first defeat of the season may have sown doubts for a seemingly invincible United, making it a good time to play them, though Wenger believes it will be a different team with a different mentality today. 'Manchester United are always able to create problems for you with their striking force if you are not stable defensively,' he notes.

'We need to be dominant at home because that was one of the gaps that existed between Manchester United and us last season. We were in the lead at home with 10 minutes to go and we lost the game. That was unforgivable.'

Yet even with David Beckham and Ryan Giggs back to add dynamism to the flanks, United have looked unusually vulnerable in the past week, conceding six goals, Ferguson stubbornly preferring Raimond van der Gouw to the superior, but persona non grata, Mark Bosnich.

Fabien Barthez may be hurried back from injury as a result but it is the longer-term absence of Jaap Stam that could be prompting their first mini-crisis of confidence. 'Stam is a very influential player,' says Wenger. 'I will not say I am unhappy that he doesn't play.'

Perhaps due to the absence of such a commanding figure, the shortcomings of United's other defenders have been exposed. Mikael Silvestre has appeared a weak link while Phil Neville's confidence looks low, suggesting he may not have fully recovered from England's Euro 2000 traumas against Romania.

If Ferguson persists with Gary Neville in central defence, Arsenal would be well-advised to employ some high crosses, though it is an under-used part of their game. More often, as is the way with the more sophisticated of European players, they prefer to pass the ball from wide into the penalty box rather than sling it in. It could be a day for Ray Parlour and his energetic virtues to return to the right flank.

The good news for United may be that Arsenal's strikers are not converting a high percentage of the chances created for them, the number of strikes on goal - and unsuccessful ones - being the highest in the Premiership. 'It's true. It's one of our problems at the moment,' says Wenger. 'That is why I put Dennis and Kanu together against Lazio because I felt I needed more efficiency in the last 25 yards. The service needed to be more accurate.'

The bad news is that Arsenal are beginning to resemble United in their ability to score goals from other positions, with Silvinho, Martin Keown and Freddie Ljungberg all contributing recently. It could be down to Kanu and Thierry Henry to attract defensive attention, creating space for others.

'I am sure Thierry will come back and score goals,' says Wenger. 'I just don't want it to be an obsession for him. At the moment, he plays like he is not happy when he doesn't score. He shouldn't put so much pressure on himself but just try to play a normal game.'

All over the pitch there will confrontations to relish; Andy Cole v Tony Adams, Beckham v Silvinho for example. The pity is that it will not also be Roy Keane v Patrick Vieira, who remains suspended, and Stam v Henry. Still. 'We have an inner confidence to play them, they are top of the league, so both teams are in good position to play an exciting game,' says Wenger.

For all that, it wouldn't be the same without some off-the-field comments from one manager to another, who may appear very different characters but share, according to Wenger, 'motivation, the love to win the game'. He questions how Ferguson will adapt to the retirement he is planning in some 18 months' time.

'It'll be difficult for him to stop because it is an addiction,' says Wenger, even if Sir Alex's second love, racing, may occupy him. 'Just imagine the guy sitting at home, Saturday afternoon at 3pm. That's why I'm scared as well. It can help if you have another passion. I don't. That's my problem. I need to buy some horses.' We will see today which trainer has the most thoroughbreds.

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: Latest transfer gossip from the tabloids and a club-by-club rumour-mill update.
fields.body:
Hand of God: Diego not sure

Diego Maradona says his new autobiography - launched last week - is his chance to 'tell the truth' - but he's still having trouble rationalising his 1986 'hand of God' goal against England.

Speaking in Buenos Aires on Thursday, Maradona talked up the book's veracity: 'I am the people's Diego. This is my chance to tell the world the truth, and to answer the doubts that people have about me.' Nevertheless, he maintains he's no idea exactly how the ball beat Peter Shilton in Mexico. 'I don't know,' he writes. 'I raised my left fist and moved my head backwards. Shilton had no idea what was happening and it was Fenwick who was the first to call for a hand ball.'

Maradona describes how he saw the linesman run back towards the halfway line and realised the goal had been given - then explains how his team-mate Jorge Valdano, now sporting director at Real Madrid, told him to keep quiet. 'All the English were protesting to the referee and Valdano, who had passed me the ball, put his finger to his mouth, saying "ssshhh" as if he were a nurse in a hospital. Anyway, who am I to doubt the honesty of the referee.'

I am Diego - 314 pages - will be translated into 30 languages and sold in 80 countries, and comes with the Maradona guarantee: 'Everything I recount in the book is true. I swear that on the lives of my daughters.'

Machete murder after Arsenal riot

Two football hooligans wearing Arsenal shirts hacked a Spaniard to death with a machete before throwing his body on to a busy Paris ring road, causing a multiple pile-up. The attack - which police believe may have been carried out by Chelsea fans in disguise - was witnessed by a lone, armed riot squad officer after the Arsenal-Real Zaragoza Cup Winners' Cup Final in Paris in 1995. The officer caught one of the attackers, handcuffing him to a roadsign, before giving chase to the other, who escaped across the courts of the Roland Garros tennis complex and then into a stable inside the grounds of an Asian embassy. When the murderer lashed out with his machete inside the stables he missed the policeman and sliced into the rear of a horse, which kicked him unconscious.

If you haven't heard any of this before, you haven't read the French thriller Blood-Red Rivers , now out in paperback in English. Not only is it wildly OTT in describing the antics of English football fans, it moves the European final from May to October. Still, it's only the first chapter, the rest of the book is fine. (Published by Harvill Panther, £5.99.)

Pub quiz: important stuff

Was it the longest pass in football? Ipswich v Millwall last week, Worthington Cup, Jamie Clapham to Matt Holland - 221 miles, points out a geographically minded reader. But is he right? At Aston Villa, a Gareth Southgate ball to Dion Dublin beats the Ipswich sliderule by 70 miles, and both beat QPR's sad 79 miles from Jermaine Darlington to Clarke Carlisle. But all these are stumped by succession of impressive Nationwide League international long balls: Bristol City's Andrew Jordan to Louis Carey (Herefordshire) 2,395 miles; Crystal Palace's Dean Austin (Texas) to Wayne Carlisle 4,643 miles; and Bolton's long-ball specialist Simon Charlton ballooning one 6,679 miles to Franck Passi in the Philippines. Overall winners so far though remains Ipswich - Jamie Clapham to Mark Venus, 25 million miles. If there's any longer pass in current professional football (Piazza's classic ball in the 1970 World Cup to Pele (Brazil legend or volcanic satallite of Jupiter) at 390m miles doesn't count, let us know. It's important.

Quote of the week

David Beckham, talking to OK! magazine. 'I definitely want Brooklyn to be christened... but I don't know into what religion yet.'

Tales from the Tabs

COLLY: WHO WANTS ME Stan Collymore says he could be driven out of football by Peter Taylor's accusations that he is greedy and overweight. 'All these untruths are coming out. Cheap shots. All I want to do is play - I'm fit and bursting to play. But who will buy me now?' Bradford, Celtic, Palace and Brentford could step in.

BLUES SPLASH CASH Already under-pressure Chelsea boss Claudio Ranieri has been told to spend big to prevent a repeat of last week's St Gallen disaster. 'We have funds available,' says Colin Hutchison. 'It's well-known that we want a wide-left player - now we need to replace Roberto Di Matteo too.'

Arsenal could move to hijack Leeds' new bid for Monaco's John Arne Riise: Riise's agent-mother says he's desperate to move to England: 'John Arne wants to play football,' says Mrs Riise. 'I hope they will lower the valuation a bit. He is a good boy, but he is not worth £6m'. Arsene Wenger is also keen on Shakhtar Donetsk keeper Yuri Virt.

John Gregory is closing on Cagliari's Honduran international David Suazo as he looks for a new Aston Villa striker.

Geoffrey Richmond has closed Chris Hutching's Bradford chequebook: 'We are not looking to sign anyone'.

David Pleat has slammed Charlton for demanding £445,000 for youngster Owen Price: Spurs have offered £4,000.

Barcelona have offered Claudio Ranieiri the chance to sign outcast Emmanuel Petit.

Coventry are set to bid for Sheffield Wednesday's Wim Jonk.

Derby youngster Chris Riggott says he can't believe his England U21 call-up: 'It's been a mad week'.

Everton are close to finalising a £25m deal with ntl - part of the cash will go to Walter Smith.

Ipswich are set to sign Bruges midfielder Gert Verheyen, and have handed Titus Bramble a 5-year £10,000-a-week deal.

Leeds are considering a new £6m offer for John Arne Riise.

Leicester have blasted Red Star for the racist abuse endured by Ade Akinbiyi and Andrew Impey. &

Liverpool are watching American Olympic striker Josh Wolff.

Richard Jobson won't be leaving Manchester City : 'It's great to be back in the City team. I'm in no rush to leave.'

Manchester United - looking again at Inter's Ronaldo and young Slovakian internationl Szilard Nemeth of Inter Bratislava - have offered £250,000 for Shelbourne striker Richie Foran - West Ham are also keen.

Middlesbrough are ready to splash £3m on Cameroon defender Lucien Mettomo - rejected by Blackburn on medical grounds.

Bobby Robson is considering making a £5m Newcastle offer for Tottenham's Sol Campbell to beat the summer rush.

Southampton boss Glenn Hoddle has signed a new 2 year deal.

Sunderland are chasing Espanyol wing-back Mauro Esteban Navas.

Tottenham are ready to move for Villa's Ugo Ehiogu after Middlesbrough refused to up their £8m bid.

West Ham's Steve Lomas has rejected a move to Bradford: 'I'm happy here - it's all just rumours and hype.'

If you haven't heard any of this before, you haven't read the French thriller Blood-Red Rivers , now out in paperback in English. Not only is it wildly OTT in describing the antics of English football fans, it moves the European final from May to October. Still, it's only the first chapter, the rest of the book is fine. (Published by Harvill Panther, £5.99.) Pub quiz: important stuff Was it the longest pass in football? Ipswich v Millwall last week, Worthington Cup, Jamie Clapham to Matt Holland - 221 miles, points out a geographically minded reader. But is he right? At Aston Villa, a Gareth Southgate ball to Dion Dublin beats the Ipswich sliderule by 70 miles, and both beat QPR's sad 79 miles from Jermaine Darlington to Clarke Carlisle. But all these are stumped by succession of impressive Nationwide League international long balls: Bristol City's Andrew Jordan to Louis Carey (Herefordshire) 2,395 miles; Crystal Palace's Dean Austin (Texas) to Wayne Carlisle 4,643 miles; and Bolton's long-ball specialist Simon Charlton ballooning one 6,679 miles to Franck Passi in the Philippines. Overall winners so far though remains Ipswich - Jamie Clapham to Mark Venus, 25 million miles. If there's any longer pass in current professional football (Piazza's classic ball in the 1970 World Cup to Pele (Brazil legend or volcanic satallite of Jupiter) at 390m miles doesn't count, let us know. It's important. Quote of the week David Beckham, talking to OK! magazine. 'I definitely want Brooklyn to be christened... but I don't know into what religion yet.' Tales from the Tabs COLLY: WHO WANTS ME Stan Collymore says he could be driven out of football by Peter Taylor's accusations that he is greedy and overweight. 'All these untruths are coming out. Cheap shots. All I want to do is play - I'm fit and bursting to play. But who will buy me now?' Bradford, Celtic, Palace and Brentford could step in. BLUES SPLASH CASH Already under-pressure Chelsea boss Claudio Ranieri has been told to spend big to prevent a repeat of last week's St Gallen disaster. 'We have funds available,' says Colin Hutchison. 'It's well-known that we want a wide-left player - now we need to replace Roberto Di Matteo too.' Arsenal could move to hijack Leeds' new bid for Monaco's John Arne Riise: Riise's agent-mother says he's desperate to move to England: 'John Arne wants to play football,' says Mrs Riise. 'I hope they will lower the valuation a bit. He is a good boy, but he is not worth £6m'. Arsene Wenger is also keen on Shakhtar Donetsk keeper Yuri Virt. John Gregory is closing on Cagliari's Honduran international David Suazo as he looks for a new Aston Villa striker. Geoffrey Richmond has closed Chris Hutching's Bradford chequebook: 'We are not looking to sign anyone'. David Pleat has slammed Charlton for demanding £445,000 for youngster Owen Price: Spurs have offered £4,000. Barcelona have offered Claudio Ranieiri the chance to sign outcast Emmanuel Petit. Coventry are set to bid for Sheffield Wednesday's Wim Jonk. Derby youngster Chris Riggott says he can't believe his England U21 call-up: 'It's been a mad week'. Everton are close to finalising a £25m deal with ntl - part of the cash will go to Walter Smith. Ipswich are set to sign Bruges midfielder Gert Verheyen, and have handed Titus Bramble a 5-year £10,000-a-week deal. Leeds are considering a new £6m offer for John Arne Riise. Leicester have blasted Red Star for the racist abuse endured by Ade Akinbiyi and Andrew Impey. & Liverpool are watching American Olympic striker Josh Wolff. Richard Jobson won't be leaving Manchester City : 'It's great to be back in the City team. I'm in no rush to leave.' Manchester United - looking again at Inter's Ronaldo and young Slovakian internationl Szilard Nemeth of Inter Bratislava - have offered £250,000 for Shelbourne striker Richie Foran - West Ham are also keen. Middlesbrough are ready to splash £3m on Cameroon defender Lucien Mettomo - rejected by Blackburn on medical grounds. Bobby Robson is considering making a £5m Newcastle offer for Tottenham's Sol Campbell to beat the summer rush. Southampton boss Glenn Hoddle has signed a new 2 year deal. Sunderland are chasing Espanyol wing-back Mauro Esteban Navas. Tottenham are ready to move for Villa's Ugo Ehiogu after Middlesbrough refused to up their £8m bid. West Ham's Steve Lomas has rejected a move to Bradford: 'I'm happy here - it's all just rumours and hype.'

webTitle: Hamann sees the danger...  as England roar back

fields.headline: Hamann sees the danger...  as England roar back
fields.standfirst: The England-based Germans are aiming to reverse their summer fortunes at Wembley
fields.trailText: The England-based Germans are aiming to reverse their summer fortunes at Wembley, reports Paul Wilson.
fields.body:
Way back in the Seventies, when footballers had frizzy perms and dreamed of landing a contract to advertise aftershave with Henry Cooper, Germany was considered the place to go to broaden your experience if, like Kevin Keegan, you had won everything possible with Liverpool.

Things have changed a bit over the past couple of decades. No one leaves to play in the Bundesliga any more, while the Liverpool team now contains no fewer than three members of Germany's Euro 2000 side in Dietmar Hamann, Christian Ziege and Markus Babbel. Liverpool players no longer complain of feeling sated by domestic success either - Everton's isolated FA Cup triumph of 1995 was the last occasion a Merseyside team won anything. And perhaps the biggest turnaround of all for football fans of a certain age came in Charleroi in June when England beat Germany in a competitive game for the first time since 1966, although recalling the dismal fare produced by both sides in that match, one would not care to argue that the era of English superiority will last half as long.

The next instalment of this atavistic rivalry takes place at Wembley on Saturday, when Keegan's England don red shirts once more to summon up the spirit of '66 for the last international under the twin towers. Hamann, the first of the present trio to wear the red shirt of Liverpool, is looking forward to the game immensely. 'I didn't particularly enjoy being in the first German side to lose to England for 34 years,' he said. 'None of us did. Obviously the record was not going to last forever, but we feel there is some pride to win back. Not just against England, but because our whole Euro 2000 was so disappointing. We are now making a fresh start under Rudi Völler, and have a couple of wins behind us. I would not say we have turned it round just yet, but we have changed a few things and the outlook is more promising. The confidence is coming back, and confidence is so important.'

If this sounds ominous, bear in mind that you could say exactly the same things about England, and Michael Owen in particular. Keegan might have needed the bluntest of hints from Alan Shearer - 'I don't want to play any more' - to review his options in attack, but there were distinct signs in the last game in Paris that England's pace and passing could pose a few more problems for the Germans at Wembley than they managed in Charleroi. As Hamann knows only too well. 'I understand how Michael felt at being a substitute for the France game, but the manager was only being sensible and checking his other attacking options,' he said. 'England are lucky to have so many forwards fighting for a place. It's a bonus if you have Andy Cole and Kevin Phillips as well as Emile Heskey, Michael Owen and Robbie Fowler. That match was a friendly, though I am sure Michael will start the game at Wembley. England will have to pick him, he's on fire at the moment.'

Responsible for starting the Steven Gerrard for England campaign this time last year - with his remark that such a talented midfielder would already be playing for his country were he German - Hamann confirms that Owen is one of the most respected England players in Germany, and along with David Beckham, probably the best known. 'Those two made big reputations for themselves in France 98,' he said. 'People still remember what they did in the game against Argentina. Like us, they might have had a Euro 2000 they want to forget, but everybody knows what they are capable of.'

Hamann played in all three of Germany's games at the European Championships, and the experience is certainly one he wants to forget. 'We knew we weren't playing well right from the start,' he said. 'The draw with Romania was disappointing, we should have done better, but we were not able to put things right on the pitch.' Asked whether it was more calamitous losing 1-0 to England or 3-0 to Portugal's reserves, he smiles and shakes his head. 'The England game was the worst we played,' he said. 'The Portugal game was strange, we were all over them in the first half and could have been two goals up, but by half time we knew that we would have to score at least three goals to go through, based on the fact that England were winning 2-1. At that time we had only managed a single goal in the whole competition, so we knew we would not be able to do it. The final result tells its own story.'

Unlike his two former Bayern Munich team-mates, now reunited at Liverpool, Hamann did not figure in Germany's victory in Euro 96, so his international experience chiefly revolves around the let-downs of 1998 and 2000. He was capped at a relatively early age and had already decided to leave the German league before the last World Cup, a victim of the notorious star syndrome at Bayern. 'I had been at Bayern since I was 16, I grew up at that club, but even when I became a regular international I was always viewed as the apprentice,' he said. 'At the age of 24 I had the feeling I could not go any further forward at Bayern. It was not the coaches' fault, I had no problem with Beckenbauer or Trapattoni, and it wasn't that I couldn't get into the team. I played regularly, but I never felt I got the attention or respect I deserved from the official side of the club, and when anything went wrong I always seemed to be the victim. I just wasn't going anywhere and I felt I needed to improve, so when an offer came in I decided to come to England.'

That explains how, after weighing up his career options, Hamann ended up at Newcastle United. Kenny Dalglish was sacked two weeks into his first season and Ruud Gullit arrived with a batch of new players and a sheaf of off-the-wall ideas, not all of which involved Hamann. 'These things happen in football,' he shrugged, alluding to what must have been a difficult and uncertain 12 months which ended improbably and painfully with the limpest of FA Cup final defeats. 'It's funny, but all my friends told me I must not go to Newcastle, that I wouldn't like it there, but that just made me all the more determined to go.

'I wanted to form my own impressions. The reason people told me I was making a mistake was because of the area, they said it was remote and unsophisticated, but I never had any problems on that front. I took my wife to show her, she liked it, and we were perfectly happy. I had a great year there, even if the move did not work out quite as I hoped from a football point of view.'

Hamann is much happier with his latest move. 'This is definitely a more ambitious club,' he said. And with his current form. 'For the first time in three years I got in a proper pre-season, free from injury, and I'm feeling the benefit,' he explained.

'I felt I had a few good games last season, but I wasn't consistent enough.' Nor has he been disappointed with English football in general. 'Standards at the top in the Bundesliga are very high, but if you look at the whole league I think the Premiership is stronger, as well as being more exciting and interesting,' he said. 'A couple of weeks ago we played against Manchester City, a newly promoted side, and they brought on George Weah for the last half hour. He scored too, as you might expect of a former World Player of the Year. That sort of thing would never happen in the Bundesliga, never in a million years. Of course in any league there are strong teams and weak teams, rich clubs and poor ones, but there's a lot of unpredictability in the Premiership.

'You can't look at many games and be certain what is going to happen, in fact unusual things happen all the time, which makes it entertaining. Everyone feels they have a chance, unless they happen to be playing Manchester United. They are not so unpredictable ... they just win all their games.'

webTitle: Brown takes route one to San Marino

fields.headline: Brown takes route one to San Marino
fields.trailText: Scotland prepare to embark on two wildly different expeditions.
fields.body:
Scotland's World Cup hopefuls embark on an expedition at the end of this week in which they are faced with two peaks of such variance that it will seem like practising on the molehill a few days before tackling the mountain.

The taking of San Marino on Saturday is the first objective, with Croatia in Zagreb the following Wednesday by a considerable distance the more hazardous of the assignments. While victory in the opening match of the double-header may appear a formality, the visit to the independent enclave in north-east Italy could have a significant bearing on the Scots' prospects of success (ie avoiding defeat) in the more formidable task which ensues.

When Craig Brown named a 26-man squad on Friday, it was indicative of his need to perfect a juggling and balancing act at the Serravalle. It will give his players proper preparation for a meeting in the Maksimir Stadium, which could have a telling impact on Scotland's chances of winning Group 6 and earning automatic entry to the finals in Japan and Korea in 2002.

The national team manager revealed that the team which faces San Marino will not be the one which plays against Croatia, recognising that the first operation will present an opportunity to give certain players some needed match practice and others a therapeutic break from what has already been a taxing two months of football with their clubs and their country at home and abroad.

Brown is not in the business of dismissing opponents out of hand, not even a team who have never won a match and who scored only one goal in their eight defeats in the qualifying series for Euro 2000. San Marino's most celebrated claim to fame remains the goal they scored after eight seconds against England in 1993, the fastest ever recorded in an international, but one which merely presaged a 7-1 thrashing.

'We wouldn't dream of taking anybody too lightly,' he said, 'but we do have to see the first match as a means of not only securing three points to keep ourselves at the top of the group, but of giving our players precisely the preparation which will be of most benefit for the hard night we can expect in Zagreb.

'That's why I can tell you now that it won't be the same team that plays both matches. The first game will be good to get some players who have not been regulars with their clubs match practice. We have a few like that, including Colin Hendry, Kevin Gallacher, Paul Ritchie and, to a lesser extent, Billy Dodds and Neil McCann.

'It's an ideal opportunity for us to allow key players to be given perhaps just part of a game to keep them ticking over, or, in maybe one or two cases, to be rested altogether. Paul Lambert of Celtic and Barry Ferguson of Rangers are good examples of players who have been on the go all the time since the start of the season.

'That does not mean we'll be inclining towards complacency. Whenever we approach a game like this, I use as my model the day the Republic of Ireland under Jack Charlton went to Lichtenstein and drew 0-0. At the time, it was unimaginable and even now, a few years on, it seems unbelievable. This was an Irish team who were practically invincible and in the care of one of the game's great motivators.

'They hit the woodwork five times and had 19 scoring opportunities in the match. But that one slip cost them a place at Euro 96. I'll be reminding our players of that during the build-up.'

Brown, in fact, has reminders closer to home, the Scots having won rather shakily by 2-0 on each of their last two visits to the grandly-styled Stadio Olimpico at Serravalle. In 1991, when Brown was assistant to Andy Roxburgh, they required a 63rd- minute penalty from Gordon Strachan and a goal from Gordon Durie three minutes later to prevent a calamity.

Four years later, in a Euro 96 qualifier, they were vulnerably ahead by a John Collins goal until three minutes from the end, when the unlikely figure of Colin Calderwood produced the second, which finally ended the anxiety.

More than simply looking after his players' fitness, however, Brown revealed that he is likely to instruct them to depart from their normal style of play against the San Marinese, adopting a policy of playing the ball quickly, often and without fuss into the heart of the home defence with a view to forcing the opposition into errors.

'The difficulty with a team like San Marino is the number of bodies they'll put between us and their goal, getting the ball through the forest of legs. We've always been reluctant to take Route One because you can't beat good defenders with that. But against lesser, inexperienced defenders, it can put them under pressure and they can suffer from that.

'Our preferred option to pass, pass, pass could be difficult. We would like to discomfort them by getting the ball in among them regularly and getting them to make mistakes. We would expect to spend a lot of time in their first third of the field and that should bring about a lot of set pieces - we have people who can take advantage of that.'

The towering Matt Elliott is unlikely to be deployed in attack, as he was in the Scots' fortunate victory over Latvia in the opening match, which took them to the top of the group. But, given the regularity with which Brown expects to win free-kicks and corners, it may be assumed he will feature regularly in the home penalty area.

As for Croatia, who began their campaign with a draw against Belgium in Brussels, any search at Serravalle for clues to the Scots' personnel and formation in Zagreb is likely to yield irrelevant intelligence.

fields.headline: Battered Chelsea ask: Que?
fields.trailText: Chelsea v Liverpool preview: Blues bemused... it's just like Fawlty Towers
fields.body:
Consistently inconsistent. It's Chelsea's infuriating fickleness that really got to Claudio Ranieri in the wake of his first experience of the ups and downs of life at the Bridge. Ticking off his players in the dressing room in Zurich, he got straight to the point: 'I don't like a team who plays really well on Sunday and really badly on Thursday.' Subdued, humbled, and dumped out of Europe by the previously unheralded but now infamous might of St Gallen, his players returned to their hotel, ate quietly and slunk off to their rooms with a lot on their minds. 'A few people didn't sleep much,' admitted goalkeeper Carlo Cudicini, 'and the next morning everyone had a bad face.'

Later, back at Heathrow there was no luxury coach to whisk these multimillion-pound underachievers back to their cars at the training ground. Just a cramped minibus more suitable for schoolboys, and they leapt out and straight on to the pitch to try to kick the errors out of their game. It was no less than they deserved, explained Cudicini. 'It's difficult to accept because it was the first round against an average team. They deserved it, they hurt us a lot on the counter attack. Now we are here to cry.'

Ranieri cannot afford to tolerate self-pity. One week and two bizarre results into his reign, it's difficult to fathom quite where Chelsea are headed. On the day he was appointed, a season-ticket holder in the Matthew Harding stand, pondered the future and reckoned that in a year's time his club will have turned into either AC Milan or Norwich.

Emotions at Stamford Bridge lurch between wild ambition and bitter fear of failure. Ranieri's Chelsea have been kicked in the stomach by Leicester, then they picked themselves up in fine style against Manchester United, only to be slapped around the chops by the Swiss. A dose of equilibrium at the Bridge would go down very well indeed. Every newly installed manager needs some breathing space, not the suffocating expectation of overnight miracles. Feel the irony: Chelsea, Johnny-come-latelys to English football's upper echelons, are more impatient than today's opponents Liverpool, whose trophy-laden heritage casts a shadow over every barren season.

The Anfield board's unstinting faith in Gérard Houllier is, the Frenchman feels, close to bearing fruit. It has taken him two seasons and more than £50 million-worth of signings to assemble a squad he believes is capable of unlocking a door marked Champions League. Who would have thought, when the European Cup was given its glitzy makeover a decade ago, that Liverpool, England's standard bearers in continental competition, would be outcasts for all this time.

Patchy early season form suggests they are still off the pace, but Houllier, welcoming a series of key players back from injury, is convinced the current Liverpool incarnation is on the verge of clicking. The return of Sami Hyypia means Markus Babbel can move over to right back to provide what promises to be a fine counterbalance to newcomer Christian Ziege on the left side of defence. Further forward, now that Robbie Fowler has completed 90 minutes for the first time in over a year, we might at last see what sparks can fly when he links up with Michael Owen.

Ranieri could have had a gentler home debut than a collision against another team with big ideas and pretensions to prove. He has to lift players with shattered confidence who haven't won since the opening day of the season. Cudicini admits morale is low: 'Amongst the players we are asking "What's happening?" A few things are wrong - if it was just one it would be easier to come out of this situation. The only thing we can do is work really hard, think about Chelsea and try to do our best. All the team has to give everything on the pitch today because if we don't start to win games in the Premiership it's going to be difficult. We have to win some games in a row to find a rhythm and some confidence. Sooner or later we have to come out of this.'

A two-week international break is well- timed for Chelsea, giving Ranieri some time to drum in his ideas and get to grips with his enigmatic club. The language barrier is not helpful. Life appears to be a little confusing down on the fields of Harlington. Consider the simple matter of a training drill for goalkeepers: Last week Eddie Niedzwiecki, who coached the number ones under Gianluca Vialli, asked Ranieri's man if he wanted to take the session. The response - ' Que? ' - was pure Mañuel from Fawlty Towers . After Ray Wilkins stepped in as interpreter, Niedzwiecki carried on while the new man stood behind the goal and observed. Not a terribly settling scenario for all concerned.

'He wants the team to play with his methods and I think he's a very good coach, but it's difficult for him to explain his ideas well,' says Cudicini. 'Maybe in a month or two he is going to be better. At the moment it's tough, but Ray, and the Italian players like Zola, Robbie Di Matteo and I translate for him. It will help when he speaks the language.'

The fundamental message, that Chelsea have to buck up their ideas fast, requires no translation.

fields.headline: Let's go!
fields.standfirst: Ten things to do today
fields.trailText: Ten things to do today.
fields.body:
Norfolk humourist Sid Kipper's East Side Story explores England's 'middle east' as part of the Norfolk Festival. Maddermarket Theatre, Norwich, 7.30pm. Adults £7, concs. £5 (01603 620917)

The fourth London Triathlon takes place at Albert Dock. Participating is Olympic competitor Simon Lessing, who has won the race for the past three years. Races are from 7.15am-2.30pm. Free for spectators (020 7928 5055).

Come along to the West Lancashire Light Railway in Preston for a gala event celebrating the role of steam trains in different industries. Industrial Day will display freight trains and diesel and steam locomotives, free guided tour of workshops for adults. 11am-4.30pm. Adults £1.75, children 75p (01772 815881)

Last chance to see the surrealist paintings of Salvador Dali at the Dean Gallery in Edinburgh. 'Optical Illusions' displays more than 50 of his works. This is the only European showing of this exhibition, which focuses on Dali's exploration of optics and perception. Open 12am-5pm. Adults £4, concs. £3 (0131 624 6200)

Make your way to London's Kew Gardens to see an exhibition of more than 60 sculptures from Zimbabwe. The organisers claim it is the largest contemporary African art collection that Britain has seen. 9.30am-6pm. Adults £5, concs. £3.50. (020 8940 1171)

Take part in a wine-tasting event in the grounds of Ickworth House, Suffolk. The late eighteenth-century mansion near Bury St Edmunds boasts a collection of paintings including the work of Velasquez, Titian and Gainsborough as well as extensive gardens. 11am-4pm. Adults £4.90. (01284 735270)

Get your kitten heels down to the Natural History Museum for the last day of London Fashion Weekend . hairstyling is available from sponsors VS Sassoon as well as fashion and beauty seminars. 11am-5pm. Tickets £7.50. (020 7413 1700)

Book lovers and youngsters will enjoy this Word for Children event which is part of the annual Word festival. The event, which is held at the Polka Theatre in Wimbledon, hosts an impressive line-up of literary talents including Lynne Reid Banks and Quentin Blake. 10.30am-5pm. Tickets £3 (020 8543 4888)

A family day at Cotswold Farm Park, Gloucestershire, where children can bottle-feed pet lambs, watch goat-milking demonstrations, take safari rides around the park and learn about nature, conservation and farm life. 10.30am-6pm. Adults £4.50; children £2.30. (01451 850307)

Explore the restored eighteenth-century glasshouses designed by Sir John Soane at Wimpole Hall, Cambridgeshire. Built in 1794 to grow pineapples and vines, they have recently been reopened after restoration. 10.30am-5. Adults £2.50; children free (01223 207257)

webTitle: Germany and England could put on a show worthy of their fine rivalry

fields.headline: Germany and England could put on a show worthy of their fine rivalry
fields.trailText: With disastrous Euro 2000 campaigns behind them and bolstered by encouraging results in friendly matches, England and Germany will both look for a new dawn at Wembley.
fields.body:
It says much for the resilience and optimism of football supporters in both countries that England's World Cup qualifier against Germany is being eagerly looked forward to, only a matter of months since two behemoths bereft of ideas or inspiration provided one of the most forgettable encounters in Euro 2000.

Obviously there is too much history between these two nations for any meeting to pass by quietly, but the general consensus after Charleroi in June was that both England and Germany had lost their way so badly, it might be years before either was ready to be re-admitted to sophisticated European society.

It might be worth remembering that, when hype and nationalistic fervour switches from the Olympics to the last ever football international at Wembley this week. England and Germany have both recovered confidence in a remarkably short space of time to the extent we can now contemplate a match on Saturday which might live up to the tradition of intense rivalry between the two sides, but both nations are still a long way short of the standards set by the best teams in Euro 2000 in terms of player production and technical ability.

Kevin Keegan and Rudi Völler might not see it quite like that, pointing to England's 1-1 draw in the Stade de France last month and Germany's emphatic 4-1 defeat of Spain in an earlier friendly. Keegan himself has questioned the validity of the latter result, however, pointing out that the game was played before the Spanish season had even started and, without wanting to detract from England's hugely encouraging performance in earning a draw in Paris, they could easily have been two or three goals down by the time Michael Owen came on had David Trezeguet and Co finished with their normal accuracy when the home side enjoyed a period of second-half dominance.

Friendlies are unreliable guides to form in any case, although the Germans did confirm an improvement by beating Greece in their opening qualifier, but the most positive effect they have provided for England and Germany has been in drawing a line under the doom and gloom of Euro 2000 and announcing a fresh start. 'Everybody knew that Germany and England could play better than we did in the summer,' Voller said. 'The whole atmosphere around our squad was wrong, but in two games we have changed that. If you get the right results you get a different atmosphere.'

England can confirm that - their late equaliser in Paris having broken a run of disappointing results and earned Keegan some breathing space. Whether he deserves it is a moot point, since he only brought Owen on for the last 15 minutes and by his own admission would still be persisting with Alan Shearer had not the Newcastle captain withdrawn his services, but either through accident or design Keegan is now recognising the youth potential at his disposal and for that he is to be applauded.

This is a manager, remember, who only a couple of months ago was talking as though the next West Ham player to be called up would be Stuart Pearce, not Joe Cole. Having gambled in vain on his old guard in Euro 2000 Keegan caused consternation by claiming World Cup qualifying matches were too important for experimentation with young players, making a few of us wonder when youth would ever be given its chance, but those fears have been allayed by a squad which includes Cole, Rio Ferdinand, Jamie Carragher, Steven Gerrard and Kieron Dyer and boasts David Beckham as vice-captain. Just about the only quibbles one might raise with Keegan's most adventurous selection yet are the continuing confidence in David Seaman and, ironically, the overlooking of Teddy Sheringham.

At a hoary old 34 the Manchester United striker is four years older than Shearer and obviously too ancient for consideration, but he happens to be in the form of his life (which Shearer never was under Keegan) and at this moment his fitness is unquestionably superior to that of either Emile Heskey or Robbie Fowler. He would hardly be a choice for the future, but as Keegan himself has said on more than one occasion, if you have the ability and the experience, who is looking at birth certificates? Probably the factor which counted against Sheringham most is that his withdrawn striking role is duplicated by Paul Scholes, now a fixture in the England team, although the pair seem to thrive in the same side at United.

More important than mere personnel matters though, more crucial even than whether Beckham remains in midfield or Owen leads the line on his own, is the knowledge that England can not only play without Shearer but use the ball intelligently.

'We have learned from Euro 2000,' said Martin Keown. 'Against France we seemed to be able to retain possession like a proper football team, and that's important.'

fields.headline: A top concierge reveals all
fields.standfirst: Kingsley Blake, concierge at the Round Hill Hotel and Villas, Jamaica
fields.trailText: Kingsley Blake, concierge at the Round Hill Hotel and Villas, Jamaica.
fields.body:
Round Hill has many celebrity connections...

Yes, Noël Coward was one of the first to own a Round Hill villa in the late Fifties. But they all have different patterns: Paul McCartney only comes at Christmas time, but Ralph Lauren frequently spends weekends at his villa. I have always lived within 15 minutes' walk of Round Hill and have worked here since 1972, so I met Jackie Onassis once but was not around when she spent her honeymoon with JFK here. One of my responsibilities is choosing the nannies we employ for babysitting - there are currently 10 because families like to spend vacations here. I remember when Pierce Brosnan stayed, my manager said to me: 'This is James Bond, so we need your very best nanny.' We have 26 villas. They can be rented out when the owners are not in residence and we also have 36 ocean-front rooms.

Any unusual requests?

I am always asked to go and choose good bits of jerk chicken and jerk pork from the market. However, once I was given a credit card and a finger measurement and asked to go and buy an engagement ring. The man described the woman he wanted to propose to and I had to meet her as she came off a cruise ship. Fortunately there was only one passenger wearing a pink floral dress!

What about a day out?

The south coast is the most special part of Jamaica: it is peaceful and beautiful. Guests should not miss Holland Bamboo Avenue, which is a 3-mile long road and a very interesting experience. Slaves had to walk from the estate to the plantation every day and it was a very rough and hot walk. Bamboo was planted along both sides of the road and it grew 20ft high and formed a bamboo arch for the whole length of the road.

What about a night out?

Friday and Saturday nights at Round Hill's restaurant are Jamaican themed, with Jamaican food and music, but my favourite nights are Mondays when we have a cook-out on the beach. Pier One and Margarataville are the hottest clubs at the moment, but we can also arrange sunset cruises.

Reservations: Elegant Resorts 01244 897999. Superior Ocean Front room $240 per night, inclusive.

fields.headline: Health check
fields.trailText: Over the summer months, 151 cases of West Nile fever including 12 deaths, have been reported in Jerusalem, Golan and Tel Aviv in Israel.
fields.body:
Over the summer months, 151 cases of West Nile fever including 12 deaths, have been reported in Jerusalem, Golan and Tel Aviv in Israel.

There have also been 11 cases of West Nile fever this summer in New York and surrounding states. This unpleasant virus is transmitted by night-biting mosquitoes and usually causes a febrile illness lasting about a week. In severe cases, inflammation of the brain can result. The elderly seem to be at a higher risk of complications associated with infection.

As there is no vaccine, travellers are advised to take steps to avoid bites by covering up and applying insect repellent to exposed areas of skin when outdoors.

To obtain a health brief tailored to your journey call the MASTA Travellers Health Line on 0906 8 224 100 (calls charged at 60p/min). For general travel health advice visit the website at www.masta.org

webTitle: The best ski resort for you

fields.headline: Where's best for you?
fields.standfirst: There are more than 1,000 ski resorts in the world.  Escape helps you find the one that meets your needs
fields.trailText: There are more than 1,000 ski resorts in the world. Escape helps you find the one that meets your needs.
fields.body:
Best for experts

Chamonix French resort famous for the Vallée Blanche though tough skiers go for the harder 'vraie' valley run. Try Collineige (01276 24262).

Jackson Hole Rugged Wyoming area. The Hobacks, a wild, ungroomed snowfield, has the toughest skiing in the US. Try Lotus Supertravel (020 7962 9933).

St Anton Experts flock to this stylish Austrian mountain village for some of the best off-piste skiing in Europe. Try Mark Warner (08708 480482).

Snowbird If you're looking for fine powder this Utah resort just 25 miles from Salt Lake City is hard to beat. Try Ski Freedom (020 8313 0999).

Verbier Skiers either love or hate this sprawling Swiss extension of London SW3. Stunning skiing as well as scary prices. Try FlexiSki (0870 9090754).

Best for beginners

Borovets Bulgarian resort with easy runs for beginners, and two English-speaking ski schools with smallish classes. Try Inghams (020 8 780 4433).

Geilo Long-established Norwegian resort, a safe place to start with thorough instructors who take no chances. Try Neilson (08705 141414).

Risoul Non-threatening resort in French southern Alps with lots of simple wooded runs beyond the nursery slopes. Try First Choice (0870 754 3477).

Villars Swiss favourite with nursery slopes in the village and others higher up (reached by a cog railway). Try Club Med (020 7348 3333).

Best for snowboarders

La Clusaz Traditional Savoyard village popular with the French, especially teenagers who snowboard by day and club at night.Try Erna Low (020 7584 2841).

Chatel Farm-village resort has a half-pipe and fun park. Boarders have the freedom of the extensive Portes du Soleil. Try First Choice (0870 754 3477).

Copper Mountain Rocky Mountains resort with a championship half-pipe with big enough walls to challenge top riders. Try Ski the American Dream (020 8552 1201).

Formigal Sunny spot in the Spanish Pyrenees with wide slopes ideal for first or second-year boarders. Try Thomson (0870 606 1470).

Livigno Lots of free-riding in this high, isolated, Italian resort close to the Swiss border. Try Airtours Ski (0870 157 7775).

Zell Am See Austrian lakeside resort is good choice for learner or improving boarders who have own areas. Try Neilson (08705 141414).

Best on a budget

Brides-Les-Bains Small French spa town has blossomed since building a giant gondola straight into the Trois Vallées. Try Motours (01892 677770).

Bareges Prices significantly cheaper in French Pyrenees spa resort with pleasing skiing. Try Lagrange (020 7371 6111).

Formigal Biggest Spanish resort close to French border with flattering pistes, served by much-improved lifts. Try Thomson (0870 606 1470).

Kranjska Gora Excellent value in this Slovenian resort in a beautiful valley near the Italian and Austrian borders. Try Crystal (0870 848 7000).

Livigno Italian outpost, not far from St Moritz, has retained its duty-free privileges. Cheap booze and excellent skiing. Try Neilson (0870 514 1414).

Best for families

Badkleinkirschheim Home of Franz Klammer is an excellent base in Austria for families of mixed ability who want to ski together. Try Crystal (0870 848 7000).

Breckenridge Old mining town in the US Rockies with miles of comfortable trails cut down the tree-lined slopes of its four peaks. Try Ski Independence (0870 555 0555).

Cervinia Fine skiing on the sunny, open slopes on the Italian side of the Matterhorn, with enjoyable long intermediate runs.Try Airtours (0870 157 7775).

Crans Montana Pleasant Swiss area on the sunny side of the Rhone Valley with 100 miles of open-piste skiing ideal for families. Try the Swiss Travel Service (01992 456123).

Best for non-skiers (on holiday with skiing friends)

Cortina Italian favourite for a winter holiday even if you don't ski. Best mountain restaurants can be reached by road. Try Ski Equipe (0161 440 0010).

Garmisch-Partenkirchen Lies at the foot of Germany's highest mountain. Lederhosen, folklore, skating and swimming. Try Moswin Tours (0116 271 9922).

Heavenly Admire sapphire-blue Lake Tahoe which straddles the California-Nevada state line. There are more than 20 wedding chapels. Try Ski Independence (0870 555 0555).

St Gervais French spa in the awe-inspiring Chamonix valley. Thermal baths, fashionable shops and valley trains.Try Snowcoach (01727 866177).

webTitle: Nigel Lloyd tracks the latest skiing trends

fields.headline: Peak thrills unlimited
fields.standfirst: After last year's millennium blues skiers are rushing to book this season's snow fix.  Nigel Lloyd tracks the latest trends on and off the slopes
fields.trailText: After last year's millennium blues skiers are rushing to book this season's snow fix. Nigel Lloyd tracks the latest trends on and off the slopes.
fields.body:
Sunny blue skies and snow-covered mountains may just be memories in the photograph album. It is time, however, to think about skiing again. Enthusiasts enjoyed good snow last winter, even if greedy millennium prices and a late Easter left some larger tour operators with fewer customers than they had hoped. Many smaller, independent companies did well, against the trend.

About 770,000 Britons went skiing last year, a drop of 105,000 on the previous season. About 450,000 bought packages, 199,000 went independently and 119,000 took a school trip. Those who missed out last time seemed to be booking earlier than usual, which is why you ought to start concentrating on the brochures now.

The weak euro works wonders for prices. Although Easter is relatively late - on 15 April - the Christmas and New Year transfers fall much more conveniently, with Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve on Sundays.

The French ski schools have at last recognised the qualifications of British instructors. Some troubled beginners may miss the good old days when you could always blame your helplessness on not being able to understand what your French instructor was trying to tell you. But this change of attitude by the French will mean that British tour companies can again offer their clients English-speaking instruction and the popular ski guiding service.

Last winter Austria was officially shunned by its European partners after the far-Right leader Jörg Haider's Freedom Party won ministerial places for the first time in a coalition government with the conservative People's Party, but generally skiers refused to join the boycott and after respectable snow, the traditional British favourite is again selling well.

Italy didn't have the best of snow, and it remains to be seen whether the resorts and tourist offices can recoup some of last year's lost bookings. Only Cortina seems to have got off to a cracking start by announcing it will open on 1 December come what may, thanks to artificial snow.

Andorra is still spending heavily on lift improvements as it projects itself as more than just a cheap destination. Bulgaria has consolidated its position with bargain-hunters and the strong pound means that Switzerland almost feels affordable.

Outside Europe, North America beckons. Canadian resorts are threatening to show their ski-tails to their US competitors, many of which had shaky early snowfalls last year and won't be helped by the strengthening of the American dollar against sterling. Vail, in Colorado, has regained its position as the top North American resort in the annual poll by Ski Magazine. Whistler, in Canada, which knocked it off the top spot last year, is down to third behind Deer Valley, Utah. Aspen, in fifth below Sun Valley, is pushing its $39-a-day lift-ticket offer for those booking before the end of November. Jackson Hole, Wyoming, tops the list for best terrain.

The Canadian dollar isn't quite so cheap for us as last year but the Canadians are cock-a-hoop about their ski prospects. Konrad Bartelski, three times a British Olympic skier and long a fan of Canadian resorts, says exciting options are opening up in less-known resorts such as Fernie, Silver Star and Big White. Snow in the western resorts is very reliable.

Despite all the hype, it is essential to put the whole North American ski scene into perspective. About 50,000 British skiers are expected to cross the Atlantic, compared with 750,000 who will head for European slopes this season.

What's New

1. The specialist brochures

The demand, it seems, is for luxury. The best hotels and the most luxurious chalets are being taken first. Last-minute bookers who hang on to see whether snow conditions are good can expect to pay above the odds. And while the low-cost airlines do have bargain fares, remember, you have to book early for the best prices and then allow for the cost of travelling from the airport to the resorts, which can dent a modest budget.

I had a taste of luxury chalets in the French Alps last February in Lotus Supertravel's (020 7962 9933) 'superchalet' Founets, just by the Bellecote piste in Courchevel 1850, and in Ski Beat's (01243 780405) chalet Annika, the most luxurious in La Plagne.

Erna Low (020 7584 2841), now represents the MGM luxury apartments. Besides being architecturally exciting, they are set beside the slopes in eight top French resorts and most have indoor swimming pools.

Ski Independence (0870 600 1462), best known perhaps for its holidays to 35 North American resorts, also has a busy ski-drive programme to 25 resorts in France and Switzerland. Motours (01892 677777) tops both these for choice with 63 ski-drive destinations in France, Switzerland, Austria and Italy.

The advantage of talking to a specialist chalet company is that its staff know the resorts and even the individual chalets intimately. Many concentrate on the great French ski areas, Val d'Isère, the Trois Vallées and La Plagne. Among these are Le Ski (0870 754 4444) which runs its own ski school and is opening its own bar in Courchevel 1650, Finlays (01835 830562), and Meriski (01451 843100). Some specialise in one resort. Others such as Ski Esprit (01252 618300) and Ski Famille (01223 363777) concentrate on looking after children.

The Ski Club of Great Britain (020 8410 2022) - subscriptions are £45 per person and £66 for a family - offers an eclectic selection of holidays for skiers of all standards. There are special holidays for the over-fifties, for off-piste enthusiasts and even weeks for unaccompanied teenagers.

Ski Lagrange (020 7371 6111) has expanded its programme to include La Clusaz, La Rosière among 38 others in France and Andorra. Flexiski (0870 909 0754) has added St Moritz and St Christoph, home of the 100-year-old Arlberg Ski Club, to the five prestigious resorts it already sells.

Stanford Skiing (020 8789 2929), which uses only Megève, has bought another hotel to cope with increased demand.

Inntravel (01653 629010), best known for relaxed holidays in mountain villages, is offering special weeks for novices to learn cross-country or downhill skiing.

Scott Dunn Ski (020 8767 0202), which headed the British discovery of Jackson Hole in the Nineties, concentrates more now on chalets and hotels in Zermatt and three French resorts.

Directory of Ski Holidays available free. Phone the Association of Independent Tour Operators on 020 8607 9080.

2. The big operators

The major firms, which singed their fingers last season, are hoping to bounce back using fat brochures full of enticements and a vast variety of resorts.

Crystal (0870 848 7000), which sells more holidays than any other operator, goes to 122 resorts in 11 countries, and has learn-to-ski-or-snowboard packages for 37 resorts. Many of its prices are lower than last year's.

Thomson (0870 606 1470) goes to more than 80 resorts in 11 countries and is strong on snowboarding. It has added 12 resorts including Alpach a friendly Austrian village..

Inghams (020 8740 4433) is fighting back after a market reverse a couple of winters ago.

As well as its usual brochure offering 10 countries, it has has another under its Bladon Lines brand for chalets and club hotels - the hot thing on the cold slopes - as well as a luxury brochure covering 44 resorts in seven countries.

First Choice (0870 754 3477) offers eight countries with club hotels mainly in France.

Neilson (08705 141414), with 11 countries, is offering Åre in Sweden, Obergurgl in Austria and Vail for the first time.

Get the big operators' brochures from travel agents, or phone them direct.

3. On the mountain

Greater environmental awareness has largely halted the expansion of ski areas into untouched valleys. Resorts are now more likely to concentrate on improving their lifts. Paradoxically, one of the exceptions is Vail, which last season suffered a series of arson attacks including the destruction of a large mountain-top restaurant complex. The resort has expanded into the Blue Sky Basin and is opening more terrain there this winter.

There is less opposition to improving existing ski lifts, even though bigger ones spill even more skiers on to already busy pistes. I'm only just getting used to six-seater chairlifts, but soon I'll have to try one carrying eight. There has been one at Vradal, in Norway since 1997, and Nauders, in Austria, installed one last year. Now comes news that six more eight-seaters are to be unveiled: in Méribel, Flaine and Les Deux-Alpes (which is promising two) in France, and in Ischgl and Hopfgarten in Austria. Each can lift up to 3,600 skiers an hour.

Also in Austria Filzmoos is replacing single-seaters with quads, there are upgrades to gondolas at Lech and Mayrhofen, new gondolas at Hintertux, Sölden, Söll and St Anton, and a new six-seater at Seefeld.

What it costs

No one can pretend that skiing is the cheapest of holidays. A family of four driving to self-catering accommodation in a French Alps centre may pay about £35 per person per day sharing in January. A package holiday - flights, transfers, hotel half-board - doesn't go much below £300 per person per week in January and at the end of the season. Add to these prices the cost of lifts, ski school and, if necessary, ski and boot hire, and you're looking at at least £500 a head. If economy is paramount, check the brochures for Andorra, Bulgaria and Slovenia.

Diary dates

The British school half-term week starts on Saturday 17 February. The French ski holidays stretch from Saturday 3 February to Sunday 4 March. You have been warned...

Free to first-timers

Some experts are worried that the average age of skiers is growing and there are too few newcomers. Vail has even started charging the over-70s, who used to ski for free. To encourage newcomers, nine nations have formed the Association of Snowsports Countries. Thirty resorts spread over five of them - Austria, France, Slovenia, Switzerland and the US - are offering a week's free lift pass, free tuition and free hire equipment to any first-time skiers or snowboarders from 20-27 January. Ask your tour operator for details.

fields.headline: Continental hotel rates soar
fields.trailText: Travellers are saving pounds on low-cost air fares to European cities only to spend them on hugely inflated hotel rates. Research carried out by American Express has shown that as airfares have been driven down by no-frills airlines, so average hotel rates have gone up by as much as one third this year.
fields.body:
Travellers are saving pounds on low-cost air fares to European cities only to spend them on hugely inflated hotel rates. Research carried out by American Express has shown that as airfares have been driven down by no-frills airlines, so average hotel rates have gone up by as much as one third this year.

Borge Ellgaard, Amex vice-president hotel relations, said the increases were due partly to a surge in short-break travellers taking advantage of deals such as Ryanair's recent £9 offer for travel to the Continent.

Amsterdam has seen the biggest price hikes with average room rates leaping 28 per cent to £90 in the past year, followed by Bologna, Brussels, Venice, Florence and Madrid. All of these cities have seen a surge in demand following the launch of low-cost services from London airports.

'There has been a massive increase in room rates across all of Europe this year. Room supply is struggling to keep up with demand and hoteliers are taking advantage of this and putting up prices,' said Nick van Marken of Arthur Andersen's hospitality division.

Some cities have become so popular that travellers taking advantage of last-minute cheap flights may find themselves lucky to get a hotel room at all. 'In Amsterdam this August there were people sleeping in the railway station because all the hotels were full to bursting point,' added van Marken.

He said rooms were also difficult to find at short notice in Madrid, Dublin, Rome and Athens.

The research also showed that there would be fewer bargains from the low-cost airlines as the increased cost of fuel started to bite into their profit margins.

Matthew Davis, director of consulting services, said the start-up airlines were less able to absorb fuel increases than their wealthier and more established rivals. 'We are already getting feedback from clients that prices are going up. The cost of fuel has tripled over the past 18 months and we are expecting fares to rise by at least 7 per cent,' he said. 'You will still get the £9 special offers to lure people onto the website but it will become more and more difficult to actually find a cheap deal.'

Starring role for self-catering

The English Tourism Council has simplified its grading system for self-catering accommodation so that people know exactly what they are getting when they book a holiday cottage or apartment.

The existing Key scheme has been replaced by a star rating - the higher the star, the higher the standard of accommodation.

'Our main aim was to simplify what was perceived to be a complicated grading scheme. Under the Key scheme there were two components to the rating, one relating to the facilities and the other to the quality of the accommodation. We have combined the rating of facilities and quality into one single system,' said Mandy Lane, ETC's head of quality standards.

In order to achieve a star rating each property has to meet a series of minimum requirements relating to cleanliness, clear pricing and booking conditions, comfortable accommodation and good facilities.

Over 8,000 properties have been given star ratings so far. Tourist Information Centres can give local listings of graded properties and the English Tourism Council publishes a Where to Stay Guide which costs £7.99 (0870 606 7204).

fields.headline: It's what is that counts
fields.standfirst: Donaldson may succeed Trimble
fields.trailText: One darkwinter Sunday morning this November Jeffrey Donaldson might wake up to find himself leader of Northern Ireland's largest political party. There is growing speculation that the opponents of the Good Friday Agreement are planning one last decisive heave against David Trimble.
fields.body:
One darkwinter Sunday morning this November Jeffrey Donaldson might wake up to find himself leader of Northern Ireland's largest political party. There is growing speculation that the opponents of the Good Friday Agreement are planning one last decisive heave against David Trimble.

Their champion this time will not be a stalking-horse but a thoroughbred, the MP for Lagan Valley who, the plotters pray, will ride to the rescue of Ulster Unionism and snatch it away from the grip of liberals and compromisers.

On one level, if the party deposes Trimble then it will be vindication of Donaldson. His ascension to the throne will be blessed by every right reverend and pious pastor from the evangelical wing of unionism as a step back to traditional unionist values.

But before he contemplates taking this path, Donaldson should take heed of Hume. I am not referring to the SDLP leader, but about David Hume, the eighteenth-century philosopher of the Scottish enlightenment. Hume was the first major thinker to deconstruct the way human beings wanted the world to be and the way it actually is. Hume coined the 'is/ought fallacy', the distinction between what knowledge through experience can cover - the 'is' of our universe - and what lies beyond this in the realm of moral or metaphysical speculation.

In the mind of every traditional unionist Ulster 'ought' to be governed on the lines of Protestant majority rule; every terrorist (at the least the republican ones anyway) 'ought' to be in jail; every illegal weapon 'ought' to be handed over; everybody living in this state 'ought' to be loyal to it.

The world is not like that. If and when Donaldson sits down at his desk on the first day of his new job he will face the same bal ance of forces that have confronted Trimble over the last years. The British, let alone the Irish Government, will never permit a return to unionist majority rule. The released paramilitaries cannot be put back in prison unless they re-offend. The IRA, fearing the very real growth of armed republican dissent, and the feuding loyalists, who fear each other more now than the Provos, are unlikely to hand over their arms. Catholics are unlikely to become convinced of the benefits of the union if the UUP unites with the Protestant supremacists. Why, after all, would you support such a coalition in the temporal world if a section of it believes you will burn in the next one? Full-blown nationalists, meanwhile, will hardly be enthusiastic about cutting a deal with the Donaldson led-UUP that falls far short of the power-sharing/Irish dimension.

The present political crisis is the old story of unionists fatally overestimating their strength and influence. The rejectionists who ousted Terence O'Neill believed they could cling to absolute power in their corrupt state despite the fact that the entire world was now watching. This obstinacy, in part, produced the Provisional IRA. Later they ditched Brian Faulkner and then indulged in political fantasies.

With the exception, paradoxically, of some loyalist leaders, throughout three politically barren decades the 'respectable' unionists ignored the elephant in their living room, the Catholics and nationalists inside their state. At the heart of the Trimbleite vision for unionism is the recognition at last that a large and growing minority here have been alienated from the union. One segment of this minority, the republican core, will never be reconciled. But there is a larger section that can accept historic compromise and the principle of consent. A smaller element may even be won over to a new secular form of unionism. Trimbleism is empirical in nature, it follows Hume's advice that we deal with what 'is' and not what 'ought' to be.

The trouble for the emotional unionists, as with all Utopians, is that their grandiose designs and moral crusades always end in disaster and defeat.

webTitle: Free Derry Corner earns its place in history

fields.headline: Free Derry Corner earns its place in history
fields.trailText:
01/10/2000: Free Derry Corner is now seen as part
                                                  of the city's history, a place for respect and conservation, but no
                                                  longer a rallying point for rebellion against the state.
fields.body:
'You are now entering Free Derry' the slogan painted in black letters on a white wall, has become one of the most enduring images of the Troubles. It has been seen over and over again on television often as the background to violent clashes between the security forces and the people of the Bogside.

Over the years most of the Sinn Fein leaders associated with the long march from armed rebellion to political respectability have addressed the supporters here. Just across the road a youthful Martin McGuinness, at that time an IRA leader in Derry, made his first public speech. It was short and to the point: 'It doesn't matter what John Hume says. We'll fight on until we get a united Ireland.'

Now Free Derry Corner is to become, officially, a national monument. Last week an alliance of Sinn Fein and the SDLP on the city council voted that the area should be handed over to the Department of the Environment's Heritage Service. The Minister who will be responsible for looking after it is Sam Foster, an Ulster Unionist member of the new power sharing executive.

It is a potent symbol of changing times. The slogan 'You are now entering Free Derry' was first painted on to the gable end of a small terraced house in the Bogside in 1969. It was during an uneasy period when the Civil Rights movement was holding massive rallies to protest against discrimination but before the Army was sent to Northern Ireland. The row of cramped houses was later demolished but the gable wall was left standing by itself and the area became known as Free Derry Corner.

It was a focal point of republican defiance. Each year the march held to commemorate Bloody Sunday in Derry, when 13 marchers were shot by the British soldiers, ended with a rally here. It was at this wall that Bernadette Devlin spoke to reporters when she was released from jail.

Free Derry Corner has changed in recent years as peace has become a reality. There are landscaped flowerbeds. On nearby walls large and graphic murals depict key moments of the area's history over the past 30 years.

It has become a tourist attraction. American visitors come in coachloads. Sometimes a group of British squaddies, coming to the end of a tour of duty, will venture up to Free Derry Corner to have their photographs taken. But the old revolutionary spirit persists. Local groups campaigning on such contentious issues as abortion and gay rights use the back of the wall to put across their message.

Free Derry Corner was not the only historic monument in the city to change hands last week. By a pleasant irony the Ministry of Defence announced that Fort George, which has been the Army's headquarters in the west side of Derry for almost 30 years, is to be handed back to its original owners. The Londonderry Port and Harbour Commissioners planned to build a flagship commercial development on the 15-acre site.

The decision to leave Fort George is part of the Government's programme to reduce the security presence in Northern Ireland. Six Army bases along the border in Co Fermanagh are also to be demolished. The Army points out that 40 military bases and installations have been closed down since 1995. At the moment there are 13,500 soldiers in the province. The hope is that, all being well, this figure will be cut to 8,000. Sinn Fein describes this process as demilitarisation. The Army prefers the more hopeful term normalisation. Unionists have been critical of this scaling down of the Army presence, which they claim is being done to pander to the IRA.

Others see it as part of a deliberate strategy to extract concessions from the IRA to help David Trimble.

The issue of policing and the demands of nationalist leaders for a full implementation of the Patten Report make it very difficult for the Government to move on that front. But a dramatic gesture from the IRA, such as another inspection of its arms dumps by internationally respected figures, might help Trimble fend off his critics.
