fields.headline: West Bank death toll hits 15
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: At least nine Palestinians were killed as violent confrontations with Israeli forces continued for a third day and brought the peace process to a new crisis.
fields.body:
At least nine Palestinians were killed as violent confrontations with Israeli forces continued for a third day and brought the peace process to a new crisis.

Guns, sticks and stones were used in the clashes in Arab East Jerusalem, the West Bank and Gaza yesterday. Among the dead was a 14-year-old Palestinian protester, killed in an exchange of live gunfire in the West Bank city of Nablus.

The latest deaths brought to at least 15 the number of Palestinians killed in the past three days. Four of the dead were Palestinian police officers. Two Israeli soldiers werekilled last week.

Last night Israeli army chief Shaul Mofaz called a 'ceasefire', saying the violence would stop. But some Palestinians refused to accept it, and clashes continued.

Yesterday was supposed to have been a day of mourning. Instead the situation grew steadily out of control. In an alley outside the Haram al- Sharif, the gleaming gold Dome of the Rock mosque in Jerusalem, young Palestinian men collected on a rooftop at the end of afternoon prayers.

They piled up their rocks, and waited for the next round. They watched Israeli forces making their own preparations down a gloomy alley.

Behind the wall, Palestinian women were gathering blocks of ice for wounds and onions for tear gas, and wrestling with a few hotheads who had brought guns along.

Dozens of Israelis stormed in and the alley was engulfed in the percussive roar of stun grenades and tear gas, and the wailing of men hit by rubber bullets. There was a frantic stampede for sanctuary and the long minutes of waiting, marked by the arrival of young men bleeding from head wounds or overcome by tear gas.

At last there was quiet. When people dared to look outside, they found smashed cars and water gushing out of the mains on to cobblestones strewn with tear-gas cannis ters, upturned water tankers, and rubble. Guarding the picture of devastation were scores of Israeli troops, now firmly back in charge, of this lane at least.

Such clashes were replicated, often in even more violent form, in the Gaza Strip, and in the West Bank cities of Nablus, Ramallah, Hebron and Bethlehem. Palestinian security sources said 300 had been hurt in Gaza alone.

The rioting had been sparked by the provocative visit to the Haram by the hardline Likud leader Ariel Sharon. He is the most hated Israeli in the Arab world, and his presence there was too much to bear.

The peace process has been deadlocked over the fate of the Haram, holy both to Jews and Muslims. Last week President Clinton was testing reactions to the idea of sharing control over it. Now such ideas seem further from reality than ever. In many parts of the West Bank and Jerusalem, Islamic clerics and Palestinian officials confessed they were powerless to contain their people's rage.

'Now I can say for sure that things are out of control,' said Faisal Husseini, the Palestinian official in charge of Jerusalem affairs.

He said he had pleaded with the Israeli authorities to stop the visit by Sharon, which Palestinians see as a brazen attempt to assert Jewish sovereignty over the Haram, the third holiest shrine in Islam. Their failure to do so, he said, was directly responsible for the bloodshed.

Such warnings were ignored, with Israeli officials claiming it was the right of every citizen to visit the Haram, or as they call it the Temple Mount, which they revere as the site of their destroyed temple.

Now, in the lanes of Jerusalem's Old City, the Palestinians say they have only begun to fight. They have draped the gate to the Haram in a huge Palestinian flag and plastered the walls with photos of the newest martyr to the struggle for control of Arab East Jerusalem.

Israel's Prime Minister, Ehud Barak, has blamed the violence directly on the Palestinian leadership.

fields.headline: Loyalist 'fat cats' face asset seizure
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The financial affairs of hundreds of loyalist and republican paramilitaries are to come under scrutiny by the Government's agency set up to seize criminal assets.
fields.body:
The financial affairs of hundreds of loyalist and republican paramilitaries are to come under scrutiny by the Government's agency set up to seize criminal assets.

The Observer has learnt that any paramilitary or ordinary criminal with more than £20,000 in the bank will be investigated by the Confiscation Agency. If they cannot account for the money, the agency will have powers through the civil courts to take cash, cars, property and other assets from them. The £20,000 threshold for financial investigation will be one of the lowest in Europe. Pursuing suspects through the civil courts will entail shifting the burden of proof from the security services to those under investigation, making a prosecution easier to obtain.

In loyalist areas such as the Lower Shankill in Belfast, paramilitary leaders travel about in four-wheel-drive vehicles, wear expensive jewellery and take luxury holidays in the Caribbean despite being officially on the dole. Their lavish lifestyles are in the main financed through the drugs trade.

Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, announced the establishment of the Confiscation Agency at the Labour Party conference in Brighton last week. He said the aim of the agency was to combat the 'mafia culture' which has burgeoned since the ceasefires. It will be based in Belfast, and although staffed by civil servants will have an input from the RUC, Customs and Excise, the Inland Revenue and MI5.

A senior RUC officer told The Observer : 'We have argued that investigators should start probing the accounts of these people at £20,000 and over because there are so many mini-criminal empires out there. It will allow us to get to those who bankroll crime and paramilitaries in a way that's not been tried before.'

A spokesman for the Northern Ireland Office confirmed that legislation would be introduced into Parliament before Christmas outlining the scope and nature of the Confiscation Agency. It was expected to be up and running before next summer.

The new agency will be modelled on the Criminal Assets Bureau in the Irish Republic, set up to tackle Dublin drug barons.

webTitle: IRA give ground on arms dumps

fields.headline: IRA give ground on arms dumps
fields.standfirst:
Two new inspections timed to strengthen Trimble's hand

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The IRA is expected to allow inspection of at least two new weapons dumps by the end of this week, shortly before next weekend's Ulster Unionist party conference in Belfast. The move is designed to strengthen embattled UUP leader David Trimble.
fields.body:
The IRA is expected to allow inspection of at least two new weapons dumps by the end of this week, shortly before next weekend's Ulster Unionist party conference in Belfast. The move is designed to strengthen embattled UUP leader David Trimble.

Maarti Ahtisaari, the former Finnish President, and former ANC general secretary Cyril Ramaphosa, are expected to fly discreetly into the Republic of Ireland, where they will be met by an IRA leader and be shown IRA weapons dumps. The weapons will be electronically tagged to ensure they will not be moved or used.

This is what one British source called 'a mutual confidence-building measure' and takes place in the context of the announcement by Peter Mandelson on Friday that IRA prisoners who escaped British jurisdiction and are living in the Republic or the US can safely return to Northern Ireland.

One of the fugitives affected is the head of the IRA's Southern Command. This leading Republican, originally from Belfast, is the man arms inspectors met last June in the first inspection of two arms dumps believed to be in Co Cork.

Republicans have told The Observer that this is the most likely reciprocation from Republicans, who will sell it to their own constituency as being their part of the 'demili tarisation process'. The announcement by the Chief Constable of the RUC, Sir Ronnie Flanagan, that six military bases across the North will close, is another part of this process.

Although anti-agreement Unionists complained bitterly that Mandelson's announcement grants virtual amnesty to IRA fugitives, pro-agreement Unionists feel that new arms inspections will help Trimble.

As one Trimble supporter said yesterday: 'We can argue that slow progress is better than no progress and that the no-Unionists won't have compromised a single IRA bullet by their rigid stance'.

Nevertheless, anti-agreement Unionists such as Jeffrey Donaldson are likely to argue that this arms inspection falls far short of what the Unionists' electorate demands. Yesterday, Donaldson told the BBC that if the UUP did not change its policy on sharing government with Sinn Fein, it faced annihilation at the next general election. Donaldson said the nine Ulster Unionist MPs would become 'two or three'.

Donaldson denied that he was starting a leadership contest. 'The leadership is an issue for another day,' he told the BBC. 'Policy is the issue for today'. He called for a return to a strict 'no guns, no government' line, which would involve pulling out of the power-sharing Executive rather than sharing power with Sinn Fein Ministers.

So Trimble faces next week's conference with his leadership dependent upon the actions of the IRA. 'We expect them to keep their end of the bargain,' said a British Government source, adding that the announcement by the Secretary of State, plus the demilitarisation announcement by the chief constable added up to 'not quite a quid pro quo but sequence is not a bad word'.

The murder of a man late on Friday night in Magherafelt, Co Tyrone is not believed to have been sectar ian. Just before 11pm, two men entered the Depot bar on the Union Road in Magherafelt, singled out a Catholic, Patrick Quinn, 32, and shot him dead. The men made their escape in a blue Sierra, with the registration GDZ 5662.

Despite initial speculation that the effectiveness of the murder indicated that the Loyalist Volunteer Force may have been involved, security sources are indicating that they now believe the murder to have been drugs-related - not that this rules out LVF involvement.

The killing of Quinn has been condemned by the local MP, Martin McGuinness.

webTitle: Adoption drive targets more gay parents

fields.headline: Adoption drive targets more gay parents
fields.trailText: Children's charities are targeting gay and lesbian couples as adoptive parents in a bid to solve Britain's crisis of children in care.
fields.body:
Children's charities are targeting gay and lesbian couples as adoptive parents in a bid to solve Britain's crisis of children in care.

To the delight of gay rights campaigners and the dismay of Christian groups, next week's launch of National Adoption Week is expected to see a rise in the number of children placed with same-sex couples.

The move follows a surge in the number of gays presenting themselves as adoptive parents, with the 1,000 threshold being broken for the first time. The number is set to increase further when a European Court of Human Rights hearing next year confirms the right of gays to adopt.

'With the Government clearly seeking to increase the number of adoptions, they must include more families of all types,' said Anne van Meeuwen of Barnardo's. 'We need to abandon rigid ideas and look at the whole range of people who might adopt children.'

But a spokesman for the Catholic Media Office said: 'The only ideal to which we should aspire is a family unit consisting of a man and a woman.'

National Adoption Week will see the launch of initiatives by groups promoting opportunities to adopt 5,000 children not placed with permanent parents.

'We estimate that there have probably now been at least 1,000 adoptions by lesbians or gays in this country,' said solicitor Gill Butler, a British adoption specialist. 'The majority are children from care. Attitudes among local authority adoption panels have softened enormously.'

The campaign for equal rights is due to be boosted early next year when lawyers expect the European Court to find that France has breached the human rights of Philippe Frette, a 46-year-old teacher from Paris, who claims he was denied the opportunity to adopt solely on the basis of his sexuality.

'What is most interesting in recent cases is that, on the whole, birth families of children adopted to lesbians and gays are not objecting,' said Butler.

The American Psychological Association, which declassified homosexuality as a mental disorder only 30 years ago, recently confirmed that there was now no evidence to suggest that children growing up with gay men or lesbians were 'compromised'.

The existing Adoption Act requires that adoption should 'safeguard and promote' the needs of a child. Local councils and judges have become increasingly liberal in their interpretation of this.

Gay interest in parenting has also been fuelled by reports that TV star Michael Barrymore and pop singer Stephen Gateley, both gay, were considering adoption. Shaun Davis, 25-year old partner of Barrymore, said: 'We're in a stable relationship, we love each other very much and we'd provide a good home for a child. That's much more than a lot of kids get.'

Links: http://www.baaf.org.uk

webTitle: Lottery at risk amid bid chaos

fields.headline: Lottery at risk amid bid chaos
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: The National Lottery is facing a crisis of Dome-like proportions and the potential loss of millions of pounds for good causes due to a meltdown in the process to decide who should run it, The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
The National Lottery is facing a crisis of Dome-like proportions and the potential loss of millions of pounds for good causes due to a meltdown in the process to decide who should run it, The Observer can reveal.

Against a backdrop of acute concern by bodies reliant on lottery cash, figures involved in the bidding process have expressed doubt for the first time about whether the new licence to run the weekly gamble for good causes will start on time next year.

Letters obtained by The Observer reveal growing anxiety among charities and the present operator, Camelot, about the way the Lottery Commission is handling the bidding for the new licence to run the lottery from next September. They show a complete breakdown in communication between key players charged with finding the best group to run the twice-weekly draw.

Charities and sporting bodies which have had such success in the Olympics would lose £4 million for each day the lottery fails to operate.

Senior executives at Camelot said that the lottery was in danger of becoming 'the next Dome'. One executive said delays, confusion over lottery targets and legal challenges mean there is now a 'real danger' the new operator will not be in a position to take over the multi-million pound business next year.

A remarkable letter from Dianne Thompson, the chief executive of Camelot, to Dame Helena Shovelton, the chairwoman of the Commission, reveals a crisis at the heart of the lottery. 'I am writing to place on record Camelot's grave concerns about the state of the licensing process,' Thompson wrote. 'We cannot identify any acknowledgement on the part of the NLC [National Lottery Commission] that it has done anything wrong, rather than this there has been created the impression that the NLC seeks to lay blame for the aberrant behaviour at the door of its legal advisers.

'All this leaves Camelot with the inescapable conclusion that it has been and will continue to be subjected to intolerable bias.'

The Observer can also reveal that Camelot considered pulling out of the bidding because it felt it could not trust the Commission to run it fairly. Such a move would be highly embarrassing for the Commission and Chris Smith, the Secretary of State for Culture, who appointed the commission members and stood by them during recent rows over how Richard Branson's People's Lottery was awarded the original licence.

The Commission had to withdraw the Branson offer after Camelot successfully challenged their decision in the High Court, which said that the Commission had been 'conspicuously unfair'.

Stuart Etherington, of the National Council of Voluntary Organisations, said: 'There is growing concern in the charity world.'

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Appeal after mother goes missing with two children
fields.body:
Appeal after mother goes missing with two children

Police appealed for help in finding Maria Dawson, missing from her home in New Addington, Surrey, with children Matthew, 13, and Sandra, 11. Her husband found a note saying she planned to live in Spain with her father.

Doors shut at Maze prison

The Maze prison in Northern Ireland finally closed yesterday. The last prisoners - three loyalists and one republican - had been transferred to other jails.

Double killing: man held

A 30-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of murder after the bodies of a man and woman were found at a house near Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria.

10p rise in minimum wage

The minimum wage goes up today from £3.60 to £3.70 an hour for workers aged over 21.

Life magazine

The dress on page 46 and 47 of Life magazine has been incorrectly captioned. It should read: Sequinned halter-neck dress with attached scarf, approximately £3,000; sandals £310; tights £95; all by Dolce & Gabbana, 6-8 Old Bond Street, London, W1 020 7659 9000.

Sainsbury's gets wind up

Sainsbury's is to buy wind-generated electricity for its distribution depot at East Kilbride. A turbine will provide up to 40 per cent of its power.

Noddy goes up in art world

Noddy Holder, ex-leader of Seventies band Slade, has recorded the lift announcements at the new £21m Walsall Art Gallery.

Oriana back

The luxury liner Oriana is due in Southampton today after an Atlantic crossing delayed by damage from a 50ft wave.

Lottery draw

The winning numbers in yesterday's draw are 12 15 27 32 40 44, bonus 35. Thunderball numbers are 7 12 14 20 31, thunderball 9.

fields.headline: British link to 'snuff' videos
fields.trailText: Britain is a key link in the biggest ever international investigation into the production and supply of paedophile 'snuff' movies - in which children are murdered on film - an  Observer investigation can reveal.
fields.byline: Jason Burke  in London, Amelia Gentleman in  Moscow, Philip Willan  in Rome
fields.body:
Britain is a key link in the biggest ever international investigation into the production and supply of paedophile 'snuff' movies - in which children are murdered on film - an Observer investigation can reveal.

The key suspect in the inquiry, a Russian who was arrested last week in Moscow for distribution of thousands of sadistic child porn videos and pictures, was traced following the seizure of his products from British paedophiles.

Dmitri Vladimirovich Kuznetsov, a 30-year-old former car mechanic in Moscow, was identified after British Customs and police traced the origin of violent child porn videos found in the UK back to Russia.

Last week Italian police seized 3,000 of Kuznetsov's videos on their way to clients in Italy, sparking an international hunt for paedophiles who have bought his products. The Italian investigators say the material includes footage of children dying during abuse. Prosecutors in Naples are considering charging those who have bought the videos with complicity in murder. They say some may have specifically requested films of killings.

British authorities yesterday confirmed that scores of Kuznetsov's videos, produced in his small flat in Moscow's rundown Vykhino district, have been found in the UK. They are concerned that 'snuff' movies in which children are killed may have also been imported.

Around a dozen British men have already been arrested and charged with offences alleged to be connected to the Russian tapes. A second Russian child porn ring, which allegedly had a British distributor, was broken up earlier this year. The investigation into the importing of violent Russian child porn which led to the identification and subsequent imprisonment of Kuznetsov started about 15 months ago after Customs seized material coming into the country. Since then there have been dozens of other finds.

'We have seen some very, very nasty stuff involving sadistic abuse of very young children, but actual deaths on film takes it a whole step further. That is very worrying,' said one senior customs officer this weekend.

British paedophiles were paying between £50 and £100 for Kuznetsov's tapes, the officer said. Further fees were paid for access to a website that features pictures of extremely violent abuse.

Though two men arrested with Kuznetsov have also been imprisoned by Moscow authorities, only one of the three remains behind bars. Dmitri Ivanov was sentenced to 11 years for actually participating in the abuse that was being filmed. The others were released under an amnesty aimed at clearing Russia's overcrowded prisons.

When officers from the Moscow Criminal Investigation Department raided Kuznetsov's flat they found two boys in a makeshift studio. They seized a huge quantity of films and other pornographic material as well as lists of clients in Italy, Germany, America and Britain.

Last week Italian detectives moved in, following months of inquiries, and arrested eight people. The police searched more than 600 homes and say they now have evidence against about 500 people. Among the suspects were businessmen, public employees and a university student. Several of them were married, with children of their own. Hundreds of people are also under investigation in Germany.

The Russian videos, which had been ordered over the internet, were intercepted when they came into Italy by post, repackaged and then delivered by undercover police officers. They cost between £300 and £4,000, depending on what type of film was ordered.

Covert film of young children naked or undressing was known as a 'SNIPE' video. The most appalling category was code-named 'Necros Pedo' in which children were raped and tortured until they died.

Police in Russia and the UK believe that Kuznetsov and his associates have been in business for more than two years in which time they are believed to have recruited around 100 boys - aged between nine and 15 - to be filmed.

'Most of the children were rounded up from railway stations. A lot of them came from the suburbs, or surrounding regions and were from deprived, problem families,' said Kiril Mazurin, a police spokesman.

'Usually when children like this arrive in the capital, they've got no idea where to go and hang around in the station. It's very easy to entice this kind of teenager - with a promise of a warm bed or a trip to the cinema.'

Many were lured away from orphanages. 'Children are not locked in,' said Mazurin. 'Anyone can come along and promise them a meal at McDonalds. It doesn't take any more than that."

Some children were paid a commission to find other boys willing to be filmed, according to reports in the Russian press, for a fee of between 100 and 300 roubles (£2.50 - £7).

Kuznetsov had given up his job in 1998 to devote himself to the lucrative pornography industry. A self-taught computer expert, he was in the process of upgrading his equipment to allow him to e-mail videos directly to clients when police raided him.

Many customers repeatedly ordered videos from him. The Naples newspaper Il Mattino published a transcript of an alleged email exchange between a prospective client and the Russian vendors.

'Promise me you're not ripping me off,' says the Italian.

'Relax, I can assure you this one really dies,' the Russian responds.

'The last time I paid and I didn't get what I wanted.'

'What do you want?'

'To see them die.'

webTitle: Free Derry Corner earns its place in history

fields.headline: Free Derry Corner earns its place in history
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: 'You are now entering Free Derry' the slogan painted in black letters on a white wall, has become one of the most enduring images of the Troubles.
fields.body:
'You are now entering Free Derry' the slogan painted in black letters on a white wall, has become one of the most enduring images of the Troubles. It has been seen over and over again on television often as the background to violent clashes between the security forces and the people of the Bogside.

Over the years most of the Sinn Fein leaders associated with the long march from armed rebellion to political respectability have addressed the supporters here. Just across the road a youthful Martin McGuinness, at that time an IRA leader in Derry, made his first public speech. It was short and to the point: 'It doesn't matter what John Hume says. We'll fight on until we get a united Ireland.'

Now Free Derry Corner is to become, officially, a national monument. Last week an alliance of Sinn Fein and the SDLP on the city council voted that the area should be handed over to the Department of the Environment's Heritage Service. The Minister who will be responsible for looking after it is Sam Foster, an Ulster Unionist member of the new power sharing executive.

It is a potent symbol of changing times. The slogan 'You are now entering Free Derry' was first painted on to the gable end of a small terraced house in the Bogside in 1969. It was during an uneasy period when the Civil Rights movement was holding massive rallies to protest against discrimination but before the Army was sent to Northern Ireland. The row of cramped houses was later demolished but the gable wall was left standing by itself and the area became known as Free Derry Corner.

It was a focal point of republican defiance. Each year the march held to commemorate Bloody Sunday in Derry, when 13 marchers were shot by the British soldiers, ended with a rally here. It was at this wall that Bernadette Devlin spoke to reporters when she was released from jail.

Free Derry Corner has changed in recent years as peace has become a reality. There are landscaped flowerbeds. On nearby walls large and graphic murals depict key moments of the area's history over the past 30 years.

It has become a tourist attraction. American visitors come in coachloads. Sometimes a group of British squaddies, coming to the end of a tour of duty, will venture up to Free Derry Corner to have their photographs taken. But the old revolutionary spirit persists. Local groups campaigning on such contentious issues as abortion and gay rights use the back of the wall to put across their message.

Free Derry Corner was not the only historic monument in the city to change hands last week. By a pleasant irony the Ministry of Defence announced that Fort George, which has been the Army's headquarters in the west side of Derry for almost 30 years, is to be handed back to its original owners. The Londonderry Port and Harbour Commissioners planned to build a flagship commercial development on the 15-acre site.

The decision to leave Fort George is part of the Government's programme to reduce the security presence in Northern Ireland. Six Army bases along the border in Co Fermanagh are also to be demolished. The Army points out that 40 military bases and installations have been closed down since 1995. At the moment there are 13,500 soldiers in the province. The hope is that, all being well, this figure will be cut to 8,000. Sinn Fein describes this process as demilitarisation. The Army prefers the more hopeful term normalisation. Unionists have been critical of this scaling down of the Army presence, which they claim is being done to pander to the IRA.

Others see it as part of a deliberate strategy to extract concessions from the IRA to help David Trimble.

The issue of policing and the demands of nationalist leaders for a full implementation of the Patten Report make it very difficult for the Government to move on that front. But a dramatic gesture from the IRA, such as another inspection of its arms dumps by internationally respected figures, might help Trimble fend off his critics.

It often seems that the peace process in Northern Ireland simply lurches from crisis to crisis. But at a political level there has been much more steady progress. Last week Trimble, accompanied by most of his Ministers, came to Dublin for the second plenary meeting of the North South Ministerial Council. In Belfast, the names of 60 members of the new Civic Forum were announced. This will act as a wide-ranging consultative body to the assembly.

This is how peace is built - slowly and with great difficulty. It will take a long time to complete the long journey from armed conflict to reconciliation. But in Derry at least, people believe that it is time to move on. Free Derry Corner is now seen as part of the city's history, a place for respect and conservation, but no longer a rallying point for rebellion against the state.

fields.headline: Horror as child organs found
fields.standfirst: Canadian police issue warrant over body parts in doctor's belongings
fields.trailText: The consultant pathologist accused of taking organs from hundreds of children at the Alder Hey Hospital in Liverpool without their parents' consent has claimed that the remains of at least two unidentified children found among his belongings in a Canadian warehouse are his property.
fields.body:
The consultant pathologist accused of taking organs from hundreds of children at the Alder Hey Hospital in Liverpool without their parents' consent has claimed that the remains of at least two unidentified children found among his belongings in a Canadian warehouse are his property.

Professor Dick van Velzen, an expert in paediatric pathology who could be extradited this week after Canadian police issued an arrest warrant, has dismissed the move as 'a misunderstanding' and insisted that the remains were given to him by the children's parents.

'The tissues recovered are not body parts or the remains of deceased children, as the police seem to understand,' he said. 'They are small parts of diseased bowel tissue which were removed by surgeons as part of routine operations elsewhere.

'At the request of parents I have performed second opinion investigations in order to establish whether or not their children suffered from a particular disease which had been discovered by me earlier,' he added. 'As I carried out these second opinion investigations on a personal basis, I have kept the leftover tissue fragments which had been entrusted to me by some parents with my other personal laboratory inventory, which was appropriately stored in a regular warehouse until suitable space became available in the Netherlands.'

The warrant was issued by police in Nova Scotia yesterday. Velzen, who left Britain in 1995, is at the centre of three inquiries into how the organs of more than 800 children were removed without their parents' consent.

The latest discovery has horrified parents in Liverpool, many of whom have already been forced to hold second funerals for their children because they had been buried without major organs.

The Canadian authorities say it will take at least six months before tests can establish from the remains found yesterday the children's place of origin.

The helpline at Alder Hey Hospital has been overwhelmed by frantic parents agonising over the possibility that their children's organs may be in Canada.

'This is a nightmare for every parent who had a child of about that age who died at Alder Hey during Velzen's time there,' said Janet Valentine, who has still not recovered all the organs of her five-month-old daughter, who died during heart surgery at the hospital in 1990. 'I've had parents who are beside themselves with terror ringing me all morning.'

The discovery was made by warehouse staff in Dartmouth who had moved in to recover the doctor's belongings, which had been stored since May 1998, after he failed to return to collect them or to pay for further storage. Eight human organs were found, preserved in plastic bags inside a cardboard box. Police have not revealed what the organs were.

Velzen, who worked at a hospital in Nova Scotia after the Canadian equivalent of the General Medical Council found him guilty of 'incompetent acts', worked in Trinidad before returning to the Netherlands. Velzen has been charged under the Canadian criminal code with 'indignity to human remains', which carries with it a five-year jail sentence.

webTitle: England accused of ethnic cleansing... 700 years ago

fields.headline: England accused of ethnic cleansing... 700 years ago
fields.standfirst: Battles of Britain
fields.trailText: Simon Schama, the controversial historian, is set to spark a new row by claiming England was the first country to conduct 'an act of ethnic cleansing on its Jews'.
fields.body:
Simon Schama, the controversial historian, is set to spark a new row by claiming England was the first country to conduct 'an act of ethnic cleansing on its Jews'.

In an episode of his History of Britain series to be broadcast by the BBC next month, Schama will say Edward I's expulsion of Jews in 1290 and his execution of hundreds of the elders of the community made England the 'first country to perform a little act of ethnic cleansing'.

Schama stresses the support of the Church and the populace for anti-Semitic violence and describes an incident when a ship's Jewish passengers - expelled from England - were deliberately drowned 'to the entertainment of the crew and all who heard about it'.

Another programme mentions that a British chronicler became possibly the first person to use the term 'holocaust' in referring, approvingly, to atrocities against the Jews under the reign of Richard I a century earlier. Researchers on the programme said last week that finding the reference gave them a 'visceral shock'.

Schama's emphasis on the poor treatment of Jews in England in the Middle Ages will anger traditionalists who have already attacked his programmes for denigrating England and the English. Schama, a British Jew, also describes the violence and brutality of Edward - known as 'Longshanks' for his great height - in his campaigns to subject and pacify the Welsh and Scots.

He calls Edward's construction of castles in Wales 'the most ambitious exercise in colonial domination ever undertaken in medieval Europe', and dwells on bloody atrocities committed during the king's campaigns in Scot land - featured in the Hollywood epic Braveheart - such as the sacking of Berwick, in which 11,000 civilians were massacred in three days.

Conservatives say English 'self-esteem and self-image' will 'take another knock' and that 'the great achievements of this nation are being run down'. There has been anger that the BBC, as a national institution, has broadcast such programmes. Previously Edward I, though known for his pride and belligerence, has been revered as the king who did most to unify Britain in the Middle Ages.

Jewish community leaders and most historians support Schama. 'These things are incredibly important,' said Dr Jo Reilly of the Parkes Centre for the study of Jewish and non-Jewish relations at Southampton University. 'So much history is airbrushed out as not being convenient, as challenging national myths. There are many episodes that are not known about in our so-called generous race relations history.'

Martin Davidson, executive producer of the programmes, said: 'We are not bringing out a heritage site gift shop. History should not confirm prejudices. It is somewhere you go not to escape the past but to understand the modern.'

There is growing criticism from ethnic minorities of the idea of 'Britishness' as projected by the heritage industry. The website of the Royal Family features long profiles of the monarchs of England. That of Edward I, who died in 1307, runs to several thousand words but omits to mention the expulsion of Jews.

Black and Asian community leaders also say they have been 'rubbed out' of mainstream histories, with the contributions by black servicemen in the Second World War, or even the pres ence of ethnic minorities in the British Isles, being ignored. 'There is a false perception that Jews and others are newcomers to British shores,' said Reilly. 'Actually they have been here for centuries.'

Schama claims 300 Jewish leaders were hanged in the Tower of London under Edward's reign. Jeremy Ashby, assistant curator at the Tower, said last week that there was no mention of this in any display or literature there. He said he had been unable to find evidence to substantiate the claim. 'The medieval Jews are fascinating and we are researching their imprisonment, but we are not sure this is true.'

Other senior curators take a stronger line. One called such atrocities 'frankly marginal, given the range of what Edward achieved. You have to doubt their relevance and interest to the public.'

jason.burke@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Prize awaits code-crackers
fields.trailText: Forget Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? That's for couch potatoes. Aim high. This weekend one of the most intellectually prestigious cash-prize competitions of all time is drawing to a close - and you still have time to take part.
fields.body:
Forget Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? That's for couch potatoes. Aim high. This weekend one of the most intellectually prestigious cash-prize competitions of all time is drawing to a close - and you still have time to take part.

Simon Singh, the bestselling author of Fermat's Last Theorem and The Code Book , is about to award a sizeable sum of his own money to whichever man, woman or child has made the greatest progress at cracking an arcane series of cryptic ciphers.

Over the past year the race to complete the 10-stage test successfully has become an international obsession, en-snaring both trained crypto-graphers and amateur fans of Singh's work.

'Everywhere I go,' Singh told The Observer on Friday, 'I find people who are involved in cracking the codes I set last year. They want feedback and clues, but I have been very careful to avoid helping anyone.'

Singh, who is currently touring America, has been astounded by interest in the competition. This week he met a woman from San Francisco and a retired gentleman from Baltimore, Maryland, who have both been devoting themselves to the complex series of puzzles for some months.

Early stars included Souraya Dyer, a 14-year-old from Eltham, South London, who topped the leader board a year ago when she was the first to crack the fourth problem.

The writer first set the 10 problems as a codicil to his book about cryptography, The Code Book , published by Fourth Estate. Singh's Code Book is a history of the science of secret codes from Ancient Egypt to the twenty-first century. Each of the codes was designed to exemplify one of the encryption techniques he had explained in the book. These techniques are now also tackled in the television series The Science of Secrecy , which Singh begins to present on Channel 4 this week.

In his 'Cipher Challenge', Singh offered a prize of £10,000 to anyone who could crack the whole set of 10 codes. He also agreed that by 1 October this year he would award £1,000 to the person who had done the best so far. As the competition stands this weekend, no one has completed all the stages.

'The competition has been led, at various points, by a teenager, a therapist, a philosopher and by the Cambridge pure mathematician Andrew Plater.'

Singh emphasises that his 'Cypher Challenge' has never really been about money. The competitors, newcomers and veterans alike, are all inspired by the thrill of the chase. 'Hopefully everyone could solve at least one of the problems. They require a range of skills, imagination as well as some knowledge of computing for the later codes.'

vanessa.thorpe@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Exit director, cue show-stopping entrance by Nunn

fields.headline: Exit director, cue show-stopping entrance by Nunn
fields.trailText: Tense encounters and dramatic exits are making their mark on the Royal National Theatre's new season. So far the explosive action has been off-stage but, according to insiders, delays and strained relationships are threatening the theatre's already shaky financial position.
fields.body:
Tense encounters and dramatic exits are making their mark on the Royal National Theatre's new season. So far the explosive action has been off-stage but, according to insiders, delays and strained relationships are threatening the theatre's already shaky financial position.

Last week the celebrated artistic director, Trevor Nunn, stepped in to take over direction of the theatre's new high-profile production of Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet after the first night had been delayed and the original director, Tim Supple, had stepped aside. Rehearsals for a major new production of Henrik Ibsen's Peer Gynt have also hit trouble. The opening of the new adaptation for the National by Frank McGuinness was scheduled for 24 October but has been delayed to 13 November.

The epic Norwegian work is due to be performed by the same company of actors working on Romeo and Juliet and is a notoriously difficult piece. Irish director Conal Morrison has found the long rehearsal process 'extremely taxing', in the words of one observer, and was forced to take several breaks due to personal problems. The production is now back on course, but the changes to the calendar of performances have created further financial problems for the theatre.

One insider said that, while Nunn still commands huge respect from the actors, his relationships with the theatre's administrators have become strained. The National's finance director, Lou Hodges, left the theatre for good in June after heated discussions with Nunn. He has been replaced, at least temporarily, by a former finance director, Anthony Blackstock, who had left for the British Museum in the late Nineties.

Those opposed to Nunn's regime accuse him of an irresponsible and arrogant attitude. They argue that he leaves decision-making expensively late and cannot get used to the straitened National finances.

'He still hankers after his days at the Royal Shakespeare Theatre in the 1970s,' said one former associate.

Nunn's own production of Anton Chekhov's The Cherry Orchard, starring Vanessa Redgrave and her brother Corin, has won raves from critics, as did Simon Russell Beale's novel interpretation of the role of Hamlet. The production of Speer , a difficult work based on Gitta Sereny's study of Hitler's chief architect, was also much praised. Colleagues who champion Nunn as a creative genius argue that he is simply doing his job.

'Really he is just fulfilling the role of an artistic director. It may sound awful to the public if Trevor replaces a director,' said the playwright Howard Brenton. 'But it is his job to take charge and manage the company.'

One actor appearing in both Romeo and Juliet and Peer Gynt agrees.

'It was jaw-dropping when Trevor came in to talk to us,' he said. 'It came as a complete surpise to us, but he just knew exactly what to do to make the production clearer. We just kept thinking, why didn't anyone think of that before?'

Supple is believed to have taken Nunn's intervention in good part.

'He is an intelligent enough man to put the play first. But it is a sensitive thing which no director would like,' said the actor.

webTitle: Doctors toppled from pedestal by TV series

fields.headline: Doctors toppled from pedestal by TV series
fields.standfirst:
Patients still have a touching faith in their doctors. But more people die from medical errors every year than on the roads, reports Amelia Hill

Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: It took 12-year-old Richie William five days to die after the doctor administered the fatal injection.
fields.body:
It took 12-year-old Richie William five days to die after the doctor administered the fatal injection.

His mother spent the first two days after the mistake trying to make the hospital realise its error and the next three watching her only son slip away. 'He knew exactly what was happening to him. I could see it in his eyes,' said Dolores, his mother. 'I asked him for a kiss right at the end and he immediately pursed up his lips. He was paralysed and couldn't speak, but he understood. He knew that he was dying.'

Richie, who suffered from non-Hodgkins lymphoma, a blood cancer, died in July 1997 after being given a spinal injection of the powerful anti-cancer drug, vincristine.

Days earlier he had been given a 75 per cent chance of recovery and this was to be his last chemotherapy session. 'He had won - he was in remission,' said Dolores. 'It was great. He had even gone back to school for a few days.'

The drug, which should only be injected into a vein, is fatal if injected into the spine, but by the time Dolores managed to convince experts at Great Ormond Street Hospital for Children in London that a mistake had occurred it was too late to save her son.

'Watching one's child die is an appalling thing for any parent, but knowing that they're dying because of one silly, stupid mistake kills you too,' said Dolores.

It was the specialist registrar John Lee who emptied the fatal syringe into Richie's body, but the mistake was the culmination of a series of accidents and misunderstandings which made it inevitable that someone would eventually die the agonising and lingering death Richie was forced to endure.

Despite the recent scandals surrounding the Bristol heart surgeons, gynaecologists Rodney Ledward and Richard Neill, and pathologist James Elwood, few patients question the diagnosis they are given by doctors or the treatment they receive.

'People still have a touching faith in the infallibility of doctors,' said William Notcutt, an anaesthetist at the Great Yarmouth Hospital in Norfolk. 'That pedestal is a dangerous thing: doctors begin to believe their own myth and become unable to accept their own limitations.'

In reality, more people die because of medical errors each year than on the roads: recent research estimated there is a one in 200 chance of being the victim of medical error, while a new study revealed that 320,000 medical mistakes take place in Britain each year, contributing to at least 40,000 deaths.

Why Doctors Make Mistakes, a major four-part Channel 4 documentary starting tomorrow, investigates this litany of preventable deaths and attempts to scale the wall of silence which surrounds medical errors.

'It's remarkably easy to hide mistakes, even quite serious ones,' said Professor James Drife, head of the Royal College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, who admits for the first time in the programme how he caused the death of a newborn baby early in his career through medical error.

'We must be open about our errors and learn from them. We need to convince the medical profession and the public that the only way to improve is to learn from our errors,' he said. 'We have to treasure our mistakes.'

The documentary reveals how fatigue, pressures of time and inexperience account for only a small proportion of medical error. Doctors, many speaking out for the first time, maintain that, unless the British culture of secrecy and denial is swept away, further mistakes are inevitable.

When the mistakes that led to Richie's death were uncovered, for example, the same chain was found to have claimed at least nine further lives in hospitals across the country.

'Every single doctor who has practised for any time at all has made serious errors,' admitted Richard Smith, editor of British Medical Journal . 'There are errors being made on every level in a big way but the British medical profession is still not able to admit that. Only when we admit that can we begin to reduce the numbers.'

When a medical error takes place in a British hospital, experts admit that the instinctive reaction of their profession is to target and weed out the doctor at the centre of the scandal. Such defensive reactions are, in part, a response to the growing problem of litigation, which is creating a culture of guilt and punishment. But, encouraged by a US group of radical experts, a quiet revolution in medical thinking is gaining momentum.

'The medical profession is currently obsessed with blame,' said Dr Don Berwick, leader of the group, whose formalised structure of communication, which obliges medical experts to speak up and discuss errors, has transformed accident and emergency departments throughout America. 'That has to change. Medicine has robbed itself of the opportunity to examine its mistakes, condemning it to repeating the same ones again and again. But doctors are humans, and as such they need to have a system that will catch the mistakes they are bound to make, dealing with them quickly and efficiently.'

His theory has revolutionised hundreds of hospitals in America and is finally attracting attention in Britain. Experts admit that it is about time. Early on the morning of 13 December, 1995, seven-year-old Ben Kolb checked into a Florida hospital for a routine operation to remove a benign tumour from his ear. Within hours he was dead, killed by a mix-up of syringes. Instead of concealing or obfuscating, George McLain and Doni Haas, the doctors involved, launched an investigation, admitted their fault and changed the system to ensure it could never happen again.

McLain now tours America, encouraging the medical profession to open up. 'It's amazing that we're still held up on this pedestal for having been open and honest about what happened and dealing with it as decent human beings,' he said. 'It scares me to think that, if we're the exception, my God, what is going on out there?'

amelia.hill@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Tory with a tartan tinge
fields.standfirst:
Deputy Conservative leader Annabel Goldie sees a lot of promise in Holyrood, reports Arnold Kemp
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: If the Scottish Conservative Party has a new face and a new future, it is personified by Annabel Goldie, a friendly, jolly woman who wears her ideology lightly, has cast aside her opposition to home rule and wants to make the new Parliament in Edinburgh a successful part of an evolving British constitution.
fields.body:
If the Scottish Conservative Party has a new face and a new future, it is personified by Annabel Goldie, a friendly, jolly woman who wears her ideology lightly, has cast aside her opposition to home rule and wants to make the new Parliament in Edinburgh a successful part of an evolving British constitution.

Only three years ago the Tories, reviled as an 'English party', were wiped out in Scotland at the general election. Now Goldie, 50, deputy Conservative leader in the Parliament and MSP for the West of Scotland, believes they are on track to win back seats both for Westminster and Edinburgh. Earlier this year they shook Labour by winning the Ayr by-election, adding a directly elected member to their 18 list MSPs.

She says: 'It is one of the consummate ironies of politics that devolution has been the instrument of renaissance for the Conservatives in Scotland.' It was right, she argues, to oppose it in principle but now it has become reality the party has embraced it with enthusiasm and 'great spirit'.

At first sight Goldie seems an archetypal West of Scotland Unionist. She is a lawyer and an elder of the Kirk. She is active in the councils of the Salvation Army, sits on the court of her old university, Strathclyde. She is a deputy lieutenant of her native county, Renfrewshire.

Her father, a stockbroker and later a shopkeeper, was 58 when she was born. And although she was clearly influenced by his table talk on politics, she says she developed her own political convictions.

She recalls: 'I was about 13 or 14, and Harold Wilson had just come to power after 13 years of Conservative rule. My interest was sparked by the sheer innovation of what was happening.

'I remember coming to my own conclusions - that nationalisation was a bizarre way to run an economy, that comprehensive education was a strange way to encourage the best in young minds. I remember thinking "I don't think this is a correct way to run a country at all".'

But she did not become involved in active politics for many years, concentrating first on establishing herself in a Glasgow legal firm.

Gradually politics took hold. Although Westminster held no attractions ('I love my life in Scotland'), she stood at the 1992 general election for Renfrew West and Inverclyde, giving Labour's Tommy Graham a close run.

She emerged as a healing figure in the party after a period of turbulence caused by disputes between radicals and traditionalists. She became vice-chairman in 1992 and chairman in 1997.

Goldie is an admirer of Malcolm Forsyth. And, though she admires in politicians a willingness to have a vision, no matter how confrontational, she says: 'Politics is the art of the possible. She recognises the Tories will benefit more from Labour's difficulties in England than in Scotland where there is the SNP to share the spoils. But she says: 'What is startling is the swiftness with which Labour's weaknesses have become manifest.'

She explains: 'This is a government that has been there for only three years. The Conservatives were there for 18 years. She says William Hague, from 'very, very difficult circumstances,' has regrouped his party and made it an Opposition presence. 'Where Labour has been extremely short-sighted is not to recognise the potency of public opinion. Not to recognise that so soon before a general election some would say is political naivety which is quite startling.'

She attacks the Scottish Executive not only because it is 'arrogant' but because it is not sufficiently free-thinking. Labour, she believes, is afraid of its creation. She says the Executive is perceived as a 'puppet of London'.

'It's a control regime, and I think that ethos of control comes from the Prime Minister - I don't think there's any question of that. The Scottish Executive feels inhibited. And that to me is highly, highly dangerous because that could be a repressive influence on devolution instead of allowing devolution to breathe, and evolve.'

The other consequence of devolution, she believes, is that 'as time goes past and as circumstances emerge there probably will be a need to look at some of the powers and see if any amendment is needed.'

She sees the UK constitution moving towards a 'lopsided' federalism. 'If you said to any constitutional expert, how would you devise a form of federal government for the United Kingdom, this is not what he would come up with because it lacks the equilibrium a federal structure enjoys in other countries... But it may all be part of the evolution of the constitution.'

She recognises the Nationalists, under their new leader John Swinney, believe the Parliament is a passport to independence. She says there may have to be a 'vigorous' debate to test whether such an idea would not be 'dangerous lunacy'. She thinks it is the duty of three unionist parties in the Parliament to resist any such idea.

For Goldie herself the Parliament is clearly an absorbing experience. What the Tories offer, she says, is a 'manageable' agenda. She promises 'prudence' and warns against unsustainable spending programmes.

For all her criticisms of the Executive, she remains hopeful about the Parliament's future. It has the chance to make meaningful improvements to public services, to support the university sector and to reverse Scotland's indifference to the enterprise culture. 'And we can do all this within the United Kingdom. There's a very, very exciting future.'

fields.headline: Labour bounces back to 11pc lead
fields.standfirst:
Observer Poll of Polls

Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Labour has bounced back to an 11-point lead over the Tories, according to an unpublished NOP survey conducted last week. A comparable poll only a week earlier put the Conservatives three points ahead.
fields.body:
Labour has bounced back to an 11-point lead over the Tories, according to an unpublished NOP survey conducted last week. A comparable poll only a week earlier put the Conservatives three points ahead.

The latest poll will come as a relief to Tony Blair, and a disappointment to William Hague who had hoped to keep his party's advantage for this week's Tory conference.

It is the second survey to show Labour back in the lead. A Mori/ Times poll, conducted before the Prime Minister's speech to Labour's conference last week, reported Labour two points ahead.

The new NOP research was mostly conducted following Blair's speech. It is part of a telephone survey of 1,000 people carried out every Tuesday and Wednesday, in part to track voting intentions for the Labour Party. According to party sources this puts Labour on 44 per cent, the Conservatives on 33 and the Liberal Democrats on 17.

The previous week's figures were: Tory 40 per cent, Labour 37, Lib Dems 19.

As ever, the results of any one survey should be treated with care. Individual figures are prone to sampling error; and Labour's lead may reflect a short-term blip following Blair's speech. If the Tories present a united front in Bournemouth, they too might enjoy a 'conference bounce'.

Nevertheless, NOP does suggest Labour is over its worst fuel crisis unpopularity and that the Tory peak is past.

This is confirmed by council by-elections held last Thursday. Labour's share of the vote held up well in contests in seats it was defending in Bexley, Camden and West Sussex. These results are broadly in line with elections before the summer holidays, and contrast markedly with contests 10 days ago when Labour was hammered.

Meanwhile, the latest Kellner/Sanders Index, a computer analysis of published polls now updated to cover the immediate aftermath of the crisis, has the Tories on 38 per cent, a four-point lead. Even on those figures, commissioned by YouGov, the new e-democracy website, (www.yougov.com) Hague would almost certainly not become Prime Minister.

On conventional assumptions of a uniform swing, Labour would still hold 309 seats, compared with the Tories' 278 and the Lib Dems' 41. The Tories need a seven-point lead to be reasonably sure of becoming the largest party, and a 10-point lead to be sure of an overall majority.

If Labour did end up with 309 seats, it would be 21 short of the 330 any party needs to outvote all others. In those circumstances, Blair would be tempted to seek a coalition with the Liberal Democrats. Together, they would hold 350 seats, and enjoy an overall majority of 41.

If history is any guide, Labour ought to recover. In comparison with past governments, a low point of 34 per cent is good going. Leaving aside the two short parliaments of 1964-6 and March-October 1974, every previous government for 40 years has sunk lower than this, and then recovered sharply at the following general election.

fields.headline: BP branded 'hypocrite' over safety breaches
fields.trailText: Oil giant BP has been accused of 'rank hypocrisy' after major safety breaches at British sites that risked thousands of lives.
fields.body:
Oil giant BP has been accused of 'rank hypocrisy' after major safety breaches at British sites that risked thousands of lives.

During the recent fuel crisis, BP gave concern for the safety of employees as its reason for not ordering drivers to deliver fuel. Yet, in spite of record profits of £4,000 a second because of the soaring oil price, BP put staff and public in danger with cost-cutting measures.

The Health and Safety Executive (HSE) has launched an investigation into BP's 'corporate culture'. Safety breaches include:

 Three major incidents last spring at its Grangemouth refinery complex in Scotland led to emergency alerts. In June, a fire broke out which took seven hours to control. Grangemouth contains 200 tonnes of highly flammable chemicals. Earlier in June a pipe exploded, blasting tonnes of earth on to a main road. In May the plant was shut after its main power cable failed. There were seven major safety alerts in the past 14 months at Grangemouth;

 The HSE was so alarmed by reductions in staffing levels at BP's Coryton refinery in Essex that in January 1999 it ordered the firm to stop operating part of its plant because it believed it could not shut it down in an emergency. In April 1999 the company was prosecuted after two contractors were overcome by nitrogen fumes;

 BP's main North Sea oil platform was shut down last summer by the HSE after two gas leaks within six days were described as having been 'near catastrophes';

 Serious breaches of health and safety regulations at BP's Sullom Voe oil terminal in the Shetlands in July 1999 led the government watchdog to demand measures 'to prevent major accidents and limit their consequences to persons and the environment'.

Michael Connarty, Labour MP for Falkirk East where Grangemouth is located, has accused BP of 'hypocrisy and double standards'. He said: 'During the fuel crisis BP was telling us it was so concerned to protect the safety of its tanker drivers that it wouldn't force them to deliver petrol. But after the number of safety alerts over the last year workers have been worried sick there could be another major incident where they won't be so lucky. It is amazing that no one has been killed.'

At Grangemouth, 600 workers will lose their jobs by 2002.

BP's record has also come under fire after breaches of pollution legislation. This month's edition of Ends - the respected environmental magazine - contains an attack on the oil giant's environmental record. This will embarrass the company, which has recently spent millions on rebranding itself to promote its green credentials by jettisoning its shield logo and using a sunflower.

At its Sullom Voe terminal BP breached rules over how much oil may be discharged into the sea 17 times in the year 1999-2000. A Scottish Environment Protection Agency spokesman said the breaches were minor, but 'the fact there were 17 over a year makes them significant'. The Institute of Environmental Management and Assessment found them serious enough to withdraw certification of the terminal - the first time this has happened in the UK.

In May 1999, BP faced a record fine for pollution in Scotland after it overfilled a tank of the Scottish Borders Council recycling centre. This contaminated the River Tweed, and BP was fined £15,000 and had to pay £200,000 in clean-up costs. Grangemouth has had a 24 per cent increase in discharge of pollutants and a fourfold increase in oil losses from spills.

A BP spokesman said: 'Unfortunately accidents can happen. But, regardless of any cost-cutting, safety is never compromised. When an accident happens our priority is to find out why and work with the authorities to ensure it never happens again.'

fields.headline: Sordid death of Top Gun
fields.standfirst:
A battered corpse and a crossbow bolt: Henry McDonald reports on the strange end of a loyalist assassin

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Every year during the last decade of the Troubles the Ulster Defence Association - Northern Ireland's largest Protestant paramilitary group - held their own ghoulish version of the Oscars.
fields.body:
Every year during the last decade of the Troubles the Ulster Defence Association - Northern Ireland's largest Protestant paramilitary group - held their own ghoulish version of the Oscars.

And the star turn at every annual ceremony for the assassins of the UDA in the 1990s for the 'best' assassin of the year was a 30-year-old loyalist from Belfast's Shankill Road nicknamed 'Top Gun'.

Stephen McKeag almost always received the trophy for being the 'top operator' among the UDA's assassination squads in the Greater Belfast. The 30-year-old UDA man according to RUC officers killed at least 12 people, most of them ordinary Catholics, during a 10-year campaign that terrorised the nationalist community in the city.

For these exploits McKeag was given a plaque made by UDA inmates in the Maze prison with his name and an AK-47 assault rifle engraved in silver.

Last weekend, the man who ran the UDA's notorious 'C' company on the Shankill Road while its charismatic leader, Johnny 'Mad Dog' Adair, was in prison, died an ignominious death at his house in loyalist North Belfast.

At first the UDA believed he had been killed by the rival Ulster Volunteer Force with whom they have been locked in a murderous feud since late August, which has claimed three lives and saw more than 900 people driven from their homes.

But it has since emerged McKeag, a legend to young extreme loyalists, died alone, in all probability from a drugs overdose, covered in bruises, alone in his home. Mystery still hangs over his death given that he appeared to have been beaten up and a crossbow bolt was found wedged in the wall of the room where his body was discovered. His life however, in particular those 10 or so years he spent at the cutting edge of the UDA's killing machine, embodies the sub-culture of sectarianism and violence that characterised the second generation of working-class Protestants that emerged from loyalist ghettos during the Troubles.

McKeag, like others from 'C' company, graduated from the street violence of the skinhead cult to the junior UDA, the Ulster Young Militants. They came into their own at the end of 1989 when a major investigation into collusion between loyalist paramilitaries and the security forces led by the Metropolitan police commissioner Sir John Stevens led to several arrests of key UDA figures.

A number of those charged with terrorist offences such as Tommy 'Tucker' Lyttle were regarded by younger loyalists as soft touches who had allowed the UDA's armed campaign to be wound down. Lyttle, it later emerged, was an informer for the RUC Special Branch.

With the old guard in the UDA out of the way, the younger, more militant members seized control of the organisation's ruling body, the Inner Council.

Once in power, these young, visceral sectarians embarked on a murder campaign directed at times against republican activists but more often simply against ordinary members of the nationalist community. By 1991 and 1992 loyalists, principally the UDA, were outkilling the IRA for the first time.

McKeag became one of the UDA's most important assassins in the period between 1990 and the loyalist ceasefire four years later. Of the dozen or so Catholics he murdered, the RUC can pinpoint two specific incidents. In 1993 the UDA shot dead a young shop assistant in a chemist on the Springfield Road in West Belfast. Their intended target had been the sister of a prominent Sinn Fein official but as so often happens in Northern Ireland the killers picked the wrong person. Eyewitnesses who saw the murder gang drive off towards Lanark Way, a main arterial route linking Catholic and Protestant west Belfast, reported that the killers shouted inexplicably: 'Follow the yellow brick road.' One of the gunmen was Stephen McKeag.

A year later UDA gunmen entered a hairdresser's shop on the Donegall Road, just off the Falls, and shot dead Sean Hughes. The RUC believe the gunman was McKeag even though the case against him collapsed in court due to the judge's doubts over witness identification.

Yet even after the UDA along with the UVF called their ceasefire on October 1994 - just three months after the IRA's historic cessation - McKeag continued to kill. The green light to reactivate the UDA killer gangs came about following the murder of Billy 'King Rat' Wright inside the Maze prison two days after Christmas 1997.

Wright had been expelled from the UVF the previous year and formed the anti-ceasefire Loyalist Volunteer Force. His plan had been to build a new alliance with those UDA battalions such as 'C' company on the Shankill which were sceptical about the ceasefire and the peace process. Wright won the admiration and trust of a number of young loyalists including McKeag.

By this time McKeag was now the 'commanding officer' of 'C' company because Johnny Adair was in prison, facing 15 years for directing acts of terrorism. Just over a week after the Irish National Liberation Army shot Wright dead in the Maze, McKeag and his colleagues decided to break the ceasefire. They attacked a number of Catholic pubs including the Clifton Tavern in north Belfast, nicknamed fatally by local nationalists as 'the suicide inn'. During that attack in January 1998 McKeag shot dead Edmund Trainor and wounded three other customers.

Such was his standing within the violent underworld of loyalist paramilitarism that McKeag even usurped Johnny Adair as a hero figure. When Adair was released early from prison under the terms of the Good Friday Agreement in September last year the LVF held a welcome home party for him in Lurgan, Co Armagh. Adair was given a rousing ovation from LVF members and supporters inside a social club. But this was nothing compared to the standing ovation awarded to McKeag, who was called on to the stage and smothered in praise for his role in sectarian assassinations.

Yet within six months 'Top Gun' had fallen out of favour with 'C' company's leadership. A series of brawls inside loyalist shebeens and the beating of a number of women involved in a local dispute resulted in McKeag being ordered off the Shankill by his UDA colleagues. He only came back to live in the area when the inter-loyalist feud erupted in late August. Adair and his comrades thought he might be useful in their war with the Shankill UVF.

McKeag, however, was understood to be opposed to killing loyalists, albeit rival ones. He took no part in the feuding and according to UVF sources was not regarded as a target.

It is known that McKeag had become increasingly addicted to cocaine and was taking the drug when he died. The danger of snorting huge amounts of cocaine was compounded by the fact that he was on highly potent pain killers for injuries sustained during a motorcycle accident in north Belfast six months ago. The car his bike crashed into belonged to a senior member of the UVF, although both factions regarded the collision as an accident.

Among the hundreds of wreaths left at his graveside in Roselawn cemetery last week were tiny silver and gold guns - a token of his other addiction, murder. Two wreaths, 10 foot wide, spelled out 'Top Gun'.
