fields.headline: Only the right e-envoy can put Britain's mouse in order
fields.standfirst:
Special report: e-finance
Net news
fields.trailText: Technology can never be a magic wand. The science of Star Trek offers no foundation on which to build a networked society, nor any clue on how to manage the transition of UK business from a manufacturing- to an information-based economy.
fields.body:
Technology can never be a magic wand. The science of Star Trek offers no foundation on which to build a networked society, nor any clue on how to manage the transition of UK business from a manufacturing- to an information-based economy.

It is the Prime Minister's wish to make Britain the best place in Europe for e-business. In many commercial respects we have already arrived. However, as a political ambition, this raises much more than a question of simple business evolution, as revealed by the recent launch of the UK Online project, which aims to digitally enfranchise the entire population in two years.

As a society, if we are to embrace both the tyranny and promise of the internet, every institution, public and private, will have to face huge challenges for which many are unprepared. Earlier this year, Tony Blair appointed senior civil servant Alex Allan as the UK's first e-envoy. Allan was given the Herculean challenge of bridging the gap between business, government and technology; the greater part of of this involved dragging many public sector agencies from the nineteenth straight into the twentyfirst century.

Allan has resigned for personal reasons, and this leaves a question mark over the succession. Should a role as important as this be a Cabinet appointment, a civil service appointment, or an appointment based on merit, experience and ability alone?

Several names have already been suggested. Jim Norton, director of e-commerce at the Institute of Directors, narrowly lost to Allan on the first occasion and appears reluctant to include his name again. Norton has said the e-envoy's role is not one job but several and that there 'are only so many hours in the day'. On Thursday he endorsed the surprise candidacy of Richard Barrington, the e-envoy's director of industry, a technology evangelist on secondment from Sun Microsystems and a popular choice for IT companies and publications.

Barrington works alongside Anne Steward, director of the CITU, and another strong potential candidate. On secondment from the Australian government, Steward is the author of a review of government IT projects and has played an important part in the design of the UK On-line portal.

More likely to be the first choice of the civil service, Steward lacks the soap-box evangelism of Barrington, but between them they have much of the political and technical experience the role requires.

If reports are correct, Blair appears to be considering expanding the role of Patricia Hewitt, the small business Minister, to include the office of the e-envoy. Creating a place for an e-Cabinet Minister may not be wise, as a single point of ownership for the collective responsibility of our digital future looks about as attractive as responsibility for the Millennium Dome.

Following on from an embattled party conference, a clever choice of e-envoy could be a positive result for the Prime Minister and offer a convenient boost to business and public confidence in the Government's plans for a digital economy - finally wiping away the shadow of the RIP Bill and other contentious e-business-related legislation.

The last thing I would advise Blair to consider is another political or civil service appointment to a role that requires its own unique degree of latitude and independence.

There is no map to follow in marking out the hazy boundaries of a wired society. The role of e-envoy demands an energetic person, one capable of expressing a collective vision of progress and policy, supported by a management team that can inspire, encourage and facilitate the enormous changes required by both public and private sector initiatives.

With the open competition for the post starting in just over a week, and an appointment expected towards the end of next month, it's time the Government demonstrated evidence of thinking 'outside of the box'.

fields.headline: Driving in my (telematic) car...
fields.standfirst:
New technology is set to revolutionise life behind the wheel, writes Jamie Doward

Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: New technology is set to revolutionise life behind the wheel, writes Jamie Doward
fields.body:
Picture the future frontline of the automobile war. Scene one. You're gridlocked on the M25 for more than an hour. By the time you come off Britain's longest car park you've bought some shares, booked a restaurant and arranged to view a house for sale nearby. As you leave the motorway a voice from the car's onboard computer directs you to the property.

Scene two. Your car has overturned. You're unconscious, but the airbag has cushioned the impact, and triggered an alarm system which alerted the emergency services. The ambulance will find you, because the car has a global positioning system.

Scene three. The petrol tank is low. A display beamed on to your rear-view mirror shows you the nearest petrol station which is offering you a free car wash.

Scene four. Although you don't know it, a car accident 15 miles ahead means you are heading for long delays. A screen built into your dashboard plots an alternative route. Meanwhile, your engine's computer diagnostics system uses the internet to book the car in for a check-up at your local garage

Fanciful? Maybe now, but not in five years' time. Telematics - providing information and services to cars using telecommunications - is new in Britain now, but it is set to be the Next Big Thing. It is already being talked about in the hushed tones analysts used to describe e-commerce five years ago.

The predictions made for the exponential growth rate of telematics business are astounding. One of the biggest players in the market, US-based firm Delphi, suggests that half of all new cars could have telematic devices fitted as standard by 2005.

The Economist Intelligence Unit predicts that more than 4 million cars sold in Western Europe in 2005 will have onboard navigation systems. And analysts at Deutsche Bank predicts that the telematics market will grow from $1 billion in 1998 to $42bn in 2010.

Turning cars into mobile super computers is driven by forecasts of unprecedented congestion. Telematics help drivers find ways around the jams or, failing that, connects them to the wired world so that while stuck in traffic, they can communicate as efficiently as if they were at home or in the office. After all, some people practically live in their cars already. US consumers spend a whopping 500 million hours a week in their vehicles. In Europe, between 50 and 70 per cent of all mobile phone minutes are accounted for by drivers.

Apart from cutting journey times, telematics' proponents argue that it reduces anxiety. 'When drivers know the nature and extent of a problem, they get less stressed about it,' said Bill McIntosh, financial director at Traffic-master, the UK company rolling out a pan-European vehicle navigation system.

The firm's roadside sensors monitor the state of traffic. The information is processed and sent to drivers, via either mobile phones or devices built into cars. Trafficmaster users can also opt to pay for a tracking system that monitors vehicles' whereabouts - handy for, say, haulage firms worried about thefts.

But it is not just technically savvy companies such as Trafficmaster which are excited about telematics. The big motor manufacturers, are disciples too, hoping that sales of this hi-tech kit will improve their tight margins.

General Motors is attempting to dominate the market with its OnStar system. Originally available only on GM luxury models, OnStar has been developed from a navigation and emergency response system to embrace other multimedia functions, such as video and email.

Significantly, GM is offering other carmakers the chance to fit OnStar, which suggests the firm will soon look to float off this business.

Analysts at Deutsche Bank predicted last May that OnStar could generate revenues of $4bn by 2005.

Meanwhile, rival Ford's Connect telematics system could be worth $3.2bn in five years. Earlier this year Ford unveiled prototype cars called 24-7s. These all have integrated telematic systems which, apart from turning vehicles into something like Kit, the camp-sounding onboard computer featured in the TV series Knight Rider, allow you to 'personalise' your car interior using a voice activation system. Want a pink dashboard? Just tell the car that's the mood you're in.

The Economist Intelligence Unit says around 20 per cent of the value of an executive's car is based on its electronics systems. By 2005 this will reach 30 per cent.

In addition, motor manufacturers know that by developing telematics systems they can can cut content deals with information providers and generate subscription revenues, so easing the cyclical nature of their industry. Ford already has a deal with AOL, while GM has Yahoo! on its side.

But will the likes of Ford and GM be able dominate the telematics industry in the long run? McIntosh said: 'The debate will be about who controls the customers. It will be interesting to see whether it is the car manufacturers or the telecoms companies. It's difficult to see how that works out, because the two sectors' planning cycles are very different, and putting anything into a car takes up to five years.'

So far the car industry as a whole has been extremely slow in cornering the market. Only 2 per cent of car phones are fitted by the manufacturer; the rest are fitted later.

Big mobile phone firms are on the prowl. Vodafone, for instance, has a dedicated telematics arm, and is planning to launch its own vehicle tracking service. The mobile phone giant is talking to a number of carmakers about supplying onboard telematic systems as standard, although it declines to comment on specifics.

But the danger is that drivers could soon have too much information. 'The industry needs to be focused,' McIntosh said. 'All this infotainment such as "where's the nearest hotel, petrol station or golf course" - where do you draw the line? Clearly, there is an issue of driver overload. There's only a certain amount of information that they can efficiently handle. Safety analysts are now starting to look at telematics.'

Nevertheless, telematics is ripe for growth. The words 'information superhighway' have just taken on a whole new meaning.

webTitle: This bankspeak may make sense in the end

fields.headline: This bankspeak may make sense in the end
fields.trailText: It is easy to understand the Bank of Scotland's irritation with the City. Until it launched its bid for NatWest, it was seen as the best-run of the British banks, with an enviable record for expanding its business while shrinking its costs.
fields.body:
It is easy to understand the Bank of Scotland's irritation with the City. Until it launched its bid for NatWest, it was seen as the best-run of the British banks, with an enviable record for expanding its business while shrinking its costs. Its move for NatWest looked like a master stroke - no management team was better equipped to sort out problems at the English clearer.

But as soon as Royal Bank of Scotland stole its idea and secured NatWest for itself, investors have been fretting about where BoS's growth will come from now and speculating about who it will make a bid for next - that is, if it is not bid for firs t.

Chief executive Peter Burt's response to this is so familiar that even he sounds weary about repeating it. The bank has so much scope for organic growth that it does not need to do deals, but will continue to look at opportunities as they arise.

Again, the results backed his strategy. Loans to customers grew by 20 per cent in the six months to August, led by a spectacular performance from business banking; profit before tax grew by 14 per cent; and costs as a proportion of income - the standard measure of banking efficiency - fell to a record low of 46 per cent.

Burt is confident it can continue to grow at this rate. Its market share has doubled in the past 12 years but is a still a relatively small 7.25 per cent. The internet is making it easier for conventional banks, as well as virtual ones, to gain customers. Bank of Scotland hopes to capitalise on this with a new product, similar to Woolwich's Open Plan, allowing customers to put all their financial affairs in one basket.

Barclays was convinced enough by Woolwich's product to pay £4.5 billion for it and Bank of Scotland claims that, Woolwich apart, rivals are 18 months behind it. But investors are unlikely to set much store by Bank of Scotland's version until it is actually up and running.

In the meantime, the focus will be on margins, which slipped to 2.47 per cent from 2.85 last time. The bank talks about technical factors, in-cluding such bankspeak as credit spread and the sterling yield curve, which could reverse to produce a one-off gain. But behind all that, pressure from new entrants and the internet will continue to force margins down.

Of course, other banks will not be immune from that, and rivals such as Barclays, whose margins are a much fatter 3.2 per cent, have much further to fall. Its loan growth is running at a much more pedestrian 5 per cent, which greatly reduces the scope to make up in volume what you give up in value. The only place it is ahead of Bank of Scotland is in costs - these account for 57p in every £1 of income, making it almost a quarter less efficient than Bank of Scotland.

Of course, that could mean that Barclays has plenty of scope for improvement while Bank of Scotland will struggle to maintain its performance. But history suggests that the good ones simply get better while the mediocre struggle to improve significantly .

Burt's denial of any takeover interest prompted a fall in its share price last week. But those who buy shares on boring fundamentals such as performance and management should invest in Bank of Scotland.

Hard choices

MIKE SMITH, chief executive of Rank Group, should be congratulated for the speed with which he has tidied up the messy and inefficient conglomerate. In just 18 months, he has raised more than £1.5 billion from selling businesses such as Odeon cinemas and Butlins holiday camps, which were finally ditched last week.

That has brought debt down from a crippling £1.5 billion to just £140 million, despite a 10 per cent share buy-back. Annual cashflow is now running at a similar level. Unfortunately for Smith, that was the easy part. The really tough bit will be persuading the City of the attractions of the bits that are left behind.

At the moment, that comprises three divisions: gaming, including Mecca Bingo and Grosvenor Casinos, Hard Rock and Deluxe, the US film processing and video duplication business. Schroder Salomon Smith Barney is, however, believed to have been appointed to find buyers for the latter and, assuming a respectable offer is forthcoming, Rank will soon be left with just the first two.

At first glance, they look decent enough businesses. Operating profits at Mecca rose 35 per cent, while Hard Rock increased by 20 per cent in the first six months of this year. But gambling is hardly the kind of business to set the City alight - casinos are notoriously unpredictable, while bingo, despite Rank's success in attracting a younger clientele, is mature.

Squeezing growth from Hard Rock will be equally difficult. Indeed, the first-half performance owed much to cost-cutting and new openings. Like-for-like sales were down by 3.3 per cent, although this was an improvement on the 9.2 per cent decline suffered last year .

Smith has said little about what he intends to do with the money. A cynic would say that reflects lack of options.

He says he intends investing in internet gambling, but that will not absorb much money. There may be a few casinos to buy but, unless it makes a decisive move overseas, there would be no need for major investment.

Hard Rock is absorbing some cash, both for refurbishments and for initiatives such as Hard Rock hotels. But Hard Rock trades partly on its exclusivity - it would never aim to be as ubiquitous as Burger King - so it is not going to need massive investment either.

The work involved in unravelling the consequences of previous spending sprees, including the disastrous acquisition of the Tom Cobb-leigh pub chain, should be enough to deter Smith from adding more businesses just for the sake of it.

That leaves one option: give the money back to shareholders. Rank has permission to buy back 15 per cent of its shares, but that would absorb less than £200m. Smith should augment that with a special dividend to bring the total to at least £500m. That would show he is serious about adding to shareholder value.

In the meantime, income seekers should consider buying the shares. Given Rank's financial position, the 7.5 per cent yield is looking pretty secure.

webTitle: Trouble by the trolley-load for embattled supermarkets

fields.headline: Trouble by the trolley-load for embattled supermarkets
fields.trailText: Three new bosses, a foreign takeover and a disastrous British one, a collapse in margins, even a merger of the fiercely independent Co-Operative retailers. These are just some of the upheavals that have shaken the food retailing industry in the 26 months since the Office of Fair Trading started its inquiry into supermarkets.
fields.body:
Three new bosses, a foreign takeover and a disastrous British one, a collapse in margins, even a merger of the fiercely independent Co-Operative retailers. These are just some of the upheavals that have shaken the food retailing industry in the 26 months since the Office of Fair Trading started its inquiry into supermarkets.

That, the companies say, is the ultimate proof that the industry is anything but a cosy cartel, conspiring to rip-off customers wherever they can. The evidence certainly gives some support to that argument.

The only two of the big quoted supermarket chains to have come through the past two years with no change in management are Tesco, which was already the market leader when the inquiry started, and Wm Morrison, the regional store which dominates parts of the north of England.

It is surely no coincidence that they are also the only companies to have managed to increase their profits and keep their margins stable - at 5.9 per cent for Tesco's UK operations and a handsome 6.5 per cent at Morrison's.

Elsewhere, there has been chaos. Somerfield, which was just completing its merger with Kwik Save when the OFT moved in, has become expert at delivering profit warnings and not much more. The boss was ejected, along with much of the post-merger strategy. He joined the bosses of Sainsbury and Safeway, both also deemed to have lost the retail touch, on the supermarket scrap heap. Safeway reckons that a typical shopping basket, which cost around £80 when the inquiry started, would now cost around £77, or £72 if you include special promotions. fields.headline: Big five 'prey on shoppers'
fields.standfirst: Competition report finds stores acting against public interest. Paul Farrelly on the findings of the 'Rip-Off Britain' inquiry
fields.trailText: It is the biggest competition inquiry ever mounted in Britain. Commissioned by the Labour government in April last year, the subject was unashamedly populist.
fields.body:
It is the biggest competition inquiry ever mounted in Britain. Commissioned by the Labour government in April last year, the subject was unashamedly populist.

In 'Rip-Off Britain', supermarket giants stood accused of milking customers and suppliers to line their own pockets. Not only were we paying more for our food than foreigners, it was claimed, big retailers were also profiting from farmers' misfortune, and bleeding our town centres dry.

The results of the Competition Commission's 16-month inquiry, yet to be published, run to thousands of pages. It has generated one of the biggest paper mountains Whitehall has seen: 400 submissions, over 1,500 detailed responses and the results of 50 individual hearings around the country.

A dozen of those hearings took place with the country's 'big five' chains - Tesco, Sainsbury, Asda, Safeway and Morrison's - which mounted a fierce rearguard attack to blunt the report's findings. Their lobbying may yet mean they get off pretty much scot-free.

In the report, a copy of which has been obtained by The Observer, the Commission finds the big five guilty of harming smaller grocers and restricting the choice of vulnerable consumers - such as the disabled, people on low incomes and the elderly with no cars - by flogging staples such as bread and milk at rock-bottom prices.

'The selling on a persistent basis, by Asda, Morrison's, Safeway, Sainsbury and Tesco, of certain frequently purchased products either below cost (that is at a negative gross margin) or at retail prices that do not cover all direct costs, operates against the public interest,' it says.

Customers in the South East, East Anglia and West Midlands, in particular, also pay more for their shopping: three of the chains use their power to set different prices across the country. Tesco's prices varied by as much as 9 per cent, the report finds.

'The setting by Safeway, Sainsbury and Tesco of retail prices across different stores in different geographical areas in the light of local competitive conditions, such variation not being related to costs, operates against the public interest,' it says.

But on each count, the Commission concludes that it is powerless to stop them. In France and Ireland, for instance, prohibition of predatory pricing has just not worked. Forcing a national pricing policy on firms is un workable. Displaying thousands of prices on the internet would be too onerous.

In some areas, the giants have massive market shares: over 50 per cent for Tesco in Uxbridge, Milton Keynes, Cambridge, Twickenham and Salisbury. The same goes for Sainsbury in south-west London and for Safeway in Dumfries. Yet the 'nuclear option' for tackling regional monopolies - the forced sale of stores - is firmly ruled out.

Of course, Stephen Byers, the Trade and Industry Secretary, can overrule the commissioners. But even on its one big recommendation, the report anticipates trouble. Forcing the big five, in areas where they are already strong, to obtain Office of Fair Trading approval for big new stores of over 1,000 sq metres would help safeguard competition, it says. But fresh legislation is likely to be needed for the DTI to act.

'As this recommendation does not follow from adverse findings on either of the complex monopoly situations that we identified, nor from facts found during the course of our enquiry, we recognise that it cannot form the basis of enforceable action by the Secretary of State,' the Commission says.

For supermarket suppliers, however, the news is better. Following many complaints, the Commission identified 52 different types of practice where the big chains have used their power to turn the screw on suppliers. In 'a climate of fear', however, none is prepared to be named in case it is blacklisted.

Many of the practices - from charging for shelf space, to coercing discounts and restricting dealings with other retailers - distort competition and operate against the public interest, the report concludes.

On this score, the industry has already moved to head off criticism. Following farmers' protests, six chains are now in talks with the National Farmers' Union and the Ministry of Agriculture over a voluntary code of practice.

The report sets out 10 provisions such a code should take in, including a ban on any form of shelf-space payment, interference with the supplier's other business activities and unfair alterations to supply contracts. Controversially, however, it stops short of advocating tough new laws. Instead, it proposes that the code should have OFT approval and provide for resolution of disputes by an 'independent party'.

'We hope all the major buyers will participate in drawing up the code, but whether or not they do so, they should be required to comply with it,' the Commission says.

The conclusions are likely to irk small farmers in particular. On the main charge of screwing the farmer but keeping checkout prices high, the chains are largely exonerated. The real price of food, indeed, has fallen 9.4 per cent over the past decade. Nor, the report concludes, is the industry making excess profits. The pressure recently has been downwards.

It will be music to the industry's ears that the Commission's own customer survey indicates a 'high degree of satisfaction' from shoppers. And Rip-Off Britain is not quite what we imagined. 'Our international price comparison showed that, even though UK prices are higher than those in France, Germany and Holland, the difference can be fully explained by exchange rates, perceived quality differences in own-label products and higher UK land costs,' the report says.

This weekend, the industry may breathe a sigh of relief. But the chains will be red-faced at many further revelations about controversial practices. Despite the supermarkets' denials, for instance, the report finds Tesco, Sainsbury and Safeway are less likely to drop their prices when competing with each other locally than other big stores.

The Commission clears the chains of wildly profiteering on own brands. But, on average, they hold back a third of the cost savings to boost mar gins. The only chain to pass on the whole saving was Morrison's. At the opposite extreme, though, Safeway keeps two-thirds for itself, the Commission finds.

The report investigated 24 chains in all, each having 10 or more supermarkets of over 600 sq metres. As well as the big five, the list included Somerfield, Waitrose, Marks & Spencer, Budgen, Iceland, family-owned Booths in the north-west, the three foreign 'hard discounters' - Aldi, Lidl and Netto - and 10 Co-ops.

Of total large supermarket sales of £52 billion a year, the big five have a 75.6 per cent market share. The rest of the sector is by no means whiter than white, especially in treatment of suppliers, the report finds. But, as far as consumers are concerned, the Commission concludes their local influence is too small to harm the public interest.

Of the big five, only Asda and Morrison's have a uniform national pricing policy, as do Waitrose, Iceland, Aldi and Lidl among the rest. Only M&S and Lidl were identified as never selling below cost.

'We recognise it is unusual, although not unprecedented, for the Commission to recommend no remedy for identified adverse effects. However, we consider that this is appropriate in the light of our overall finding that the market is generally competitive,' the report concludes, leaving the politicians to sort out the inevitable row.

webTitle: Top Gunn enjoys taste of success

fields.headline: Top Gunn enjoys taste of success
fields.standfirst: John Gunn: His fall from grace was public and unjustified. But the former B&C chief is getting even the way he knows best
fields.trailText: Ten years on from the collapse of his financial services empire British & Commonwealth, John Gunn is on a roll once again. Last month Christows, the West country stockbroker he helped to build, was taken over for a cool £40 million.
fields.body:
Ten years on from the collapse of his financial services empire British & Commonwealth, John Gunn is on a roll once again. Last month Christows, the West country stockbroker he helped to build, was taken over for a cool £40 million. And next year three more investments made by B&C's former chief executive are set to come to market with a total price of up to half a billion.

For the wheeler dealer who was at the helm of one of the City's biggest financial crashes, success - like the best of revenges - is sweet. Since B&C went under with debts of £1.5 billion in 1990, Gunn has been beavering away quietly and far more profitably. Now 58, he started out again as a 'one-man incubator' to growth companies, providing a mix of business experience and his own money, long before venture capitalists reached for the fruits of the hi-tech garden.

Along the way, he spent eight years fighting the Department of Trade and Industry. And when his day in court finally came, he won spectacularly. Gunn was the classic City scalp presumed guilty until proven innocent. The trauma still leaves him spitting blood at the politicians, the bankers and the toffee-nosed, blue-blooded City establishment that froze him out. Among the few notable exceptions, Gunn singles out Nigel Rudd, founder of Williams Holdings, and Nick Brigstocke, now chair of CSFB's London broking arm, as faithful supporters.

The real venom remains reserved for the watchdogs and Whitehall. 'I never want to work in a high-profile job or regulated firm again. Just look what they did to me,' Gunn says. 'Regulators, civil servants, they're all lying, cheating, scheming bastards.'

For the Cheshire railwayman's son, the new start was as much about retaining sanity, while fighting the DTI, as regaining a fortune. In the past decade, he has made some 25 investments. By no means all have been money-spinners. But West 175, the TV production company whose board he first joined after defeating the DTI, has quintupled his money. And the most successful to date, Turbo Genset, a developer of cheap electricity generators, has reaped Gunn a 130-fold gain after making its debut on the Stock Exchange in July.

Gunn is coy about his newly-made fortune. But he admits he would easily make the annual British rich list tables. 'This is what I really joined B&C to do. There we set up the first development-capital trust after 3i,' Gunn says. 'They knew if I went to work with private companies, firms were getting a lot of business experience they couldn't usually afford.'

In the mid-Eighties, Gunn already had the world at his feet. After studying German at Nottingham and Berlin universities, he started his career in the foreign-exchange department of Barclays Bank in Manchester, before joining a small money broker in the City of London. In 1978, backed by the wealthy Cayzer family, he and the management team bought the operation out. By then called Exco, it floated on the stock market and by 1985, after a string of acquisitions, it was worth £500m. But following boardroom rows Gunn walked out, only to be snapped up by the Cayzers' British and Commonwealth.

Formed in 1955, B&C had once been Britain's biggest shipping line, but it had since diversified into aviation, hotels and the City through fund manager Gartmore. Financial services, Gunn believed, was where the action was. A £2bn string of deals followed, including Exco, estate agent Abaco and, just three days before the 1987 stock-market crash, a £430m buyout of the astute Cayzer family's stake.

For Gunn the timing of those moves - before Black Monday, recession and the property slump - was hardly propitious. Nor were his dealings with Gary Klesch, a sharp US dealmaker who failed to come up with cash in a £500m carve-up of rival broker Mercantile House.

But Gunn's misfortune too far was the £400m takeover of Atlantic Computers, a computer-leasing business, in 1988. Founded by the late John Foulston, owner of Brands Hatch, Atlantic was effectively a pyramid selling operation, whose apparent profits masked huge liabilities. B&C wrote off £550m when the 'black hole' came to light, the banks panicked - needlessly, says Gunn - and put in the administrators. 'We only needed a bridging loan. It was containable. The estimate was £45m. B&C shouldn't have gone under.'

Writs flew like confetti and the DTI moved in. In 1994, Gunn was fiercely criticised in the inspectors' report, which the DTI used to bring disqualification proceedings against the main players. The case was the most expensive ever, costing upwards of £5m, when it finally came to court in 1998. Six out of nine B&C and Atlantic directors were barred. But it was hardly the DTI's finest hour.

'As regards Mr Gunn, I have found no culpability in his relevant conduct,' the judge found, overturning all the main criticisms of the inspectors' investigation. Last year, too, City advisers on the deal, led by Barclays, stumped up £150m to settle claims of negligence.

'The DTI report was false. We took them apart. I didn't do anything wrong and wasn't prepared to say I did,' Gunn says. 'It was like a Star Chamber. It was rigged. It shouldn't happen, but it does. To be scapegoated in this manner was appalling.'

Despite being judged innocent, the affair still lingers. This summer, City advisers to Turbo Genset insisted the inspectors' criticisms be included in its flotation prospectus - and that the judge's remarks be included, too. The result was two pages of adversarial small print, which will be repeated every time Gunn sits on the board of a firm going to market.

Not that he'll fret. A Californian vineyard and a holiday home in Switzerland mean Gunn and his German wife now get away from it all whenever the fancy takes them. The family firm Scheidegg, indeed, takes its name from the last station on the Jungfrau mountain railway. 'I'm making up for all the holidays I never took before. It's repayment time certainly to my wife.' Scheidegg, too, is building a tidy nest egg for his three daughters: the eldest is 34 and he has 31-year old-twins.

Over the next year, Gunn is counting on two more innovative engineers for his next success: Corac Group, a developer of high-speed compressors, and Mechadyne, a maker of fuel-efficient engine valves. DAT, a software engineer, and LBM, an internet email business, may follow them to market in short order.

Deliberately, Gunn seeks to help firms exploit technology developed at universities. Turbo Genset, for example, came out of London's Imperial College. And ironically, for all his travails with the authorities, Gunn's is exactly the sort of expertise the Government is now trying to tap. 'Business and government go hand in hand,' he says. 'The DTI should get out of regulation and try to help winners. They keep getting it wrong.'

Subject: John Gunn

Born: 15 January 1942

Job: Chairman, Scheidegg

Other Directorships: Numerous, including Turbo Genset, West 175 Enterprises,. Glenchewton

Hobbies: Golf opera, skiing, walking, German literature

This summer, City advisers to Turbo Genset insisted the inspectors' criticisms be included in its flotation prospectus - and that the judge's remarks be included, too. The result was two pages of adversarial small print, which will be repeated every time Gunn sits on the board of a firm going to market. Not that he'll fret. A Californian vineyard and a holiday home in Switzerland mean Gunn and his German wife now get away from it all whenever the fancy takes them. The family firm Scheidegg, indeed, takes its name from the last station on the Jungfrau mountain railway. 'I'm making up for all the holidays I never took before. It's repayment time certainly to my wife.' Scheidegg, too, is building a tidy nest egg for his three daughters: the eldest is 34 and he has 31-year old-twins. Over the next year, Gunn is counting on two more innovative engineers for his next success: Corac Group, a developer of high-speed compressors, and Mechadyne, a maker of fuel-efficient engine valves. DAT, a software engineer, and LBM, an internet email business, may follow them to market in short order. Deliberately, Gunn seeks to help firms exploit technology developed at universities. Turbo Genset, for example, came out of London's Imperial College. And ironically, for all his travails with the authorities, Gunn's is exactly the sort of expertise the Government is now trying to tap. 'Business and government go hand in hand,' he says. 'The DTI should get out of regulation and try to help winners. They keep getting it wrong.' Subject: John Gunn Born: 15 January 1942 Job: Chairman, Scheidegg Other Directorships: Numerous, including Turbo Genset, West 175 Enterprises,. Glenchewton Hobbies: Golf opera, skiing, walking, German literature

fields.headline: Space: the Fen frontier
fields.standfirst: Hi-tech Cambridge faces growing pains as it tries to preserve its cloistered charm, write  Faisal Islam  and Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: The explosive growth of Silicon Fen is testing the limits of the infrastructure of East Anglia's version of hi-tech Silicon Valley in California.
fields.body:
The explosive growth of Silicon Fen is testing the limits of the infrastructure of East Anglia's version of hi-tech Silicon Valley in California.

A report published tomorrow will warn that growth in the region - and across the country - is threatened. The report, entitled 'The Cambridge Phenomenon Revisited', by Segal Quince Wicksteed, the consultancy which first spotted the concentration of new technology companies around the city in 1985, blames jammed roads, lack of offices and homes, and poor public transport.

A rich vein of hi-tech companies, including Arm, Autonomy and Cambridge Antibody Technology, have tapped into the area's top-rated scientific research. But the growth of the hi-tech economy has long been pushing up against wider infrastructure constraints.

The crunch has come. Today's news that the expansion of the Wellcome Trust's Genome campus is in doubt comes after a planning row.

'There are big problems,' says Dr Mike Lynch, Britain's first software billionaire and chief executive and founder of Autonomy. 'Quality office space is now very rare. It's very difficult to hire staff. Many people with young families can't afford to live here.'

There is scattered evidence of large US firms spurning Cambridge because they could not find large enough premises,and of senior academics turning down prestigious professorial posts because of difficulties in finding homes.

Bill Wicksteed says: 'These developments are perhaps a harbinger of things to come.'

The rejection of the genome campus expansion plan is not the first time the local authorities have resisted major investment. In the Sixties, Cambridge City Council refused to let IBM build its European research centre there, sending thousands of jobs to Hampshire instead.

Lynch says: 'The council has a slightly ambivalent attitude to the economics of the area. It seems to take the view that people don't have to have a car: they can walk to work. But the train station is at the other end of town.'

The UK's hi-tech research hub also happens to be a small city of outstanding natural and cultural beauty. Residents and councillors do not want to sacrifice the green belt that stops the city boundaries creeping outwards. Yet the concentration of world-leading research institutes is luring feverish investment into the area.

'Unless the traffic and space problems are sorted out they will act as a brake on growth,' says Lynch .

The report says the councils often restrict planning permission 'to establishments with a strong research content and may exclude HQ activities we see as vital'.

Cambridge is ringed by market towns: Newmarket, Ely, Huntingdon, St Ives, Royston and Saffron Walden. All are home to firms rejected by Cambridge.

The lack of space in the city is acute for companies and intolerable for workers. There are only 70,000 houses, costing an average of £100,000; the average salary is about £20,000. Wicksteed estimates that every acre of office development requires 15 acres of housing and infrastructure.

He adds: 'Firms are recruiting from further afield, which is not desirable for companies which thrive on community and networking.'

Moves to build more housing in the area have been announced, but this still leaves the transport problem. 'A lot of development has been absorbed without a corresponding central government infrastructure investment,' Wicksteed says..

'The UK is not used to investing in advance of growth. But firms will not develop motorways or public transport themselves.'

Cambridge itself may resist development, but Wicksteed believes growth can be channelled into the surrounding area, as far north as Peterborough, across Suffolk in the East and to Stansted airport in the south. For this vision to be realised, ambitious and imaginative plans to bolster public transport are being formulated, starting with a fast east-west train link.

'Rather than look at Cambridge as just a city, the council needs to look at it as an employment hub with a 40-mile radius,' says Lynch.

At a recent dinner at a Cambridge college, contrasting opinions on congestion and lack of space were voiced.

A leading venture capitalist said these were 'nice problems to have', adding: 'The market will sort it out.'

Another investor disagreed strongly: 'If South Cambridgeshire council had been in charge of Birmingham during the nineteenth century, there would have been no industrial revolution.'

webTitle: No thought for the morrow? You bet

fields.headline: No thought for the morrow? You bet
fields.trailText: There were two starkly contrasting images in Thursday's papers. One was of a tottering 89-year-old Baroness Castle leaving the Labour Party conference platform after another impassioned plea for the Government to restore the link between increases in the basic state pension and wage inflation. The ovation she received was warm enough to turn bread into toast.
fields.body:
There were two starkly contrasting images in Thursday's papers. One was of a tottering 89-year-old Baroness Castle leaving the Labour Party conference platform after another impassioned plea for the Government to restore the link between increases in the basic state pension and wage inflation. The ovation she received was warm enough to turn bread into toast.

The other arresting picture was of a chorus line of Butlins' redcoats, all of whom up until last week worked for Rank, the leisure firm that also owns the Hard Rock Cafe chain. But on Thursday the Redcoats found out that they had a new employer after caravan park giant Bourne Leisure paid £650 million for the Butlins' holiday camps.

Following the sale, Rank said it intended to focus on its core operations, chiefly casinos - both in the high street and in the crepuscular backstreet dens of cyberspace.

It is not hard to see why Rank wants to focus on this area. The gambling industry is set for exponential growth. Not a day goes by without a new online gambling joint springing up or a new scratchcard game going on sale. Analysts tell us the online gambling market alone will be worth around £3.5 billion in five years' time.

Everywhere you look the gambling culture is manifest. Everybody knows their 'appetite for risk'. Go to any mortgage lender or financial adviser and you'll be asked how daring you are in making investments. It sends a shiver down your spine when you can look a financial adviser in the face and state: 'I have an SAS-style attitude to risk.' See how they swoon. We are all gamblers now.

Castle would certainly not approve. The generation she speaks for was never asked whether it wanted to gamble. There was a simple trade off. The state took a chunk of your wages and in return looked after you from the cradle to the grave.

But today's generation, the risk generation, isn't interested in Castle. Why all the fuss about making provision for the future? Best to enjoy the good times now. Today's average income is nearly 70 per cent more than it was 10 years ago, while the cost of living has risen less than 40 per cent. The stock market may have been a bit shabby this year but put it in context. Over five years we've seen unprecedented returns. Those windfalls from the demutualised building societies are still sloshing through the system.

What is worrying is the apparently growing consensus that the good times will continue to roll, that the upside doesn't have a downside which we need to protect ourselves against. This seems to be true both at the micro and macro levels. Last week we learnt that the household savings ratio - the difference between what households save and what they spend - has equalled a 37 year low.

Outgoings now total 97 per cent of our income. Three years ago outgoings represented only 87 per cent. Economists say this clearly shows that consumers have confidence in the economy.

But there is a fine line between confidence and recklessness. This generation, the generation that spends today with little thought for tomorrow, may recall what happened last time the difference between total household income and total household expenditure fell to 3 per cent. The year was 1988. The boom preceded a spectacular bust.

At the other end of the scale, the big telecom companies such as BT and Vodafone that have helped drive the FTSE relentlessly north in recent years, are now scaring European banking regulators, who worry that they have borrowed too much money - a whopping £117bn - to pay for the new generation of mobile phone licences. Some argue that this is a similar scenario to the nightmare that was the property sector in 1992. Too many firms borrowed too much money in a bid to cash in on the property boom. When the market turned, many firms were left high and dry.

Of course, companies, investors and consumers have all learnt the lessons of the Eighties, so this couldn't happen again.

But don't bet on it.

webTitle: Virgin in mobile phone deal with Sainsbury

fields.headline: Virgin in mobile phone deal with Sainsbury
fields.trailText: Virgin Mobile, the fledgling mobile phone network, is poised to expand its operations in the high street by selling its handsets in Sainsbury's stores. The deal, to be announced tomorrow, will be followed by link-ups with Iceland and WH Smith, to be unveiled later this month.
fields.body:
Virgin Mobile, the fledgling mobile phone network, is poised to expand its operations in the high street by selling its handsets in Sainsbury's stores. The deal, to be announced tomorrow, will be followed by link-ups with Iceland and WH Smith, to be unveiled later this month.

The move represents a significant step forward for the company, which has been strong on selling direct to customers over the phone or via the internet but has, until now, done little to establish a high street presence outside of selling through Virgin-owned stores.

'This is going to take us up to 2,000 outlets, away from the 300 stores we sell through at the moment,' a spokesman for Virgin Mobile said. Under the deal, Sainsbury's will stop selling Orange phones in its aisles and replace them with two Virgin products.

With the advent of pre-pay phones, and falling cost of handsets, selling phones in supermarkets is becoming increasingly important to network operators.

More than 40 per cent of handset sales over the Christmas period now come through the supermarkets and other large stores rather than via specialist shops.

Virgin, which is keen to position itself as a consumer champion in the mobile phone market by offering what it claims are transparent tariffs, is also talking to the other big retail chains in a bid to tap the non-specialist market.

Later this week all the mobile phone operators unveil quarterly subscriber figures. Virgin is expected to show that it now has more than 400,000 subscribers.

fields.headline: Supermarkets abuse power
fields.standfirst: Rein them in, says leaked Competition Commission report  Superstores will need OFT go-ahead
fields.trailText: Britain's big five supermarket chains will be forced to win Office of Fair Trading permission before building new superstores. This is the central recommendation of the long-awaited Competition Commission investigation into the firms' growing power.
fields.body:
Britain's big five supermarket chains will be forced to win Office of Fair Trading permission before building new superstores. This is the central recommendation of the long-awaited Competition Commission investigation into the firms' growing power.

After a 16-month inquiry, the Commission's report was passed to Ministers in August and is to be published by Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers within weeks.

It finds that the big five damage smaller grocers and limit consumer choice by selling staple items at rock-bottom prices. 'We conclude that the practice of persistent below-cost selling when conducted by Asda, Morrison, Safeway, Sainsbury and Tesco - ie those parties with market power - operates against the public interest,' the Commission says.

Tesco, Sainsbury and Safeway are accused, too, of acting against the public interest by charging extra at stores facing less local competition. All the big chains denied acting uncompetitively.

Controversially, however, the report comes out against forcing supermarket groups to sell off stores in areas where they are deemed to be too powerful. It rules out other measures - such as publishing prices on the internet for shoppers to make comparisions - as unworkable.

Instead, to limit growing monopoly power, it recom mends that the five should have to gain OFT consent for any new supermarket of more than 1,000 square metres within a 15-minute drive of one of their existing branches.

'We think that a dedicated unit should be established to deal with such cases within the OFT,' the report says.

Following complaints, especially from small farmers, the Commission urges an OFT-approved code of conduct to improve the chains' treatment of suppliers. The proposals are likely to hit growth and unnerve supermarket shares this week. Farmers will be angered, too, as the report dismisses claims of supermarket profiteering and a 'Rip-Off Britain'.

DTI Ministers, however, remain concerned about local supermarket monopolies and may yet take further action, when the report is published.

'There is a very wide range of prices around the country. The chains are getting away with what the market will bear,' one Whitehall source said. 'The view is: "Why should someone in Derby pay £2 for a kilo of washing powder when people elsewhere pay £1.50?' "

Ministers are looking to the revamped OFT, under new director-general John Vickers, to act on the findings. 'Ministers have made it plain that they want consumer protection at the OFT to be strengthened because until now it has been very weak,' one source said. 'If the OFT does not have systems to monitor prices then it will have to get them quickly.'

The Government is also concerned that certain chains are stifling competition by snapping up land on which rivals could build. Of 408 sites held in land banks, 190 are owned by Tesco, the market leader, the report finds.

'One of the things Ministers are considering is requiring them to publish details of land holdings, so it is clear what they have and where,' one Whitehall source said.

webTitle: Business: Get ahead, get on a smart bike

fields.headline: Get ahead, get on a smart bike
fields.trailText: A radical transport congestion solution based on smartcards is poised to give a whole new meaning to the phrase 'on your bike', writes Nick Mathiason.
fields.body:
A radical transport congestion solution based on smartcards is poised to give a whole new meaning to the phrase 'on your bike', writes Nick Mathiason.

Adshel, the country's biggest supplier of bus shelters, litter bins and other street furniture, is close to agreement with councils in London, Birmingham, Cardiff and Kingston to introduce the SmartBike - a novel way of encouraging commuters to cycle.

Would-be cyclists buy a card that entitles them to use a bike around town before dropping it off at any one of up to 15 docking points at railway stations, bus garages and key city centre areas.

The scheme has already been tried out in Rennes, northern France, with much success.

Andy Moug, Adshel's commercial director, says the scheme will be free to local councils. In return, Adshel expects to get free advertising hoarding sites for its clients.

'The only real risk we have is if someone steals the bike, but because they are so distinctive they won't get far,' he said.

Transport pressure groups are enthusiastic. 'We are in favour of this initiative and look forward to seeing its wider application,' said a Transport 2000 spokesman. 'With a company like Adshel, who maintain and manage bus shelters, it is a plus point.'

fields.headline: BoS eyes A&L takeover
fields.trailText: Bank of Scotland is considering a bid for Alliance & Leicester, the former building society. Sources close to the bank said that A&L was one of a number of options it was 'looking seriously at' following the failure of its bid for NatWest. But it is believed that some members of the board question whether a bid is necessary, given the bank's current growth.
fields.body:
Bank of Scotland is considering a bid for Alliance & Leicester, the former building society. Sources close to the bank said that A&L was one of a number of options it was 'looking seriously at' following the failure of its bid for NatWest. But it is believed that some members of the board question whether a bid is necessary, given the bank's current growth.

Interim results announced last week showed a 20 per cent increase in loans and a 14 per cent profits rise.

Some Bank of Scotland divisional directors believe it should concentrate on maintaining that growth instead of taking on the distractions of a deal. But critics question whether this rate can be sustained and point to the continued deterioration in margins - 2.47 per cent in its first half compared with 2.85 per cent a year earlier - as evidence of the pressure it faces.

The City has been pressing the bank to do a deal since the Royal Bank of Scotland won the battle for NatWest, and there was some disappointment when chief executive Peter Burt appeared to rule out a bid at last week's results presentation. Like NatWest, A&L is cheap - its shares have fallen from 941p 18 months ago to 575.5p, and it stands at a discount to most of its peers.

But it is far smaller than NatWest - at Friday's close, it was valued at just £3 billion - and, although there would be scope for cost savings, these would be far lower than at the bloated English clearer.

A&L is also under pressure to agree a takeover. Its core mortgage business is becoming increasingly competitive, its margins are falling and lending growth is sluggish. One of the largest institutional investors said A&L's network would give Bank of Scotland a ready-made network in England.

But Alex Potter, banking analyst at Commerzbank, questioned whether other investors would welcome BoS increasing its exposure to the very competitive mortgages market.

fields.headline: Move a little bit closer
fields.standfirst: Blair's new Labour had little time for unions - until last month that is.  Oliver Morgan reports
fields.trailText: Before going to the Labour Party's lucrative gala dinner at Brighton's Metropole Hotel last Tuesday, Tony Blair put in an appearance at a party held by his favourite union boss, Sir Ken Jackson.
fields.body:
Before going to the Labour Party's lucrative gala dinner at Brighton's Metropole Hotel last Tuesday, Tony Blair put in an appearance at a party held by his favourite union boss, Sir Ken Jackson.

Blair, still radiant from his conference speech that afternoon, made another, rather briefer, pronouncement in a room at the Old Ship Hotel, down the seafront from the conference compound.

He wanted to thank the trade unions, which had been a 'rock' during the tempestuous fuel protests that brought the country to a standstill and dumped on the Labour party in the opinion polls. They were the true friends of the Government.

It seemed heartfelt: there were smiles all round from the assembled members of the Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union. As Jackson observed: 'Of course they need us. They've got to listen to what we want - after all, they are soon going to need what we have got in our back pockets.'

A Minister - AEEU sponsored - standing close by said: 'Ken's right, we have taken a bad knock and we have got some real problems now. When that happens you need to look for your friends.'

But even as Blair spoke, Ministers, including key union fixer Ian McCartney, were negotiating with Rodney Bickerstaffe, general secretary of public service union Unison, and John Edmonds of the GMB.

They were trying to thrash out a compromise on pensions, the issue threatening to overshadow the carefully co-ordinated Brown-Prescott-Blair conference fightback.

Less than 24 hours later, two-thirds of conference delegates inflicted on Blair his first conference defeat since he became leader in 1994, voting to restore the link between pensions and earnings. 'This is how it used to be in the good old Seventies,' union delegates told each other.

Indeed September was saturated with resonances from 1978-79: fuel pickets and the winter of discontent; the role of lorry drivers in both; the remonstrations of public-sector unions - then Nalgo and Nupe over pay, now Unison over pensions.

But things are a bit different now. Thanks to Blair, conference is not policy making. The Government downplayed the vote. This was why Blair emasculated the unions in the first place. But if it did not matter, said the unions, why had Ministers spent the two weeks since the TUC conference in Glasgow in increasingly frantic negotiations? Why had Blair, Gordon Brown and John Prescott dragged Bickerstaffe, Edmonds and Bill Morris of the T&G in and out of meetings on Wednesday morning?

Perhaps the answer goes back to Blair's Tuesday night back-patting. Obviously the Government does not want to be beaten about in public by the unions - and Brown will have to exercise all his political skill in delivering a pensions package in his pre-Budget report at the end of this month. But Blair seems to accept - now he no longer commands the polls - that a closer relationship between government and the unions is at least expedient, if not wholly to his liking.

The embarrassment is in the timing - just as Blair admits their importance, and is conciliatory in public, the unions deliver an old-fashioned knee in the gut. Both sides will be hoping that Wednesday was the exception that proves a new rule.

Unions believe they ought to be, and are being, taken seriously, having shown restraint as Labour's modernisers distanced them from the party. John Monks, the TUC leader - who said last year the TUC was being treated like the 'embarrassing elderly relations' by Labour - believes there has been a change in relations, despite the pensions difficulties.

'They were glad for what the TUC and the T&G did over fuel,' he says. 'Bill and I are working closely together on that with them now, and they're grateful.'

It is not just fuel. Other crises this year have given unions the chance to show their value, and put industrial negotiation back in fashion. The important role played by the T&G's chief motor industry negotiator, Tony Woodley, in the rescue of Rover is recognised in the Department of Trade and Industry.

Behind-the-scenes liaisons between ISTC officials, DTI and Welsh Office Ministers and executives of steel company Corus helped keep the Llanwern steel works in Wales open - despite thousands of job losses across the group. And the Government accepts it would have been next to helpless in dealing with problems at Sellafield had it not been for GMB officials providing information.

In short, in the age of the network economy, the unions provide a ready-made industrial network for Labour to use. Union restraint in public means the Government is able to tap it without entering a politically damaging Faustian deal along the lines of the 'social contract' engineered in the Seventies by another resonant name - Jack Jones. The effect within Government, according to Whitehall insiders, is that the stock of 'old Labour' Ministers with close union contacts is at a premium - Blair paid direct tribute to Prescott in his speech for this reason.

One ministerial adviser said last week: 'There has been a lot more fixing this year. Those who know their way around the union movement - and the difference between the TUC (which seeks consensus) and the affiliate unions (which couldn't care less) - have seen their stock rising. Some Ministers have believed that all you needed to do to keep the unions on side was have a cup of tea with John Monks.'

The point is recognised by Peter Kilfoyle, who delivered his own crisis to the Government when he announced his resignation as Defence Minister because Labour was falling out with it core voters.

'The modernisers came in like the Khmer Rouge in 1997,' he said. 'They said it was year zero - forgot about the unions and the grass roots. I think they are not just saying they're listening; there has been a definite change.'

The change in the relationship is reflected in more than the warm words of Blair, the volatile, rarefied mood of an unusual party conference.

Unions are growing: in 1999 membership rose for the first time in a generation (see table). Unions are capitalising on new laws to strike deals with employers. They are using ballots to achieve their aims in the workplace. There is now a reason to join.

Nevertheless, there are serious challenges for the movement, which a link with Labour cannot solve in the long term. Thousands of manufacturing job cuts this year has seen the loss of many union members.'New' industries are anti-union and employ young people who have no links to the movement. Those who do join have different priorities.

As one ministerial adviser - formerly a TUC official - says: 'The relationship will probably change because many now join them for the services they can provide - like legal advice - rather than for their political influence.'

The TUC recognises this - its stakeholder pension is a move into financial services, and it is ever more likely that this is where future union value will reside.

Monks and other forward-thinking unionists believe the movement will be most useful to the Government by securing its own future through adapting to change.

But that does not mean he hasn't a short-term agenda - chiefly focused on fairness at work and the Europeanisation of industrial relations - which relies on political influence and government policy. There are those, such as McCartney, whose language is almost identical to Monks's.

Notwithstanding the pensions vote, both unions and Government have seen the expediency of getting closer and are happy to be more public about it. They can do a lot for each other, but their roles will be very different.

The message of last week was actually how little it resembled the Seventies.

fields.headline: Geek heroes
fields.standfirst: Can the launch of a dotcom make compulsive viewing? Well, Tony Garnett did his best
fields.trailText:
Attachments BBC2
Can You Live Without... Mum C4
Head on the Block BBC2
Extreme Lives BBC1
fields.body:
Attachments BBC2
Can You Live Without... Mum C4
Head on the Block BBC2
Extreme Lives BBC1

It's pretty difficult to squeeze high drama out of a scene starring a crashing computer, but Attachments, BBC2's latest from Tony Garnett's World Productions, makers of This Life and The Cops, gamely gave it a go. 'We've got a crisis here!' someone helpfully explained to those of us for whom a frozen screen merely prompts a resigned sigh, a boiling kettle and a reboot. A bit of speedy editing and some pacy beats-per-minute attempted to add to the tension, until, that is - phew! You really had me worried for a moment there! - the screens kicked in again.

A drama about an internet start-up necessarily involves young people trading lines like: 'I've got to rewrite some CDI code and I'm working on that Chatsoft you asked me to do. I'm not just sitting on my arse!', while doing exactly that.

Though stupid people thinking aloud often makes for great soap-opera tension, smart people thinking in front of computer screens - even attractive smart young people in front of screens full of pretty graphics and shot in claustrophobic close-up - just doesn't and thus the scenes sometimes resembled those dog days days inside the Big Brother house.

The office, sort of Warehousey, kind of dark, probably in Clerkenwell, is pungent with yoof stereotypes: Brandon, the nude-skateboarding techy geek who can't get laid; Sophie, the earnest young lesbian whose controversial polemic on the Queen Mother attracted a crazed email stalker; then there was Reece, the up-winding, womanising coder (if this were Are You Being Served?, he'd be working in gent's outfitting and trying to cop off with Wendy Richard); Jake the designer, who hasn't yet been given a personality, though that may be a statement in itself; the site's founders, Mike and Luce, the very model of the modern inter-racial marriage, who already talk shop in the missionary position and whose love life is surely doomed. And, on the periphery, Mike and Luce's female lodger (careful, Luce!) and the newly employed see-thru sales manager, Yvonne, the scary, singleton thirtysomething ('I know I'm not good-looking') who hid her (prettier) rival's CV to ensure she landed the job.

Last week, I met a young entrepreneur who assured me that Attachments was so convincing it was practically a fly-on-the-wall documentary charting his own start-up tribulations. For the rest of us, though, the emphasis needs to shift away from the sedentary still-life in real-time landscape of the office if it is to engage and succeed like This Life or The Cops . So far, it's mostly a cautionary tale - netheads should worry less and get out more.

Young people today, eh. If they don't need to get out more often, they really ought to get out less. The second series of Can You Live Without... introduced us to 24- year-old Owen Hughes, who lives at home and spends every penny of his £12,000 salary on clubbing and clothes. Lucky boy! The only thing his mum doesn't do for him is the ironing - his gran does that. Owen moved out with around 900 pairs of trainers, 437 golf clubs and a TV... but could he survive for two weeks in a flat on his own without his mum?

Budgeting was a problem. After rent and bills, he was left with £90 a week, of which he blew a third on the very first night. The next 14 days proved that Owen was a clear favourite to make it to the final of the fecklessness Olympics: he forgot he needed a razor to shave and without someone to kick him out of the front door, he was invariably late for work; then he threw a party without a bottle opener and, later, when attempting a roast dinner, was reduced to reading the instructions on the potatoes. I hadn't realised potatoes came with instructions, but it was a godsend for Owen, who otherwise might have been tempted to mash them raw and use them to clean the bath.

Around the middle of week two, our hero furrowed his brow and came close to his first existential crisis: where was his life going, exactly, and why? 'I really want to work for a car company, in the service department! But here I am, doing it. I'm sure no one looks at me and goes, "Oh I wish I did that". A terrible pause: "I'm almost positive really".'

After the fortnight was up, Owen was still alive but struggling. 'I suppose I've got to be a bit more responsible. But I don't want to. I still want to play football over the park on a Sunday. And act like a kid.' Mother smiled lovingly, Gran prepared to reshoulder the burden of the shirts and Can You Live Without... Mum revealed itself to be the tragicomedy of the week. A word to the entire young female population of Wales: this man-child may look like the lead singer of a boy band, but please, please, whatever else you do, try not to let yourself fall in love with Owen Hughes.

At least Owen's still got a job, unlike Torsten Friedag, the star of Head on the Block, the New Labour 'superhead' whose touchy-feely style pretty much did for him on day one at the Islington Arts and Media School, during which he played the Beatles to a roomful of bemused 11-year-olds. You couldn't help thinking: 'No! Wrong! Not those old white guys with guitars!'

That was screened a fortnight ago and the two subsequent episodes continued to reveal that Friedag was to tough inner-city schoolkids what Owen Hughes was to naked potatoes: full of enthusiasm but without much in the way of experience.

This week, seven months into the new regime, the pupils were filmed crowding round the camera, shouting: 'Who runs this school? We do', while IAMS continued to haemorrhage staff, morale and resources. One mother, despairing of her youngest son's increasing truancy, took him off to live in Wales. One hopes he falls in with the right crowd and learns to iron his shirts, and that Friedag finds a nice job at the kind of school where his naively enthusiastic Dead Poets Society performance might be more appropriate. Head on The Block made for riveting but guilty viewing because, quite simply, there should never been camera there in the first place.

Aside from the Olympics, easily the most deliciously escapist, uplifting yet completely pointless activity of the week was captured in BBC1's Extreme Lives. Adrian Nicholas is a skydiver with an almost fatalistic approach to his work. It isn't enough for Nicholas to leap out of a plane at several thousand feet, deploy a parachute and float gently to the ground, he has to do it faster and for longer than anyone else - and preferably while wearing a winged outfit that makes him look like a pupae Superhero. 'Most people in the world don't live; they just exist. I want to fly, like Peter Pan. Why not?' he said.

Well, some reasons sprang to mind as one watched him prepare to beat the world record for the longest time spent in freefall (set in 1960 by a US test pilot who had hurtled to earth from 102,000 feet at 600 miles an hour): death, for example. But Adrian wasn't going to let a trifling thing like his own mortality get in the way of a good time, especially when he had the world's most supportive girlfriend to stitch together his plastic Icarus wings and pack his Peter Pan parachute.

Last spring, in northern California, Nicholas beat the record. He really did fly. It looked like the most wonderful thing anyone could ever do and was enhanced by a soundtrack that included Moby's 'Everloving', a personal in-car stereo favourite, particularly in traffic jams. I really must get out more.

fields.headline: Shoppers buy value, not values
fields.trailText: Fair trade chocolate and coffee may be a familiar sight on household shelves. But a new study has found the British do not practise what they preach when it comes to 'green' groceries.
fields.body:
Fair trade chocolate and coffee may be a familiar sight on household shelves. But a new study has found the British do not practise what they preach when it comes to 'green' groceries.

The most in-depth research ever undertaken into ethical consumerism has found that, although most people claim to take environmental and social issues into account when filling their shopping basket, such discrimination largely evaporates before they reach the checkout.

The study also found that, far from being regarded as a positive or fashionable description, younger people dislike the label of 'ethical consumers'.

According to the independent Co-operative Bank survey, 88 per cent of those questioned claimed to be ethical shoppers who took environmental and social concerns into consideration. But when the same people were asked in more depth about their actions in the supermarket, only 23 per cent could name any behaviour on their part that would justify their claim.

'We were concerned and surprised by these findings,' said Simon Williams, co-author of the report and head of corporate affairs at the bank. 'The enthusiasm of the early Nineties seems to have leaked away and the most pessimistic interpretation of these figures is that ethical consumerism is just a temporary trend which is already sliding out of fashion.'

Although one in three people questioned believed the impact a product had on the environment was important, one in seven would choose a product because of the company's environmental policies. And, despite the wave of consumer consciousness shown by the recent anti-capitalism demonstrations in Prague, Seattle and London, over three-quarters of those questioned rated brand name, value for money and customer services above ethical considerations.

The survey of almost 2,000 people also turned the assumption that younger people are more value-driven on its head with the discovery that those under 35 are far less concerned than their elders in making ethical decisions. This group rarely recycles, does not shop locally and is far more interested in fashion and convenience than other sections of society.

While around 60 per cent said they felt they did not have enough information to make an ethical judgment on a company's behaviour, over half the respondents nevertheless believed their choice could make a difference to companies' ethical policies.

'When shoppers feel they can make a difference by choosing ethically, they usually are far more inclined to do so,' said Williams. 'But this survey has shown the vast majority of the public are still failing to act on their beliefs.'

But other experts reject the temptation to blame the consumer for failing to carry through their convictions. 'It's easy to blame the consumers for being lazy and unconcerned, but why should we look to them, the least informed and least resourced part of the equation, to change the way the world works?,' said Rob Harrison, editor of The Ethical Consumer Magazine.

'Markets are not consumer-led, they choose to indoctrinate the consumers to want things,' he added. 'The companies and the Government have more responsibility to operate ethically than the consumers. The Government can regulate unethical products and services out of the market and force companies to give consumers the information they want and need.'

'The enthusiasm of the early Nineties seems to have leaked away and the most pessimistic interpretation of these figures is that ethical consumerism is just a temporary trend which is already sliding out of fashion.' Although one in three people questioned believed the impact a product had on the environment was important, one in seven would choose a product because of the company's environmental policies. And, despite the wave of consumer consciousness shown by the recent anti-capitalism demonstrations in Prague, Seattle and London, over three-quarters of those questioned rated brand name, value for money and customer services above ethical considerations. The survey of almost 2,000 people also turned the assumption that younger people are more value-driven on its head with the discovery that those under 35 are far less concerned than their elders in making ethical decisions. This group rarely recycles, does not shop locally and is far more interested in fashion and convenience than other sections of society. While around 60 per cent said they felt they did not have enough information to make an ethical judgment on a company's behaviour, over half the respondents nevertheless believed their choice could make a difference to companies' ethical policies. 'When shoppers feel they can make a difference by choosing ethically, they usually are far more inclined to do so,' said Williams. 'But this survey has shown the vast majority of the public are still failing to act on their beliefs.' But other experts reject the temptation to blame the consumer for failing to carry through their convictions. 'It's easy to blame the consumers for being lazy and unconcerned, but why should we look to them, the least informed and least resourced part of the equation, to change the way the world works?,' said Rob Harrison, editor of The Ethical Consumer Magazine. 'Markets are not consumer-led, they choose to indoctrinate the consumers to want things,' he added. 'The companies and the Government have more responsibility to operate ethically than the consumers. The Government can regulate unethical products and services out of the market and force companies to give consumers the information they want and need.' amelia.hill@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: No high street bank is going to get the better of me, growls Watchdog reporter
fields.standfirst: Charlotte Hudson stands up for herself, she tells Natalie Sutton
fields.trailText: Charlotte Hudson stands up for herself, she tells Natalie Sutton.
fields.body:
Charlotte Hudson, BBC's Watchdog reporter, is looking forward to all the wrongs she will be asked to put right in her new series. And when it comes to sorting out her own finances, Charlotte is not afraid to complain, especially to larger financial institutions.

'I get really fed up when I hear stories about the big banks. We did a petition last year when Barclays were closing branches. We were talking to an 89-year-old woman who was very savvy, but at her age she didn't want to go online, which was the only alternative they were offering. At the same time they were running a high-profile ad campaign with big names, so they clearly weren't short of funds.

'I had a bad experience recently with Lloyds. They offered the biggest free overdraft when I was a student, so I had stayed with them. In my line of business if you're not working, you're not earning: I miscalculated while I was out of the country and got seriously overdrawn. Rather than ring me up the bank kept writing to me, charging more with each letter and making my overdraft bigger. They were so rude.

'These were the people who, months earlier, had been excited to hear that I worked in TV and insisted on me coming into the branch personally. The bank swallowed my card; I was furious. They then transferred my account to another branch without telling me. I was in tears and this horrible account manager that I'd never heard of insisted on seeing me before giving me my card back. The cashier dealing with me gave me a complaint form and said "fill it in and then close your account". So I did.'

'I'm good at nasty letters, and I immediately had the general manager calling and begging me to change my mind. I never did. I bank with First Direct now. I think that because they were the first to do the telephone banking thing, they know that they've got to be really good at it. I've got into internet banking too, but it does take quite a long time. I like paying bills online although nothing is in writing and it can go wrong.'

The worst watchdog stories for Charlotte are those that involve harm to animals: 'Everyone gets in-volved then. The best stories are when the worm turns and you get someone who has actually worked for a company telling you some of the things that go on.'

Charlotte goes on: 'I used to be good with money just like my mother. But I'm not that brilliant at the moment. I've no pension but I have got an accountant, who has helped me put my tax money away for next year.'

Charlotte shares a flat with two girls, so most living expenses are shared: 'I have three credit cards, which I use mostly abroad although I have done that juggling act of taking on another credit card to pay less interest. I'm also keen on direct debits.

'Holidays are my biggest expense, and meals out. If I stopped going out I could get a mortgage. I love entertaining. Beaky (Evetts - another reporter on Watchdog ) has very expensive tastes in clothes; I prefer Mark One and New Look. It's odd really, I can spend £60 on a meal out but I'd think quite carefully before spending that much on clothes.'
