fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: Is there really such a thing as a £150 PC?
fields.body:
How would you like a new PC for just £150? Info4pc is offering Intel 500 MHz PCs at this price to people who are prepared to complete monthly questionnaires for two years.

The Lancashire company, which also goes by the name Smartalk, says: 'The questions will not be of an intimate or intrusive nature and your name and address will not be disclosed to third parties. The data will be used for discovering trends and compiling statistics, which will be sold on to third parties.'

Noel Glendon of Info4pc claims there is no catch to the offer. He says the questions asked are similar to those found in questionnaires posted through your door - usually with a free pen and the offer of having your name entered in a prize draw. You may be asked what soap powder you use, whether you have life insurance or how often you go skiing, for example. He says its questionnaire takes about 10 minutes to fill in.

However, people who apply to join Info4pc's scheme must sign a contract binding them to completing a questionnaire within the first 14 days of each month for two years. Any questionnaires filed after the 21st of a month will attract a late fee of £9. And if they fail to file altogether, Info4pc will terminate their contract and charge a £600 penalty, less £18 for every month in which they have completed a questionnaire. This puts the total maximum cost of the computer at £750.

The penalty fee is obviously designed to claw back the value of the computer if participants fail to meet their side of the bargain. However PC World says that a PC of this specification should cost no more than £550 including VAT. A spokeswoman says: 'This is low specification - the PC would be OK for basic tasks, but would be very slow for use on the internet. You could rack up some pretty large bills.'

 Seen an ad or mailshot that looks too good to be true? Write to What's the Catch? The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.

webTitle: Money writes: It was Christmas Day - but no one feels very merry

fields.headline: It was Christmas Day - but no one feels very merry
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
Our house caught fire on Christmas Day 1998 and the whole of upstairs and roof were burnt. Our insurer, Hiscox, sent in the builders, who made an awful mess of every job.

We have had some of the work put right, but now everything has stopped and it seems the insurance company is at odds with the loss adjusters. They admit the work has to be done but how long must we wait?

We are both 75 and it has been a rotten experience.
FR, Warrington

Hiscox agrees that the work done was not up to standard. When you first complained, it insisted that a director of the loss adjuster's firm visit your house to check the junior employee's recommendations. Saying that you did not need to move into a hotel while your home was restored was particularly harsh. Rebuilding started and eventually the insurer paid the contractor in full, even though the final work had not been done.

Hiscox has now agreed to pay whatever is needed to rectify the faults. A new surveyor estimated this at £4,000 although you reckon there is still about £6,000 of work to be done. Hiscox has agreed with you to settle at £5,000. At your request, it is sending a cheque so you can choose your own builder.

Computer problems

On 5 July, I sent a cheque for £1,623 to First National Tricity Finance in full settlement for a computer I had bought from Time Computers, to meet the deadline of 12 July.

On my return from holiday on 26 July, my bank statement showed that the cheque had not been put through and the first monthly credit instalment of £70.69 had been deducted.

First National denied receiving payment. Since I could not prove the envelope was not lost in the post, I sent another cheque. Ten days later, I discovered that they had found the original cheque as well as the second so I had to pay the bank to stop one of the cheques. They deducted a further instalment in August.
RH, Leeds

Abbey National, which owns First National, admits that you have had poor service. Your first cheque was 'temporarily mislaid' so the computer started charging you interest automatically. As Money Writes readers know, there have been other complaints about First National failing to accept payment in full settlement of an interest-free credit agreement.

When you sent the second cheque, customer service staff should have manually intervened to stop further deductions from your bank account. The bank has now sent you a cheque for the two payments wrongly deducted, with £50 compensation for out-of-pocket expenses.

Fair shares for trustees

In 1997, when my son was born, I opened a Kidzone savings account with Bradford & Bingley held in trust in my name. I was surprised to be told in March that, as a trustee account holder, I did not qualify for the share distribution, but was not fussed until I read in Cash that I should receive shares.

I contacted Bradford & Bingley, who sent the transfer document. But this, if I understand it correctly, says that we would be entitled to a share distribution only if I had a separate account or my son was disabled. I find this most bizarre.
AL, London

Earlier this year, Bradford & Bingley had to identify the accounts owned by people unable to look after their own money and held by carers, called trustees on the accounts. It wrote to all customers and confused many parents holding children's accounts because they too are trustees.

Children with accounts held in trust can get a share handout if they meet all the eligibility requirements: at least £100 in the account on 25 April 1999, 21 May 2000 and 3 December 2000; and no change to the names on the account. The society is finalising details towards the end of this month.

Careful driver pays penalty

My 35-year-old daughter, a careful driver, had accumulated a nine-year no claims bonus with her insurer, NIG Skandia. In February her car was broken into and she claimed on her comprehensive policy.

This was her only claim, yet her discount has been reduced from nine years to three, thereby more than doubling her previous year's premium. Where is the logic in that?
PM, Leicester

Although the damage was not her fault, the insurance company penalised her because, obviously, it could not reclaim the repair cost.

As she had no protected no claims discount, her bonus dropped by six years, from 65 per cent to 38 per cent. But this is not the only reason why her premiums increased so much.

Last year, NIG Skandia withdrew the policy she had and substituted a more expensive one. This cost £329 but, to soften the blow in year one, NIG charged only £219. This year she had to suffer the full impact which, with a smaller no- claims discount, was £427.

Paying tax as a non-resident

As an English non-resident living in Brazil, I have UK income tax deducted every month from my pension. Is there any way round this? I own no property, nor have I any assets in England, and have lived in Brazil for 15 years.
RL, Rio de Janeiro

Even if you are not resident in the UK, you are taxed on UK pensions unless the Inland Revenue has negotiated a double taxation agreement with your new homeland. There is no double taxation agreement with Brazil so, even if you are taxed again in Brazil, you still have to pay the Inland Revenue. You can, however, offset your pension income against UK personal tax allowances if you are a British citizen.

Write to Financial Intermediaries and Claims Office (FICO) International, General Services Unit, St John's House, Merton Road, Bootle, Merseyside L69 9BB, England. Tel +44 151 472 6214/6216. Fax: +44 151 472 6067.

fields.headline: Cool, calm, collected - and rich
fields.standfirst: Your passion for hoarding can be turned into big money, reports  Barbara Oaff
fields.trailText: Your passion for hoarding can be turned into big money, reports Barbara Oaff.
fields.body:
As a child Robert Opie collected things. The usual stuff: stamps, coins, matchbox cars. But at 16 his acquisitive attention turned to something a bit different - contemporary packaging.

'It seemed both weird and sane,' says Opie. 'I had absolutely no money and there I was in 1968 spend ing one-and-sixpence on various tubes of toothpaste that I was never going to use.'

To-day his collection stretches back to Victorian times; it is featured in books, exhibitions and is the basis for two museums. It's fair to say his modest, if strange, investments have paid off.

But is this the case for most collecting fanatics? Can their particular and pec-uliar hoards really gain in value, or would they fail to attract interest even at a village bring-and-buy? 'If there is a genuine collectors' market out there, with an international audience, they can make a profit,' says Tim Wonnacott, chairman of Sotheby's South.

Gwyn Jones, managing editor of Collect it! magazine, agrees, pointing out that one man's trash can indeed be another's treasure. 'People collect everything and it is possible to make money on it all - carrier bags, sick bags, bottle tops, washing machines, coat hangers, barbed wire, bricks.'

Even bits of medieval royals can attract a high price these days. Bonham's sold a snip of Edward IV's beard for £500 this year, and a lock of Charles I's hair went for more than £4,000.

But like most investments there are simple rules to keep in mind. And it helps if you are lucky, too.

Greg Vandike is a case in point. He grew up surrounded by music. His parents were in the business and, as a boy, he saw the Rolling Stones and the Beatles; he got to meet the likes of David Bowie and Pink Floyd. 'Sometimes they'd give me things or just sign things and I'd keep it all,' says Vandike, who went on to become a band promoter, organising gigs for artists such as the Sex Pistols.

He kept any left-over sou venirs. 'Spare posters, programmes, tickets, you name it.' Storage was always a problem; the garage was regularly cleared out. 'I must have burned at least three-quarters of everything.'

What remained, Vandike later realised, was a 'little goldmine'. One album alone could now fetch £5,000. In addition to being an avid collector, Vandike is now an ob-sessive dealer - he claims to be one of the world's most respected dealers in rare records from the Fifties, Sixties and Seventies. 'Not bad for someone who just happened to be in the right place at the right time,' he says.

But an ad hoc approach does not always pay dividends. Sometimes what is required is good old fashioned meticulousness. Enter Ronnie Roter. Twenty-five years ago he decided to become an expert in his chosen subject - Gone With The Wind . 'I am now the UK's foremost authority on the film. I am by far the leading collector outside America.'

Roter owns thousands of pieces, from signed books to bound manuscripts estimated to be worth $20,000 each. Then there is a letter written by Clark Gable that Roter bought from an elderly American. 'It's probably worth £5,000 to £10,000,' he says. 'Prices really have shot up astronomically; what I own is worth a lot of money - at least £200,000.'

Yet not all collections, no matter how comprehensive or obscure, gain in value. Alexander Crum Ewing, director of collections at Bonhams, explains further. 'We once had a lady ring us up with 2,000 Smurfs. The most they would fetch is £1 each, but moving them as a lot would be very difficult. We said the best she could do was buy herself a woolly scarf, block out several Sundays and set herself up at a car boot sale.'

So what makes a good in-vestment and what makes a dud? Hugh Scully, presenter of the Antiques Road Show and valuer for online auctioneer QXL.com, provides a simple answer. 'Value is governed by quality, rarity, fashion and nostalgia.'

Here's how to get the mix right. First, do your research. 'Know what you should be buying and what you should be paying,' says Jones of Collect it! Next, make sure the area you are collecting has potential - either it is a steady bet, a good outsider or a complete long shot where you try to predict what will be the next big thing. The latter, says Jones, is a real risk, 'but that's the fun of the gamble'.

When you do start to buy, go for what you like. 'Choose what excites you, what in-spires you, what tempts you,' says Wonnacott of Sotheby's.

And always get the best quality you can afford in the best condition you can find. 'You're much better off with one perfect, decent piece than five tired, mediocre pieces,' says Crum Ewing.

Once your collection starts to build, get it properly valued and fully insured. 'Do this sooner rather than later,' advises David Hoyles, insurance manager for Age Concern Enterprises.

If you do put a piece on the market, check out where it will sell best - with a dealer, at an auction, or on the internet. Seek advice from the relevant collector group.

Also bear in mind any financial implications of the sale. If you make more than £7,200, you'll face capital gains tax. If you trade a lot, the Inland Revenue may deem you to be earning an income and tax you accordingly. 'This is very open to interpretation,' says Jon Briggs, associate director of Chart-well Asset Management. 'Timing is important.'

More and more people are getting into collecting. The market is worth £650 million a year according to Business Intelligence Service, which says the average spend has increased 11 per cent. This begs the question of what that money is being spent on, and which markets will be hot in the future.

'If I knew the answer to that, I would now be on a very large yacht in the south of France sipping a nice cool Sancerre,' says Scully. 'But I can give a few hints. Look out for things that are of today, that reflect the end of the twentieth century and the dawn of a new millennium.'

But even if a collector does get it right, they are usually loth to sell their treasures anyway, regardless of how much they can make. 'Collectors are passionate people and I know of no case where someone has willingly parted with a collection,' says Scully. 'To many it would be worse than divorce.'

Wonnacott agrees. 'It's never about the financial gain; it's always about the pleasure involved. It is something deeply ingrained in us. Maybe it goes back to our hunter-gatherer instinct. We feel a compulsion to go out and find things that bring us joy and happiness and comfort. Things that we can bring back into our inner space - our haven.

'And once they are in place, there is no way you will want to part with them, whether they are worth 50p or much more.'

Sometimes what is required is good old fashioned meticulousness. Enter Ronnie Roter. Twenty-five years ago he decided to become an expert in his chosen subject - Gone With The Wind . 'I am now the UK's foremost authority on the film. I am by far the leading collector outside America.' Roter owns thousands of pieces, from signed books to bound manuscripts estimated to be worth $20,000 each. Then there is a letter written by Clark Gable that Roter bought from an elderly American. 'It's probably worth £5,000 to £10,000,' he says. 'Prices really have shot up astronomically; what I own is worth a lot of money - at least £200,000.' Yet not all collections, no matter how comprehensive or obscure, gain in value. Alexander Crum Ewing, director of collections at Bonhams, explains further. 'We once had a lady ring us up with 2,000 Smurfs. The most they would fetch is £1 each, but moving them as a lot would be very difficult. We said the best she could do was buy herself a woolly scarf, block out several Sundays and set herself up at a car boot sale.' So what makes a good in-vestment and what makes a dud? Hugh Scully, presenter of the Antiques Road Show and valuer for online auctioneer QXL.com, provides a simple answer. 'Value is governed by quality, rarity, fashion and nostalgia.' Here's how to get the mix right. First, do your research. 'Know what you should be buying and what you should be paying,' says Jones of Collect it! Next, make sure the area you are collecting has potential - either it is a steady bet, a good outsider or a complete long shot where you try to predict what will be the next big thing. The latter, says Jones, is a real risk, 'but that's the fun of the gamble'. When you do start to buy, go for what you like. 'Choose what excites you, what in-spires you, what tempts you,' says Wonnacott of Sotheby's. And always get the best quality you can afford in the best condition you can find. 'You're much better off with one perfect, decent piece than five tired, mediocre pieces,' says Crum Ewing. Once your collection starts to build, get it properly valued and fully insured. 'Do this sooner rather than later,' advises David Hoyles, insurance manager for Age Concern Enterprises. If you do put a piece on the market, check out where it will sell best - with a dealer, at an auction, or on the internet. Seek advice from the relevant collector group. Also bear in mind any financial implications of the sale. If you make more than £7,200, you'll face capital gains tax. If you trade a lot, the Inland Revenue may deem you to be earning an income and tax you accordingly. 'This is very open to interpretation,' says Jon Briggs, associate director of Chart-well Asset Management. 'Timing is important.' More and more people are getting into collecting. The market is worth £650 million a year according to Business Intelligence Service, which says the average spend has increased 11 per cent. This begs the question of what that money is being spent on, and which markets will be hot in the future. 'If I knew the answer to that, I would now be on a very large yacht in the south of France sipping a nice cool Sancerre,' says Scully. 'But I can give a few hints. Look out for things that are of today, that reflect the end of the twentieth century and the dawn of a new millennium.' But even if a collector does get it right, they are usually loth to sell their treasures anyway, regardless of how much they can make. 'Collectors are passionate people and I know of no case where someone has willingly parted with a collection,' says Scully. 'To many it would be worse than divorce.' Wonnacott agrees. 'It's never about the financial gain; it's always about the pleasure involved. It is something deeply ingrained in us. Maybe it goes back to our hunter-gatherer instinct. We feel a compulsion to go out and find things that bring us joy and happiness and comfort. Things that we can bring back into our inner space - our haven. 'And once they are in place, there is no way you will want to part with them, whether they are worth 50p or much more.'

webTitle: Take a closer look at Tessa rates

fields.headline: Take a closer look at Tessa rates
fields.standfirst: A new ruling means account holders could be entitled to a top-up, writes  Maria Scott
fields.trailText: A new ruling means account holders could be entitled to a top-up, writes Maria Scott.
fields.body:
Savers with Tessa accounts should check the rates they are being paid. They may be entitled to compensation if they have been earning less than on a comparable account with the same bank or building society, or if their money has been locked in by penalties.

A ruling was issued by the Financial Ombudsman Ser vice last week on how banks and societies should treat Tessa savers after a flood of complaints about poor rates on the now obsolete ac-counts. Several organisations are likely to have been in breach of the guidance laid down by the Ombudsman, and some savers might have been short-changed by more than £150.

But some banks and building societies seemed in no mood last week to simply top up and backdate Tessa rates.

It looks likely that savers will have to do the leg-work themselves and lodge a formal complaint with their bank or society. If it does not offer a solution that suits them, he or she can appeal to the Ombudsman.

The nub of this row is that many banks and building societies have been paying less on Tessa accounts than on Isas, the Government-backed tax-free savings scheme that replaced the Tessa in April 1999. Savers have become unhappy, particularly since they were often unable to transfer their Tessas to another organisation because of penalties.

The Ombudsman said he would probably not order compensation if the provider passed at least one of two tests: It paid a 'fair' rate of interest on the Tessa. 'Fair' means that it was at least as good as that paid on any other account with less onerous features in the bank or society's range. The account would not necessarily be an Isa, therefore.

 It told investors by 5 May 1999 that the Tessa could be moved freely. The Ombudsman ruled that savers should have been told within 30 days of the scrapping of Tessas, on 5 April 1999, that they were 'superseded' accounts. Savers should have been able to move without penalty after that time.

The Ombudsman says that in cases where compensation is appropriate he would order the bank or building society to pay the difference between the Tessa rate and the comparable account up to the date the investor was told the account could be transferred without penalty.

Britannia building society is paying 6.4 per cent on most of its Tessas against 6.85 per cent on its mini cash Isas. Until July it imposed penalties of 90 days' notice on savers who wanted to move their money. But Britannia believes it does not need to do more to comply with the Ombudsman's ruling. A spokeswoman said: 'We feel the Ombudsman is messing in an area where he shouldn't be.'

Abbey National pays 5.95 per cent on a variable rate Tessa, while its Isas pay between 5.95 and 6.65 per cent. Abbey told customers in February 1999 that the Tessa would soon be superseded but it did not remove the £30 administration fee for transfers until August.

Nevertheless, Janet Connor, director of savings, says the bank stands by its rate and believes Tessa custom-ers have been given a fair deal. The Tessa's rate has compared well with the base rate over the period.

Others look to have a clearer position to defend.

Bristol & West said it did not expect to have to fend off complaints. B&W's Tessa carried a penalty until April this year, but the bank had reviewed rates on the variable Tessa and, when its maturity bonuses were taken into account, these had been equivalent to those on the bank's Isa and others comparable accounts. The Ombdusman says that bonuses can be counted towards the overall rate on a Tessa, when comparing it with other accounts.

Halifax looks to be in the clear.

Its Isa Saver account, paying between 4.15 and 6.6 per cent, has a seven-day notice penalty for withdrawals; the Tessa account pays 6.05 per cent, but there are no penalties. So the terms on the Isa are more onerous than on the Tessa, rather than the reverse - one of the issues the Ombudsman has highlighted.

Customers of other organisations may have some difficulty working out whether they have received a fair deal. Several organisations have now equalised Isa and Tessa rates, but rates may have been out of line before this.

Another complication is that the Isa rate is not necessarily the one to compare with a Tessa, given that the Ombudsman says the Tessa rate must be as good as any other account with less onerous features. However, the Ombudsman's office says a comparison with Isa rates would be a reasonable starting point.

Savers must complain first to the bank or society; if no resolution is reached, they can contact the Ombudsman on 020 7931 0044 (societies) or 0845 766 0902 (banks).

webTitle: Justice finally breaks the wedlock deadlock

fields.headline: Justice finally breaks the wedlock deadlock
fields.standfirst: The Human Rights Act should make life easier for unmarried partners and gay couples, says  Neasa MacErlean. But are our judges up to the challenge?
fields.trailText: The Human Rights Act should make life easier for unmarried partners and gay couples, says Neasa MacErlean. But are our judges up to the challenge?
fields.body:
Don't hold your breath for it - but the UK is tomorrow embarking on a path that is likely to produce stronger rights for couples who live together rather than getting married.

The Human Rights Act, which comes into force tomorrow, enshrines a set of rights that all citizens will be entitled to. These include the rights to liberty and security, respect for private and family life and 'an effective remedy'. No one really knows how UK judges will interpret the new law - because a rights-based approach is new to the UK - but there is some consensus that cohabitees will gradually see their rights strengthened.

Since the Act specifically rules out discrimination against individuals on the ground of their sexual orientation, gay people are likely to acquire rights over the long term which would put them on a par with heterosexual couples - who can get married. Law firm Belmont Hodgson, which specialises in gay issues, is planning to challenge the Inheritance Tax situation - under which gay couples miss out on the more favourable tax treatment for husbands and wives.

If a wife dies, for instance, there is no IHT on any gifts or assets of hers which she passes to her husband. If, however, a woman living with another woman dies, the partner is liable for IHT on those assets if the estate is bigger than the current IHT threshold of £234,000 and if the other IHT exemptions are used up.

Belmont Hodgson's case concerns two men who lived together in a committed relationship for 30 years. Partner Andrew Belmont is in correspondence with the Inland Revenue but says: 'We expect the case to be fully contested.'

The Revenue has said it will continue to interpret the law as it does at the moment - giving IHT relief only to married couples - unless it is explicitly informed that the law has changed, either in a court case or via new tax legislation.

The difficulty about mounting this sort of challenge under the Human Rights Act is the cost. Since government bodies such as the Inland Revenue may decide to fight these issues all the way, any legal challenge could be very expensive. The Act is based on the European Convention on Human Rights and represents a fundamental change in the way UK law works.

Instead of protecting rights by coming to very specific conclusions through court hearings (the way that case law works in this country), the Act states the broad rights to which all citizens are entitled. It could be said that tomorrow marks the biggest change of approach since Henry II laid down the makings of the modern legal system back in the 1150s.

Mediation and family law expert Alastair Logan of the Logan Partnership in Guildford believes that the 'right to respect for private and family life' could see legal changes to improve the lot of unmarried cohabitees and their children. 'Children have a right to a family life. Does it matter to a child if its mummy and daddy are married or not? I don't think so. But are you discriminating against that child if they are then treated differently? I can see that there will be a lot of pressure in this area.'

At the moment, a mother can win maintenance payments for herself from her ex-partner only if she was married to him. It could be argued that a child she now looks after is disadvantaged and discriminated against if there is less money entering the household because the parents never tied the knot.

But many of the challenges brought under the new law are likely to be rather complicated in this way. It is possible, for instance, that a case for a more generous Legal Aid system could be made under the 'right to an effective remedy' which states that 'everyone... shall have an effective remedy before a national authority...' An imaginative judge might say that the current remedies are ineffective since people cannot afford to go to law. A more traditional approach would be to say that the remedy is available, and it is up to individuals how they sort out paying for such a remedy.

Some bodies have been long prepared for tomorrow's changes. The Financial Ombudsman Service (FOS), for instance, is preparing for a slight increase in the number of people asking for a hearing in front of a tribunal, under the rights now outlined to fair trials.

At the moment, the different ombudsmen who work in the FOS office try to keep such hearings to a mini mum, so that cases can be dealt with quickly, easily and fairly informally.

The senior ombudsman, Walter Merricks, says: 'We're not going to go overboard on it - but from 2 October people will be entitled to ask for a hearing.'

In theory, the Act applies only to public bodies - so, for instance, that a worker in the private sector would have less chance of asserting their right to privacy against an employer than a local government officer, a teacher in a state school or a soldier.

This issue could well come to a head if employees are sacked when bosses monitor their emails and find something they do not like. Linda Parry, of solicitor Keoghs in Bolton, believes that the law could be made to stretch to the private sector if employment tribunals (themselves public bodies) feel they have to apply the Human Rights Act to all people who appear before them.

It is difficult to imagine that tribunal chairs would wish to develop different rulings for private and public sector workers. The bigger problem, in practice, could be the issue of remedies that tribunals could give out.

'There is no automatic right to compensation,' says Parry. While a tribunal could give an award for damages, if it thought someone had been unfairly dismissed, it may be inclined to seek a non-financial solution, such as reinstatement of the employee.

The crucial issue is how judges interpret the law. It may be that it takes another 10 years before a more modern set of men and women occupy the judges' seats.

The case for 'civil partnerships'

The part of last month's Liberal Democratic Party conference which most annoyed the Daily Telegraph was the proposal for 'civil partnerships'. Some commentators have started calling it a plan for 'gay marriage' - but that is not an accurate description.

Under the Lib Dem plan - put forward to coincide with the Human Rights Act - both heterosexual and gay couples could ask to have their partnership registered in a half-way house between cohabitation and marriage.

'Although the Liberal Democrats have not said it as such, I would expect that the new rights would be a bit less than you would get in marriage,' says family law expert Mark Harper of law firm Withers. 'Maybe the rules on maintenance would be different. It may be that the new law would say that the people cohabiting would be expected to be self-supporting if they split up.' After marriage, however, a dependent spouse can apply for maintenance from the other partner.

The Lib Dem proposals do say that the civil partnership would cover prop erty, inheritance and pensions issues (as well as maintenance - although, as Harper says, this could be watered down if there are no children involved).

While the Law Society, the solicitors' body, has called for a wide-ranging cohabitation law which would cover people living together, the Lib Dem plan would require people to opt into it. Hilary Siddle of law firm Holden & Wilsons in Lancaster has been heavily involved in the Law Society campaign. 'Reform of the law could stop a lot of litigation over things written on the back of a fag packet,' she says. The offices of family lawyers are full of impoverished ex-partners who realise too late that the law gives them little help if they want a share of their ex-partner's wealth. A wife could win the marital home in a settlement, while a cohabitee may end up with nothing.

But when the Law Society published its cohabitation proposals last year, it felt politicians would not welcome such a controversial change. Siddle says: 'When the Government has decided that it won't introduce no-fault divorce, it certainly won't take on board changes that take non-marital relationships under the state umbrella.'

fields.headline: On the market
fields.standfirst: Aberdeen Global Champions Fund
fields.trailText: Aberdeen Global Champions Fund
fields.body:
Contact 0800 353737

Aim To provide capital growth by investing in companies that can benefit from developments in globalisation, innovation (technology) and/or communication.

Bells & whistles The fund will be run by Aberdeen's US equities team, headed by star manager Katherine Garrett-Cox. She says: 'The leaders of tomorrow are those companies which demonstrate the know-how, strength and vision to exploit the major themes that are driving world growth: globalisation, innovation and communication... With a dynamic approach and without traditional asset allocation constraints, we are able to anticipate the evolution of these themes and exploit growth by cherry-picking individual stocks.'

How it works The fund will typically invest in between 50 and 75 stocks, a mixture of proven, world-class companies and smaller, less-established companies that offer potential for growth. It will be biased towards the US and will initially have 75 per cent invested there. Typical investments may include AOL/Time Warner, Heineken, Intel and Pfizer.

Minimum £500 lump sum, £50 a month.

Charges 3.75 per cent initial until October 20 then rising to 4.25 per cent; 1.5 per cent annual.

Tax Maxi- or mini-Isa; Pep and Isa transfers available.

Risk Medium/high.

Should you invest? Amanda Davidson of London independent financial adviser Holden Meehan,says: 'We may well recommend this - the managers have got a good track record. It's also going to have some higher-risk investments in there, and it's heavily biased towards the US, but you would expect that for a fund concentrating on these themes.'

Chris Wicks of Glossop-based Bridgewater Financial Planning says: 'Aberdeen has a great track record in this sort of thing, but it's not mainstream. I would use this for any spare cash left over once you've got the rest of your portfolio sorted out along traditional geographical asset allocation lines.'

Points out of 10 Davidson - 7, Wicks - 7.

fields.headline: Web watch
fields.trailText: To avoid being sent endless details of unsuitable properties, log on to a website and get a feel for what you are looking for.
fields.body:
Being sent endless details of unsuitable properties is one of the more tedious parts of moving house. It's much easier to log on to a website and get a feel for what you are looking for.

Most well-known estate agents have their own website offering basic property searches: examples are www.knightfrank.com or www.haart.co.uk. Flats or houses for sale or rent can be chosen according to geographical location or value.

Most property websites, however, are connected in some way to a financial service. For example, www.rightmove.co.uk is sponsored by Halifax, and www.assertahome.com is a subsidiary of CGNU and pulls together a massive portfolio of properties nationwide.

www.smartestates.com is a totally independent site offering everything from a property search and mortgage suggestions to the organisation of your removals online. Registration is obligatory before viewing its properties, but giving an address (home or web) will not necessarily provoke unsolicited mail.

www.findaproperty.com is also completely independent and covers the whole of Britain. Properties alone are marketed on this site, with no advertising by anyone other than the estate agents supplying property details. It is updated daily, which makes availability more accurate than most.

www.propertyfinder.co.uk is a very thorough site. Several views of the property are offered as well as detailed specifications. There is also an impressive range of properties abroad.

www.onepercent.co.uk calls itself London's internet estate agent but it is actually one of many. The site is updated frequently, which means that the properties on view are actually available at the time. Properties are sold through the website for a fee of 1 per cent including VAT, which is far cheaper than through an agency. If the thought of buying a property online is too frightening, it does have operators available by telephone. The site is thorough: it has good photographs and a comprehensive floor plan of each property.

www.home.co.uk is one of the few sites which acts like a search engine in itself by pulling together property details from several other sites and consequently the database is huge. This site has facts relating to around 200,000 properties and can guarantee that 60-70 per cent of the properties are available at all time.

www.homemovers.co.uk is another site claiming to be Britain's largest property database. This is difficult to prove but the site does have some helpful information, particularly for the first-time buyer, involving types of mortgage, conveyancing and the actual process of moving house.

www.globalresident.com is a site reserved for property rental in central London exclusively. Only one photograph of the outside of the house or flat is shown and very few details are given before you need to contact a viewing agent. Drifting past an estate agent's window, however, is not much more help. www.gonative.co.uk is a great site for people considering property rental on a short-term basis. Ninety per cent of its transactions are corporate lettings. It offers a high calibre of service to the tenant (including pick up from the airport) and allows landlords to log in from abroad.

In general, property for sale needs to be high in price to merit the marketing tools of, say, 3D virtual tours. Just for fun, log on to www.ipix.com and sample these more sophisticated pictures.

webTitle: Ease the pain of university fees

fields.headline: Ease the pain of university fees
fields.standfirst: Parents need to plan. Saving your potential undergraduate's child benefit is a good start, says  Virginia Wallis
fields.trailText: Parents need to plan. Saving your potential undergraduate's child benefit is a good start, says Virginia Wallis.
fields.body:
Whatever your views on private education, you have to admit it has one advantage: by the time your child goes to university, you will be used to parting with substantial amounts of cash three times a year. Parents who choose the state sector face an expensive shock.

Saving up to put your child through university is no different from putting aside money for anything else. If you know when you'll need to spend it, how much you will have to contribute towards tuition fees and living expenses and you have a fair idea of the return you can expect on your savings, working out what you will need is relatively simple.

Yes, but it's only simple if you have those sorts of facts at your fingertips. Since my elder daughter is only eight, I'm not really familiar with tuition fees and the like.
If she was off to college next week and chose the costliest option, studying in London, the most your Local Education Authority (LEA) would expect a family with an income of£40,000 or more to contribute each year would be £2,195. This comprises £1,050 for fees and £1,145 towards her upkeep (£995 in her final year). A student loan of £3,445 would pay the rest of her living costs.

So if she does a three-year course I can wave goodbye to nearly £6,500?
In today's money, yes. But if the costs rise in line with inflation at 2.6 per cent, in 10 years' time the total will be more like £8,500.

But presumably if I could set aside £6,500 now, I needn't worry about rising prices so long as the rate of return was greater than inflation.
That would be more than enough. But given that a lot could change in 10 years and that your daughter may want to do a course lasting longer than three years, £6,500 is a reasonable target. What about your other daughter?

She's five.
So there's every chance that by the time she starts university, your elder daughter will have finished?

Yes, but what difference does that make?
The amount the LEA expects you to contribute is based on your income, not on the number of students you support. So if they were to go at the same time, your contribution would be shared between them. But since they're likely to go at different times, you'll need to set aside another £6,500.

I'm not sure I can spare the first £6,500 and I certainly haven't got £13,000.
Could their grandparents help?

Not really. They're doting, but not well off. What next?
What about your younger daughter's child benefit? If you saved that, you would have a lump sum of more than£10,000 in 13 years' time. Assuming the £10 a week benefit rises with inflation and your savings earn 5 per cent, that would be about £2,000 more than you would need to fund her uni versity costs. You could amass the same sum in 10 years by saving the £15 a week you get for your elder daughter as well.

Is that as well as or instead of setting aside the £6,500?
As well as, if you'd rather she didn't have to fund most of her living costs by taking out a student loan.

Would saving their child benefit be enough to keep them out of debt altogether?
No. To have a chance of doing that, as well as covering what the LEA would expect, you would need a lump sum of around £21,000 for the first-born; £23,000 for the second.

How much a month would I have to save to do that?
About £100 for each child.

And if I don't save that much I suppose I'll just have to feel guilty about allowing them to get into debt?
No. Student loans are a cheap way of borrowing, so the alternative to saving up first is to offer to pay off their loans after graduation. And they may always be hired by an employer who pays off their debt.

fields.headline: Our neighbours are so nice, we live with them
fields.standfirst: Co-housing  brings personal and financial benefits, writes  Graham Norwood
fields.trailText: Co-housing brings personal and financial benefits, writes Graham Norwood.
fields.body:
Have you talked to your neighbour today? This week? If you are in London, what about this year?

People disenchanted with isolated homes could consider co-housing. This is the concept of collaborative housing designed and run by residents who want their own private space but wish to operate as a community when that works better - looking after dependants or cooking meals, for example.

The first modern co-housing project was started in Denmark nearly 40 years ago by young urban professionals. They were not committed to communal living; they simply wanted good childcare. The model now constitutes 5 per cent of the country's housing.

In the US, the Co-housing Network has come closest to setting out a philosophy for this kind of living. It sets out four main characteristics:

 a participatory process - residents design, sometimes build, the community

 a neighbourhood design - private houses for families or individuals, but also communal facilities such as lounges, meeting rooms and childcare areas

 resident management - local people run the facilities

 non-hierarchical organisation - different individuals lead on different areas of activity but there is no one overall leader.

British co-housing is growing, with 11 groups joining a new umbrella organisation and several operating independently. Communities exist or are starting at Bruton in Somerset, Exeter, Edinburgh, Lewes, London, Bath, Rotherham and the Colne Valley. Some link communal living with new-age activities such as meditation and green politics; others stress that it is simply a common- sense way of organising homes, and have otherwise-traditional residents among their number.

One successful scheme is The Community Project at Laughton in East Sussex, which even has a website to promote its activities. Three large buildings have been converted into 17 family houses, and four new houses are to be built there shortly. Some 23 acres of land and other buildings provide communal facilities for the 35 adults and 23 children in the group.

The project is a company which owns the freehold of all land and buildings, and community members purchase individual properties by leasehold. Each leaseholder then becomes a director of the company.

This structure optimises the financial position for the company and gives it legal sanctions against any community member failing to meet community obligations - a standard structure for co-housing groups.

Not every group is as far advanced, and getting the critical mass of funding and purpose to start such a project can be tough. 'Half of our group want co-housing on a site in Exeter, and half want it in a rural area outside,' says Lynn Wetenhall of the Exe Co-Housing Group, which has been in existence for two years but has still to find a site for its community.

'About a year ago we were incredibly close to getting a site near Cullompton, but we were two or three households short of having the right funding,' she says.

If you can get the funding, the practical and financial rewards can be high. Britain's first new-build co-housing project starts construction soon near Stroud town centre, where eight flats, 18 houses and one community house will be built. People bought into the scheme by committing at least £5,000 each for a plot deposit and the rest will be required in tranches as building progresses. Each plot-owner becomes an equal shareholder in a company to own the land and the communal house.

Each flat has two bedrooms and will cost an estimated £47,000 to complete - £18,000 for the land and the rest for building work. The houses range from three to five bedrooms and will cost around £125,000 each to complete - cheap at the price, as Stroud estate agents estimate a comparable existing modern house would cost around £190,000.

One of the longer-established UK co-housing communities is Frankleigh House, a huge former school in Bradford on Avon, which started in 1995.

The house is now owned equally by 13 people. There is a swimming pool, tennis court and 17 acres of meadows. The property cost £285,000 and may now be worth around four times that amount.

Some of the funding for Frankleigh came from the ethical Triodos Bank, which supports a handful of Britain's co-housing ventures. Unlike most high street lenders, it will provide co-housing mortgages in the conventional way and also lends on the basis of personal guarantees - legally binding agreements to repay fixed amounts in the event of defaulting on a mortgage.

For new-build, Triodos will consider lending 50 per cent of the value of the land and two-thirds of the build ing costs; for existing properties being converted to co-housing, it will consider lending between 50 per cent and 70 per cent of the cost.

'We make a judgment about the social and financial benefits of a new type of housing like this,' says Triodos spokesperson Susan Jenkins. 'Co-housing often involves car-pooling, growing organic vegetables and so on, so it clearly makes a contribution to the community.'

It may also get neighbours talking to each other again.

Further information

UK Co-Housing Network

Triodos Bank - 0800 328 2181

Exeter co-housing group - lynn.w@eclipse.co.uk

webTitle: Heather Connon: Spread your bets on dotcoms

fields.headline: Spread your bets on dotcoms
fields.trailText: The profits warning from Intel, the chip-maker, was a major shock to investors.
fields.body:
The valuation of technology stocks is predicated on them beating the already-optimistic forecasts of investment analysts, so it was hardly surprising that the profits warning from Intel, the chip-maker, was a major shock to investors.

Ever-bullish analysts are doing their best to explain why Intel's warning is not necessarily bad news for the entire sector: special factors, such as earlier shortages of Intel chips, have caused this temporary blip; mobile phones are taking over from personal computers as the way to access the internet.

But there is little doubt that investors are becoming much more nervous about the new economy than they were. Despite attempts at a rally, most notably last month, the Techmark 100 index is more than a third below its March peak, while Nasdaq has fallen by a quarter over the same period. Should those with technology holdings be selling now? Or does the recent dip in the market make this a good time to buy?

Much depends on the type of stocks you hold and your attitude to risk. The consumer-oriented stocks - internet service providers such as Freeserve or e-tailers such as QXL and Lastminute - have already fallen far more sharply than other technology stocks, but there could still be further to go. A survey by accountants PricewaterhouseCoopers found that 20 of the top 150 European dotcoms could run out of cash within a year and that fewer than a quarter of British ones are yet making profits. Many will need to raise new money - extremely difficult in the current market - merge, or they could go out of business.

Spotting winners among those supplying the software, the architecture and the services required for life on the web is a little easier. Most analysts believe that Autonomy, the Easdaq-quoted company which specialises in analysing the huge content of the web, is a clear leader in its field. ARM Holdings has a blue-chip customer base and its licences are growing fast.

Pace Microtechnology is one of the dominant supplier of digital receivers and decoders; Baltimore is growing rapidly on the back of its security products.

But change in the market can happen rapidly. These companies may have a head start, but they can be caught. The flotation of ARC, rival to ARM, shows that a dominant position is not invincible.

The best way to reduce the risk of picking losers is to spread your bets by buying into a trust. Henderson, which runs two unit trusts and an investment trust, had a good reputation but Brian Ashford-Russell, who ran the funds, is departing so these are best avoided for the moment. Jeremy Batstone, of NatWest Markets, favours 3i, the venture capital group. Although it looks expensive - its shares are at an 85 per cent premium to asset value - its valuation method is conservative and its spread of investments is impressive.

webTitle: Long term care: Why this time it's personal

fields.headline: Why this time it's personal
fields.standfirst: Government reforms leave the elderly vulnerable to higher care charges,  Neasa MacErlean reports
fields.trailText: Government reforms leave the elderly vulnerable to higher care charges, Neasa MacErlean reports.
fields.body:
There are management consultants in the US who advise the owners of nursing and residential homes on how they can make their residents more dependent. In that great free market, the entrepreneurs who run old people's homes know that they will make more money from people who have greater physical needs and who are too frail to shop around for help elsewhere.

The Alzheimer's Society is concerned that a similar sit uation could develop here. The Government's plans to refocus the funding of long-term care will give a clear incentive to homeowners to provide nursing care whenever they can.

Under the proposals announced in July and likely to be debated in parliament this year, people going into homes will find that their nursing costs are paid for by the state. However, they will still have to fund their own 'personal care costs'. The owners of most nursing homes peg their fees in relation to the level of government funding available. At the very least, most will automatically raise their fees to absorb the extra funding available. At the worst, some will find ways of making their clients more dependent. This is not as far-fetched as it might sound. There is already considerable evidence to show that home residents are systematically over-drugged and in a state of chemically induced dependency.

The Government is soon to receive a huge blast from charities representing the elderly. A letter from a consortium of groups, including Help the Aged and the Alzheimer's Society, is to be sent to all MPs by the middle of this month, expressing their 'profound disappointment' over the plans.

Moves to overhaul the present system of long-term care were started in 1997 when the Labour Government announced the creation of the Royal Commission on Long-Term Care for the Elderly. This reported last year, urging that all nursing and personal care costs be met by the Government. The Government was understandably wary of the costs involved. It decided to go for a much cheaper option, funding the nursing care element, which it announced in July this year. (Personal care costs would still be funded if the elderly people involved could not meet the bill themselves - but many people would still be forced to sell their homes and use up all their pensions on homes' fees.)

The big problem with the proposals is the narrow definition of nursing care. Under the plans, someone with Alzheimer's would get very little financial assistance. Helping someone get dressed is defined as personal care, as is helping them eat their food or go to the toilet. Nursing care is something done by a registered nurse. As the law stands, there need be only one nurse on duty in a nursing home at any one time. Nursing care will largely be restricted to medical duties such as dispensing drugs.

The charities are also angry that the Government has done little to encourage healthy living and prevent dependency. 'We are profoundly disappointed with the proposed Government solution,' says Mervyn Kohler of Help the Aged. 'It has missed the opportunity to do anything of any value whatsoever.'

Prevention has been very low down the list of Government priorities - though it is enormously cost-effective. Older people who keep themselves fit have a far higher chance of having a longer and healthier old age.

The tiny charity Research into Ageing has just commissioned research into reducing the effect of falls. Hardly a glamorous subject, the study of falls has huge implications for both individual and state.

One in three women over 65 and one in five men have a fall each year. About 20 per cent of these falls lead to injury or fracture. The majority of admissions into hospital in this age group, and 40 per cent of nursing home admissions, are due to falls. Fractures, which are mainly due to falls, cost the National Health Service £940 million each year.

Research into Ageing is now working on a short physical education programme which appears to cut the chances of falling by 50 per cent by, for instance, strengthening ankles, the lower leg and the physical confidence of pensioners. National programmes of this sort would have a negligible cost to the state. To the individual it might mean a weekly visit to a gentle aerobics class. But the costs saved could be enormous.

Similarly, early diagnosis can prevent people from losing their sight or developing osteoporosis, conditions that frequently send the sufferers straight into nursing or residential homes at a huge personal and financial cost. For instance, it is now possible to get a bone density test for £10 - an examination which, if you take it at 50 or 60, can steer you away from osteoporosis and give you several extra years of independence in your 80s or 90s.

The charities are all concerned that a major legislative change on long-term care is likely to come only once in a generation. The system adopted in parliament in the next year could still be in place in 20 or 30 years.

The Alzheimer's Society has launched a letter-writing campaign to encourage its members to write to their MPs, registering their demand for a more imaginative, equitable approach to long-term care.

Even the Government's most direct attempt to help the estimated 40,000 peo ple a year who sell their houses to pay for long-term care is being criticised as financially unsound for individuals. Someone in this position could take a loan from their local authority to postpone the sale of their home until after they died - but interest would build up on the fees they owed.

But if they went this route, they would lose any entitlement they might have to Attendance Allowance, worth £53.55 a week.

The Nursing Home Fees Agency, an independent financial adviser, calculates that they would be out of pocket by an average of £43,000 after five years.
fields.bodyText: There are management consultants in the US who advise the owners of nursing and residential homes on how they can make their residents more dependent. In that great free market, the entrepreneurs who run old people's homes know that they will make more money from people who have greater physical needs and who are too frail to shop around for help elsewhere. The Alzheimer's Society is concerned that a similar sit uation could develop here. The Government's plans to refocus the funding of long-term care will give a clear incentive to homeowners to provide nursing care whenever they can. Under the proposals announced in July and likely to be debated in parliament this year, people going into homes will find that their nursing costs are paid for by the state. However, they will still have to fund their own 'personal care costs'. The owners of most nursing homes peg their fees in relation to the level of government funding available. At the very least, most will automatically raise their fees to absorb the extra funding available. At the worst, some will find ways of making their clients more dependent. This is not as far-fetched as it might sound. There is already considerable evidence to show that home residents are systematically over-drugged and in a state of chemically induced dependency. The Government is soon to receive a huge blast from charities representing the elderly. A letter from a consortium of groups, including Help the Aged and the Alzheimer's Society, is to be sent to all MPs by the middle of this month, expressing their 'profound disappointment' over the plans. Moves to overhaul the present system of long-term care were started in 1997 when the Labour Government announced the creation of the Royal Commission on Long-Term Care for the Elderly. This reported last year, urging that all nursing and personal care costs be met by the Government. The Government was understandably wary of the costs involved. It decided to go for a much cheaper option, funding the nursing care element, which it announced in July this year. (Personal care costs would still be funded if the elderly people involved could not meet the bill themselves - but many people would still be forced to sell their homes and use up all their pensions on homes' fees.) The big problem with the proposals is the narrow definition of nursing care. Under the plans, someone with Alzheimer's would get very little financial assistance. Helping someone get dressed is defined as personal care, as is helping them eat their food or go to the toilet. Nursing care is something done by a registered nurse. As the law stands, there need be only one nurse on duty in a nursing home at any one time. Nursing care will largely be restricted to medical duties such as dispensing drugs. The charities are also angry that the Government has done little to encourage healthy living and prevent dependency. 'We are profoundly disappointed with the proposed Government solution,' says Mervyn Kohler of Help the Aged. 'It has missed the opportunity to do anything of any value whatsoever.' Prevention has been very low down the list of Government priorities - though it is enormously cost-effective. Older people who keep themselves fit have a far higher chance of having a longer and healthier old age. The tiny charity Research into Ageing has just commissioned research into reducing the effect of falls. Hardly a glamorous subject, the study of falls has huge implications for both individual and state. One in three women over 65 and one in five men have a fall each year. About 20 per cent of these falls lead to injury or fracture. The majority of admissions into hospital in this age group, and 40 per cent of nursing home admissions, are due to falls. Fractures, which are mainly due to falls, cost the National Health Service £940 million each year. The system adopted in parliament in the next year could still be in place in 20 or 30 years. webTitle: Maria Scott: Customers win as Standard Life listens

fields.headline: Customers win as Standard Life listens
fields.trailText: Having beaten an attempt earlier this year by members to force it to demutualise, Standard Life has come under huge pressure to demonstrate clearly the benefits of mutuality.
fields.body:
Like the Prime Minister, insurance giant Standard Life is listening. Having beaten an attempt earlier this year by members to force it to demutualise, it has come under huge pressure to demonstrate clearly the benefits of mutuality.

Last week it acted, announcing that it will help policyholders with endowments that are at risk of fail ing to repay homeloans. The undertaking is not a commitment to repay loans, come what may, but should ensure that the policyholders do not have to dip into their own pockets to make up for lower-than-expected returns.

Provided Standard Life earns at least 6 per cent on its investments, the insurer has agreed to plug any gaps. If it earns less, policyholders will have only part of the gap filled. The commitment will cost the firm£60 million a year, but the money is coming from its healthy reserves, rather than from customers and should not, the insurer is adamant, affect their future returns.

At the same time, Standard Life is reducing charges on new and existing pen sions. These will now carry maximum charges of less than 1 per cent, and several confusing layers of charges are being scrapped. The move brings Standard Life products in line with government rules on charges for the new stakeholder pension, to be available from next April.

The move will make a real difference to policyholders, and forecasts for improved returns underline the rip-off levels of charges that have prevailed in the pensions industry until now. Standard Life calculates that a 45-year- old who started a personal pension five years ago and is paying £150 a month into a fund now worth £10,000 will have £4,600 more in his fund when he reaches 60 - assuming investment growth at 7 per cent - than under the old fee structure.

The move on endowments comes just days before the regulatory authorities announce plans for cleaning up the endowment scandal. But better late than never.

There will be much rhetoric from insurers this week attempting to disconnect shortfalls from suggestions of mis-selling. It is true, of course, that shortfalls are a result of falling investment returns, not mis-selling. But most home owners and many insurers and lenders know that even if endowments were not mis-sold, they were oversold.

Standard Life's decision to underwrite losses is a common sense approach to solving the problem. It could have squirmed and wriggled, but it has chosen to admit tacitly that it bears some responsibility for the disappointment policyholders feel.

Its position on pensions is notable. The Observer has consistently called for insurers to cut charges on existing pension policies. Insurers have been forced, by Government action and media pressure, to reduce the swingeing costs of their pension products, but the emphasis has been on new ones. Millions of people have older contracts with much heavier costs and penalties that may make it uneconomic to move to one of the newer cheaper plans.

Other insurers should be studying Standard Life more carefully. Many will be unable to afford across-the-board price cuts because their businesses have been built on fat charges. If price- cutting on existing policies takes hold widely, it will increase the pressure for mergers and takeovers.

Tony Blair's insistence that he is listening to voters may have left many sceptical, but Standard Life's demonstration of empathy with its policyholders should help when next it faces its electorate in a demutualisation vote.

webTitle: Wealthcheck: Into shares and out of the country

fields.headline: Into shares and out of the country
fields.standfirst: John wants to work abroad and buy a home here, he tells  Margaret Dibben
fields.trailText: John wants to work abroad and buy a home here, he tells Margaret Dibben.
fields.body:
John McCarthy

Age 34

Lives in London

Occupation Transport controller

Earns £19,000

Mortgage None

Debts None

Investments £23,000 in shares, £12,000 in Isa/Tessa Scottish Widows with-profits plans (2) Scottish Life with-profits plan, £10,000 in various building societies

Pensions £220 a month to NPI personal pension

Aims To work abroad

John McCarthy met Atsuko at evening classes. She is Japanese and they were both learning German. They are now married and have a son and daughter, Sean and Kennedy, aged two and four, but John has the urge to travel.

During the day he works from the Royal Free Hospi tal, for a charity that arranges transport for patients. He is also studying for a BA in English. When he graduates next year, he will take a TEFL course and wants to teach English abroad for a year or two.

'By that time I will be 35 and the older you get, the less chance you have of getting a job, particularly in a place like Japan where they only want younger teachers.' He has not yet decided where he will go. 'Perhaps Switzerland, Thailand or Japan. I only like big cities.'

Wherever it is, Atsuko will stay in London with the children. She is resident in the UK but has never worked in this country and has no National Insurance number.

John's hobby is dealing in shares. 'I am interested in gadgets, so in the technology boom I bought into a few companies that I knew about. When interest rates and inflation are low, I would not bother putting money in the bank. If you put it in the stock market, you may halve it or you may double it, but at least you have excitement along the way.'

He was successful until the downturn in the dotcom market, which turned £30,000 of shares into £25,000. He tries to cash in when he makes profits but knows that he does not always sell unprofitable shares soon enough. He does not have a sharedealing budget. He says: 'If my wife was working, I would have more disposable income and would deal more.'

At the moment he pays £220 a month in rent and is happy to sell the shares to buy a house.

'I would miss the stock market because I really enjoy it. But bricks and mortar is one of the most profitable and reliable things you can invest in, and you have the security of a house.'

He has around 30 building society accounts, some dormant and some paying economic rates. 'I am not totally in favour of carpet-bagging but you don't want to be the mug who is left behind.'

He wants to know if he can have a stakeholder pension while he is working abroad and whether he should open one for Atsuko.

He thought he had plenty of life insurance but it turns out to be only the small element that comes with savings policies and free accidental death insurance from the bank.

Adviser 1: Danielle Leich

Someone who is UK domiciled can become non-resident for income tax if they work overseas for at least one full tax year. Then his income is not taxable in the UK, regardless of where it is paid. He can invest up to £3,600 a year in a stakeholder pension while abroad, provided he does not lose his UK residency. Non-earning spouses can also contribute, so John could use some of his surplus cash to buy a pension for his wife. The person making the contribution needs to satisfy the residency test.

His with-profits savings plans are combined savings and life insurance policies and the amount of life cover payable is the minimum sum assured. If John requires life cover without savings, he should opt for term insurance as the premiums are cheaper.

Whether to get separate policies for him and his wife depends on the amount of insurance needed. If his wife died, he would have to fund childcare costs, so John should consider a family income policy, which is a type of decreasing term insurance providing income over a fixed period.

Atsuko has no income, so, if some of the building society accounts were in her name, she could claim interest gross. John should also consider giving her some of his investments to use her annual capital gains tax exemption if he makes enough profit to pay the tax. But he must remember that a spouse can use the money given however he or she wants.

Danielle Leich works for PriceWaterhouseCoopers.

Adviser 2: James Dalby

Some of John's money on deposit is unlikely to be earning the best rate of interest. Sainsbury's Bank Instant Access account pays 5.1 per cent gross. The Legal & General Easy Access Tracker account pays 6.25 per cent. Atsuko should make sure she is receiving interest on her savings gross, by completing Inland Revenue form R85, available from bank branches. John should check which Scottish Life fund he is contributing to and possibly consider switching to an alternative.

I would not advocate chasing windfalls, but pulling out is a tough decision: do you stay in the account with miserly interest in the hope of a windfall or move the money elsewhere for a better rate?

John is clearly not aware that he is woefully under insured. Insurance takes on many guises and it is easy to become complacent when you have a number of different policies.

It is extremely important that he assess his life insurance situation as a priority. He has a number of accidental death policies, but they are limited to paying out only on death from an accident.

One of the best steps he can take towards buying a house is to have a decent deposit. He could consider liquidating some of his shares or pulling some of his building society deposits together. If he were to sell shares, he should consider whether to transfer any to his wife first to use both their capital gains tax allowances.

James Dalby works for Bates Investment Services.

Advice is for guidance only

Do you want to appear in Wealthcheck? Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: cash@observer.co.uk. You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

webTitle: Happy hunting ground for 'King of Bartering'

fields.headline: Happy hunting ground for 'King of Bartering'
fields.standfirst: Pay what you can afford, not what you're told, 'Andy' tells  Natalie Sutton
fields.trailText: Pay what you can afford, not what you're told, 'Andy' tells Natalie Sutton.
fields.body:
Andy, a film director of 35, is known as the 'King of Bartering' by his friends. His first experience of haggling with shopkeepers was when he was 15 and desperate for a punk shirt from Kensington Market. 'I kept making this poor bloke go up and down a ladder to fetch a different shirt. When I turned up the next day, he gave in and sold it to me for the money I had.

'I never used to pay the full price,' he says. 'Especially on electrical goods, TVs and stereos. You soon find that you don't have to if you are cheeky or humorous en-ough to get away with it.

'As a student, I used to go to Tottenham Court Road, from one electrical shop to another, asking the salesman to write down his lowest price on a business card. I would then go next door, show them the card and ask if they could give me a lower price. I would carry on to the next shop and the one after that, asking the same thing. Eventually, I would be given the very lowest price possible, but only if I paid then and there - because they soon caught on.'

According to Andy, on certain items worth around £600 to £700, it is possible to bring down the price by up to £200. 'I remember helping a friend to buy a video recorder and she came away with £80 off the marked price and about six videos thrown in.

'If you think about it, it's no different to how people behave professionally. A film producer, for example, will have a budget and will haggle with the caterers or with the people who supply equipment to bring down their price. It's a question of trying to pay what you consider to be reasonable and paying what you can rather than what you are told.'

Bargains in store - if you've nerve

Comet set the cat among the pigeons a year ago when it launched 'The Comet Price: Always low prices guaranteed'. This was accompanied by a warning that the chain was no longer prepared to haggle. Come again? This made consumers feel that they'd been missing a trick - and for how long?

Their Hotpoints and Whirlpools suddenly lost their sparkle - could they have got them for even less? According to a recent Mintel report on white goods sales, 54 per cent of the people interviewed claimed to bargain on price, with empty nesters being the most vocal. A John Lewis salesperson confided that customers attempted to haggle on price 'all the time' and would go back and forth between retailers claiming that so- and-so was offering it for less and could they match the price? This, the saleperson claimed, often included requests for John Lewis to go below even the famous 'never knowingly under- sold' price promise.

While research- ing this article, I tried my luck in retailers such as Dixons, a Sony Centre and Currys and nobody flinched when I suggested buying three or more items in the hope of securing a discount.

In Sketchley I was told that it's always worth asking for a discount if you're having a few things cleaned at the same time. In Habitat, as at Home- base, John Lewis and Comet, any ex-display items suddenly take on the mantle of products in a car boot sale and the rules are instantly rewritten. And, of course, independent retailers can often operate with the flexibility of a market trader.

'Leeway' and 'margins' are key words that most shoppers probably don't mutter under their breath as they mosey along the high street. They would do well to give them a thought. Most retailers, sales assistants and, in particular, store managers, do have a certain amount of leeway - as the extremely forthcoming man in Comet was eager to inform me. And, when it comes to margins, as long as the retailer is making a profit, they are prepared to move a little if it's a case of making, rather than losing, a sale. If sales are down one week - although the average consumer has no idea of whether this is the case - it is likely to mean that the following week, should you try to drive even the softest of bargains, the retailer is likely to say yes.

It's worth asking: they can only say no. Suggesting that they 'throw something in' can be a winner. Since I told people what I was writing about, anecdotes have abounded: videos bundled in with TVs; free duvets with beds; toasters with ovens - you just need the nerve to ask.

The thrill of the chase...

Anne Sampson, pictured, has just launched an internet business called Farm Connection, which sells luxury food direct from specialist producers. She is a professional haggler and has haggled for everything from a hotel room to the price of a LearnDirect course, part-funded by Business Link.

'A lot of it is confidence,' she says. 'Once you've done it a few times, you get used to it. I wasn't brought up to haggle: my parents thought it was rude to question the price of something.

'I think it boils down to knowing what you want; knowing what you're prepared to pay for something, recognising what value it has to you, and then understanding that there is a middle ground on which to negotiate.

'Research is important. When I bought my house I needed a washing machine, a fridge and a vacuum cleaner. I did my research. I'm not so sad that I do a spreadsheet, although I do make notes, using newspapers, websites and going into shops.

'In the end I went to Currys, thinking "This is the arena in which to play". There was a young chap in there and I told him what I wanted to buy. He added the prices up and I asked "What discount can you offer me for buying all three here?" They were actually quite good prices, but I just thought I'd be cheeky. He checked with his manager and offered me 6-7 per cent off. I said: "Couldn't you round it down?" He winced and went back to his manager and they came back with "Staff only get 10 per cent".

I was quite nonchalant and I was almost acting it out. I was always prepared to walk away. But I left feeling quite triumphant, as I got 10 per cent discount, free delivery, interest-free credit and they even installed the washing machine. The discount paid for the vacuum cleaner and I took it away there and then, thinking "I've got it in the boot of my car and I got it free because I haggled for it".

'I suppose my advice is not to be afraid to try it. My husband is even more of a haggler than I am. He can quite happily say "What's today's discount?" or even "What's the Sunny Saturday Discount?". My granny was really into jumble sales but she didn't call them that because "jumble" sounds rubbishy. She used to say: "I'm going sale-ing' or 'I'm going to a rummage". The negotiating gave her a real buzz.

'After a successful haggle, I get the feeling that I've saved a bit of money so I can go and buy something extravagant.'

How to get the best price

 Do your research

 Shop around

 Ask yourself what you are prepared to pay for something

 Be confident

 Act knowledgeably

 Be lighthearted and pleasant

 Don't come across as over-keen

 Be prepared to walk away: you can always come back later

 Act as if you do it all the time - if your voice starts to wobble, you'll lose credibility

 Don't punch air in the shop - it's uncool (and it's just as uncool to do it in the car park)
