According to a recent Mintel report on white goods sales, 54 per cent of the people interviewed claimed to bargain on price, with empty nesters being the most vocal. A John Lewis salesperson confided that customers attempted to haggle on price 'all the time' and would go back and forth between retailers claiming that so- and-so was offering it for less and could they match the price? This, the saleperson claimed, often included requests for John Lewis to go below even the famous 'never knowingly under- sold' price promise. While research- ing this article, I tried my luck in retailers such as Dixons, a Sony Centre and Currys and nobody flinched when I suggested buying three or more items in the hope of securing a discount. In Sketchley I was told that it's always worth asking for a discount if you're having a few things cleaned at the same time. In Habitat, as at Home- base, John Lewis and Comet, any ex-display items suddenly take on the mantle of products in a car boot sale and the rules are instantly rewritten. And, of course, independent retailers can often operate with the flexibility of a market trader. 'Leeway' and 'margins' are key words that most shoppers probably don't mutter under their breath as they mosey along the high street. They would do well to give them a thought. Most retailers, sales assistants and, in particular, store managers, do have a certain amount of leeway - as the extremely forthcoming man in Comet was eager to inform me. And, when it comes to margins, as long as the retailer is making a profit, they are prepared to move a little if it's a case of making, rather than losing, a sale. If sales are down one week - although the average consumer has no idea of whether this is the case - it is likely to mean that the following week, should you try to drive even the softest of bargains, the retailer is likely to say yes. It's worth asking: they can only say no. Suggesting that they 'throw something in' can be a winner. Since I told people what I was writing about, anecdotes have abounded: videos bundled in with TVs; free duvets with beds; toasters with ovens - you just need the nerve to ask. The thrill of the chase... Anne Sampson, pictured, has just launched an internet business called Farm Connection, which sells luxury food direct from specialist producers. She is a professional haggler and has haggled for everything from a hotel room to the price of a LearnDirect course, part-funded by Business Link. 'A lot of it is confidence,' she says. 'Once you've done it a few times, you get used to it. I wasn't brought up to haggle: my parents thought it was rude to question the price of something. 'I think it boils down to knowing what you want; knowing what you're prepared to pay for something, recognising what value it has to you, and then understanding that there is a middle ground on which to negotiate. 'Research is important. When I bought my house I needed a washing machine, a fridge and a vacuum cleaner. I did my research. I'm not so sad that I do a spreadsheet, although I do make notes, using newspapers, websites and going into shops. 'In the end I went to Currys, thinking "This is the arena in which to play". There was a young chap in there and I told him what I wanted to buy. He added the prices up and I asked "What discount can you offer me for buying all three here?" They were actually quite good prices, but I just thought I'd be cheeky. He checked with his manager and offered me 6-7 per cent off. I said: "Couldn't you round it down?" He winced and went back to his manager and they came back with "Staff only get 10 per cent". I was quite nonchalant and I was almost acting it out. I was always prepared to walk away. But I left feeling quite triumphant, as I got 10 per cent discount, free delivery, interest-free credit and they even installed the washing machine. The discount paid for the vacuum cleaner and I took it away there and then, thinking "I've got it in the boot of my car and I got it free because I haggled for it". 'I suppose my advice is not to be afraid to try it. My husband is even more of a haggler than I am. He can quite happily say "What's today's discount?" or even "What's the Sunny Saturday Discount?". My granny was really into jumble sales but she didn't call them that because "jumble" sounds rubbishy. She used to say: "I'm going sale-ing' or 'I'm going to a rummage". The negotiating gave her a real buzz. 'After a successful haggle, I get the feeling that I've saved a bit of money so I can go and buy something extravagant.' How to get the best price  Do your research  Shop around  Ask yourself what you are prepared to pay for something  Be confident  Act knowledgeably  Be lighthearted and pleasant  Don't come across as over-keen  Be prepared to walk away: you can always come back later  Act as if you do it all the time - if your voice starts to wobble, you'll lose credibility  Don't punch air in the shop - it's uncool (and it's just as uncool to do it in the car park)

fields.headline: Ballet gaga
fields.standfirst: Mozart, Queen and Versace collide
fields.trailText:
Ballet for Life Béjart Ballet, Sadler's Wells, London EC1
Angels and Exiles Clore Studio, Royal Opera House, London WC2
fields.body:
Ballet for Life Béjart Ballet, Sadler's Wells, London EC1
Angels and Exiles Clore Studio, Royal Opera House, London WC2

Béjart's Ballet for Life should really be seen in a vast arena filled with ovating fans. It is a requiem-rock show celebrating the deaths and careers of Freddie Mercury (singer), Jorge Donne (dancer), Gianni Versace (designer) - oh, and Mozart. The 90-minute spectacle is way overblown for a modest north London theatre, even though members of Mercury's band, Queen, were in the audience.

Aids ribbons were on sale in the foyers - both Mercury and Donne died of the disease. Donne, Béjart's muse and lover, was iconised on film, to Queen's anthem 'I Want To Break Free'. The dread initials were spelt out by Gil Roman, the company's deputy director and its most extraordinary dancer. He took the role of Death on Two Legs, the saturnine spirit who haunted the show, finger to his lips.

Ballet for Life is so cheesy, so far over the top, that it takes your breath away (to quote one of Queen's songs). At the start, the cast rise from the dead, flourishing shrouds like banners. They seek redemption through synchronised acrobatics and defiant solo spots. Then they insist in the finale that The Show Must Go On, before retreating beneath the sheets.

An angel stalks past on TV-screen platform soles; a Versace-clad couple waltz while corpses embrace each other; a Freddie figure whips off his wig but hangs on to his leather trousers. Mozart and Mercury provide the musical inspiration, from Così fan tutte to 'Radio Gaga'.

The choreography is gibberish, performed as though it makes a higher sense. If you are not totally blown away by Béjart's chutzpah, it is hard not to giggle.

Matthew Hawkins has created his own very personal phantasmagoria in Angels and Exiles. Commissioned by the Back Garden Project at the Royal Opera House, it used the Clore rehearsal space as a celestial studio. Mirrored walls suggested a parallel universe; extracts from César Franck's Redemption sounded like heaven. Sung and recited words (by Franck's collaborator, Edouard Blau) spoke of 'exiles on the far-off shore' seeking a language of faith.

Hawkins started his eclectic career at the Royal Ballet and the grammar of classical ballet still informs his fantasies. Choreographing for Royal Ballet dancers was a kind of coming home. He asked them to draw deep on the fundamentals of their technique while sustaining the eerie lightness of visions, sylphs, sprites.

Costumes by his favourite designer, Pearl, resembled Maori body art. A pink satin serpent of discarded pointe shoes (designed by Sophia Clist) was draped over the barre - a reminder of the fall from grace. The fluid architecture of the piece was hard to discern in such a diffuse space, as Hawkins and dancers from his company as well as the Royal Ballet were multiplied in the mirrors.

A companion piece at matinées by six members of Anjali Dance Company reflected Hawkins's ideas in another light. Dressed by Pearl, they seemed denizens of Prospero's island. The scaly pointe-shoe cable became a fish, a seaweed garland, as these performers with learning difficulties improvised ritual dances. With music by Mendelssohn and Richard Strauss, the programme provided a stranger kind of magic than anything dreamed up by Béjart for his company of beautiful people.

fields.headline: Indecent proposals
fields.trailText: I often think that it's lucky for the world I was born female. As a woman, I'm bad enough, but, as a man, I'd be unstoppable.
fields.body:
I often think that it's lucky for the world I was born female. As a woman, I'm bad enough, but, as a man, I'd be unstoppable. If it didn't come naturally, I'd work at it.

I'd do something in the city, which paid a lot, but corroded my immortal soul. I'd only go out with willowy blondes. I'd be down at the pub every opportunity I got, getting the rounds in, telling jokes, and showing off the glory that is 'he-me'.

I'd pick fights with other men all the time, ostensibly because they were looking at my bird, or knocking over my pint, but really because, secretly, I'd be gay, and this would be the only chance I'd get to touch them.

Even if 'he-me' was genuinely straight, and especially if I was young and straight, I'd think gay men had it made. Of course, I would - looking at the gay man's lifestyle, how could I possibly not?

The average young homosexual has all the no-strings sex he can cope with, optimum disposable income, a groovy social life, no one nagging about settling down, no marriage to dodge, and no children to worry about. All that, great dress sense, and the option of true love, too - it would sound like a pretty good deal to 'he-me'.

The sort of guy I'd be, I'd want that kind of lifestyle, too, but I'd know it would be a small miracle if women let me get away it. I'd have to be very young, very rich, or a particular kind of famous to pull off having that much sex, fun and autonomy - a rock star, say, or a footballer.

It's traditionally held that sport and music are routes out of poverty, but it could be that, like many other forms of male success, they're also about avoiding the 'boring bits' of heterosexuality for as long as humanly possible. Likewise, everyone assumes that it's hatred and ignorance which leads to gay bashing on the streets, and homophobia per se, but maybe it's more the case that straight boys are plain jealous of the sexual freedom and variety that gays enjoy.

Straight men would love it if women let them carry on the way gay men let other gay men, but the reality is we don't. Obviously, there are exceptions - the gay homebod, the female siren - but, on the whole, women want fidelity, trips to Ikea, and promises to be home within seconds of leaving the office. As a rule, we do not want to meet men up on Hampstead Heath for a quick anonymous shag.

If heterosexual couples frequently bore each other, it is all men's fault for not thinking ahead. Way back in time, monogamy was invented by men to keep women in line. They clearly never intended for it to apply to them also; they didn't realise that, a few aeons later, they'd be down at the pub, nervously checking their watches, and saying: 'Just a half, I've got to be back.' You just wouldn't get dreary repressed scenes like these in gay pubs. Nobody ever rushed home to appease their exfoliating scrub.

For every man (and woman) marriage suits down to the ground, it seems to bore and constrain thousands of others. Bearing this in mind, it seems ridiculous for gay people, especially men, to be campaigning for the right to get hitched. This week, Mary MacLeod, the chief executive of the National Family and Parenting Institute, said that gay marriage was ultimately 'inevitable'. Since then, there has been the usual outcry about what an affront this would be to our noble heterosexual institution. What tripe. It seems to me not to be a question of: should gays be allowed to marry? but rather: why on earth would they want to?

In an age when straight men are ducking and diving like never before to avoid marriage, it seems odd to see gay men opting to go down the same perilous road. It is only fair that gay couples should be recognised in terms of inheritance, pensions and property, and that legislation should be put in place. But marriage - are they completely serious? More pertinently, would gays be so keen if the heterosexual community were trying to force married respectability upon them?

If so, I'm astonished and disillusioned. Heteros are always looking for new ways to wind each other up, but I thought better of gays. Once gay marriage is here, once the Pandora's Box is opened, it's odds-on that homosexuality will stop being the best fun a young guy can have, and become a pale facsimile of the all the more boring bits of heterosexuality.

It will be all: 'But why won't you marry me?'; great groaning articles on 'Men who won't commit to other men'; and 'Only half a Seabreeze for me, I've got to get back.' Before you know it, gay men will be working as hard for their sex, and their sexual autonomy as straight men, realising too late that the grass wasn't greener on the other side of the heath.

barbara.ellen@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: And your point is...?
fields.standfirst: Politics through art. Great, if you fancy barbarity, banality - and no Steve Bell
fields.trailText: Protest and Survive Whitechapel Art Gallery, London E1, until 12 November
fields.body:
Protest and Survive Whitechapel Art Gallery, London E1, until 12 November

Prehaps you would like to see a man's naked backside being beaten with a wooden bat? Not once, not twice, but a hundred violent strokes until the flesh is a bleeding pulp. What about a camera swooning in and out of focus at the sight of a woman's breasts? Or maybe a photograph of a passenger jerking off beneath his tray of airline breakfast?

You have the right to refuse, of course. Just don't bother to go. But what if you are attracted by the title, Protest and Survive, or have read that the exhibition promises 'to recover the political voice that has been glossed over in art from the Sixties to the present?' Maybe you were hoping for something about civil disobedience, anarchism, Pinochet, the poll tax or the bomb, given the use of the CND slogan as a title. Maybe you were hoping to take the kids. Abolish these hopes, reduce your expectations to the tiniest nub and you might get something from this show - always assuming that you are inured to the sight of sadistic barbarity.

Protest and Survive is loopily incoherent. On the one hand, it wants to bore you to death with actuality - glum, defeatist tracts, photographs of urban rats, press cuttings and footage of ancient rock concerts. On the other hand, it is stuffed with art that speaks exclusively to an art-world audience - parodies of Joseph Beuys, lampoons of Abstract Expressionism, S & M videos that add a footnote to Seventies Body Art. That's before you even consider the relics of obscure protests staged by long-ago artists: enough documentation to fill a stack in the Arts Council Library.

There is sharp-witted art to be found among the chores, some of it even concerned with social protest. Margaret Thatcher administers her own brand of medicine from a video above the operating table in Richard Hamilton's Treatment Room , a walk-in theatre in which you represent the living individual she is busy hectoring. Chad McCail has invented a further series of succinct and beautiful pictograms to illustrate the cycle of sexual repression from one generation to the next.

The Bank collective is showing its Lowry skit - a quota of matchstick men from the artist's production line, with the pithy subtitle Would you be worried if one of these Northerners ceased to exist? Mel Ramos parodies David's super-smooth Cupid as a medallion man with sideboards and perm... but we're back to art about art.

It's obvious from the absence of turgid captions and the jargon-free catalogue that the curators want this show to be immediate and accessible, not some experience cordoned off behind the history of art or society. But if you weren't around when Cosi Fanni Tutti was hiring herself out as a porn model in 1973 you could be baffled by the suggestion that this was any kind of useful protest, let alone a protest vindicated by the display of her crotch-shots at the Hayward Annual. I guess the Austrian artist Valie Export was making some point about the homeless by lying in various gutters, but the impact of her action is only recorded in German newspaper cuttings.

There is a crucial difference between immediate and obvious. A monopoly game based on the World Trade Organisation, an Evian fountain splashing out a trite message about the Western luxury of water, a folk costume - puffed sleeves and a full skirt embroidered with images of Bosnia - entitled The Mother of all Battles. Stop slacking, you want to shout, get out of the starting gate and come up with some thing that doesn't look blindingly obvious or half-baked in a world that contains artists like Steve Bell.

I don't understand why Bell is not in this show. There is a fine cartoon by Robert Thompson from Private Eye - northern father, pointing out smoke-stacked landscape to son, 'One day all this will be art galleries' - and a Daily Express photograph of a stripper protesting at Eton. So it can't be snobbery about the media or cartoons. Nor can it be a ban on successful artists, otherwise a whole wall would not have been devoted to Wolfgang Tillmans.

Perhaps it's some Reithian notion of political balance. This would explain the inclusion of Gilbert and George's far-right Cocky Patriot, flanked with Union Jacks, though not the 10-to-one ratio of men to women. But it's much more likely that Bell's draughtsman ship, not to mention his political nous, would be out of place in the low-watt aesthetic of this show, which would rather display snapshots of Peter Tatchell than any of Peter Kennard's radical photomontages.

It wouldn't be hard to come up with a more inspiring cast list from the last 40 years: Ed Keinholz, Hans Haacke, Komar and Melamid, Tim Rollins and the Kids of Survival. But they would all be too energetic, too visual for Protest and Survive . This is not a show about activism so much as shrugging defeat - 'No to bad things' says the wan joke on the placard abandoned on the gallery floor.

fields.headline: Why Stacey's bigger than Britney
fields.standfirst: She was an unknown jazz singer. Now she's an internet star...
fields.trailText: In February, an editor of  CBS Sunday Morning, the biggest arts and current affairs show on US television, was casting about for a little item to offer some relief from unending babble about the Clintons. She came across an article about a young New York postgraduate student who went to Europe for her masters in comparative literature and wound up in England as a jazz singer. The story was duly filmed and broadcast and Stacey Kent's life has not been the same since. Astonished CBS executives declared that they had never known such a massive reaction to a musical item in the history of the show.
fields.body:
In February, an editor of CBS Sunday Morning, the biggest arts and current affairs show on US television, was casting about for a little item to offer some relief from unending babble about the Clintons. She came across an article about a young New York postgraduate student who went to Europe for her masters in comparative literature and wound up in England as a jazz singer. The story was duly filmed and broadcast and Stacey Kent's life has not been the same since. There's more than a fair chance that her new one, Dreamsville, will join them.

She does not scat or improvise or indulge in vocal gymnastics, but follows an older, more affable tradition that goes back to Bing Crosby and Mildred Bailey. This is the art which takes classic American songs with warm, witty lyrics and proper tunes and delicately sets them swinging. When people are given a chance to experience it in the hands of a performer as gifted as Kent, they fall for it in large numbers.

In July she provided the evening entertainment at a summit meeting held by Bill Gates and fellow movers and shakers. In August she sang at Clint Eastwood's seventieth birthday celebration.

On an impulse, she signed up for a jazz course at the Guildhall School of Music, where she met and fell in love with saxophonist Jim Tomlinson, now her husband. They worked together in Vile Bodies, the Thirties-style dance band resident at the Ritz, and this led to her appearance in Ian McKellen's film of Richard III, set in the Thirties, and hence to a deal with Candid Records.

She still cannot quite believe it, but evidence arrives daily in the form of emailed fan letters. 'By the time we get home from a gig, they've already started arriving,' Kent says. 'A lot of them say things like, "I've never done anything like this before but..." and go on to reveal the most intimate thoughts and feelings that the songs have brought to the surface. There's a sense of relief, too, as though they've been searching for something like this without knowing quite what they were looking for. Melodic songs - poetic, romantic songs - appeal to all kinds of people. I know it's not just nostalgia, because I hear from all kinds of people, including quite young kids.'

The new album has turned out to be an unofficial request programme. 'Very often they end by suggesting a song to me, one they'd like to hear me sing, and I've included some of them on the CD. Almost always it's a ballad, their dreamiest song, so that's why we called it Dreamsville.'

Stacey Kent's band, a very sharp jazz quintet led by Jim Tomlinson, has remained virtually unchanged since the beginning, and is a joy on its own account. Between them, the couple have created a genuinely personal style. 'Jim and I never worry about what we're going to do next or what direction we're going to take. We're passionate about what we do and we love to see people enjoying it.'

Dreamsville is out tomorrow on Candid Records

fields.headline: Playing the game
fields.trailText: Admittedly I am not often to be found jumping into my trousers at an hour of Saturday morning when normal people are still in bed waiting for their wives to get up and turn the central heating on.
fields.body:
Admittedly I am not often to be found jumping into my trousers at an hour of Saturday morning when normal people are still in bed waiting for their wives to get up and turn the central heating on, but I'm so excited at having been instructed to go and stand about in the rain to watch our newly ironed secondary schoolboy roll about in the mud with hundreds of other 11-year-olds who don't know one end of a rugby ball from a lifesize model of the Sydney Opera House that I can hardly eat my bowl of honey nut loops and drive at the same time.

But it is his first week, and I am delighted to note with complete bewilderment that the little fellow has already proved himself a credit to his budget-quality uniform (which we have had custom-made for someone with longer arms), having been awarded a merit for picking up litter while a prefect happened to be standing behind him and another in science for finding the chemistry lab almost in time for his lesson.

Yesterday he came home attempting conversational Spanish (though I imagine counting to eight has its limits at Andalusian dinner parties) and has expressed an interest in perhaps taking up a musical instrument, with its vistas of philharmonic possibility or, more likely, the risk of, say, rockabilly not turning out to be his metier after all and us being landed with a novelty double bass-shaped sideboard after one term.

Still, it is all very new and thrilling. And how it takes me back to my own first few faltering years at grammar school, drifting from class to class in a cloud of chalk dust from having blackboard rubbers banged on my head for declining irregular Latin nouns in too irregular a fashion ('No thanks, I've just had one!') and wondering how soon I could leave and get a job at the sauce factory.

But that was long-trousered scholarship back in the dark ages. Ear-tweaking has long been dropped from the curriculum in favour of child-centred learning, school dinners modernised with the introduction of saturated fats (or SATS, as I believe the popular acronym has it) and CSEs sensibly phased out to pave the way for easier A-levels.

The rest, as they say, is history, albeit with an optional module in rainforest studies. Not for nothing am I the kind of responsible parent who has kept up with educational developments down the years with a view to making a prudent decision when it comes to choosing a school that not only scores 'low to negligible' in the national glue-sniffing and spliff-making league tables, but is also conveniently on the way to dropping the other two off at the juniors.

We arrive in good time for the boy to spend hours trying to jam his boots on the right feet before hobbling across the pitch to join his fellows under the watchful eye of the games master, who has just returned from the world bellowing championships in Helsinki. For minutes I am fascinated at the sight of children doing as they're told. The sun comes out. A cheer goes up. Ah, the playing fields of England!

I am moved to make a large spontaneous donation, and accordingly buy a hot dog and a cup of tea from the PTA fundraisers' refreshments stand. On the other hand, to the untrained eye rugby can look like uninteresting chaos and I am soon reduced to talking about proper football with the other dads and wondering how long this goes on for.

But the little scrumster seems to enjoy it, and we are soon back home exhilarated and grubby (him) and ready for a snooze in the chair (me) when my wife appears at the living-room door holding her baking spoon.

'Party?' she says, which turns out not to be a coded invitation to a bout of sexual shenanigans while her cherry scones are in the oven but a reminder that we're expecting 30 of the boy's chums from his old school round later this afternoon for a hyperactive reunion of hot dogs, fizzy drinks and exaggerated accounts of how many species of live family pet they'll be expected to dissect in year 8, so naturally she'll need me on hand to organise a game of rounders and prepare sedatives for the adults.

Oh well, how hard can it be? And, hey, maybe I get to blow my own whistle

fields.headline: Septuagenarian heaven
fields.trailText: Charles Mackerras and Colin Davis Barbican, London
fields.body:
Charles Mackerras and Colin Davis Barbican, London

I have nothing against youth; I tried it once, and quite enjoyed it. But let's celebrate seniority. Let's celebrate Charles Mackerras, who turns 75 in November; and Colin Davis, 73 a few days ago. Both conducted at the Barbican last week, and achieved the rare mix of orchestral precision and that touch of wildness which makes a performance special.

Last Tuesday Mackerras opened the BBC Symphony Orchestra's seventieth-anniversary season with Harrison Birtwistle's Sonance Severance 2000, a clumsy title that takes almost as long to say as the piece does to play. Birtwistle wrote it for the reopening of Severance Hall in Cleveland, and it lasts about two minutes. Short, then, but not little. Birtwistle's orchestra, large and loud, transports us to that timeless zone where every thing flashes by in an instant, yet seems in a state of suspended motion.

This exuberant fanfare begins deep in the orchestral bowels, with rumbling bass drum soon joined by double-basses and cellos. The thick textures briefly split to reveal glimpses of Debussyan clear sky, immediately obliterated by a crunching blast of raw power. In the music's dying echoes, the trumpet sounds a faltering last post. Saturated with atmosphere, the piece sets the scene: but for what? Perhaps Birtwistle's new opera, The Last Supper, which opens at Glyndebourne later this month.

After Birtwistle's brevity, Bartók's Concerto for Orchestra seemed discursive, if hardly long-winded. The little dance of the second movement was sardonic and sour, while the 'interrupted intermezzo' of the fourth movement had a desperate tipsiness that was most moving. To follow, Pamela Frank gave a big-boned performance of Dvorák's Violin Concerto. Some of her phrasing was a shade sketchy, but she revelled in the virtuosity that the piece requires.

It was in Janác ek's Sinfonietta that orchestra and conductor really let loose. Mackerras, of course, has been the composer's champion for half a century, but experience has not routinised his performances. There are passages in the Sinfonietta which have a rhythmic and sonic exuberance bordering on craziness, and the whole orchestra played with the energy of the possessed. This was the BBCSO's first concert at the Barbican since adopting the hall as its new 'home', and it made a hell of a house-warming.

I don't think Colin Davis matched that the following day, but he came close. If Janác ek is Mackerras's first love, then Berlioz is Davis's, and here he continued his year-long Berlioz Odyssey with the London Symphony Orchestra. Yuri Bashmet, the viola soloist in Berlioz's Harold in Italy, played the opening movement with the brakes on, impeding the forward momentum. At times he coarsened his tone to exaggerated effect, yet elsewhere he found the requisite subtlety, investing the slenderest thread of sound with an aching poignancy.

The Symphonie Fantastique followed, a performance hindered by squawks from the PA system outside the auditorium, so intrusive that Davis had to break off the third movement and begin again. Fortunately the LSO soon re-established the mood, the strings in particular playing with astonishing refinement. That third movement, with its imitation of a rustic wind-band, can seem arch, but the 'March to the Scaffold' was riotous, while the 'Dream of the Witches' Sabbath' had, like Mackerras's Janác ek, a touch of madness. While they may not be growing old disgracefully, Davis and Mackerras still have fire in their bellies.

fields.headline: World record holders
fields.standfirst: Twenty-five Ali Gs from all over the planet. Who will be the DJ world champion?
fields.trailText: 'It's all about the beats, man,' Malaysia's DJ Acid informs me, minutes before walking on stage at last Sunday's DJ World Championships in Greenwich. In the context of this annual contest to decide the finest turntable wizard on the planet, saying 'It's all about the beats' is the equivalent of a Miss World contestant saying she wants to travel the world and help people. The difference is - these people mean it.
fields.body:
'It's all about the beats, man,' Malaysia's DJ Acid informs me, minutes before walking on stage at last Sunday's DJ World Championships in Greenwich. In the context of this annual contest to decide the finest turntable wizard on the planet, saying 'It's all about the beats' is the equivalent of a Miss World contestant saying she wants to travel the world and help people. The difference is - these people mean it.

Twenty-five years after rap music's pioneers took part in competitive block parties in The Bronx, hip hop culture has gone truly international. Not only do teenagers in every provincial town in western Europe speak and dress like Ali G, but they do the same in Asia, Africa and South America too. In the shadow of the Dome, contestants from 25 countries have flown over to demonstrate their scratching skills to an audience of more than 3,000 aficionados. The winner will receive a grand prize of... er, absolutely nothing. It is, you see, all about the beats.

Backstage, this year's finalists stand and fidget. 'I'm kinda nervous,' says DJ Craze, from the US. He looks around. The other DJs stand smoking cigarettes, warily eyeing up the competition. 'It's amazing: few of us share a common language. It's quite difficult to speak to people - but I think the music does all the talking.'

Like Olympic basketball, the DJ World Championships is an international event at which America always wins. DJ Craze, though hardly a household name in his own country, has been crowned world champion on two previous occasions.

DJ Nasha, 27, and fresh from winning the Indian final, sits stageside. He wears the uniform of hip hop consumers everywhere: baggy jeans and a hooded sweat-top. Nasha - real name, Ridesh D'Souza - grew up in a middle-class family in the small town of Mumbai. He packed in a university degree in business management after only one term, and now hawks his DJ skills around Mumbai's house and garage clubs. 'They don't understand hip hop over there,' he complains. 'I make money playing to commercial audiences. And I use that money to buy rap records on the internet.' Each 12-inch single costs about £30.

D'Souza walks up to centre stage, where the 25 are being whittled down to 12 finalists. 'I'll come back,' he says, nervously. An MC corrals the DJs together, and starts to read through the list of names -D'Souza's is worryingly absent. He wanders back to his seat, and I offer my sympathies. There's always next year, I mutter. D'Souza, jetlagged from his flight, obviously reeling from his emotional bombshell, and probably crippled financially by the journey, smiles sheepishly. He looks on the verge of tears. For the rest of the night he will sorrowfully stalk the venue, clutching at a pink cuddly toy for comfort.

The other failures look equally despondent. 'It was the turntable,' complains DJ Venom, from Croatia. 'The needle jumped.' 'The record jumped,' moans Tunisia's DJ Mourad. 'The needle was everywhere,' blasts Ireland's JP. I'm detecting a pattern here. In a competition where a DJ's skill focuses on his ability to scratch a record as furiously and proficiently as possible, the finger of blame for failure will invariably be pointed at the stylus.

There's precious little melody to distinguish one DJ from the next. DJ-ing, traditionally with an emphasis on tune and structure, in this form mutates into a vicious bloodsport. Contestants rush from turntable to turntable, throwing on vinyl discs and scratching them until they squeal. It has more in common with plate-spinning than music.

Or trainspotting. There is actually a group of men at the front taking notes. 'Isn't this great?' yells Blade, a 10-year veteran of the UK's underachieving hip hop scene. He points to the stage, where a DJ stands jumbling noisy beats and bleeps. 'This is fucking raw, man!'

As America's DJ Craze is crowned world champion for a record third time, D'Souza scurries off to the practice room. Two turntable decks stand plugged into a wall, and DJs line up to manhandle them into submission. Someone, thoughtfully, has removed the speakers.

How long, I wonder, before this becomes an Olympic event?

fields.headline: British beauties?
fields.standfirst: Sam Mendes's First World War tank crew take on Andrew Lloyd Webber's Sixties football team
fields.trailText:
To the Green Fields Beyond Donmar, London WC2
The Country Wife Crucible, Sheffield
The Beautiful Game Cambridge Theatre, London WC2
fields.body:
To the Green Fields Beyond Donmar, London WC2
The Country Wife Crucible, Sheffield
The Beautiful Game Cambridge Theatre, London WC2

At first, it seems unlikely. After Oscar glory with hyper-contemporary, star-laden American Beauty, Sam Mendes returns from Hollywood to his Donmar home - and decides to direct a play by a little-known dramatist set in a wood during the First World War.

Actually, it's not so surprising. Nick Wright's To the Green Fields Beyond has this in common with American Beauty: a predictable outlook is disguised by a streak of stylistic daring. Everyone would expect a film about the American suburbs to show that life weighs heavily on its inhabitants, but no one could have anticipated that this routine perception could be made so visually compelling. No one would expect a play about a tank crew - which includes an Irishman, a West Indian, a Sikh and a Scot - on the eve of battle to do other than give them a good character and send them off to die. But no one would have thought that the dialogue of these characters would be so pungent.

She has, one man complains about a prostitute, 'no parsley on her lemon'. There is, an officer accuses a journalist, 'something curly about you'. You can think that these phrases are arresting - and also think that arrest isn't always helpful to a play. Barnacled with idiosyncrasy, the dialogue makes you stop to admire it, rather than taking you into the heart of a not-very-suspenseful dilemma - should these men funk their fight?

It's a patchy piece, but it does show Mendes's gifts. You can smell waste and Woodbines in Anthony Ward's design - a dusky glade hung with hurricane lamps. There's a wonderfully agile episode in which the men, preparing for their last assault, mime and chant their actions in the tank: in doing so they become closer, and like a piece of machinery. The piece is, as was American Beauty, brilliantly cast, with Ray Winstone, Dougray Scott, Nitin Ganatra, Finbar Lynch and Danny Sapani outstanding.

In Sheffield, the Crucible is again lit up by the combination of Michael Grandage's direction, Christopher Oram's design and Victoria Hamilton's acting talent. Last year, Hamilton shone as a girl pretending to be a boy pretending to be a girl in As You Like It . In William Wycherley's 1675 play The Country Wife she puts on trousers again - this time at the behest of her jealous husband, anxious to conceal her beguiling features. The subterfuge proves inflammatory: pert in pantaloons, she is enthusiastically snogged by a passing wit.

These gender-bending kisses are one of many moments which wire The Country Wife into the present. Its tale - of an imprisoning marriage and a string of guilt-free adulteries - suggests that injunctions to meekness and chastity were simply a huge cul-de-sac in the history of women's lives. Suzanne Burden is a voracious, beady Lady Fidget, Hermione Gulliford a delicately perturbed Alithea. As the ingénue who develops a flair for scheming, Hamilton produces a squeaky-doll version of herself: romping, tousled, dealing her aged husband fierce, sexy little punches, and making herself more delectable all the while.

Each quip is crisply delivered, rather than lingered over. In Oram's lovely design - an aquamarine space striped with pale light - as one door closes, another opens. Little gusts of music puff the action along. Seamlessness and speed are the hallmarks of Grandage's direction.

If you think of Andrew Lloyd Webber's musicals as a flu to which the West End regularly succumbs, you'd have to say that The Beautiful Game is not the most virulent strain. This treatment of the Troubles in Northern Ireland, which focuses on the fortunes of a young football team, kicking off in Belfast in 1969, tries to break the mould.

Threading his music through with the warble and wail of pipes, Lloyd Webber has produced an instantly catchy, soupy ballad 'Our Kind of Love'. Refreshingly, the cast sing in Belfast accents, which makes you realise how seldom you hear anything other than Home Counties, Estuary or Transatlantic sung on the British stage. Meryl Tankard's lively choreography creates, if not a team, a collection of individual talents - who punch, kick, leap and twist in their own separate spaces.

And Michael Levine's design shrugs off the elephantiasis associated with Lloyd Webber productions. A suitably mangy prosce nium arch, which looks as if it's been gnawed by rats and touched up with phosphorescence, frames the action. The dank walls split apart, once to show bomb damage and once to offer Advent-calendar glimpses of a tourist version of an Emerald Isle, all blue lakes and green hills.

But the essential Lloyd Webber infection - a gut-rotting sentimentality - remains. Ben Elton's words are sometimes chirpy, sometimes squirmy, sometimes both at once: a newly-married man, dauntingly swathed in his underwear, nips into bed singing about how he'll 'lose my cherry for the very first time'. The Catholics have all the best tunes - indeed, almost all the tunes. But there are no arias to the IRA.

fields.headline: Essex appeal
fields.standfirst: Can scary videos and filthy lyrics help Red Snapper turn their hipness into sales?
fields.trailText: In a film studio in south London, I'm listening to the soundtrack of my childhood reborn in mutant form. Richard Thair of Red Snapper stands in front of a camera focused tightly on his head. He grins and leers before lip-synching the chorus, every nervous dart of the eyes or lick of the lips taking on a more sinister air in close-up. The claustrophobic feel of the video matches the edgy, modern funk booming from the speakers, based around a riff that will be recognisable to anyone who grew up in Britain in the Seventies. It's from one of the strangest, sexiest pop singles ever made - David Essex's 'Rock On', sampled over frantic beats in Red Snapper's fine new single, 'Some Kind of Kink'.
fields.body:
In a film studio in south London, I'm listening to the soundtrack of my childhood reborn in mutant form. Richard Thair of Red Snapper stands in front of a camera focused tightly on his head. He grins and leers before lip-synching the chorus, every nervous dart of the eyes or lick of the lips taking on a more sinister air in close-up. The claustrophobic feel of the video matches the edgy, modern funk booming from the speakers, based around a riff that will be recognisable to anyone who grew up in Britain in the Seventies. It's from one of the strangest, sexiest pop singles ever made - David Essex's 'Rock On', sampled over frantic beats in Red Snapper's fine new single, 'Some Kind of Kink'.

The fact that the group are making a video at all is testament to their newfound determination to finally translate their awesome live reputation into record sales. Unusually for a band that emerged from the club scene, all three are talented musicians. They rarely do session work now, but you'll still see their names in the credits of records by friends such as Beth Orton and the Chemical Brothers. David Ayers, an American who moved to London from Virginia 12 years ago, earned his living playing classical guitar in restaurants. Ali Friend learned double bass at school, eventually picking up electric bass too and gravitating towards hip hop and P-funk bands. Thair, a drummer, has played live with The Aloof, Sabres of Paradise and The Sandals.

Red Snapper formed in the mid-Nineties and soon became a popular name to drop on the club scene. Over the past five years they have also built up a diverse following for their live shows, but the past year has been painful for them. Their manager quit, there were financial worries, and they all suffered the kind of personal crises many of us have to face as we enter our thirties. Ayers's mother died, and Thair went through the end of a long-term relationship with the mother of his four-year-old son. Compared to this, Friend's trauma of breaking a finger while playing football may seem rather petty, until he explains that he couldn't play bass for four months and there were times when the doctors treating him were unsure if he'd ever play again.

In the middle of all this, they began work on their best album to date, interspersing moody, atmospheric instrumentals with funkier, soulful vocal tracks to make a collection that flows smoothly from beginning to end, a soundtrack for urban Britain that suggests a more revved-up Massive Attack.

They've called it Our Aim is to Satisfy Red Snapper, from a picture taken by their accountant while on holiday in Florida. It showed a restaurant sign in which the day's fish special had got stuck on the end of the establishment's slogan. They liked it because it made them laugh, but also because they have always aimed to please other people primarily by pleasing themselves first.

'It's hard making a living doing the kind of thing we do,' says Ayers, 'and if you didn't love the music you made, if you went to all this time and trouble and the record sucked, it would definitely not be worth it.'

Red Snapper are the kind of band who worry about 'selling out'. They're also, fortunately, the kind of band who'll follow their instincts even when it makes no commercial sense at all. Take 'The Rough and The Quick', a catchy track sung by their new guest vocalist, Karime Kendra. 'I want the kind of night that I read about/You know the ones you find on the top shelf,' she sings on the chorus, before going on to describe - in explicit detail - exactly what she means by that. Since it's unlikely to get airplay, the only way you'll get to hear this very female take on sexuality is to sample the album.

'There's more passion and aggression in these new tracks, more of the energy of the live show,' says Friend. 'So far, people talk about us, they come to see us live, but they don't buy the records. Hopefully this album will change that.'

'Our Aim Is To Satisfy Red Snapper' is out on Warp, 9 Oct. Their UK tour kicks off at Elka in Bristol, 2 Nov

fields.headline: 'It is like electricity, like magic'
fields.standfirst: Dancers shared the joy of Billy Elliot at the film's premiere, writes Jann Parry
fields.trailText: Who would have thought that the next big thing to catch the popular imagination would be a boy doing ballet? Even now, centuries after men took up dancing, ballet is seen as much odder than blowing a brass instrument or stripping in a working men's club. Proper boys charge down the street with football boots slung around their neck: Billy Elliot must be a weirdo because his shoes have pink ribbons instead of laces.
fields.body:
Who would have thought that the next big thing to catch the popular imagination would be a boy doing ballet? Even now, centuries after men took up dancing, ballet is seen as much odder than blowing a brass instrument or stripping in a working men's club. Proper boys charge down the street with football boots slung around their neck: Billy Elliot must be a weirdo because his shoes have pink ribbons instead of laces.

Dancers at Wednesday's London premiere punched the air when Billy Elliot, played by Jamie Bell, finally expressed in words and movement what dancing meant to him. 'Yeah, that's what I feel - it is like electricity, like magic', admits Royal Ballet principal Sarah Wildor. She was invited to the premiere with her husband, the dancer Adam Cooper, who has a part in the film. They found themselves sitting next to Hugh Grant. 'You should have seen the expression on Sarah's face,' says Darcey Bussell. 'She was trying to pretend she hadn't noticed him - but he must have noticed her. She looked gorgeous.'

For Bussell, the best bit was 'when the boy goes crazy in front of his dad. It's all that emotion you bottle up - and he found the way to let it out and really went for it. Like him, I wasn't stage-struck. I just loved burning off the fire inside me - it's an impulse you can't help'. Cooper agrees: 'As you get older, you tend to lose sight of what drove you to dance in the first place. You can be free of the real world, lose yourself in your dreams. At that age, I used to let off steam jumping around doing tap - ballet was much too hard'.

Billy Elliot hits home because it is based on a true story. Scriptwriter Lee Hall rang the Royal Ballet three years ago and asked if any dancer came from a mining town. 'I do' volunteered Philip Mosley from Barnsley, a first artist in the company. He is the youngest of seven children, with an elder brother who was a militant miner. Both his grandfathers were miners, who offered to support him at ballet school if his parents couldn't cope.

'I had to get up at 3am to travel in my father's car to London for the Royal Ballet auditions,' remembers Mosley. 'I told Lee how I'd never seen a ballet, let alone any of the exercises the other boys were doing in the changing room beforehand. My parents cried when I was accepted and they cried when they left me at the school. My twin brother hid in the car so I shouldn't see how much he missed me.'

Without knowing it, Hall also hit on the boyhood story of Sir Kenneth MacMillan, the great Royal Ballet choreographer who died in 1992. His father had been a miner in Scotland and was unemployed in Great Yarmouth when his son declared he was going to become a ballet dancer. Kenneth's mother had died when he was 12, and for him, like Billy Elliot, dancing was his escape from grief, poverty and the grinding reality of everyday life.

He, too, had an inspirational teacher - in fact, two. He did far more ballet lessons than he ever let on, either to his disapproving father or his schoolmates. He forged a letter in his father's name, asking Ninette de Valois for an audition for her Sadler's Wells Ballet School in 1944. When he was accepted, his father gave in - but never saw him dance.

So what is the lure of ballet for children who, like MacMillan, like Mosley, may never have seen a professional performance? Instead of being packed off to ballet class by ambitious mothers, they discover its challenges for themselves. They already fantasise themselves as Fred Astaire: they have a natural sense of rhythm, a facility for tap, for expressing their inner life through energetic movement. Then they discover the lure of discipline; classical ballet technique is so rigorous that it obliterates every other thought. It is liberating because it frees the anxious mind of its internal monologue.

'We were concerned with what got Billy going,' says Peter Darling, the film's choreographer. ' The dancing had to be part of the narrative, telling us who he is. So I worked with Jamie eight hours a day for three months, finding out what drove him as a dancer. He's fantastic because everything comes from the heart - there's a reason for every move'.

Dancers watching the premiere, whether from the Royal Ballet or Matthew Bourne's Adventures in Motion Pictures, think Bell's a star - and the image of their younger selves.

fields.headline: Bacon, dregs and tomatoes
fields.standfirst: It's a bumper week for clichés - invisible men, relationship comedies. Oh, and a donkey-boy
fields.trailText:
Hollow Man (112 mins, 18) Directed by Paul Verhoeven; starring Kevin Bacon, Elisabeth Shue, Josh Brolin
Love & Sex (107 mins, 15) Directed by Valerie Breiman; starring Famke Janssen, Jon Favreau
julien donkey-boy (94 mins, 15) Directed by Harmony Korine; starring Ewen Bremner, Chloë Sevigny, Werner Herzog
Abendland (140 mins, 18) Directed by Fred Keleman; starring Wolfgang Michael, Verena Jasch
Goya in Bordeaux (102 mins, 15) Directed by Carlos Saura; starring Francisco Rabal, Maribel Verdú
fields.body:
Hollow Man (112 mins, 18) Directed by Paul Verhoeven; starring Kevin Bacon, Elisabeth Shue, Josh Brolin
Love & Sex (107 mins, 15) Directed by Valerie Breiman; starring Famke Janssen, Jon Favreau
julien donkey-boy (94 mins, 15) Directed by Harmony Korine; starring Ewen Bremner, Chloë Sevigny, Werner Herzog
Abendland (140 mins, 18) Directed by Fred Keleman; starring Wolfgang Michael, Verena Jasch
Goya in Bordeaux (102 mins, 15) Directed by Carlos Saura; starring Francisco Rabal, Maribel Verdú

When Mephistopholes gave him the gift of invisibility, all Christopher Marlowe's Faustus could think of doing was having childish fun at the expense of the pope and the cardinal of Lorraine. In his 1897 The Invisible Man (subtitled 'A Grotesque Romance'), H.G. Wells lent a moral dimension to the phenomenon by having his mad scientist discover his evil, primitive side through invisibility in the manner of Dr Jekyll.

Paul Verhoeven's Hollow Man follows a similar course, adding only special effects and state-of-the-art scientific mumbo-jumbo to James Whale's classic 1933 version of Wells's novel.

The title refers to an overreaching, Porsche-driving scientist, Dr Sebastian Caine (Kevin Bacon), head of a secret research unit hidden beneath a Washington DC warehouse, set up by the Pentagon to explore the possibility of creating invisible agents. Making animals invisible is easy; making them visible again is apparently the problem.

But once Caine has 'cracked reversion', he cons his team into letting him be the subject of the first human experiment. Faustian pranks are followed by Wellsian evil as Caine goes steadily mad, ending up stalking his assistants in their underground laboratory, like the monster in Alien .

Technically impressive, but otherwise commonplace, the film's not unenjoyable. Inevitably, there's the lubriciousness we associate with Verhoeven, who, we infer, believes that all moviegoers are voyeurs, thus halfway to being invisible men and only too eager to spring on to the screen and indulge their lusts.

In the 1930s, Hollywood film-makers were forced by the censors to invent what the philosopher Stanley Cavell dubbed 'the comedy of remarriage' (eg The Philadelphia Story, The Awful Truth, Mr and Mrs Smith) to deal in a light-hearted way with mature women and men by bringing them together not to be wed but to reunite them after separation or divorce.

This form was no longer necessary when the Production Code was abandoned in 1967 and social mores changed. It was replaced by what we might call 'the relationship comedy', best exemplified by Annie Hall , in which the protagonists are able to survey with amused frankness a succession of sexual relationships without the viewer regarding them as promiscuous or immoral. But whereas the comedy of remarriage demanded deft plotting, the relationship comedy hardly needs a story at all, just a thread of memory and some bright lines.

Writer-director Valerie Breiman's debut film, Love & Sex, is a fairly typical example of the genre and has thirtysomething journalist, Kate Wells (Famke Janssen), looking back on her life wryly. It comprises 13, mostly unsatisfactory, relationships since losing her virginity to a French teacher in high school. The pretext is knocking off a 2,500-word article on relationships in an afternoon to keep her job on the Los Angeles-based magazine, Monique.

Everything keeps reverting to the one real love of her life, the painter, Adam Levy (Jon Favreau), who's funny, kindly, overweight, romantic and the father of the child she miscarried. The trouble is that Adam has had only two previous affairs and, plagued by retrospective jealousy, he's left Kate so he can try to catch up.

This is a lightweight version of Allen's masterpiece as seen from the point of view of Annie Hall who, in this case, is the one with gloomy tastes in movies (Kate's favourite is Murnau's Nosferatu). Janssen and Favreau are an attractive couple and they share the best lines.

As Groucho Marx might have said, if you haven't got a wide berth, get hold of one before Fred Kelemen's Abendland and Harmony Korine's julien donkey-boy come your way.

Because that's what you'll want to give to these ugly, incoherent, miserablist movies that believe they're making fundamental statements about the human condition.

Each ends up with the leading character carrying a child through the streets (in one case, a girl murdered by pederasts; in the other, a stillborn baby). Both pictures look as if they've been shot through unwashed, frosted-glass windows and the experience of watching them is like being keel-hauled rather slowly.

Abendland is set in a squalid, unnamed East German city near the Polish border (though, in fact, the locations are Portuguese) on one single night. The unemployed Anton breaks away from his lover, the laundry assistant, Leni, and the pair wander round the town, drinking and whoring.

Anton strikes up an acquaintance with a crazed foundry worker who's lost his job because no one needs bells any longer. Leni picks up men in bars, humiliates Anton, is beaten by a sadistic client and finds refuge in a sleazy hotel-cum-nightclub, whose owner pays for his coke habit by pimping and hiring his billiard-room to homicidal pederasts.

This slow, painful picture is evidently influenced by Andrei Tarkovsky, most especially his devastating Stalker, but lacking power and conviction, it neither observes the world we know nor creates a persuasive alternative.

The 25-year-old Harmony Korine, who wrote the script for Larry Clark's Kids and directed the unintelligible Gummo, joined the Dogme group to make julien donkey-boy and in addition to awarding him their certificate of approval, they've lent him one of their cameramen and one of their editors.

The result is a meaningless, random movie about a dysfunctional New York suburban family made up of a homicidal schizophrenic (Ewen Bremner) working at a home for the blind, an untalented teenage wrestler, their pregnant, harp-playing sister (Chloë Sevigny), their querulous, overbearing father (Werner Herzog) and a doddering grandmother.

It's often difficult to see their faces in the gloom and their actions are random and puzzling. Like Abendland, julien donkey-boy was shown in competition at Venice last year and has received plaudits on the festival circuit. But far from being the next big thing, it reminded me of the worst avant-garde pictures of the 1960s.

In Carlos Saura's Goya in Bordeaux, the 82-year-old Spanish painter (Francisco Rabal) looks back over his life from his deathbed in French exile in 1828. It's a stylised movie, handsomely photographed by Vittorio Storaro, and very much in the style of the imaginative portraits of artists pioneered by Huw Weldon's Monitor .

In his 1897 The Invisible Man (subtitled 'A Grotesque Romance'), H.G. Wells lent a moral dimension to the phenomenon by having his mad scientist discover his evil, primitive side through invisibility in the manner of Dr Jekyll. Paul Verhoeven's Hollow Man follows a similar course, adding only special effects and state-of-the-art scientific mumbo-jumbo to James Whale's classic 1933 version of Wells's novel. Making animals invisible is easy; making them visible again is apparently the problem. But once Caine has 'cracked reversion', he cons his team into letting him be the subject of the first human experiment. fields.headline: Dress to impress
fields.standfirst: London's hippest designers have found the perfect showcase for their talents - shop windows
fields.trailText: You can find more high-profile, heavyweight, contemporary architects to the square inch in Sloane Street than anywhere else in Britain, though not necessarily all at the same time. The transformation of what was a dowdy slice of Knightsbridge into a key address for international fashion names, up there with the via Montenapoleone and Rodeo Drive, has had the unexpected side-effect of turning the street into an outdoor catwalk, along which architect after architect sets out to make as powerful an impression with high-profile new shops as possible.
fields.body:
You can find more high-profile, heavyweight, contemporary architects to the square inch in Sloane Street than anywhere else in Britain, though not necessarily all at the same time. The transformation of what was a dowdy slice of Knightsbridge into a key address for international fashion names, up there with the via Montenapoleone and Rodeo Drive, has had the unexpected side-effect of turning the street into an outdoor catwalk, along which architect after architect sets out to make as powerful an impression with high-profile new shops as possible.

The architects are every bit as competitive as their fashion-designer clients, following each other up and down the street, and often ripping out each other's handiwork. But they must work with what is, architecturally, the most limited of material. All there is to put across a complex range of messages that must telegraph target audience and price level is that brief glimpse of the interior through the window from the street.

The febrile nature of the fashion business means that in Sloane Street shops come and go in a bewildering blur. Taking a break from museums in Berlin and Law Courts in Salerno, architect David Chipperfield has opened up a store for Dolce and Gabbana, just across the road from what was Nigel Coates's shop for Katharine Hamnett that now accommodates Gucci. Eva Jiricna, of the Faith Zone at the Dome, designed a store for what was Joseph's flagship, next to Norman Foster's Esprit, that is now Tommy Hilfiger. Last week the store which Future Systems has designed for Marni - a recently arrived Italian label - opened in what was yet another Joseph shop.

Future Systems, best known for the remarkable Media Centre at Lord's, has created a shop for Marni with an intense blue interior visible a mile away. Which of course in fashion is part of the point. It instantly sets the brand apart from the rest of the field. Once inside, a few deft moves have served to transform the rectangular format of a conventional shop unit. The floor is defined by a free-form puddle of reconstituted glass that stops short of the walls. The ceiling is mirror-finish stainless steel like a splash of mercury. Together they create a remarkably fluid, ambiguous space.

The clothes are displayed on a clump of stainless steel trees that swoop down like palm fronds, weighed down by clothes on Perspex hangers. The edge of the sales area is defined by a swooping, sinuous, continuous ribbon of steel that rises and falls, and flares out at various points to accommodate horizontal display surfaces and the cash desk. It looks closer to the lush curves of the TWA terminal at Kennedy airport designed in the late 1950s by Eero Saarinen than conventional hi-tech, and represents an intriguing evolution of Future Systems's work. Jan Kaplicky and Amanda Levete, its two partners, are now exploring the sensuous potential of contemporary materials, rather than celebrating the imagery of the machine.

Given the uneasy relationship between architecture and fashion over the years, it is remarkable that architects put quite so much energy into such projects. But they do. John Pawson, for example, spent two years working on his store for Calvin Klein in Manhattan with its cashmere smooth stone floor and its serene spaces. And Issey Miyake was probably the most important client that the great Japanese architect Shiro Kuramata ever had. And in Britain Miyake used both Stanton Williams and David Chipperfield.

Architecture has been both fascinated by, and dismissive of, fashion. Le Corbusier once put the sense of barely concealed mutual antagonism into words when he suggested that style in architecture was of no more significance than the feathers on a woman's hat, pretty enough but of no real importance. But Adolf Loos found the issue of clothes one of abiding interest. He wrote a series of essays in which he claimed to find the restraint of English tailoring the perfect expression of modernity.

Architects like to see themselves as being somehow beyond fashion. They regard their work as being concerned with permanence and seriousness. But they have also looked on jealously at fashion's strengthening grip on the popular imagination. Meanwhile fashion has secretly craved some of the cultural credibility that comes from the heavyweight baggage that architecture brings.

Partly the mismatch is to do with different timescales. Three months is an eternity in the frenetic fashion year while architecture is lucky not to look hopelessly out of date by the time it has negotiated the treacle-like speed of the construction process. And even when they are finished, most buildings after a decade or so when they may, or may not look contemporary, must endure another quarter of a century in which they are regarded as hopelessly outmoded.

Then, if they are lucky, the best of them may be understood for their intrinsic qualities rather than through the filter of any particular stylistic language. It is an entirely different pace to fashion.

Yet fashion is about a whole range of issues that are anything but trivial. Fashion is about money - it's a huge industrial system, as well as being a close reflection of power and status and sex.

And architecture has come to matter a great deal to fashion. It can be used to create a setting for designers that distils the essence of what they are trying to say about their clothes. You could see it as a particularly elaborate form of packaging. Just as you find that high-fashion shops wrap purchases in tissue paper, then put them in a box, and put that box in a cloth bag, then put the whole lot into a glossy carrier bag with rope handles, so the architectural wrapping of a store becomes equally elaborate through the adoption of heavyweight architectural firepower.

Perhaps the ultimate in the process is Prada, which is working simultaneously with Rem Koolhaas, and Herzog and de Meuron, who are undergoing the giddying shift of scale that takes them from turning a power station in Bankside into a temple of art to creating a temple to black nylon handbags for the company's Tokyo flagship.

webTitle: Now here's a play with legs...

fields.headline: Now here's a play with legs...
fields.standfirst: Tantalus took a lifetime to write, half a year to rehearse, and lasts 10 hours. So if you want to see it when it comes to Britain, better book your babysitter now
fields.trailText: Denver, Colorado, is the mile-high city at the foot of the Rocky Mountains. It may be short on oxygen, but it is long on culture, with arguably the best-equipped performing arts centre in America. Since March, theatre people from all over the world - eight leading actors (four British and four American); 13 other American actors; an Irish composer; a Greek designer; a Japanese lighting designer - have been in Denver researching and rehearsing  Tantalus , John Barton's 10-hour series of plays.
fields.body:
Denver, Colorado, is the mile-high city at the foot of the Rocky Mountains. It may be short on oxygen, but it is long on culture, with arguably the best-equipped performing arts centre in America. Since March, theatre people from all over the world - eight leading actors (four British and four American); 13 other American actors; an Irish composer; a Greek designer; a Japanese lighting designer - have been in Denver researching and rehearsing Tantalus , John Barton's 10-hour series of plays.

It takes five weeks to rehearse a normal-length play: Tantalus has needed 26 weeks because of its length and because of the virtuosity that had to be developed by its actors.

I am an old hand at epics: The Ring at Bayreuth took 16 weeks; The Wars of the Roses at Stratford nearly a year. So I know that while long rehearsals encourage proper work, they also demand endurance. We have had to stick at it like Tantalus himself, though I hope the resemblance ends there. The gap between his aspirations and achievements slowly drove Tantalus mad. As he reached forward for a bunch of desirable fruits, they were blown out of his reach. A large rock was suspended over Tantalus, specifically to amuse Zeus, because he could unloose it at any moment he chose. Our rock is unloosed in Denver on Saturday 21 October when Tantalus opens.

Tantalus is a very contemporary exercise. Each play is a digestible hour, an episode of a shocking soap opera, and full of incest, violation and sexual betrayal. Who started this squalid little Trojan War? And who can think of a way of getting out of it without losing face? Was Helen of Troy raped, or was she willing? And how dare we men presume to behave like gods when we clearly still haven't learnt how to behave like men? Sometimes the plays seem chillingly apt. Here in Denver there is a tragic school called Columbine High. Their teachers rang the other day to ask if there was any nudity. If there were, they would be unable to bring a teenage party.

Denver has allowed me nearly a year to try to find out how to do Tantalus. When I read the first draft I was excited, but I didn't think it was quite right. How could it be? A new piece of such ambition was bound to be initially indistinct here and there. Clearly it needed time. I read it when I was running the Old Vic. Initially it was hoped to be mounted there. All attempts (with the leadership of producer Michael Kustow and the RSC) to raise money in Europe proved inadequate. We even tried the Dome, but were told that they were not having theatre, as it was élitist and old-fashioned.

It was Don Seawell that saved Tantalus, and we owe an enormous debt to him. He is the chairman and founder of the Denver Center for the Performing Arts. He is a great businessman, impresario, lawyer and patron of the arts. He has known John Barton for half a century and became a governor of the RSC when I started it in 1960. Years later, he has had the vision (and some would say the lunacy) to back Tantalus . 'Our endowment fund is very healthy and I want to do something special,' he said to me.

It is difficult to describe this enterprise without hyperbole. It is by far the longest piece of new writing of recent years. It has rehearsed for half a year. It is the most expensive regional theatre production in America's history. But the money has not been spent on thousands of extras and huge sets. It has bought us time. Time stops theatre people taking easy solutions, or repeating ourselves; and it helps us meet the challenge of the new. Without time, theatre work is based on formula, not on discovery.

It wasn't just the challenge that made me eager to be involved in Tantalus. I suppose I am working on it because I couldn't not - which may sound a silly reason, but is nonetheless real. I love John Barton, what he stands for and what he has done for the theatre. And Tantalus calls into play practically everything that interests me. It is expressed through lean, witty, verse - the speeches are constructed in quick three or four-beat lines, which are speedy, antithetical and frequently comic. It demands the use of music and movement; and it provokes the audience's imagination so that they believe the impossible.

So if I am asked what on earth we did in 26 weeks of rehearsal, the answer is simple: we worked. We asked questions. We researched. We developed. We saw that research and development (something that is automatic in industry, business or in science) was an invaluable part of collaborative art.

The scenes of Tantalus have been rehearsed as melodrama and as farce. We have mimed them, we have sung them, and we have expressed the actions by making primal sounds. We have worked in full mask and in half mask and in no mask. We have improvised. We have at all times revelled in the artificiality of theatre, in the fact that it is a game of make-believe which can persuade an audience to concentrate with the complete absorption of children at play. Theatre is not 'real'; it is not even true. It is rather a trust; a compact between actor and audience to pretend that what is being done can be imagined to be true. If this trust is violated by improbability or excess, the result is bad theatre.

So Dionysis Fotopoulos has made his stage designs from the experience of rehearsal. The actors developed their costumes with him. Mick Sands, the composer, has built up his score from the very inflections and gut sounds of each scene. And I was surprised last week to see where our work had led us. This wasn't by imposing a concept, but through creating together. The production has, I hope, turned into a post-modernist surprise. Yet it remains Greek - a twenty-first century view of the past, distantly related to contemporary video games and animated films. As far as the process is concerned, it has been modern theatre at its healthiest. It has also been frequent hell, as well as heaven.

One of the problems of a long rehearsal period is that real life obtrudes in a way that isn't possible in the month or six weeks normally given to a play. People have fallen in love (which has been fine); and out of love (which has occasionally been difficult). There have been illnesses and accidents, two walkouts, and one actor who couldn't (in my estimation) handle the particular form of the text, had to go. Dental operations, urgent visits to boyfriends, weddings and celebrations of grandmothers' birthdays have all taken their toll. This ferment of activity has gone on in public, because we have been (gratifyingly) much visited by journalists. The British journalists have been intrigued by the comings-and-goings, sensing a little spicy gossip perhaps. The Americans have been totally indifferent, accepting them as a normal part of showbusiness.

I had two brilliant young directors with me because the vast size of this project demanded double and often triple rehearsals. Edward Hall had a prior commitment and had to be away for eight weeks to direct Henry V at Stratford. But I wanted him very much, not for family reasons (in work it never arises), but because he is very good. It is not his fault that he is my son.

But then our other director, Mick Gordon of the Gate Theatre, went away too: first for a weekend to Argentina, which turned into 10 days because he got engaged; and then for a weekend to London from which he never returned. His agent wrote to Denver saying that there had been artistic differences. Since there hadn't been any, either with the cast, Edward or me, we all remain a mite bewildered.

Sadly it has not been quite so easy with the author himself. I have known John Barton for 50 years, since student days at Cambridge. I have acted with him, directed with him, and often argued with him. When I was about to start the RSC it seemed natural to ask John to join me. He had been, in the meantime, a don at King's College, Cambridge, and in America. But he did not want to be an academic; he didn't even want to be a director, though he has proved himself to be one of the best. He has always wanted to be a writer; and what is more, a writer of plays. Now, in his seventies, he has given us Tantalus, and astonished all of his friends who thought he would never quite finish it. The full text now exists, and will shortly be published.

But the full text is not what we are playing at Denver. We have had to cut and rearrange in the interest of making things work on the stage. It is ironical and sometimes painful that I now find myself editing my old friend's text, for John himself has often been the most ruthless editor of other men's plays.

After the first three weeks in Denver, John went back to England of his own volition. He was worried about his health and needed his doctors. But I believe he was also disturbed and angry about the need for his vast work to be adapted. He said he had to leave it to me and went. He did not return and has been away for nearly all the rehearsals. Happily, he will be here during the opening sequence of performances.

What should have been essentially a collaborative process with the author has turned into collaboration with the cast, my fellow directors and Colin Teevan, our dramaturge. It is not what I would have wished. I was always the final editor of this production otherwise I wouldn't have felt able to do it. But I prefer to have the dramatist in the rehearsal room.

Last week, we played three-and-a-half hours of our epic to a preview audience. They not only seemed to understand the stories we were telling, they were apparently eager for more. The hooks of classical myth are still strong. 'Tell more and act less,' are my watchwords for the actors. Next week we shall offer another three-and-a-half hours; the week after, we shall finish the previews. Then, on 21 October, we shall put it all together in one day.
