fields.headline: Meet the e-mother
fields.standfirst: She's the post-millennial earth mother, effortlessly combining the school run with a great salary and a very flat stomach. But how do mere mortals measure up to the mum who can have (and do) everything
fields.trailText: She's the post-millennial earth mother, effortlessly combining the school run with a great salary and a very flat stomach. But how do mere mortals measure up to the mum who can have (and do) everything.
fields.body:
I did OK! when my baby was born. My mother was a bit bemused - 'Which magazine have I got to go and buy again?' - but all my gay friends thought it was fabulously camp. The photographer arrived when my son, Griffin, was a week old. I was tempted to leave it a bit longer to allow for some of the tidal wave of water retention to subside. However, every pound off my thighs was another eye bag in night feeds so I reck oned I better hurry up and do it before I looked totally raddled. The high point of the shoot was when I was explaining what a marvellous baby Griffin was and he projectile vomited. Still, I take it as a mark of his innate style that he managed to miss both the photographer and my sofa.

Hello! and OK! have got a celeb baby shoot conveyor belt going. No wonder - motherhood has never been more fashionable. Cherie, Posh, Iman, Catherine Zeta Jones, Emma Thompson, Meg Mathews, Patsy Kensit and Madonna have all given birth recently. Every week the celebrity magazines bring a fresh crop of oohs and aahs as born-again celebrity dads go misty-eyed over their freshly minted offspring. Beside them, shiny new celebrity mums lounge, their limbs arranged so as to conceal that tiny bit of cellulite they might be carrying in the nanosecond before the personal trainer or cosmetic surgeon has whisked it away. Got the pop carrier and pile in the country? Puke on one shoulder, as long as it's your baby's and not your own, is the next status symbol on the A-list shopping list.

Still, if motherhood is de rigueur - Gucci is doing baby slings for the baby who has everything, including label-obsessed parents - the question is, what sort? Here are the varieties of ideal motherhood, available this season: 1) Selfless Stay-at-Home Mum. A bit frumpy. Glow of contentment. 2) Wicked Single Mum. A bit tarty. Glow of vodka Red Bull. 3) Thrusting Career Mum. A bit stressed out. Glow of laptop at three in the morning as she tries to catch up on work once baby is asleep. 4) Rock Chick Mum. A bit spaced-out. Glow of victory when she can get into size 6 Earl jeans half an hour after the birth. 5) Yoga Mum. A bit irritating due to burbling absolute rubbish while sipping wheat grass. Glow of inner peace.

The bad news is that the kind of mum we're all supposed to be aiming for now is none of the above and yet all of them at the same time. She is the e-mother, the 'e' standing for everything, which is what she manages to do. A sort of post-millennium earth mother, the e-mother combines the simple homely (in the best sense of the word) sexiness of Nigella Lawson, forever whipping up delicious and nutritious meals for her children, with the ferocious ambition of Nicola Horlick. She is glamorous like Joely Richardson, but grounded like Emma Thompson. She may work, but not so that it interferes with breast-feeding, the school run and/or trips to the gym. She still manages to earn a good salary and does so without having a nanny. Oh yes, and she has a very flat stomach.

Daisy Goodwin is a highly successful TV executive with Talkback Productions who has just had her second child. She is an expert at juggling career and motherhood, but even she finds the new e-mother a bit daunting. 'You're supposed to be cooking fashionable meals while wearing a cardi trimmed with ribbon and kitten heels and wearing a lot of make-up, but not too much,' she says. 'You have to earn loads of money, but also produce very bright children who are also very secure.' The flat stomach thing is especially irksome. 'Madonna is a nightmare,' says Goodwin. 'She had a Caesarean two weeks before me. I saw a picture of her coming out of hospital looking terrible and I was relieved. Now there's another picture of her and her tummy is a lot flatter than mine's going to be in a decade. I thought, "Bloody hell."'

Kim Blake runs her own fashion PR company. 'You're meant to be all-singing, all-dancing Patsy Kensit back in shape in six weeks,' she sighs. 'You've got to be an earth mother, company director and Mrs Walton all rolled into one. Sometimes you feel like you're compromising on everything.' If this sounds eerily similar to the moan of the 80s Having-It-All Superwomen, then there is a twist. The e-mother has to tightrope-walk without a net. She isn't allowed a nanny. She must demonstrate her commitment to the maternal role by looking after her children herself, while doing everything else as well.

Maxine Drane has been a nanny for 11 years. She says, 'There has definitely been a drop off of work over the past couple of years. More women are working from home and just want help a couple of days a week.' Drane dreads the e-mother who has an office at home. 'I can't just get on with things,' she says. Either through guilt at not giving her little darlings her own full-time attention, or because she doesn't trust the nanny to perform the task to her impossibly high standards - she might slip a non-organic Penguin biscuit in to little Tarquin's lunchbox! - the e-mother is forever popping out of her office and getting in the nanny's hair.

The e-mother orthodoxy holds that it is cruel and heartless to hand your baby to someone else. Real mothers - proper moth ers - change their own offspring's nappies. I remember an early visit from the health visitor. As she was leaving, she informed me she would be round in a few days time. I said that wasn't convenient, as I would be working. 'Who's going to look after the baby!' she exclaimed. I was tempted to say I was going to leave him on his own with a chainsaw, but I didn't think she had a sense of humour.

'I felt totally alienated. I went to one National Childbirth Trust class and I could have been in a different dimension,' remembers Kim Blake. 'Everyone else who was having a baby was going from fourth gear to neutral. I went from fourth to third. I don't know if that was a good idea or not, but financially and emotionally I needed to go back to work.' This is the reality for many women and yet it is totally at odds with the e-mother philosophy. If the 80s was the decade of the power-dressed female executive wheeling a fax machine into the delivery room, then the Zeros are producing an equally unrealistic stereotype. The e-mother making organic biscuits with her kids with one hand, while firing off a few e-mails to her dotcom business with the other.

There is something faintly 80s about having a Norland in full rig following along a few steps behind you, pushing a huge Mamas and Papas pram, but is the other option really workable? Elle McPherson famously doesn't have a nanny. However, when she took two-year-old Flynn to the set of Friends , she collapsed from exhaustion. As for Posh, she may not have a nanny, but she's got her mum and David, of course. To do without childcare you need a really good back-up. Step forward grandma. With many people retiring younger and being in better health for longer, the role of grandparents as unpaid childcarers is now key. Melanie Blatt of All Saints takes her mum with her to recording sessions to look after her child.

Part of everyone else's nanny phobia is the Louise Woodward effect. We'd rather struggle ourselves than risk the childcare version of the cowboy builder. But it's more than that. The increasing numbers of women who now have babies later means they want to spend time with them. The number of women aged 35 and above who give birth has increased by 65 per cent over the past 10 years, while the numbers aged 29 and under has fallen steadily.

I started off saying I didn't want a nanny. Then I returned from the parallel universe I was living in and realised I needed help. I then decided that I would get temporary nannies when I needed them, all highly trained, of course. I booked my highly trained help for a couple of days. She let me down the night before. My mother was away, my partner's mother is many miles away. In the words of Ghostbusters : 'Who you gonna call?' In my case, it was Mercedes, my Ecuadorian cleaner who's turned out to be a bit of a diamond. Frankly, though, if the paper boy would stand still long enough I'd probably be handing Griffin to him by now. I tell people I'm bringing up my child to be bilingual. The truth is Mercedes doesn't speak a lot of English.

TV presenter Ulrika Jonsson managed without a nanny for a year when her son Cameron, now five, was born. 'I was totally happy to dedicate myself to the baby. I immersed myself, I didn't worry about my waistline or the stretchmarks on my bosoms.' Nine months later she went back to work. 'When I went away to work on Gladiators I discovered a new-found freedom that I had had before I was pregnant. That was the beginning of the revolution. It was like breaking out of a shell,' she explains. Ulrika is now pregnant again. This time she will have help. 'It's a bit pretentious to say you're not going to have a nanny. A bit earth mother,' she says. 'This time around there won't be the same independence as was possible with one child.'

The rise in infertility is another factor in the e-mother's desire to Do It All Herself. Having children is now seen as a privilege. One in six couples now has problems conceiving. My partner and I had a slight hitch. I had to take fertility drugs and have an operation, although, by a fluke, I subsequently became pregnant naturally. For Jonsson, too, while having her son Cameron with her now ex-husband, cameraman John Turnbull, was relatively easy, conceiving with her new partner, now also ex, travel executive Marcus Kempen, wasn't as easy. 'I fell pregnant the first time we didn't use anything with Cameron. This time we didn't use anything for over a year and nothing. I thought, "Oh, I've been drinking and having too much of a good time and I've made myself infertile." The doctor said wait for 18 months. But I didn't want to wait. I wanted a baby now.'

For e-mothers, children are so precious, they must be cherished, adored and stimulated 24 hours a day. 'With Cameron, I used to take a shower and put him in the rock-a-by car seat next to me and I'd be singing to him in the shower.' Kim Blake can top that. 'People said I shouldn't bring my daughter in with me at night, so I slept on a camp bed next to the cot for the first six months. I was totally exhausted,' she admits. Neither, however, is as driven as the woman I saw in the park the other day. She had flash cards all round her baby's head in the pram.

I recently encountered a room full of e-mothers at my local antenatal clinic. I casually mentioned that I'd left Griffin at home when he was six weeks old while I went away to work for six days. The Joseph Tricot-euses passed judgment. 'I miss my baby even if I leave her with my husband so I can go to the supermarket,' said one, shrill with horror at my heartlessness. Another was stunned by my apparent lack of maternal instinct. 'She screams if either of us leave the room!' she said of her own baby.

It wasn't always like this. As Aminata Forna describes in her book Mother of All Myths in the 18th century, 'Babies were wrapped tightly in swaddling clothes and often hung up on a peg'. Maybe Elle should have tried that? Today, however, we live in an increasingly child-centred world. As we become more cynical about adult human nature, so we imbue infants with a saintly fragility. Every degree we fall out of love with ourselves is one more degree to fall in love with our children. We don't so much change nappies now as pay homage.

Step one in e-mother baby worship is breast-feeding. At the same antenatal clinic where I was virtually stoned for not having Griffin strapped to me 24 hours-a-day, I committed another e-mother cardinal sin. I pulled a bottle of formula out of my handbag. Now, I did give breast-feeding a go. However, it was like the storming of the Normandy beaches. It took me, my maternity nurse, my other half and baby, plus nipple guards and KY jelly and it still didn't work. I could have persevered, but since I'd acquired a comedy cleavage - 36H - I wimped out.

We all know that breast-feeding is best for the baby, but there is also a lot of guff talked about it. Even if you are better at it than I was, the truth is it's a full-time job in itself. You are chained to the sofa. Yes, you can express milk, but that takes time, too. I wonder how many of the celeb e-mothers who seem to glide seamlessly from The Portland to the Met Bar are actually breast- feeding? Certainly, their reed-like figures suggest they're not. The other great lie about breast-feeding is how much weight it will help you shift. Breast-feeding does help contract the uterus, flattening your stomach, and it burns 500 calories a day. That said, you will be absolutely ravenous, so capable of clearing the fridge at one sitting, and have a chest area that looks as if someone took a foot pump to it.

The cult of self-sacrifice is key to all ideals of motherhood. In parts of Asia, Africa and South America, a motherhood cult known as Marianisma (after the Virgin Mary) decrees huge sacrifices on the part of poverty-stricken mothers in favour of their children. We have our own version of that same cult here, of course. Single mothers on benefits, who shuffle to the shops in their slippers to buy expensive Tommy Hilfiger tops for their kids. Only we don't worship those mothers. We force them out to work.

'Once a mother fed, clothed and comforted her offspring and there, for better or worse, lay the limits of her obligations,' writes Amanita Forna. 'Today her responsi bilities have doubled. She is also in charge of her children's emotional stability and psychological development_ Successful motherhood now means producing a high- achiever as well as a well-balanced adult.'

What about the role of the father in all of this? E-mothers have perfectly supportive partners. In real life, things aren't always so smooth. As Ulrika Jonsson says ruefully of her relationship with the father of her unborn child, 'I went in wanting to have a baby with this person and I didn't know it would be a disaster. I didn't just search out this sperm'.

If your relationship does survive the pregnancy, the period after you give birth can be traumatic. The most modern and equal of relationships begin to revert to a more traditional pattern, especially if you're breast-feeding. Michael Douglas tells Hello! that he is 'the official burper', but the bulk of the hard labour is still Catherine's. Extended families who may have been but a distant presence also suddenly become part of your life, bringing with them different expectations of how your relationship should be.

How many other mothers on reading the rumours surrounding the break-up of Meg Mathews and Noel Gallagher's marriage - Meg is said to have been discovered wandering naked in the garden of her £2m Bucks mansion 'out of it' - felt a pang of sympathy? No one advocates drug use while in charge of small children. However, here was a woman who'd been used to spending entire afternoons handbag shopping. Suddenly it was her stomach that had gone baggy and she had a bawling baby to boot. Meg managed to hold off going to parties until Anaïs was 10 weeks old. She left her first post-baby bash after just 40 minutes.

'I want to go home to my baby,' she said at the time. 'I love parties, but at the moment they're not my thing.' Unfortunately, it seems she changed her mind. Meg is said to have checked in for help with depression at The Priory. Noel is also said to be having psychotherapy. At least Meg looked the part, able to wear a see-through top within weeks of giving birth. Appearance is vital to the e-mother. Ulrika Jonsson says of her second pregnancy, 'This time around there is much more pressure to be sexy. I'm 5kg up on what I was last time. If you've got big knockers you don't see your tummy or your feet. I had this dream of being a trendy mum and look like a sort of hippy Madonna, but it hasn't really come to fruition.' And as for Posh, 'She makes me feel bad. She makes me feel fat,' she reveals. If Mrs Beckham makes Ulrika feel fat, what hope for the rest of us?

Jonsson demonstrates one of the ironies about the e-mother. While it is essential that you look sexy, preferably having slipped back into your hipster jeans after the birth, it is equally vital that you don't behave in too sexy a way. Jonsson was castigated for posing for a set of risqué fashion pictures after the birth of her son.

'I really don't feel that just because you give birth we have to stop living and enjoying other sides of things,' she says. 'You can be a mother and be sexy, too.' She's right, of course. Women such as Carol Smilie who regain their shape after birth are congratulated for it. Still, the reaction to women who are then seen out on the town having a good time is less positive.

'When I had Cameron, I suddenly discovered going out, because in a confusing way I was a mother and single again. I didn't go out a lot. Maybe one night a week. But maybe I'd been out and I was drunk and I was heavily criticised,' she remembers. One newspaper bracketed her with Fergie as the worst mothers in Britain. It's an accusation that still hurts. 'What makes you a bad mother is behaving irresponsibly when you're with your children. If you're getting pissed or throwing up in front of your five-year-old that is a different thing,' says Jonsson.

In the past, for women, marriage was not preceded by a long period of singledom. However, today's e-mother may be yesterday's Ladette. Step forward Zoë Ball. It will be interesting to see how Zoë cuts it as an e-mother. Her baby is due on Christmas Eve. She is definitely giving it her best shot. Ball famously gave up her job so she could be in the correct de-stressed state to conceive. The fact her husband is a millionaire might have eased that decision. Even so, conception didn't happen as planned. She spent a good few months playing Wife instead of Mother. 'I made every dish in Jamie Oliver's cookbook,' she recently revealed.

Food is key for the e-mother. Once breast- feeding is finished (and it can go on for years) only organic food will do. I know one mother who allows her child to go to McDonald's with her friends, but insists she takes her well-balanced organic meal with her in little Tupperware containers. While the other children tuck into fries, this child eats broccoli. I thought I'd done OK with this bit of e-motherdom, having purchased organic baby rice for Griffin. I told my health visitor proudly. She just gave me a look and suggested I try some fresh food.

Kate Winslett, whose baby is due this week, is obviously well on her way to e-motherdom. She will take six months off after the birth - gold star to Kate - to live The Good Life with her hubby. On the subject of the birth, Kate has been quoted as saying she wants no drugs. 'If I need help during labour we'll ring my acupuncturist.' I laughed so much when I read that that I almost ruptured a stretchmark.

So there we have it, the world according to e-motherdom. And what a lovely, rose-tinted fantasy it is. The idea that any baby will 'be packed in the bags and he'll be on the road' - as Catherine Zeta Jones says of her son in Hello! - is ludicrous. Babies are a huge disruption, hopefully a nice one, to your life and to your relationship. Zoë Ball reveals: 'I was saying I wanted to be at home - I've sort of turned into my mother.'

That was before she got pregnant. Wait till she's had the baby. A couple of months of night feeds and she'll feel like her mum and look like her grandma.

Baby talk

'This has to be the the happiest time in my life. Alexandria is the force around whom everyone is gathered. My soul feels complete.'
Iman

'No one can prepare you for that moment of seeing him for the first time. Just before Dylan was born I turned to Michael and said, "I'd do this again."'
Catherine Zeta Jones

'I can't stand the thought of our baby being delivered by someone I don't know. I've had a good training for labour with some of my film roles, especially Titanic, when I was immersed for days in freezing tanks of water. I want a drug-free birth - it's what women are designed to do and we should bloody well get on with it.'
Kate Winslet

'Everyone is talking about babies. I want one. It's definitely getting to the stage where I want another baby.'

fields.bodyText: I did OK! when my baby was born. My mother was a bit bemused - 'Which magazine have I got to go and buy again?' - but all my gay friends thought it was fabulously camp. The photographer arrived when my son, Griffin, was a week old. I was tempted to leave it a bit longer to allow for some of the tidal wave of water retention to subside. However, every pound off my thighs was another eye bag in night feeds so I reck oned I better hurry up and do it before I looked totally raddled. The high point of the shoot was when I was explaining what a marvellous baby Griffin was and he projectile vomited. Still, I take it as a mark of his innate style that he managed to miss both the photographer and my sofa. Hello! and OK! have got a celeb baby shoot conveyor belt going. No wonder - motherhood has never been more fashionable. Cherie, Posh, Iman, Catherine Zeta Jones, Emma Thompson, Meg Mathews, Patsy Kensit and Madonna have all given birth recently. Every week the celebrity magazines bring a fresh crop of oohs and aahs as born-again celebrity dads go misty-eyed over their freshly minted offspring. Beside them, shiny new celebrity mums lounge, their limbs arranged so as to conceal that tiny bit of cellulite they might be carrying in the nanosecond before the personal trainer or cosmetic surgeon has whisked it away. Got the pop carrier and pile in the country? Puke on one shoulder, as long as it's your baby's and not your own, is the next status symbol on the A-list shopping list. Still, if motherhood is de rigueur - Gucci is doing baby slings for the baby who has everything, including label-obsessed parents - the question is, what sort? Here are the varieties of ideal motherhood, available this season: 1) Selfless Stay-at-Home Mum. A bit frumpy. Glow of contentment. 2) Wicked Single Mum. A bit tarty. Glow of vodka Red Bull. 3) Thrusting Career Mum. A bit stressed out. Glow of laptop at three in the morning as she tries to catch up on work once baby is asleep. 4) Rock Chick Mum. A bit spaced-out. Glow of victory when she can get into size 6 Earl jeans half an hour after the birth. 5) Yoga Mum. A bit irritating due to burbling absolute rubbish while sipping wheat grass. Glow of inner peace. The bad news is that the kind of mum we're all supposed to be aiming for now is none of the above and yet all of them at the same time. She is the e-mother, the 'e' standing for everything, which is what she manages to do. A sort of post-millennium earth mother, the e-mother combines the simple homely (in the best sense of the word) sexiness of Nigella Lawson, forever whipping up delicious and nutritious meals for her children, with the ferocious ambition of Nicola Horlick. She is glamorous like Joely Richardson, but grounded like Emma Thompson. She may work, but not so that it interferes with breast-feeding, the school run and/or trips to the gym. She still manages to earn a good salary and does so without having a nanny. Oh yes, and she has a very flat stomach. Daisy Goodwin is a highly successful TV executive with Talkback Productions who has just had her second child. She is an expert at juggling career and motherhood, but even she finds the new e-mother a bit daunting. 'You're supposed to be cooking fashionable meals while wearing a cardi trimmed with ribbon and kitten heels and wearing a lot of make-up, but not too much,' she says. 'You have to earn loads of money, but also produce very bright children who are also very secure.' The flat stomach thing is especially irksome. 'Madonna is a nightmare,' says Goodwin. 'She had a Caesarean two weeks before me. I saw a picture of her coming out of hospital looking terrible and I was relieved. Now there's another picture of her and her tummy is a lot flatter than mine's going to be in a decade. I thought, "Bloody hell."' Kim Blake runs her own fashion PR company. 'You're meant to be all-singing, all-dancing Patsy Kensit back in shape in six weeks,' she sighs. 'You've got to be an earth mother, company director and Mrs Walton all rolled into one. Sometimes you feel like you're compromising on everything.' If this sounds eerily similar to the moan of the 80s Having-It-All Superwomen, then there is a twist. The e-mother has to tightrope-walk without a net. She isn't allowed a nanny. She must demonstrate her commitment to the maternal role by looking after her children herself, while doing everything else as well. Maxine Drane has been a nanny for 11 years. She says, 'There has definitely been a drop off of work over the past couple of years. More women are working from home and just want help a couple of days a week.' Drane dreads the e-mother who has an office at home. 'I can't just get on with things,' she says. Either through guilt at not giving her little darlings her own full-time attention, or because she doesn't trust the nanny to perform the task to her impossibly high standards - she might slip a non-organic Penguin biscuit in to little Tarquin's lunchbox! - the e-mother is forever popping out of her office and getting in the nanny's hair. The e-mother orthodoxy holds that it is cruel and heartless to hand your baby to someone else. Real mothers - proper moth ers - change their own offspring's nappies. I remember an early visit from the health visitor. As she was leaving, she informed me she would be round in a few days time. I said that wasn't convenient, as I would be working. 'Who's going to look after the baby!' she exclaimed. I was tempted to say I was going to leave him on his own with a chainsaw, but I didn't think she had a sense of humour. 'I felt totally alienated. I went to one National Childbirth Trust class and I could have been in a different dimension,' remembers Kim Blake. 'Everyone else who was having a baby was going from fourth gear to neutral. I went from fourth to third. I don't know if that was a good idea or not, but financially and emotionally I needed to go back to work.' This is the reality for many women and yet it is totally at odds with the e-mother philosophy. If the 80s was the decade of the power-dressed female executive wheeling a fax machine into the delivery room, then the Zeros are producing an equally unrealistic stereotype. The e-mother making organic biscuits with her kids with one hand, while firing off a few e-mails to her dotcom business with the other. There is something faintly 80s about having a Norland in full rig following along a few steps behind you, pushing a huge Mamas and Papas pram, but is the other option really workable? Elle McPherson famously doesn't have a nanny. However, when she took two-year-old Flynn to the set of Friends , she collapsed from exhaustion. As for Posh, she may not have a nanny, but she's got her mum and David, of course. To do without childcare you need a really good back-up. Step forward grandma. With many people retiring younger and being in better health for longer, the role of grandparents as unpaid childcarers is now key. Melanie Blatt of All Saints takes her mum with her to recording sessions to look after her child. Part of everyone else's nanny phobia is the Louise Woodward effect. We'd rather struggle ourselves than risk the childcare version of the cowboy builder. But it's more than that. The increasing numbers of women who now have babies later means they want to spend time with them. The number of women aged 35 and above who give birth has increased by 65 per cent over the past 10 years, while the numbers aged 29 and under has fallen steadily. I started off saying I didn't want a nanny. Then I returned from the parallel universe I was living in and realised I needed help. I then decided that I would get temporary nannies when I needed them, all highly trained, of course. I booked my highly trained help for a couple of days. She let me down the night before. My mother was away, my partner's mother is many miles away. In the words of Ghostbusters : 'Who you gonna call?' In my case, it was Mercedes, my Ecuadorian cleaner who's turned out to be a bit of a diamond. Frankly, though, if the paper boy would stand still long enough I'd probably be handing Griffin to him by now. I tell people I'm bringing up my child to be bilingual. The truth is Mercedes doesn't speak a lot of English. TV presenter Ulrika Jonsson managed without a nanny for a year when her son Cameron, now five, was born. 'I was totally happy to dedicate myself to the baby. I immersed myself, I didn't worry about my waistline or the stretchmarks on my bosoms.' Nine months later she went back to work. 'When I went away to work on Gladiators I discovered a new-found freedom that I had had before I was pregnant. That was the beginning of the revolution. It was like breaking out of a shell,' she explains. Ulrika is now pregnant again. This time she will have help. 'It's a bit pretentious to say you're not going to have a nanny. A bit earth mother,' she says. 'This time around there won't be the same independence as was possible with one child.' The rise in infertility is another factor in the e-mother's desire to Do It All Herself. Having children is now seen as a privilege. One in six couples now has problems conceiving. My partner and I had a slight hitch. I had to take fertility drugs and have an operation, although, by a fluke, I subsequently became pregnant naturally. For Jonsson, too, while having her son Cameron with her now ex-husband, cameraman John Turnbull, was relatively easy, conceiving with her new partner, now also ex, travel executive Marcus Kempen, wasn't as easy. 'I fell pregnant the first time we didn't use anything with Cameron. This time we didn't use anything for over a year and nothing. I thought, "Oh, I've been drinking and having too much of a good time and I've made myself infertile." The doctor said wait for 18 months. But I didn't want to wait. I wanted a baby now.' For e-mothers, children are so precious, they must be cherished, adored and stimulated 24 hours a day. 'With Cameron, I used to take a shower and put him in the rock-a-by car seat next to me and I'd be singing to him in the shower.' Kim Blake can top that. 'People said I shouldn't bring my daughter in with me at night, so I slept on a camp bed next to the cot for the first six months. I was totally exhausted,' she admits. Neither, however, is as driven as the woman I saw in the park the other day. She had flash cards all round her baby's head in the pram. I recently encountered a room full of e-mothers at my local antenatal clinic. I casually mentioned that I'd left Griffin at home when he was six weeks old while I went away to work for six days. The Joseph Tricot-euses passed judgment. 'I miss my baby even if I leave her with my husband so I can go to the supermarket,' said one, shrill with horror at my heartlessness. Another was stunned by my apparent lack of maternal instinct. 'She screams if either of us leave the room!' she said of her own baby. It wasn't always like this. As Aminata Forna describes in her book Mother of All Myths in the 18th century, 'Babies were wrapped tightly in swaddling clothes and often hung up on a peg'. Maybe Elle should have tried that? Today, however, we live in an increasingly child-centred world. As we become more cynical about adult human nature, so we imbue infants with a saintly fragility. Every degree we fall out of love with ourselves is one more degree to fall in love with our children. We don't so much change nappies now as pay homage. Step one in e-mother baby worship is breast-feeding. At the same antenatal clinic where I was virtually stoned for not having Griffin strapped to me 24 hours-a-day, I committed another e-mother cardinal sin. I pulled a bottle of formula out of my handbag. Now, I did give breast-feeding a go. However, it was like the storming of the Normandy beaches. It took me, my maternity nurse, my other half and baby, plus nipple guards and KY jelly and it still didn't work. I could have persevered, but since I'd acquired a comedy cleavage - 36H - I wimped out. We all know that breast-feeding is best for the baby, but there is also a lot of guff talked about it. Even if you are better at it than I was, the truth is it's a full-time job in itself. You are chained to the sofa. Yes, you can express milk, but that takes time, too. I wonder how many of the celeb e-mothers who seem to glide seamlessly from The Portland to the Met Bar are actually breast- feeding? Certainly, their reed-like figures suggest they're not. The other great lie about breast-feeding is how much weight it will help you shift. Breast-feeding does help contract the uterus, flattening your stomach, and it burns 500 calories a day. That said, you will be absolutely ravenous, so capable of clearing the fridge at one sitting, and have a chest area that looks as if someone took a foot pump to it. The cult of self-sacrifice is key to all ideals of motherhood. In parts of Asia, Africa and South America, a motherhood cult known as Marianisma (after the Virgin Mary) decrees huge sacrifices on the part of poverty-stricken mothers in favour of their children. We have our own version of that same cult here, of course. Single mothers on benefits, who shuffle to the shops in their slippers to buy expensive Tommy Hilfiger tops for their kids. Only we don't worship those mothers. We force them out to work. 'Once a mother fed, clothed and comforted her offspring and there, for better or worse, lay the limits of her obligations,' writes Amanita Forna. 'Today her responsi bilities have doubled. She is also in charge of her children's emotional stability and psychological development_ Successful motherhood now means producing a high- achiever as well as a well-balanced adult.' What about the role of the father in all of this? E-mothers have perfectly supportive partners. In real life, things aren't always so smooth. As Ulrika Jonsson says ruefully of her relationship with the father of her unborn child, 'I went in wanting to have a baby with this person and I didn't know it would be a disaster. I didn't just search out this sperm'. If your relationship does survive the pregnancy, the period after you give birth can be traumatic. The most modern and equal of relationships begin to revert to a more traditional pattern, especially if you're breast-feeding. Michael Douglas tells Hello! that he is 'the official burper', but the bulk of the hard labour is still Catherine's. Extended families who may have been but a distant presence also suddenly become part of your life, bringing with them different expectations of how your relationship should be. How many other mothers on reading the rumours surrounding the break-up of Meg Mathews and Noel Gallagher's marriage - Meg is said to have been discovered wandering naked in the garden of her £2m Bucks mansion 'out of it' - felt a pang of sympathy? No one advocates drug use while in charge of small children. However, here was a woman who'd been used to spending entire afternoons handbag shopping. Suddenly it was her stomach that had gone baggy and she had a bawling baby to boot. Meg managed to hold off going to parties until Anaïs was 10 weeks old. She left her first post-baby bash after just 40 minutes. 'I want to go home to my baby,' she said at the time. 'I love parties, but at the moment they're not my thing.' Unfortunately, it seems she changed her mind. Meg is said to have checked in for help with depression at The Priory. Noel is also said to be having psychotherapy. At least Meg looked the part, able to wear a see-through top within weeks of giving birth. Appearance is vital to the e-mother. Ulrika Jonsson says of her second pregnancy, 'This time around there is much more pressure to be sexy. I'm 5kg up on what I was last time. If you've got big knockers you don't see your tummy or your feet. I had this dream of being a trendy mum and look like a sort of hippy Madonna, but it hasn't really come to fruition.' And as for Posh, 'She makes me feel bad. She makes me feel fat,' she reveals. If Mrs Beckham makes Ulrika feel fat, what hope for the rest of us? Jonsson demonstrates one of the ironies about the e-mother. While it is essential that you look sexy, preferably having slipped back into your hipster jeans after the birth, it is equally vital that you don't behave in too sexy a way. Jonsson was castigated for posing for a set of risqué fashion pictures after the birth of her son. 'I really don't feel that just because you give birth we have to stop living and enjoying other sides of things,' she says. 'You can be a mother and be sexy, too.' She's right, of course. Women such as Carol Smilie who regain their shape after birth are congratulated for it. Still, the reaction to women who are then seen out on the town having a good time is less positive. 'When I had Cameron, I suddenly discovered going out, because in a confusing way I was a mother and single again. I didn't go out a lot. Maybe one night a week. But maybe I'd been out and I was drunk and I was heavily criticised,' she remembers. One newspaper bracketed her with Fergie as the worst mothers in Britain. It's an accusation that still hurts. 'What makes you a bad mother is behaving irresponsibly when you're with your children. If you're getting pissed or throwing up in front of your five-year-old that is a different thing,' says Jonsson. In the past, for women, marriage was not preceded by a long period of singledom. However, today's e-mother may be yesterday's Ladette. Step forward Zoë Ball. It will be interesting to see how Zoë cuts it as an e-mother. Her baby is due on Christmas Eve. She is definitely giving it her best shot. Ball famously gave up her job so she could be in the correct de-stressed state to conceive. The fact her husband is a millionaire might have eased that decision. Even so, conception didn't happen as planned. She spent a good few months playing Wife instead of Mother. 'I made every dish in Jamie Oliver's cookbook,' she recently revealed. Food is key for the e-mother. Once breast- feeding is finished (and it can go on for years) only organic food will do. I know one mother who allows her child to go to McDonald's with her friends, but insists she takes her well-balanced organic meal with her in little Tupperware containers. While the other children tuck into fries, this child eats broccoli. I thought I'd done OK with this bit of e-motherdom, having purchased organic baby rice for Griffin. I told my health visitor proudly. She just gave me a look and suggested I try some fresh food. Kate Winslett, whose baby is due this week, is obviously well on her way to e-motherdom. She will take six months off after the birth - gold star to Kate - to live The Good Life with her hubby. On the subject of the birth, Kate has been quoted as saying she wants no drugs. 'If I need help during labour we'll ring my acupuncturist.' I laughed so much when I read that that I almost ruptured a stretchmark. So there we have it, the world according to e-motherdom. And what a lovely, rose-tinted fantasy it is. The idea that any baby will 'be packed in the bags and he'll be on the road' - as Catherine Zeta Jones says of her son in Hello! - is ludicrous. Babies are a huge disruption, hopefully a nice one, to your life and to your relationship. Zoë Ball reveals: 'I was saying I wanted to be at home - I've sort of turned into my mother.' That was before she got pregnant. Wait till she's had the baby. A couple of months of night feeds and she'll feel like her mum and look like her grandma. Baby talk 'This has to be the the happiest time in my life. Alexandria is the force around whom everyone is gathered. My soul feels complete.' Iman 'No one can prepare you for that moment of seeing him for the first time. Just before Dylan was born I turned to Michael and said, "I'd do this again."' Catherine Zeta Jones 'I can't stand the thought of our baby being delivered by someone I don't know. I've had a good training for labour with some of my film roles, especially Titanic, when I was immersed for days in freezing tanks of water. I want a drug-free birth - it's what women are designed to do and we should bloody well get on with it.' Kate Winslet 'Everyone is talking about babies. I want one. It's definitely getting to the stage where I want another baby.' Victoria Beckham 'Motherhood has had a huge impact on me. When you have children you have to step outside yourself. You look at life from a different perspective.' Madonna

fields.headline: The infiltrators
fields.standfirst: Martin and Philip live the Yardie life. Plush Docklands flats, brand new BMWs, bulging wallets... and all paid for with drug money. The only difference is that Martin and Philip are undercover cops. Here, they reveal what it's like to 'go native', and how they were almost killed in a Birmingham drug bust
fields.trailText: Martin and Philip live the Yardie life. Plush Docklands flats, brand new BMWs, bulging wallets... and all paid for with drug money. The only difference is that Martin and Philip are undercover cops.
fields.body:
The drug deal was going horribly wrong. Instead of coming away with £10,000 worth of premium quality crack cocaine, Martin Maynard and his friend Philip Etienne had been ambushed by a team of armed Yardie gangsters who were trying to steal their money.

Martin had lost count of how many shots had been fired. One had been so close he had felt its heat as it whistled past his ear. He had somehow fought his way out of the car and made a desperate run for a nearby low wall. It was only when he reached it that he risked a glance behind him.

'I was shaking with fear. I looked back and saw Philip staggering round the rear of the Mondeo. He was limping, obviously in pain, and as he passed under a streetlight I could see his right leg was soaked dark with blood. One of the gunmen was standing right in front of him, about eight feet away, and his gun was aimed directly at Philip's chest. I heard him shouting: 'D'ya want another one, bumba clot? D'ya want it again?'

'I was thinking, "Oh Jesus, he's going to shoot Philip. He's going to fucking kill Philip". In that fraction of a second, I had to make a decision that I would have to live with for the rest of my life. To my right was the safety of the main road. The gunman hadn't seen me, I wasn't injured, I could easily make it across. On my left was Philip, moments away from being shot dead in cold blood. It was the hardest, most agonising decision I have ever had to make. And there was just no time for it. I took one last glance at the main road, sucked in a deep breath, turned towards the gunman and started running.'

It was the end both men had long feared. For the previous eight years, Philip and Martin had lived among the upper echelons of London's criminal underworld. During that time, they dealt in guns, stolen high-performance cars, stolen passports and traded vast quantities of cocaine, ecstasy and crack. With their plush Docklands flats, brand new BMWs and bulging wallets, they made a mockery of the notion that crime doesn't pay.

Able to lay their hands on vast amounts of cash at a moment's notice, and with a sizable group of dedicated henchmen at their beck and call, the pair were just the kind of high-ranking professional villains that other crooks felt most comfortable dealing with. Which was just the idea. Because, in reality, Philip and Martin were undercover police officers working for Scotland Yard's most elite unit: SO10.

Also known as the Crime Operations Group, SO10 (the first two letters stand for Specialist Operations) is one of the most secretive divisions within the whole of the police force. Even Special Branch (SO12), which works hand in hand with MI5, is relatively open about the nature of its work. In contrast, all of the books, brochures and information packs produced by the Metropolitan Police - even their own website - fail to mention SO10 at all.

The reality of working undercover is a world away from anything that has ever been portrayed in film or on television. It is something the vast majority of police officers are totally unprepared for.

'Working in uniform or even moving into CID, you spend your time chasing after kids nicking cars or blokes with 50 quid's worth of dope in their back pockets,' says Martin. 'You never meet a real criminal. They're the people who always have a couple of grand in their wallet. They have the car of their dreams parked outside the house of their dreams. They eat in the best restaurants and get into the best clubs without ever having to queue up. When you work undercover, you have to become just like them.'

Part of the challenge is working alone. Although there might be surveillance and back-up in place at the beginning of a job, officers are totally alone thereafter. With no radio or warrant card, they can neither call in help or prove who they are. And it is often only at the last minute that they will find out where a deal is to take place.

'Not only do you not know where you are going, but you also know surprisingly little about your target,' adds Philip. 'It sounds crazy but it's standard SO10 procedure that you don't delve into the background of the people you are after. The reason is clear: the more you know about someone, the more you'll end up thinking about it, even if it's only at the back of your mind. If you've been told that the man you are sitting with always keeps a pistol down the side of his boot, you're going to jump through the roof when he gets a sudden itch on his calf and reaches down to scratch it. The only way to be relaxed is to not know.

It's a similar problem when it comes to identifying people. Sometimes you get given pictures so you can make sure you have got the right person, but then when you walk into a pub for the first time to meet them, you have to remember that you're not supposed to know what they look like. You can't be seen to recognise them.'

For those who get past the initial assessment, the only way to qualify to work for SO10 is to go through what is widely considered to be the most difficult and demanding training course the police force has to offer. Based at the Peel Centre in Hendon, North London, the same place where the Met puts its raw recruits through their paces, the course starts at 7am on a Monday and runs straight through until 4am the following morning. If they're lucky, students manage to grab a couple of hours' sleep before starting again at 7am on Tuesday. And so it goes on, day after day, night after night, for two solid weeks.

During that time, there are lectures about points of law, constant exams, assessments and exercises. There are detailed role-playing sessions where recruits learn to deal with every conceivable situation, as well as hands-on instruction in the use of hidden tape recorders, transmitters and technical equipment. They are taught about dealing with informants, reading body language, how to dress, how to act, how to speak while they are undercover. Most of all, they learn how to keep out of trouble - physical and legal.

Gathering evidence while undercover is fraught with difficulty. Critical conversations can be recorded with special devices, but a whole new set of skills needs to be learned in order to get the best from them. Under the Police and Criminal Evidence Act, a police officer can only interview someone if they have first read them their rights. If they haven't done that, then any evidence obtained, no matter how damning, becomes inadmissible in a court of law.

So if an officer is recording a target who begins to implicate themselves in a crime but then stops halfway through, the undercover can't ask them for more information. If they start firing questions, defence lawyers will argue that it constitutes an interview and the case will be thrown out.

The most notorious example of this came a few years ago when 39-year-old mother-of-two Patricia Hall, vanished from her home in Pudsey, Leeds, on a freezing January night. Though hundreds of people disappear each year hoping to leave their troubles behind and start over, they almost always leave some kind of trail, take a bunch of personal items or stockpile cash to sustain them. Patricia had done none of these things - she hadn't even taken any warm clothing.

Detectives investigating the case quickly discovered that, shortly before she vanished, Patricia allegedly told her husband, Keith, that she was going to leave him for another man, sparking a series of furious arguments. Keith, who insisted that Patricia had simply walked out on him after one particularly nasty row, became the prime suspect in his wife's murder, but not a scrap of evidence could be found to prove he was responsible or even that she was dead.

Six months on, Keith placed an advert in the lonely hearts column of his local newspaper and an undercover officer known as Claire was brought in to respond.

The relationship quickly flourished, and after a few months Keith proposed marriage. Claire told him she was terrified of Patricia coming back into his life, that the only way she could go forward with the relationship would be to know the absolute truth about what happened. Sitting in Claire's car, which had been fitted with microphones and recording devices, Keith said nothing for a while then whispered: 'It's okay, she's dead.'

'How do you know?' asked Claire.

'How do you think I know? I was sleeping downstairs, then I woke up. I strangled her. There was a voice in my head telling me to do it.' Later that same night, Keith explained that he had burned the body and that the police would never find it. He was arrested and charged with murder three days later.

At trial, the judge, Mr Justice Waterhouse, ruled the recordings - the only real evidence against him - could not be heard because they breached the code of practice governing interview procedures. 'However good the intentions of the police officers involved, and however skilful a performer the undercover police officer may have been, the effect of what was done was to negate the defendant's right not to incriminate himself.' Keith Hall was acquitted of all charges and continues to protest his innocence. 'I did not murder my wife,' he said outside the court. 'It remains a mystery to me where she is.'

Some undercover operations last only a few hours, others can go on for months or even years. At their simplest level, they can involve nothing more than a phone call. At the other end of the scale, a complete change of identity and location may be necessary. Most of the time, the true scale of an SO10 operation is kept hidden from public view. A line in a local newspaper that a quantity of drugs has been recovered after 'an undercover police operation' gives little indication about the time, effort and danger involved in such work.

Philip was once kidnapped and tortured during an operation, while Martin narrowly escaped attending a meeting where an informant was shot dead. 'You never think that one job might be more dangerous than another,' says Martin. 'As far as I'm concerned, they are all dangerous.

Any situation can get out of hand. And having to deal with such a wide range of personalities makes it even harder. In life, you always have some people that you get on with and some people that you don't. Those exact same conflicts exist when you are undercover. The difficulty there, though, is that you can't just walk away, you have to carry on with the job, no matter how much of a prat you think the person you are dealing with is.'

The stress of pretending to be someone else comes from all directions. Undercover officers often comment on the fact that they don't like the way members of the public look at them when they are working. Especially for those who are in uniform, they are normally treated with a degree of respect. When they play a drug dealer or fraudster, people refuse to make eye contact, cross the road to avoid them, and security guards hover nearby whenever they are out shopping. It's this kind of stress that makes SO10 officers more susceptible to corruption.

During one operation, Philip was acting as the money man in a drugs buy and had £60,000 in an old carrier bag. The meeting was delayed for four hours, so rather than taking the money back to his office, he just popped home and watched a bit of TV. 'I left the money in a bag on the sofa and went upstairs to the bathroom. At the same time, my wife arrived home and almost had a heart attack. She thought I'd stolen it.'

Another danger in 'going native' is becoming too like the people that you target. You can become so absorbed in the role you are playing, you find it almost impossible to stop. In the mid-80s, Operation Own Goal set its sights on a group of football hooligans following Chelsea.

Teams of young, relatively inexperienced, officers were sent out to join the notorious Headhunters gang and report back. Hangers-on were not welcomed by the hooligans. The only chance the officers had of surviving was to participate in everything that was going on. And to be seen to participate. The job that ended the careers of Philip and Martin began in Handsworth, Birmingham, when an informant for the local drug squad passed on a tip that his former friends, Carl and Lenny Marshall, were well on their way to becoming the biggest crack dealers in the Midlands.

The Marshalls, however, were selling the stuff in lumps the size of house bricks, each with a wholesale price of up to £90,000. Broken up into street-size deals, the same crack would be worth more than £500,000.

The Jamaica-born brothers had inspired such fear among the residents around their home that they were able to operate with virtual impunity. They had also successfully identified every single member of the local drug squad and all their unmarked vehicles, countering any attempts to monitor their activities. The Marshalls also refused to deal with white buyers, ruling out any kind of standard sting operation.

West Midlands police decided to launch an undercover operation against the gang, but found they had only one experienced black undercover officer. He was successfully introduced to the gang via an informant, but to act on his evidence would leave the informant exposed to retribution. More undercover officers would be needed and Martin and Philip, by then two of the most experienced officers at SO10, were called in.

Over the next few weeks, Martin met Carl on a number of occasions and bought nearly £1,000 of crack from him. 'All the deals took place in dark alleyways with me surrounded by Carl's cronies. They were incredibly aggressive and went around in combat trousers, heavy boots and tracksuit tops with hoods up over their heads, so you could never see their faces. I've dealt with plenty of people who have been much scarier, but still it was a job I wanted to get out of the way as quickly as possible.'

A date was set for Martin to buy £10,000 worth of crack. At the moment the drugs were produced, a back-up team of West Midlands officers would swoop down and arrest the gang. At least, that was the plan.

Just after 7pm on a cold October night, Philip and Martin were sitting in the undercover car waiting for Carl to show up. Rather than a BMW or a Merc, they had been forced to take a Mondeo, hardly a typical drug dealer's car, because all the other vehicles in the SO10 pool had been booked out. Carl was already an hour late, but in a series of phone calls he had assured them he was on his way. The pair felt they had no option but to wait. The car was parked in a side street opposite a busy Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant. Although it was dark, there were plenty of people about and the back-up team were just seconds away. There was no real cause for concern.

Two men in combat trousers walked by the front of the car, then turned and knocked on Philip's window. 'Do you have a light?' one of them asked. Philip wound down the window to tell them he didn't, but the second there was a gap, both men reached inside the car and tried to grab the keys from the ignition. Martin instantly jumped out of the car and gave the signal to the back-up team that they were in trouble. Then he got back in the car, expecting Philip to drive off. But he'd lost his grip on the keys, and as Martin sat down, Philip got out of the car to try to retrieve them. At that point, Martin realised there was no point staying in the car and went to get out again. He opened the door and found himself staring down the barrel of a gun.

'I didn't know who the gunman was - I couldn't see his face, just his eyes floating in the shadows inside the hood of his jacket. I didn't know where he came from, either: he just appeared from nowhere, the second I opened the car door, filling the gap and blocking my escape. There was a gun in his pocket and he was pointing it right at my head, finger on the trigger. His voice, a harsh mix of Birmingham street slang and Jamaican patois, was loaded with aggression. 'Get back in the car, bumba clot,' he screamed. 'Back in the car, get back in the fucking car, before I kill you.'

'Jesus, I was terrified. I could feel everything leaving my body. I felt dead already. I just wanted to cry - that's how bad it was, I just wanted to sit there and cry right in front of him. Somewhere behind me, I could hear my partner, Philip, fighting with the other men, the two guys who had come up to the car and asked for a light. I knew he was in trouble, but I couldn't take the time to look round. I couldn't even blink.'

'That's when the shooting started. It's nothing like the movies - when someone fires a gun in real life, it's deafening. But at the same time, the sound is totally crisp, as clear as a bell, a perfect sharp crack like a giant banger on Guy Fawkes. And immediately you're surrounded by smoke, like a genie's come out of its bottle.'

Neither Martin nor the man threatening him had any idea who had done the shooting, or who had been shot. They were equally startled. As far as the attackers were concerned, Philip and Martin were a pair of drug dealers who had come up from London. It was highly likely that they had guns of their own.

Martin took advantage of the confusion to make his dash for freedom. He pushed past the gunman and ran for the wall, a bullet zipping past his head as he went. He reached the wall and gave the signal to the back-up team again. He could not believe that they hadn't got there yet. What was going on?

And then he saw Philip and turned back.

Philip takes up the story: 'The first shot had gone right through my calf and now I was about to take another in the chest. I felt sick inside, as I realised there was nothing I could do. I was all alone, literally staring death in the face. He was moving the gun from side to side and the light kept catching against the triangular sight over the muzzle. It was coming in and out of view, totally hypnotic. For a while, all I could see was the gun and the sight, as though there was nothing else in the world. And I knew it would be the last thing I would ever see.

'I was still staring at the gun when I became aware of a flash of movement at the edge of my vision. It was Martin. I forced myself not to watch as he sprinted closer. Instead, I looked at the gunman's eyes for the first time and thought, right, you're going to get it now. He was so busy showing off the gun, playing the macho gangster, that he hadn't even noticed.

'Martin powered in with both arms flying and smashed straight into the gunman who was sent sprawling on to the car. He bounced off, while Martin span round with the momentum of the impact. The gunman tried to level his weapon, but was too shaken to line up the shot. Martin was still spinning when the bullet ripped into his right shin. I could see his leg deforming as the bullet entered. His leg whipped round fast and he flew back through the air, landing hard on his back.

'The gunman was winded, and despite my injury, I knew I had to act quickly, I hobbled over while he was distracted and struck him hard in the throat with my forearm. He went straight down on the floor. 'That's when I made my big mistake. I assumed the man underneath me had dropped the gun. I was so sure, I didn't even bother looking for it when I sat on him. I wound up to deliver a haymaker that would put him out of his misery. Then I felt him twist his hand and push the barrel of the gun under my buttock. "Oh fuck," I thought. "He's still got the damn thing..."

'I felt the bullet enter my body just below my groin and travel up into my pelvis. The force of the shot picked me up and dumped me hard on my back. I felt like my insides were on fire and just lay on the Tarmac, totally still, waiting for the gunman to finish me off.'

fields.bodyText: The drug deal was going horribly wrong. Instead of coming away with £10,000 worth of premium quality crack cocaine, Martin Maynard and his friend Philip Etienne had been ambushed by a team of armed Yardie gangsters who were trying to steal their money. Martin had lost count of how many shots had been fired. One had been so close he had felt its heat as it whistled past his ear. He had somehow fought his way out of the car and made a desperate run for a nearby low wall. It was only when he reached it that he risked a glance behind him. 'I was shaking with fear. I looked back and saw Philip staggering round the rear of the Mondeo. He was limping, obviously in pain, and as he passed under a streetlight I could see his right leg was soaked dark with blood. One of the gunmen was standing right in front of him, about eight feet away, and his gun was aimed directly at Philip's chest. I heard him shouting: 'D'ya want another one, bumba clot? D'ya want it again?' 'I was thinking, "Oh Jesus, he's going to shoot Philip. He's going to fucking kill Philip". In that fraction of a second, I had to make a decision that I would have to live with for the rest of my life. To my right was the safety of the main road. The gunman hadn't seen me, I wasn't injured, I could easily make it across. On my left was Philip, moments away from being shot dead in cold blood. It was the hardest, most agonising decision I have ever had to make. And there was just no time for it. I took one last glance at the main road, sucked in a deep breath, turned towards the gunman and started running.' It was the end both men had long feared. For the previous eight years, Philip and Martin had lived among the upper echelons of London's criminal underworld. During that time, they dealt in guns, stolen high-performance cars, stolen passports and traded vast quantities of cocaine, ecstasy and crack. With their plush Docklands flats, brand new BMWs and bulging wallets, they made a mockery of the notion that crime doesn't pay. Able to lay their hands on vast amounts of cash at a moment's notice, and with a sizable group of dedicated henchmen at their beck and call, the pair were just the kind of high-ranking professional villains that other crooks felt most comfortable dealing with. Which was just the idea. Because, in reality, Philip and Martin were undercover police officers working for Scotland Yard's most elite unit: SO10. Also known as the Crime Operations Group, SO10 (the first two letters stand for Specialist Operations) is one of the most secretive divisions within the whole of the police force. Even Special Branch (SO12), which works hand in hand with MI5, is relatively open about the nature of its work. In contrast, all of the books, brochures and information packs produced by the Metropolitan Police - even their own website - fail to mention SO10 at all. 'Working in uniform or even moving into CID, you spend your time chasing after kids nicking cars or blokes with 50 quid's worth of dope in their back pockets,' says Martin. 'You never meet a real criminal. They're the people who always have a couple of grand in their wallet. They have the car of their dreams parked outside the house of their dreams. Although there might be surveillance and back-up in place at the beginning of a job, officers are totally alone thereafter. With no radio or warrant card, they can neither call in help or prove who they are. And it is often only at the last minute that they will find out where a deal is to take place. 'Not only do you not know where you are going, but you also know surprisingly little about your target,' adds Philip. 'It sounds crazy but it's standard SO10 procedure that you don't delve into the background of the people you are after. The reason is clear: the more you know about someone, the more you'll end up thinking about it, even if it's only at the back of your mind. If you've been told that the man you are sitting with always keeps a pistol down the side of his boot, you're going to jump through the roof when he gets a sudden itch on his calf and reaches down to scratch it. The only way to be relaxed is to not know. It's a similar problem when it comes to identifying people. Sometimes you get given pictures so you can make sure you have got the right person, but then when you walk into a pub for the first time to meet them, you have to remember that you're not supposed to know what they look like. You can't be seen to recognise them.' For those who get past the initial assessment, the only way to qualify to work for SO10 is to go through what is widely considered to be the most difficult and demanding training course the police force has to offer. Based at the Peel Centre in Hendon, North London, the same place where the Met puts its raw recruits through their paces, the course starts at 7am on a Monday and runs straight through until 4am the following morning. If they're lucky, students manage to grab a couple of hours' sleep before starting again at 7am on Tuesday. And so it goes on, day after day, night after night, for two solid weeks. During that time, there are lectures about points of law, constant exams, assessments and exercises. There are detailed role-playing sessions where recruits learn to deal with every conceivable situation, as well as hands-on instruction in the use of hidden tape recorders, transmitters and technical equipment. Critical conversations can be recorded with special devices, but a whole new set of skills needs to be learned in order to get the best from them. Under the Police and Criminal Evidence Act, a police officer can only interview someone if they have first read them their rights. So if an officer is recording a target who begins to implicate themselves in a crime but then stops halfway through, the undercover can't ask them for more information.
