fields.headline: The final cut - but not  the last word
fields.standfirst: Film 'special editions' are now plentiful. But the  re-edits of Apocalypse Now and The Exorcist will be genuine cinema events, suggests  Andrew Collins
fields.trailText: Film 'special editions' are now plentiful. But the re-edits of Apocalypse Now and The Exorcist will be genuine cinema events, suggests Andrew Collins.
fields.body:
How tantalised are you by the prospect of seeing the 'spider-walk' scene in its entirety? Does the idea of finally viewing 'the French plantation' segment have you salivating? Perhaps you don't have the slightest clue what I'm talking about.

If so, then you're not a hardcore fan of either The Exorcist or Apocalypse Now, for the spider-walk and the French plantation are those films' fabled 'lost scenes', long chattered about in the same breath by the sort of moviegoer for whom the houselights never quite go up. In fact, the spider-walk scene - in which the possessed girl Regan walks like a spider down the MacNeil house stairs - has just lost its mystique. It's been on general release in America for a fortnight now as part of 11 new minutes in a restored version of The Exorcist.

Indeed, so many punters turned out to see it, the 27-year-old film shot to number two in the US box office behind another horrorfest Urban Legends (though The Exorcist, on a more limited release, took more per theatre). Result: the spider-walk has gone public. It no longer belongs to the collective imagination of Exorcist obsessives - they'll have to find another film to obsess about.

A similar fate is about to befall the French plantation. It was announced this week that Francis Ford Coppola has re-edited and remixed his psychedelic 1979 Vietnam epic Apocalypse Now for theatrical release. It includes almost an hour of new footage (old footage really), and though this new three-and-a-half-hour version falls short of the mythical five-hour version, it will delight and dismay Apocalypse Now cultists in equal measure. Why? Because even though the restored film will give them at least some of what they've been dreaming of for the last 20 years - including, we trust, the 25-minute French plantation interlude (of which more later) - it will also destroy the myth. What's the point of great lost scenes when they become found?

As Karl French notes in his Bloomsbury Guide to Apocalypse Now: 'The idea of this lost footage is appealing but will retain its mystique only as long as it remains unseen.'

Not for nothing does Apocalypse Now still exert this strange spell over sane individuals two decades later. Although the term 'cult' can be a euphemism for 'unpopular', a fervent fringe following sometimes reflects the true depths of a piece of work. Certain films develop what's known in the music biz as a fan base, and often one as hungry, devoted and partisan as any rock band's.

People have always had their favourite films, but only in the Seventies, during merchandising's first boom, did movies really start to attract the same sort of fan worship as rock'n'roll. When badges, baseball caps and branded lunchboxes came along you could actually advertise your allegiance to a film. With Star Wars, manic devotion to movies became a phenomenon, and notching up repeat visits to the cinema demon strated your faith. There is a significant divide though between the mainstream mania of Star Wars and the arch, almost Masonic appreciation of a cult film like Apocalypse Now or Spinal Tap. After all, everybody likes Star Wars; many are baffled by Spinal Tap.

There is also a big difference between 'restored' footage and a 'director's cut', although the former is not far behind the latter in terms of becoming a marketing ploy. The debate over which is superior, plain old Blade Runner or Ridley Scott's subtly altered, narration-free version, may be typical of the sort of hot air expended in the name of cult worship, but the very term 'director's cut' has been stripped of its artistic connotations through overuse. It would be more honest to call the first Blade Runner the 'studio cut' and not call the second one anything at all.

Steven Spielberg called his 1982 second draft of Close Encounters Of The Third Kind the 'Special Edition', and though it did contain restored footage - a cargo ship in the Gobi desert - the bums-on-seats highlight was all new: a peek inside the mother ship. The new version was actually three minutes shorter than the original - 800 existing prints of which were, by the way, destroyed at the behest of Columbia. This was not restoration, it was an act of Stalinist vandalism.

The fact that punters paid to see Close Encounters again five years later alerted studios to the money-making potential of re-issuing old films with bits stuck on the end, despite the implicit light of dissatisfaction it casts upon the original. George Lucas took retouching to its multi-million dollar extreme when he digitally remastered all the special effects of his Star Wars trilogy for the 1997 reissue. Scenes weren't so much restored, as drawn on.

Away from the cinemas, video has become a natural home for 'added extras' - the US video of Natural Born Killers contains the gory footage trimmed to ensure its theatrical R-rating - likewise Laserdisc (where Spinal Tap 's truly great lost scenes were first glimpsed) and now DVD, whose 'special features' are often a unique selling point.

The DVD of Apocalypse Now was released last year in the States. True to form, it featured a film-length commentary by Coppola, plus one deleted scene: the air strike on Colonel Kurtz's compound. So, that's one - count it - measly scene for aficionados of a film known to exist in a five-hour rough cut. As Peter Cowie notes in his forthcoming guide to Apocalypse Now: 'Fans of what has become one of the world's greatest cult movies could be forgiven for craving more.'

The Apocalypse Now Book, published by Faber this month, contains a detailed description of the five-hour film. The French plantation sequence is the most fully formed and vital omission. For those who have even a casual acquaintance with Apocalypse Now, it comes after the death of Larry Fishburne's teenage conscript Clean, when the boat commandeered by Willard (Martin Sheen) pulls up to a fog-bound quay which leads to the genteel quarters of a group of colonial French.

The US soldiers eat dinner with the French, and Willard shares an opium pipe and bed with a young woman. All very picturesque, but it's easy to imagine how much this diversion might have slowed down the film - by the time of Clean's death the journey upriver is picking up pace. Assuming Coppola and his editor Walter Murch have included the French plantation in their new cut, those of us who have dreamed of seeing it in full will soon be able to decide for ourselves.

The spider-walk in The Exorcist (which has been digitally smoothed out - it didn't work technically for director William Friedkin in its raw form) has been going down well in the States. The new Exorcist also restores a happy ending (happier, anyway), in which Lee J. Cobb's detective rediscovers his faith, which pleases writer William Peter Blatty, who fought at the time for a more uplifting Catholic message. If this does indeed 'deepen the spiritual foundation of the film' (Friedkin's words), it's still being rather crassly marketed as The Exorcist: The Version You've Never Seen.

Which brings us back to Spielberg, who's planning to restore footage to ET: The Extra-Terrestrial for its twentieth anniversary theatrical re-release - surely a case of market forces leading artistic vision by the nose. I mean, who exactly has been sitting up all night discussing the restoration of the unfabled lost scene in which Harrison Ford cameos as the school principal? Actually, it would be fun to see that - as the only reason it ended up on the cutting room floor was that Ford's then-girlfriend and ET screenwriter Melissa Mathison also made a cameo as the school nurse, and was so bad she begged Spielberg not to use the scene.

Back in the real world, of course, it would be preferable if directors just left well alone. No more special editions or versions we've never seen, no more digital remastering - just get on with making new films.

That confirmed fiddler William Friedkin himself quotes the story about the great post-Impressionist painter Pierre Bonard, who once entered the Louvre with his brushes and palette and started retouching one of his own paintings. When the guards tried to throw him out, he insisted he was Pierre Bonard: 'That's my painting, I'm just fixing it!'

'Monsieur Bonard,' replied one of the guards. 'It's in the Louvre. It's finished.'

The spider-walk in The Exorcist (which has been digitally smoothed out - it didn't work technically for director William Friedkin in its raw form) has been going down well in the States. The new Exorcist also restores a happy ending (happier, anyway), in which Lee J. Cobb's detective rediscovers his faith, which pleases writer William Peter Blatty, who fought at the time for a more uplifting Catholic message. If this does indeed 'deepen the spiritual foundation of the film' (Friedkin's words), it's still being rather crassly marketed as The Exorcist: The Version You've Never Seen. Which brings us back to Spielberg, who's planning to restore footage to ET: The Extra-Terrestrial for its twentieth anniversary theatrical re-release - surely a case of market forces leading artistic vision by the nose. I mean, who exactly has been sitting up all night discussing the restoration of the unfabled lost scene in which Harrison Ford cameos as the school principal? Actually, it would be fun to see that - as the only reason it ended up on the cutting room floor was that Ford's then-girlfriend and ET screenwriter Melissa Mathison also made a cameo as the school nurse, and was so bad she begged Spielberg not to use the scene. Back in the real world, of course, it would be preferable if directors just left well alone. No more special editions or versions we've never seen, no more digital remastering - just get on with making new films. That confirmed fiddler William Friedkin himself quotes the story about the great post-Impressionist painter Pierre Bonard, who once entered the Louvre with his brushes and palette and started retouching one of his own paintings. When the guards tried to throw him out, he insisted he was Pierre Bonard: 'That's my painting, I'm just fixing it!' 'Monsieur Bonard,' replied one of the guards. 'It's in the Louvre. It's finished.'

fields.headline: On the pill
fields.standfirst: It promises worry-free sex and pain-free periods, but the pill has its down sides. This seven-point plan will help you make the most of it
fields.trailText: It promises worry-free sex and pain-free periods, but the pill has its down sides. This seven-point plan will help you make the most of it
fields.body:
Dear Jane, I have been suffering painful periods for the past five years, so my doctor has suggested I start taking the pill. I have some reservations, however, as I believe that the pill has some side effects, such as thrush. Is there anything that can be done through nutrition to minimise these?

This letter is typical of many I receive. And although taking the pill will probably alleviate period pain, it can cause side effects including thrush, fluid retention, raised blood pressure and blood clots in the legs, as well as the more worrying and well-documented increased risk of developing cancer of the cervix, breast and liver. These will be exacerbated if you smoke or are overweight. Recently, I've had several queries over the link between the pill and cancer, particularly of the breast, liver and cervix. But according to the Cancer Research Campaign, there doesn't seem to be a cause for concern, especially in women taking the pill for less than 10 years. The old pill and cancer scares were based on women taking pills with a far higher oestrogen content than is currently prescribed. If you're at all worried about side effects, discuss them with your doctor.

I've identified seven common side effects that might be experienced when the pill's artificial hormones are introduced into the body. Here are some nutritional strategies to help counter them.

1. Weight gain Many women develop an insatiable hunger when they start taking the pill, especially for sweet foods. Drinking a glass of water instead of reaching for some food is the first strategy to try. Eating slowly and ensuring your diet includes plenty of fibre-containing fruits and vegetables will also help to make you feel full. Try eating smaller meals more often and make sure you really concentrate on the eating experience. Also learn to differentiate between physiological and psychological hunger pangs, and don't give into the latter. If you follow these guidelines, you shouldn't gain weight through food, although you may start to retain extra fluid.

2. Depression It is common for women to feel down when they start taking the pill. This is due to changes in the way the brain manufactures such endorphins - or 'happy hormones' - as serotonin and noradrenaline. Eating more vitamin C-rich fruits, along with lean sources of protein (chicken, smoked salmon, etc) can help your body to correct any imbalance. Avoid overly sweet foods, however, which can aggravate depression in the long run.

3. Fluid retention If your body starts retaining fluid, the following nutritional tips may help to disperse it:

 Keep your salt intake down.

 Eat more potassium-rich foods (including all fresh vegetables, but green, leafy vegetables in particular, along with bananas, tomatoes and oranges).

 Drink 2.5l of water every day to help your body to dilute the salt in its tissues and enable it to excrete more salt and fluid.

 Regulate your intake of alcoholic drinks and drinks containing caffeine.

4. Bacterial infections The pill can disturb the healthy bacterial balance of the gut (causing it to become bloated or painful) and vagina (sometimes leading to thrush). Try countering this with the following steps:

 Take a daily dose of either a small pot of live yogurt containing lactobacillus or bifidus, or a pill containing acidiphilus.

 Boost your intake of yeast-suppressing foods, such as fresh vegetables, garlic and olive oil.

 Eat more zinc- and iron-rich foods to discourage the growth of candida.

 Over a period of a couple of weeks, try sticking to a diet that is low in yeast and sugar - including white flour, brown or white sugar, Marmite, cheese, fruits that haven't been peeled, raisins and sultanas, grapes, grape juice and alcohol. Making your body a yeast-free zone will take effort, but can be very effective in clearing up pill-related thrush. If this doesn't work, however, you may need an anti-fungal medication, which your doctor can prescribe. Once the levels of candida in your vagina have diminished, resume a balanced diet.

5. Vitamin B deficiencies Many studies have been carried out on the effects of oral contraceptives on the body, particularly of its oestrogen component on the body's stores of tryptophan and vitamin B6, deficiencies of which can aggravate depression. There is also evidence to suggest that the pill depletes the body's stock, and metabolisation, of vitamin B1, causing irritability, disturbed sleeping patterns and fatigue. It is, therefore, important that you boost your intake of foods containing the B group of vitamins, including dairy produce, eggs, lean red meat, wholegrain cereals and dark-green, leafy vegetables.

6. Folic-acid and zinc deficiencies Folic acid is a powerful antioxidant that has been shown to decrease the risk of pregnant women having babies with neural-tube defects, such as spina bifida. Folic acid also helps our bodies to absorb iron and other essential nutrients that are vital for maintaining healthy blood. Because the pill disrupts the body's folic-acid status, you should replenish its stores by eating plenty of foods that are packed with this B vitamin, including fresh orange juice and green, leafy vegetables.

Zinc deficiency, which is also associated with oral-contraceptive usage, compromises the body's ability to absorb folic acid, too, and may furthermore have a negative impact on the libido and immune system. You can compensate for this by eating zinc-rich foods, including seafood, canned sardines, turkey, lean red meat, hard cheeses and wholegrain cereals.

7. Protect the heart Because taking the pill can increase the risk of high blood pressure, it is advisable to reduce other heart-disease risk factors, such as high cholesterol levels. It is also good to eat anti-oxidant containing fruits and vegetables.
